final_content:
Gave in (to… myself?), bought a domain, and installed Textpattern. [ laughs ] This must be… what, the fourth site that I’ve had? But I can probably stick with this one for a while. Hopefully, anyway.

Anyhoo, enjoy the site. There isn’t a whole lot here, as the site’s only been in existence for about two hours (-ish), but give me time and things’ll start showing up.

Also semi-related to moving on: the first term of the year is over. This is a very good thing. :) ... Yeah. It’s just really good to be done with this last set of classes. Advanced Modern Lit was interesting (a bit painful, actually, but interesting), and Physics was… alright, whatever, so the term wasn’t actually that bad. But I am glad that it’s over with. Next term brings a study hall that I plan to fill with courses taken online through NTC for college & hs credit, which should be cool. $99/credit, which isn’t bad at all when one considers that there’s no other tuition fees. [ shrugs ]

In any case, it’s nice to move on. Got a fresh start here on a website, starting a fresh term on Monday. Take a deep breath. Now go.
For those with inkjet printers: stay far far away from any refill gets. Get the new cartridge; opportunity cost outweighs the benefit (I salute thee, Mr. Nelson).

3:45 and off to Northwestern College in Minneapolis. Or Roseville, or something like that.We have today off from school (end of term and all), so I (well, my parents and then I) figured that I might as well spend it doing something productive, like traveling to Minnesota to visit a college or something. “Or something” being Nathan M, so it’s more like “to visit a college and something”. Yeah.

So just before I fell asleep last night (and, by the way, one wakes up a lot more easily to an alarm clock if there’s already classical music playing), I remembered something that I should bring, so I stick a post-it note (generic brand; they’re cheaper and just as good, and yes, I keep post-it notes at my bed-side) on the back of my alarm clock and turned it (the clock) around backwards so I’d remember whatever it was I was supposed to. So now, it’s 3:30 and I’m remembering that there’s… something that I’ve forgotten, dang it.

It’s… noonish, and it seems that the time thinger on this site is one hour off. [ adds to to-do list ]

I’m in Nathan’s dorm at NWC, working… on my blog? Nathan doesn’t have Intro to Music today (but he informs me that he has a test on Monday and that I should help him study).

Mom & I got here around 9:00 this morning (our discussion whilst we traveled was more or less coherent, considering the ungodly hour). Went to Music Theory, which was interesting and informative. Definitely something that I need to get into a lot more (should have done it years ago). Chapel (in Maranatha Hall, not the actual chapel) followed, which was kinda cool. This trio of rappers rapped several times over with stuff that I think was original, actually. The guy in the middle mostly just stood there and nodded his head, and when he did sing (talk? verbalize?), his face turned red. But don’t get me wrong, they weren’t bad. I just don’t really like rap.

Nathan then gave me a general tour of the campus, which is growing on me. I was a bit turned off by the oldness of a few of the buildings (and, in my opinion, concrete block should be covered by something more than white paint when considering classroom walls), but it’s cool.

So… we don’t really have anything to do until 12:35, which is lunch (which we will be meeting Alison M. for), and then until 2:00. We’ll figure out something, likely.

And this touchpad is really beginning to get on my nerves. I’m using Nathan’s laptop, and I keep hitting the pad while I type. Gah.

So Nathan invites Ben M over for… something or other, swimming I think. We ran over to the Ericson Center (Nathan refused to tell me why) by way of Purgatory and then proceeded into the Hell adjascent to the Center.

Just so your perception of me isn’t entirely shattered, Hell & Purgatory are both parking areas. Nobody really knows why.

But anyway, we get to Hell the parking lot and look for a tan car with two doors. Nathan, again, wouldn’t tell me why. We found the car, and then searched it for keys. I kept expecting some security guy to come up to us and politely ask what we were doing, but such fears were unfounded.

We found the keys and went into the Ericson Center to look for a phone (there are phones all over the campus. like everywhere.) by means of which to call Ben M, who, apparently, Nathan had invited over for the evening. Now that I know what’s going on, Nathan asks me if I can drive stick (that tan car is a manual) in order to go pick up Ben at wherever he was (somewhere in central Saint Paul). Ha. I’ve driven a stick shift… twice, I think?

So we go back to the car to practice (Nathan wanted me to teach him), but none of the keys worked. The car didn’t yield any other sets of keys (but did contain some old Chinese food, a rotten apple and a container of some unknown substance under the seat), and Ben had no idea where any other keys might be (his brother’s card, evidently). So, Ben goes, “Well, my room-mate can probably give me a ride.”

Problem solved. And now I find out that the food court closes the grill at 7. Gah.

Update: Ben just walked in. Guess who had the real keys.

It’s past one in the morning. That was weird. I’m talking to a friend over the internet, and I look at the clock, and it’s past one. Huh. Though I’m told that that’s “still very early on college time.”

Woke up to the initial alarm this morning at 8:30, and went back to sleep. Got up to my mom’s phone message left at 9:30, saying that she’d be over in 20 minutes to pick me up, which I found mildly odd, since she had said earlier that she’d pick me up at 9:30. I probably would have found it more so had I gotten more sleep, but it doesn’t really matter.

Neither of the dorm-folk were really awake when I left, but Nathan was sufficiently conscious to groggily shake my hand prior to my departure. Love that guy.

So… Mom and I went shopping at a nearby mall which wasn’t enormous, but it was of fair size. Nice and clean. Had breakfast, which consisted of an Italian sub (they didn’t have the spice & herb bread, but wheat worked) and a cold caramel something-or-other from Caribou. Good pick-me-up.

Browsed through a few stores, including the Apple store (you know that you’re going to be enormously successful for at least the next decade if you only have to place your logo on the storefront and people pack the location at 10:00 am) and a air-toy store (kites, little fun flying things, potato guns, etc).

Looked through Lands’ End for an hour or so where I found two shirts that fit me perfectly. You have no idea how happy that made me.

I think we had lunch at Wendy’s before we made the trek home. I slept for a while in the car, which is rare and indicative how tired I was. [ grins ] Which is strange, because I did get in a good seven hours of sleep… ah well.

It started with something simple – how hard could it be to print a set of business cards? But no, we first had to copy the images onto the hard drive, then open them up in Publisher (wait… how?), get the thing to print 10 per sheet (‘cuz we’re going to cut them apart afterwards and hope that the cuts are straight), fiddle with the printer, watch it destroy 4 sheets of the $.40 glossy paper, print a regular sheet, copy that sheet onto the $.40 glossy paper with the color copier, notice that the copier skewed the color, and then finally realize that the image was too pixely when printed to be any good anyway.

So. Guess who got no results at his local OfficeMax? Me! Yay! And guess who was particularily impressed by the incompetence of the employees?

Gah.

Or in a book. Or something.

Just finished my music theory assignment for the week… yech. I mean, it’s great stuff (I’m finally learning what the heck I’ve been doing for the last few years of improv work), but it’s really not-easy. I’ve learned to feel the chords and their progressions, and figuring out the mathematical connections is a bit challenging. viÂ°7(6/4) and all that.

Hannah woke me up at around :) this morning with the reminder that “I have drivers’ ed this morning!” Gah. So, me being the absent-minded individual that I am, thinking that the class was at 6:30, freaked out and was ready to go at 6:25. We’re on the way to the school and Hannah says, “You do know that it’s at 6:45, don’t you?”

Eeeee….. [ yawn ] And then the library didn’t open until quarter-after.

I’ve got this 4th hour study hall that I’m going to try and turn into an independent study – taking classes online through NTC. Should be nice; you get college credit (at roughly $99/c) and HS credit at the same time.

I’m fairly sure that I’m going to go for a project management course and a prep course for A+ Certification, which I figure I need to get eventually, so why not get credit for the prep? ‘Course, it does cost roughly $300, but I’m selling my tablet, so I should be able to cover it.

Fun.

Maybe. I don’t know, I’m just really happy. HA!

Piano instruction went well. Really well. And I didn’t even learn much. [ laughs ] This Sunday is the recital, and we were going over the song that I’m going to perform, and the instructor told me that it would be a “good recital for [me]”, and (as I was about to walk out the door) that “it’s fun to work with a good musician.” ... I’m floating. That’s the first compliment that he’s given me, and, from him, it was a big one. [ happy sigh ] Probably sounds like a little thing, but I don’t care. I played Monk & Neagle on the way home (thanks Danielle), which is my very-happy CD. [ grins ]

So yeah. I walked in the door after getting home and encountered Fritz. I honestly don’t think I’ve seen a more pathetic sight in my life. The poor dog’s rear half has been shaved and he has a metal cone around his neck. The cone’s to keep him from chewing/licking on whatever the problem is with on his rear back, but it looks very sad. He’s a bit depressed right now, lying in the entry. He’s a dog, by the way. :)

An Academic Decathlon regional competition was held in Merrill this morning, first one that I’ve been to thus far. My mom asked if she could come, but really, why would a parent come to cheer on a student who’s busily making little marks with a #2 pencil on a ScanTron sheet?

The tests weren’t that bad, I suppose. For Decathlon tests, anyway. Questions like, ... never mind, I was going to give you an example, but I’ve blanked out entirely. [ checks online tests ]

Okay, here we are:
1. How many years elapsed before Europeâ€™s population recovered from its steep decline and reached 1347 levels? (answer: 200)
2. A biogenic amine that contains a ringed molecule composed of six carbons and two hydroxyl groups is called a(n)... (answer: catecholamine)

Anyway. I’m writing this from one of the programming labs back at the HS. I’m trying to get the school to fund the courses that I’m going to take through NTC this term, because I really don’t want to pay for the credits the school will pay for them for me.

And at the moment, the intro to programming class is presenting their homemade PowerPoints (they’re not presentations, see, they’re PowerPoints) on themselves. ... Which doesn’t really have anything to do with the rest of the post, so that’s probabbly enough said there. [ grins ]

And I need to get my business cards printed sometime after school… not sure where. I’ll likely try Press Express (came recommended), but I hear that the UPS Store does a decent job.

The end.
So. Is it strange that I typed “upsstore.com” into the Firefox address bar and ended up with a site telling Jens Jacob to “give me my money back” (jensjacob.net)?

Wow. I just recommended this music video to a friend of mine, and he pointed out something that I totally missed – what the song’s all about. [ shakes head ] Gah, can’t believe I missed it. I got the pulse of the song easily enough, but there’s a bit more to it.

Watch it, I guess. Actually, no. Load it, but forget the video the first time and read the lyrics while you listen. And then watch the video.

‘Cause I know I might lose you by taking a chance
But love without pain isnâ€™t really romance…
Royksopp

[ lyrics ] [ video ]
Found a cool programming toolkit – SAJAX, used for easily implementing AJAX (and if you’re not a geek, you won’t know what that is; use Wikipedia) in web applications. Fun.

Or something. This hour (to be my independent study) was spent setting up the A+ Cert class through NTC (scheduling stuff), polishing off a sermon index admin interface for my church’s website and… well, figuring out a way to download stuff from SourceForge without getting caught in a filter somewhere. Fun.

My registration at NTC has been approved and my courses duely activated. I’m taking the A+ Cert course alone, for the moment, as Mrs. Dachel tells me that it would likely be difficult to complete more than the three credits that said course consists of. Although, at the rate that I’m going at, ... we’ll see. [ shrugs ]

The course isn’t bad, actually. It’s like… an interactive textbook? So not greatly engaging, but it does its job.

But anyway, the NTC reps were more or less helpful getting everything going. It took a couple days, but I was really impressed by their response time. I approve. ;)

:) I watched Hannah work with Texas (her horse) this evening, and I am truely impressed. She’s been training this horse up from nothing, and they’ve really made a lot of progress. I enjoyed watching Hannah’s face light up each time he did something right; she’s really devoted a lot of time into him.

Also interesting is Texas’s yawn. I can’t say that I’ve seen a horse yawn, and the fact that this guy really has a square muzzle makes his yawn really quite interesting. If you haven’t seen a horse’s yawn, I recommend it. [ grins ]
... is down. Why? I wanted to download that Mannheim Steamroller album that I bought earlier! [ grumbles ]
Avoid wearing a shirt that is looser-fitting than your pants.

1) Is there anywhere that one can buy and download a music video, legally, without any DRM to worry about? And not iTunes?

2) The video for “Wake Me Up When September Ends” is thoroughly depressing. Love the song, though.

So. I left PGCC at about 12:40 for the Saint Germain Evangelical Free Church where the music recital was to be held, armed with a map courtesy of Google Local. After turning off 17 onto 70, I traveled the 2.8 miles prescribed and found absolutely no church. I went on for another mile or so, then retraced my steps (steps?) until I reached 17 again. Definitely no church there. At that point, I happened to check my gas meter (and a good thing, too), and realized that I had better stop at a gas station before I went out church-seeking any further. I stopped in Eagle River (closest to where I was) at a Marathon (where I came this close to putting deisel in the tank). ... They really need to label the displays on the fill islands more clearly. I ended up watching the “gas pumped” display instead of the “total price”, and when I realized my mistake, my tank had already been filled with $5.34 worth of gas. Which was good, I suppose, but I only had four dollars on me. The cashier inside was, more or less, understanding about it, and gave me an IOU.

Gah. I opted to then stop for directions, and stopped at a house that was right about where the church should have been. A woman came to the door a minute or two after I knocked, then called her husband over (as “he [knew] directions better”). I learned from them that the church was a good five minutes further on, past “a bar, a restaurant and a go-kart track”. This was going way off of the map that Google had delivered. But go there I did, and I did find the church (street number 6065 in the middle of the 7000s) in time for the latter two thirds of the recital (I was in the last half, fortunately).

Anyway, I afterwards grabbed a twenty from an ATM at a gas station in Saint Germain, then trekked back to the Marathon in Eagle River to pay back the $1.34 (where the cashier revealed that ”[she] actually didn’t expect [me] to come back; [she was] impressed”).

I managed to find my way back home without any undue mishaps. The end.
The company that I use to sell hosting through just applied a massive service upgrade to their hosting packages, at no extra cost! Huzzah!

Ended up riding the bus to and from school today. [ frowns ] Any respect that I formerly may have had for the regular driver is gone. If a guy can’t keep control of a busload of kids, I… okay, so keeping control of a busload of kids can’t be easy, but if he doesn’t… whatever. I’m done.

I’m just glad that I can drive most days. But my younger three siblings… I’d definitely drive them in and back, but what with colliding schedules and schools opening and closing at different times… Well, I dealt with it and so can they. I realize that that sounds cruel and unfeeling, but… hm, I’ve worked myself into a moral corner, haven’t I?

Okay, not the first snow, but the first serious snow. Serious enough for me to drive home at 35-40 mph the whole way back from a Council meeting just to avoid sliding into the ditch, anyway. It’s cold enough that it’s snowing, but the ground isn’t so cold so as to keep the snow from melting upon impact. Yech.

Although Kyp (Council treasurer; skiier and hockey’er) was particularily excited about it. He sat on the edge of the couch through the entire duration of the meeting, wearing his jacket… Like a little boy who’s watching… the first snow come down?

My parents had intended to spend the next couple days elsewhere, mostly because my dad has a business meeting but also because they wanted a few days of together time. Unfortunately, due to several factors (i.e. possibly impending sickness, woodstove uncertainties and others), my mom’s decided to stay home. I mean, no, it’s not unfortunate that Mom’s going to be home, but I’m just sorry that she had to miss the getaway with Dad. :/ I don’t like it when my parents have to give up stuff for the kids. I realize that that’s the way it works, but I feel like… gah.

[name removed] is not coming up to expectations. I have a resellers plan from them, and I swear, the nameservers have been going down regularly for the last couple weeks. I’m a bit ticked off. I mean, not only is it effecting my blog (which reaches… what, 2 people?) but it’s cutting off my business presence which means potentially lost funds. Gaaah.

Slaved over a new secret project (superbucket) for a good bit of the day, and worked on siding the garage at the rental house for most of the remainder.

Bruce (piano teacher) called yesterday looking for information on a possible website, and I was able to call him back today. Turns out that his girlfriend (who lives in Maryland, which explains more of why he’s moving there) makes these hand-made pillows that she wants to advertise and sell online. It’s interesting: I’ve done more projects for hobbyists than otherwise, I think. Or maybe not, but I’ve done at least… three…

Just called Calah to see if she’d be around tomorrow morning for Childrens Ministry musicking, and suffice it to say that I decided she wouldn’t. :) She was at a birthday party for Niccette (Danielle answered the phone: “Hello, this is the Princess Party!”) and… yeah. I feel bad for calling, cuz she’s going to give herself another minor guilt trip over not being available for a committment that she had wanted to make. Ah well.

1. This cancor sore is driving me nuts.
  2. [ sighs ] All I want it the username changed on the hosting account… Is that so hard?
  3. The site selection part of the ACT info gathering app is broken.
  4. My business site has had visitors from Hong Kong and Spain! :)
  5. I left my planner at school… gah. Although, this is only the first time…
  6. And what about Danielle? Hm.

Am feeling very… null today. Haven’t felt that way for a while. You know, the state of mind where nothing really feels. A bit fatalistic, althought that’s probably just because I don’t really care what’s going to happen two minutes from now. Which sounds callous, but… Never mind, that’s not going anywhere.

The snow fell a few days ago (yes, eight inches at once), and the end result are these (sans the chickens).

Just a sample… I have more, and probably better ones than the ones shown here. I’ll get them up later.

This is an old entry… images are broken. Sorry.

I just got off the phone from a lengthy conversation with aJ, and I have come out of it with a theory:

People who are depressed would rather stay depressed than anything else. Mostly because of the change involved in moving from depression to… anything else. There’s some kind of strange security in knowing where/how you are, and you’d almost rather stay in that state of mind than have to move your mindset over to something else.

In theory, anyway.

I also came up with this beauty, following some statement quietly spoken over the phone from the other end.

Situation: the person that you’re talking to speaks something softly, but not too quietly. You then intelligently respond, “huh?” They say “Nothing…” and then you answer whatever they had just said that you hadn’t appeared to hear.

What really happened: the person on the other end says that something just quietly enough so that you, on your end, would be able to hear it but get the impression that the other person hadn’t meant for you to hear it. Heaven knows why the other individual wanted that. You then, politely, query on what they had said. They push it to the side, intending for you to pursue the topic that they had already semi-indirectly established, knowing that you now know that there’s something that they want to say.

... Yeah.

An Armin O. sent me an email asking if I was interested in… well, here’s the message (sans the last name):
———————————————————-
Subject: free domains

Hello,
are you interested in this domain names:
www.url-4-free.com
www.url-4-free.de
www.web-for-free.de
www.url-www.com
www.url-www.de
www.idnt.be
www.t42.be

Best Regards

Armin O.

(One time mail â€“ no spam)———————————————————-

Okay, yeah, an excellent offer, but… is this spam, or… not? The address that it came from was armin@[ the domain of a photographer’s website; the same as Armin’s last name], which looks un-spammerly… but I can’t imagine that she’d have just sent me that email. Must have been mass-sent…. but why?

UPDATE

Okay, she replied to the message that I sent, asking for clarification of her original offer. The reply is as follows:
———————————————————-
Dear Isaac,

I offers this Domain names to you to the purchase.
Prices and purchase completion over sedo.de

Thanks much———————————————————-

So yeah, more or less spam. Spam sent by a human as opposed to a bot/virus, but spam none-the-less. Free domains…

[ shameless plug ]
Speaking of free domains, Glyph Solutions is now offering free domains with the purchase of web hosting! Huzzah!
[ end shameless plug ]

Well, most of the Rhodys (Rhody’s? Rhodies?). A couple families couldn’t make it, one because a sister died and the other because… actually, I’m not sure.

But in any case, the dinner was excellent and the conversation was good. I’m enjoying being able to semi-relax a bit.

My mom made several quotable comments, the most notable of which are approximated below:

  1. “How much sugar would you like? Five forks or four?”
  2. “Is that a real maple tree growing out of the Christmas cactus behind you?”
  3. “No, actually, it’s not over your head. It’s in front and to the left.” (this spoken when assuring Hannah that the topic being discussed was not “over her head”, but… never mind.)

The Sarkinnen (I believe that’s spelled correctly) cousins showed up later on, having had their own Thanksgiving dinner with their various sub-branches of the family tree. An… active game of Spoons was played, and no one was seriously impaired as a result.

Tomorrow: Thanksgiving with the Bowens.

[ shudders ] It’s cold outside. 20 degrees, okay, but when you’re standing out there for hours on end without moving around much, it’s cold. No, I wasn’t ice fishing (those guys are nuts). After getting back from a movie (Yours, Mine & Ours; it wasn’t bad), I spent a few hours helping Dad get the two garage doors up for the rental place’s garage. Not a bad garage, as garages go.

And on an unrelated note, I eagerly await the day when I can switch this building over to a broadband connection. Eeeee.

I’m creatively dead. [ scowls ] No music, no visual design, my code’s messy… Actually, no, my code’s not bad, but the rest of it’s all ick.

I’m working on a project for a client, and I’m truely getting nowhere. The system’s set up (shopping site), but the design is… [ frowns ] not doing so well.

Just in case you wanted to know.

Hannah and I (plus Mom and Dad, though Mom did leave early on) watched the first half-ish of MiB 1. A bit… odd. :) Not really Dad’s kind of movie, though he was kinda facinated. Not like facinated like “Woah – cool!”, more like “Woah – ... ... that’s kinda… weird…”.

So… Hannah and I are sitting here in the LGI, after realizing that… I need to finish this later; Hannah wants to leave.

Continued at 8:52 AM
I’m writing this from the school library. Driver’s Ed started at 8:45, due to the two hour delay that I haven’t told you about yet. So. We got here originally at 6:45, which is when DE would have normally begun. However, there was this little hand-made sign on the door of the LGI saying something to the effect that there’s a two hour delay for the school district, so you’re two hours early. Gah. This after I had gotten up at 6:05 to bring Hannah in, driven through the fog (which, incidentally, was the reason for the delay), got to the school, left my keys in the car… I’m whining; apologies.

So anyway… here I am, and I should probably start getting something done.

I just gave away my voice… [ heavy sigh ] Not that serious; I just signed an internet-based petition to… See, here’s the thing – I don’t even know what I signed. But sign it I did, and I lost my ability to consciously back (or not, depending) the effort that the petition was going for.

Several things to note:

1. During physics, Josh informed me quite somberly that he was glad that we are to start Rennaisance (sp?) literature in Early Eng. Lit., and that he “would push for a test” on this unit. This after we, as a class, opted not do do one on medieval lit. And this before he threw a wad of paper at Brandon. It was provoked. :D

2. Mrs. Chrisinger went through a bit of art this evening with the Decathlon team, and made the comment that tempera was “what you used in the day-care when you were little.” It struck me very strongly as a line that might have been from a book that Ray Bradbury might have written, about a world where the young were placed in day-cares while… while something, anyway. Very strange.

3. “A Christmas Carol” opened tonight. Mi familia is likely going to go tomorrow.

4. I wrote in my blog!

5. Was able to convince the server administration for the Pine Grove website that it was a good idea to raise the file upload limit to 15MB, which is very good for the sermon upload system.

The end.

I’m at church where Michael Lane is giving a seminar on evolution vs. intelligent design. It’s cool – there’s a lot of stuff in here that I didn’t know about and that I still don’t remember enough about to write coherently about, so I won’t try.

But meanwhile, Pastor Darrell’s email is still broken. Gah. And… I need to cut this off and get back to the post later; Mike’s about to start speaking again (the break for lunch just ended).

[ 2:03 pm ]
Next break. He’s running about 10 minutes behind schedule, which might be partly because Mike put too much liver into a beaker full of…. of some kind of acid. The thing over flowed and kept overflowing. :) Very cool.

Anyway, Darrell’s email. A great guy, and he’s very nice about it, but it’s gotta be a bit frusterating when you’ve been trying to use your email for the last four days and it hasn’t been working. Gah. I’ll have to work on that when the seminar is done. I’d do it now, but we’re using his laptop for Mike’s presentation and I can’t get to Darrell’s user account without screwing up the other presentation on the account that we’re working with.

Anthony is online, the poor guy.

Welcome to a world where every attention-starved entity feels entitled to broadcast his/her thoughts to the world and where ruthless corporate minds take advantage of every lapse in security possible.

Ah well. There goes another one. [ grins ] Enjoy.

Anthony’s Blog

It’s really nice to be able to stumble out of the 2-degree weather and into a warm, wood-heated home. Really nice. And then, your mom makes hot chocolate for you… [ sighs happily ] The only thing missing is a Christmas carol playing on the stereo, but you take what you can get.

Had an interesting discussion with Calah, Beau and Matt over lunch this afternoon, partially regarding the various aspects of gender in American culture. Things like why no one looks twice at a girl wearing a tie and how people would react if a guy walked into school wearing a skirt and heels. (Personally, I think Avril Lavigne looks good with a tie, but I don’t think that proves any kind of point, so… whatever.)

And here’s an interesting thought: if a guy is gay, then he’s attracted to the male sex. That would give him a female-role in whatever relationship he might end up in, from his point of view, so it’s almost some kind of slightly twisted male-female relationship. Same thing conversely with lesbian females, right? So the only really homosexual relationship possible, assuming that a gay individual switches gender roles, would be between a gay guy and a lesbian female. But then, that’s really a straight relationship, isn’t it?

... Yeah, that’s a little bit strange to think about, and probably something that you weren’t expecting to see in my blog. New things happen every day. Example: I found out today that Aaron Pierre likes trance music. Cool.

Hooray for a new cousin-once-removed! :) Stef just brought little Gavin into the world, and the family couldn’t be much happier. [ sighs ] Only one day overdue, which doesn’t really matter so I’m not sure why I mentioned it, but… ! That’s very exciting.

Saw this on CiD (one of the polls). Honestly, this is the coolest thing since… well, probably since… whatever, I have no idea. But it’s cool.

[ read the story ]

[ read the CiD poll= ]

It’s remarkable how easily the silence of another person can completely tear down a positive mood. Not make it negative, but just bring it down entirely. Nothing left. … [ sighs ] And all brought on by the female gender. Go figure.

Was able to get quite a bit of work in this evening, but only on a project for Dad (well, for Dad’s research program thing; Wisconsin Potato Breeding Program) and the Jemhil project. Fun fun fun.

I got a call from Mr. Koth (I believe that the first name’s Tim, but I could be wrong. Been wrong before.) asking if I was still interested in a part-time job with the coffee hut chaing (Magic Joe’s). I am, -ish, but it’ll be tricky making Decathlon, home, another official paid job and the freelancing business work together.

Man, I am depressed.

I’m still waiting for you to be the one I’m waiting for. – RelientK
You’re spirit’s divided, you will decide if I’m all you’ll be waiting for. -Royksopp
Added a donations section to this website. Who knows, some benevolent and wealthy visitor may stop by and drop in a few dollars. Worth a shot.

Right. So I got up at 5 this morning to get Hannah to school at 6:45 for Chem work, and neither of the Chem instructers were there. Mr. Larson showed up at 7:05 and let her in, claiming that he both stopped to pick up breakfast and “had a woman to deal with” as reasons for being late.

I’m in the library now at 7:22. Couldn’t log in for a bit; the server kindly informed me that I was “logged onto too many workstations at once.” This being the second time that this has happened, I visited the network admin room to see if Zimmerman was around. He wasn’t, which I would have expected. Anyone who has to get to school before 7:15 is either working there or… never mind. Anyhoo, turns out that the workstation that I was still logged onto was the one that I was using in Dachel’s room 4th hour yesterday. Gah.

And the little tabs that prop the keyboard up are broken off of this keyboard. ... Vandals.
I’m tired.

My alarm clock went off and I awoke, two events which do not always coincide, but this time it worked out. Aaron’s alarm went off at roughly the same time, which I thought odd because my clock was set for 5:00 and he generally gets up at 6:00. “Aaron, it’s 5:00!” ”... It is?”

Feeling particularly well-rested, I strolled downstairs and took note of the clock on the stove. 6:07. Dang it.

What followed was a series of preperatory events carried out in some haste, for Hannah had drivers ed this morning and I had intended to take her in, since I kinda needed the worktime before school and we still need to pick up Phantom of the Opera after school. And egg-dropping supplies. [ adds to to-do list ]

Hannah and I just finished watching it. Well, I just finished watching it and Hannah just woke up. :)

Phenomenal story. Translated well into film. Powerful, intriguing, thought-provoking. A bit depressing. “Learn to live life alone,” sayeth the first song played during the credits. What a terrible way to be.

Mi familia (plus Will, a guy from church and Eric Gustafson, whom Ethan invited to bring chocolate) ventured out onto the slightly snowed-over lake for skating. [ sighs ] My feet suffered. Between the skates and the… Oh, the skates.

These are Goodwill skates mind you, and aren’t bad at all. The only thing is that the laces are just small enough to fit through the holes, provided that the little plastic caps on the ends of the laces don’t break off. And when they do break, you’re in for twenty minutes of meticulous lace-threading. And, if you have semi-large feet, you’ll have a bit of a difficult time jamming your feet into the skates cuz you really can’t make them any looser without unlacing the top few holes and you really don’t want to un-lace those after the work that went into lacing them in the first place. Gah.

But regardless, we had a grand old time. A few quotes:

  • “Oh look, it’s dead.”
    • Referring to a… dead.. s’more.
  • “Here, use this!”
    • Referring to a foot-long screwdriver that Ethan pulled out of nowhere to offer for my use
  • “Where’s the chocolate?” “Under the hatchet.”
    • Self-explanatory
  • “What do you do for fun?” “Oh, I make sine waves in Photoshop.”
    • Actually, this one was from a conversation with GamePhreak last night regarding a secret project that I can’t tell you about yet.

The end.

I’m lonely. [ sighs ] I just realized all over again how much of a workaholic geek I really am. Funny how that doesn’t usually bother me… Probably something to do with the fact that my birthday’s coming up and I honestly can’t think of anyone that I’d ask along. ... Actually, no, that’s a lie, but there’s the whole reciprocal friendship thing. I have a history of finding people that I truely want to be strong friends with, only to either have it fall through or to realize a couple months later that the only person wanting the friendship was me.

Life. Beau tried to psychoanalyze me and my life on Friday. It was a short conversation.

Yay for a new and shiny template. The photo that you see is from the Milwaukee Art Museum (referred to internally as “MAM”, which I find amusing), and I can’t remember if I took it or if my mom did. Forget the art, the building is spectacular. The architecture (I love architecture) is splendid.

Most definitely a Monday, though I didn’t really know it at the time. A Monday in retrospect (add that one to the novel-title list).

Got to school at 6:45-ish to drop Hannah off for Driver’s Ed and got to spend the next half an hour wandering the school and trying to make the time go faster by playing calculator games until the library opened. Which it did, and I was able to get a bit of work done on mi bloggo (adding the Milwaukee theme) and… something else. aJ stopped by and we exchanged polite conversation in which I expressed my desire for a black leather trenchcoat and Jake Ciela expressed his amusement at said desire. Apparently, if I also dyed my hair white as I was originally planning and got those bright blue contacts, I could be the next Euro pop star or something.

I walked into English and Diana tells me that Collete told her that I would probably be starting work at the Magic Joe’s coffee thing sometime soon. ... Hopefully I’ll be informed directly soon. :)

Show Choir performed for the morning and evening 6th grade concerts and again for the local Rotary group’s meeting. It is really quite cramped in the little mini-conference room in the basement of the Claridge (hotel). Wohlleber and I were struck by the facts that (1) “Christmas” had been censored from every non-song-title bit of the 6th grade concert program (replaced with “Holiday”) and that (2) so many of the names of the 6th graders sounded dangerous. Furyk, Biedrzyski, Schwarts, Nuszkiewicz, Metropulos (sounds Greek), Crofoot... What happened to Smith and Jones?

The (6th grade) band and chorus really didn’t do that badly. The band wasn’t all that great, actually, but for a bunch of 6th graders who have had their instruments for a grand total of three months, it wasn’t bad at all. The chorus was generally in unison, except for the parts where they weren’t. Harmony, I mean. It’s interesting; Carla (choir director) is pretty predictable in her selection of choral pieces. There’s usually one “clever” one (i.e. a play on another song or something), a “cute” one and a song that cuts you to the heart and makes you really contemplate your role in life. This year’s were entitled “O Christmas Tree” (“why are you needles falling?” “why are you always leaning?” “you are a fire hazard!”), “Gloves” and “The Christmas in Me” (emphasis mine), respectively.

One final event: Council officer meeting. We had pizza and talked about Council stuff, more or less. I was bestowed with the honor of ordering the pizza, and after inadvertently calling Home Medical Services was able to successfully place a delivery order (“And what kind of crust would you like on those?” “Oh! Cheese-stuffed!” “We don’t offer that.” “Well… what are the options?” “Thin-crust and hand-tossed/deep-dish.” “Um… one of each.” “So it doesn’t really matter?” “Nah. Do whatever you want; knock yourself out.” ”(uncertain laugh)”). I brought up the Council website and what the heck should be done with it near the end and found myself a new member of the PR committee. I’m not really sure if I was transfered from Student Awareness or if I’m now on both…

[ yawns ] Bruce still hasn’t called. I’d better call him.

Today’s my dear mother’s birthday. :) Happy birthday, Mom.

The 8 minute bell just wrang (wrung? and why do we have an 8 minute bell?), so this needs to be short. Long story short, Hannah didn’t have Driver’s Ed today so I got up 1.5 hours early. Upside: I got extra sleep. Kinda.

[20:38] Isaac Bowen: Spack
[20:39] GamePhreak: Spack
[20:39] GamePhreak: So, spack’s up?
[20:39] Isaac Bowen: Foon, mostly.
[20:40] GamePhreak: Really? I’m pretty sporkin’ myself.
[20:40] Isaac Bowen: This has been like… a two-prong day. If that.
[20:41] GamePhreak: Spack! Only so many spork words!
[20:41] GamePhreak: I’ve run out already!

[ gasps ] I got a 502 server error from Google! Google!

Time: 6:20 PM CST
URL: http://base.google.com

Huh. And here I thought they were perfect…

Update at 6:22 PM
All fixed. :)

Update at 6:23 PM
It’s down again! 502 server error! [ grumbles ] Get with it, guys…

Can I just say that this is the dullest project that I’ve had yet? I’m getting ready 14 megs worth of text (for the unitiated, that’s a lot of text) for web presentation. This pastor wrote this magazine for years and years and now they want it all online… [ sighs ] I’m definitely charging hourly for this, but it’s really tedius.

Somewhere around 3:17 PM CST, I’ll have 17 years under my belt. Huzzah. :) Today is also the anniversary of the Boston Tea Party, as well as the birthday of Beethoven, which means that somewhere along the line Public Radio will be playing the Happy Birthday song.

Anyway… Stopped at Walmart to pick up treats for Show Choir after dropping off Hannah and then picked up Dad (who had just dropped off the truck at the shop). Which reminds me – I don’t think we switched keys… [ grins ]

post_title: You can't call the Netherlands collect.
final_content:
Unfortunately. The web host that I subscribe to for reseller hosting (hosting that I donate, not sell) is being stupid and won’t fix whatever server I’m on. I wanted to call them to complain and tried calling collect, but… you can’t call the Netherlands collect.

And now I realize that I can’t post this because the ikebowen website is hosted on the failing server and… gah. I’m switching hosts.

This was written at 11:37 AM.

Right, it’s now 12:02. I have since subscribed to another host and, as soon as they activate my account, I’m switching. Grrr.

Quote:

“I am a Passenger: this reminds me of you in a very good way http://www.toothpastefordinner.com/technology.jpg ”

Finished (mas o menos) a new template for this site. Thought that the Milwaukee theme was a bit… swampy. Yeah.

So anyway… Remember that I had subscribed to another host for my reseller hosting? I’ve got all of the sites from the old one backed up to move to the new one, but I can’t access the appropriate control panel on the new one because the port that it’s at it blocked here at school. Gah.

So now I have to wait until I get home to get everything moved over… [ sighs ] And Anthony’s site went down because he can’t connect to his DB. Which is strange, because every one of the other sites on that server (under my reseller) are working perfectly… including this one, actually.

Ah well. Looks like I’ll have to get some schoolwork done instead. :)

Had our second-to-last Christmas performance this afternoon as a school lyceum. It was a good thing that the program was abridged; I’m fairly sure that most of the audience wouldn’t have been pleased at sitting through two hours of music.

The best part was one disabled boy in the Concert band. Blind, in a wheelchair. His helper-person (unsure of the title) sat next to him. He played the little jingle-bell thing, his helper-person telling him when to start and stop playing. Seeing him when he got to play was the coolest thing ever… The look on his face was pure joy, utter happiness. Wow. Don’t see that every day. It’s kind of bittersweet, reacting to his reaction and realizing that he’s only getting this because he’s… disabled. Ironic that those who have a sub-normal understanding of the world enjoy it more. Ignorance is bliss, I suppose. Wow.

On the other end of the spectrum, a friend of mine just found herself on one end of a bit of a relational crisis. Well, not crisis, but a friend of hers got a bit upset when he realized that… never mind, I’m not going to get into that. Pray for her, if you get the chance.

[ sighs ] It’s Tuesday. Two more days, then break! Huzzah!

Show Choir did the final Christmas performance for the year, this one for the Rotary club at the Claridge in town. The Kiwanis group was there earlier when we performed, but the Rotary attendence was fewer in numbers so we had more room to move. :)

Matt, Adam and I went to a Chinese buffet for lunch. Haven’t been anywhere Asian since the Mongolian grill in Texas (very cool; go to one if you have the chance). Almost forgot my fortune cookie, but I managed to grab one before I left. :)

The fortune was this: “Statistics are no substitute for judgement.” ... Kind of strange how those seem to match up with who gets them. Well, not always, but the last two that I’ve gotten were pretty applicable. Kudos to the Chinese people who think of those little aphorisms.

Just read the most… something article that I’ve ever seen in Newsweek. Honestly, go read it. Not really “news”, per se, but… yeah.

Frankincense in Aisle Five!
The Last Word; Anna Quindlen

Just realized that this site was down, and was able to fix the problem without too much trouble. Turns out that the server that I’m now on (just switched) doesn’t run mod_php, so I can’t use php_value’s in my .htaccess files. Go figure.

On that note, the new server seems to be in a different time zone. Guess I’ll have to switch all of the time offsets again… [ sighs ]

I walked in the door at 11:11 pm this evening after driving home from King Kong. A phenomenal movie; I highly recommend it. Yes, it’s over three hours long, but it doesn’t feel long.

... Except for a certain sequence near the midsection, but that’s the exception. :) I won’t say anything much about the plot, but it’s definitely one for the must-see list over break.

Went with Danielle, Bill, Coral and her boyfriend (new acquaintence). A fun bunch; I had fun. Danielle gave me her Christmas present – a metronome, the scurge of the improvise-whatever-you’re-playing-on-the-spot musician. But I really need one for my playing-music-that’s-written-down endeavors, so it’s very helpful (and timely). Thanks to Danielle, if you read this.

I feel like yawning, but I can’t. [ frowns ] That’s bothersome. But it’s 11:20, and I’d better be getting to bed… Goodnight.
I’m talking to Barbi and we stumbled upon another novel title: “Wherever Together”. Not as cryptic as “Given Gavin” or some of the others, but it stills bears addition.

[ sighs happily ] It’s Christmas Eve. Aaron just left, taking Mom (and Abbey) to see Narnia again. Dad and Ethan are outside doing something related to either firewood or snowmobiles and Hannah’s off with her horse. I’m here in my office, appeasing my need to blog and talking to Barbi online.

Mi familia watched three full-length movies in a row last night, which I really think is a record for us. [ grins ] March of the Penguins (the abridged version; we skipped a good deal of it), Sky High and The Incredibles. Great selection, no? :)

I’m working on music for an offertory for the Christmas service tomorrow. It’s going to end up being a two-part piece, one based on “What Child is This?” and the other being “Jesu, Joy of Man’s Desiring”. Should be fun; I’m still trying to mesh the two together. I might record it and post it if it’s any good when I’m finished.

Barbi just signed off, leaving me with no good reason to stay online… The end.

Where to start… It’s Thursday afternoon, and a selection of Rhody delegates has stopped by for the day. Kind of a post-Christmas gathering, since we weren’t really able to do a huge family thing for Christmas.

Dad took me out to dinner last night, which was nice. Good to be able to talk for a few minutes without any real expectations.

aJ called to invite me to Heather & Jacob’s wedding on Saturday. I don’t know either of them that well, so… ah well. That’s New Year’s Eve as well, and I expect we’ll have some family event or suchwhat.

And most recently, I’ve applied a new look to this site. Not sure if it’s something that I’ll keep around, but if I develop it a bit more maybe it’ll be worth keeping.

post_title: The Boar's Head, the Metrodome... etc.
final_content:
Oh gosh… We just finished a rousing series of Christmas caroling around ye olde piano. :) The Sarkinnens are still here, along with Grace Anne & Gary and Grandpa. The Boar’s Head Carol was among the list, the history of which (included in the carol book) I… was going to place below, but the Sarkinnens took the book to drop off at the library on their way home.

Anyway, it is mentioned in said history that they carry out a boar’s head at an Oxfordian dinner every year. Grace Ann, the librarian at a school in Ripon, said, “What do they do with it in between?” [ laughs ] Sounds exactly like something Hannah would say. Speaking of Hannah, she was heard to mistakenly call one of my metronomes “a metrodome” after the conclusion of our caroling. Heee… Fun. I love my family.

I was talking about Heather and Jacob’s wedding, trying to get Mom and Dad to recall the two main participants. “Heather and Jacob. Remember Jacob? Red hair…” Jennifer: “A mutant!” :D Something to do with the fact that the genes for red hair are a mutation of human DNA or something… I don’t know. :)

Ethan’s showing Stacy his pictures of a deer from the North field. Stacy: “Oh, he’s a little guy!” Ethan: “He’s not a little guy! He’s just far away!”

Huzzah for the second new theme in… yeah, in two days. The last one (blue_orange, for those who knew it by that name) wasn’t that great. I like this, though.

“Bargo” is a mix of three different identifiers: “bar” for the bars of the header/footer, “g” for “green”, and “o” for “orange”. :) Okay, so not very clever, but vatevah.

In any case, I was going for a more “open” design; something that would allow for more expansion as needed. blue_orange was a bit restricting. The sidebar looked kinda cool, but wasn’t very flexible. This sidebar is more flexible (well… not really, actually), and I’ll add more content later.

Yeah. The thing was coded with 4 div’s for each larger box (one for each edge’s background), and with a single tag for each button (of a fixed size with a single background img). The boxes expanded vertically, but there was no really good way to make it work at all. Four div’s for anything is really too many.

Although, that could be fixed if CSS allowed for multiple background images, but I haven’t the faintest as to how that could be accomplished. “background1: url(...);”? Nah. There’s no really good way to do that, either. Might be cool, though.

On a slightly (but not extremely) unrelated note, I’m having a bit of trouble telling the article titles not to have that orange underline. If anyone has any ideas, let me know. [ frowns ] It’s not letting me do ”.article .heading a { border: 0px; }”, for some reason.

I’m going over the stats for this website, and contrary to anything one might expect (given the relative lack of anything notable present here), this site’s racked up roughly 380 hits in the last week. :) Now I realize that that’s nada for more experienced folk, but it makes me happy. :)

I’m seeing hits from the US, the UK, Hong Kong, Germany, France, India, Belgium, Austria, Australia, Japan, Nepal, Romania, the Netherlands (can’t call that place collect), Canada, Finland, Ireland, the Bahamas, Norway, Latvia (Latvia?), Denmark, Sweden, Spain, Singapore, Thailand, Italy and (gasps) the Czech Republic. Ha!

Finally settled on a site theme that’s going to stick around a while. It’s loosely based on the winXP theme “OS Minimal 2” (the blue variation). I’ll probably have to contact the designer who did that one for permission, cuz I’m likely going to end up posting this theme at the Textgarden...

Anyhoo, I also added Ran Aroussi’s rather excellent Tagging Textpattern plugin. I’ve never really liked having to use categories for my posts, but I like tagging.

Tagging, for the unitiated, is simply throwing a bunch of keywords that fit your post into a little box on the left. This allows the system to use them as kind of combination between categories and searches. Kinda.

The list of tags is at ikebowen.com/tag, and I’m not totally sure where to put the link on the sidebar. It doesn’t really fit anywhere… Details, details. Bah.

Uncle Bobby came last night and left a few minutes ago. Thankfully, he turned on his phone before he put too much distance between himself and us; he left his insulin equipment behind. :) He’s a good guy. He came over to work on the barn with Dad, but we got some skiing and such in while he was here.

Aaron and I got his punching bag put up in the basement, next to the new-and-shiny weight machine. He’s not really sure how to use it (the punching bag; the weight thing came with an instructional poster with pictures), so he’s just slamming it around at the moment. I can feel it through the floor, but it sounds more like something hitting wood than a vinyl bag… hm.

It’s New Year’s Eve. Nothing really special planned… we’ll probably watch a few movies or something. Mom just walked in and made note of the postcard leaning against my monitor with the phrase “Head-Smashed-In-Buffalo-Jump” (look – there’s a website!) written in watercolor beneath an inspiring image of over-scaled buffalo standing at the edge of a cliff. A momento of the rest of the family’s trip to Canada this summer while Hannah and I were gone, I believe. :) Abbey showed me an assortment of postcards that they had picked up and asked which I would prefer. Really, was there a choice to be made?

So… I’m working on my Macbeth essay for English. Yes, I did procrastinate for the entire week. Fortunately, we also have Monday off, so I’ll get a chance to work on my Shakespeare project (on which I also procrastinated) before vacation’s over.

Quote of the day: “Mom, he keeps telling me ‘no’ when I’m right!” – spoken by Abbey (who brought you “can’t see nuttin nout no noculars!”) when in particular distress over Aaron’s repeated contradiction to… something.

Mom woke me up initially with a cheery greeting of “White rabbit!”

“White rabbit” is a tradition that came from who knows where. The goal is to be the first person to say “white rabbit” to everyone else on the first of the month. Personally, I wouldn’t mind winning a month or two, but (1) I’m a late sleeper and (2) my memory is prone to failure. Particularily on early Sunday mornings.

So anyway. Mom woke me up with a reminder that yes, I had indeed both overslept and forgotten our monthly ritual. So I fell back asleep, but managed to mutter something about how dastardly it really is to… something. Dad woke me up some time later (haven’t a clue when Mom came in) to inform me that I had half an hour to get up, get cleaned/dressed, eat and fill the woodstove before we left for church. Ee.

The time that mi familia spends at church is split into two halves with a bit of time in between. (So more like two sets of 1/5 splits with one 1/5 in the middle?) The first… half is spent in the Children’s Ministry. My mom heads that up and the rest of us are Shepherd Group leaders (excepting Abbey and Aaron, who are in Shepherd Groups). Between you and I, she’s done a phenomenal job with the program.

Anyhoo. Today being New Years and being the day where our regular lesson-teacher-person (there must be a real title…) wasn’t able to make it, we had a fun day. The other weeks are fun too, but this week was only for games and such. A selection of snapshots will follow, but I don’t have time to post them just now. [ adds to mental to-do list ]

Back at home, we lunched on leftover pizza (oh! I wrote a poem about leftover pizza – will have to post that later), brocholli-cheese soup (Mom’s soup is the best), and… other stuff. Casual lunch. Mom and Dad crashed afterwards and the rest of us watched a 321-Penguins video and The Lord of the Beans (“I am named for the sound that I make in my throat – ahem.”). Good stuff; the guys at Big Idea must have a lot of fun with these. Which reminds me (though it’s not really related): I need to watch Office Space before it’s due. Maybe tomorrow… We have Monday off of school as well, which is nice.

Sledding and other snow-based activity came next, but I really don’t feel like detailing it. Suffice it to say that the snow was cold, and I managed to dump an entire (well, mostly entire) shovel-full of snow down my neck without any help whatsoever. :)

Dad’s finished making the popcorn. Duty calls.

aJ was going through her old message logs and found the novel titles that we stumbled upon during the summer:

Given Gavin
My Heart Was Crying
Clinging to the Wind
She’s One of Them

1. Was told that by a friend of a client that said client was quitting their job and was “counting on [the] website” that I’m building for them for income. Gah. I’m 17, dang it, and don’t even work fulltime!
  2. The phone wars. Hannah’s got hour long phone calls, I’ve got hour long online stuff, Mom and Dad are trying to get in edge-wise… This is nuts. We’re all decent about it, but this is not good.
  3. Anthony’s starting his own web service – ProSpaceLive. Go buy something from him.
  4. It looks like my site template breaks when someone makes a comment. That’s grand.
  5. Post-Christmas-vacation-letdown this week. Can definitely feel it coming.

Okay, so it only takes 5 extra minutes to get from home to school when the car at the front of the other 8 cars is going 35 mph. But still.

Mom and Dad are leaving this morning for a few days to themselves. Best wishes to them. Jennifer and daughter Stacy (aunt and cousin, respectively) are coming for the duration.

Aaron was a bit distraught this morning at the lack of apparent justice. Someone ate two poptarts. ... He feels very strongly about justice.

My English paper on Macbeth (more specifically, the importance of solilquies) is only two pages long. But it’s double spaced and in 10pt Garamond, so… hm. I need to bring up my B, though, so hopefully it’ll be decent enough.

Wouldn’t have had a clue had Google (the ones with the masses of silly putty) not announced it to the world.

Happy Birthday to Braille. :)

The school has never had a very good network set up. It works most of the time, yeah, but there always seem to be problems with the grades server or the internet connection or something. Today it’s the internet and the user fileserver, evidently. Yech.

It’s fourth hour and I’m in my independent study, trying to take an A+ Cert prep course online. I can’t; the network can’t work up enough bandwidth to let me download the current lesson. Gah.

So…. I’m using the time to register for the ACT and the SAT instead, both of which have websites that are of significantly smaller pages than my coursework.

And now it’s time to leave. What did I accomplish thus far? ... I did make a rather cool desktop, actually.
