[18:24] Isaac Bowen: Hello?

The bus was a bit late and was a bit slow this morning. I don’t generally ride the bus, but I need to get home at the same time as the rest of the kids b/c Mom and Dad won’t be home until around 5:00. -ish.

But I still had time to buy classygeek.com before school… I have plans for that one. :)

I’m working on my Macbeth project, which started out being a trial and ended up being a radio show. :)

I’m trying to do all of the vocals meself, but I had a terrible time trying to tweak my voice into sounding feminine. Which, as someone pointed out, is rather a good thing… Anyhoo, I had a friend of mine in New York record the female parts over the internet. :) Fun. The resulting audio was a bit choppy, so I put in… well, you can listen to it. The explanation is corny, but it works. So there.

Listen to the project

It’s only half done, btw.

Huzzah! I just received (well, last night, anyway) my first commissions payment for web hosting! :) For selling two hosting plans and a domain, I racked up $191.50! Hurrah!

I have training for work at Magic Joe’s from 1-6 this afternoon. I take this to mean that I have gotten the job there (it’s a chain of little drive-through coffee huts), though I haven’t really been informed that. The email that I got from them regarding training said something along the lines of “You’ll remember that we had talked about you getting a job at Magic Joe’s. We have you scheduled for training on Saturday…”, so I assume that that’s meant to mean that I’m hired. :) I’m on the work schedule, anyway.

And… I can’t sign in to my AOL/AIM email account. Odd. I don’t use that account for email, but Trillian keeps telling me that I’ve got mail. [ frowns ] But I can’t… sign in. Huh.

As strange as it sounds, I was trained for my first job today. “Real” job, anyway. Real paid job. I took the second work shift and learned how to run a coffee hut. :) Wasn’t bad; I enjoyed it. Stopped at Walmart afterwards to pick up a stressball, jellybeans, milk and pants.

I won’t go into more detail because I really don’t feel like it… And it’s not likely that anyone would read it anyway. :) The majority of this site’s visitors don’t even stick around for 5 seconds, so anything that I do do here is more or less futile. With the blog anyway; the internet’s over-blogged anyway. So… hm. What should do with this site, then? That deserves a bit of thought…

Woah. Google’s offering a free specialty edition of Norton Antivirus with a 6 month subscription with their new Google Pack... package. Wonder how they wrangled that one…

The thing includes the following software titles:

  • Google Earth
  • Google Desktop
  • Picasa
  • Google Toolbar (IE)
  • Google Pack Screensaver
  • Firefox w/ Google Toolbar
  • Ad-Aware SE Personal
  • Norton Antivirus
  • Adobe Reader 7

Okay, so that last one’s not so impressive, but they had me at the free edition of Antivirus. Woah.

And about time. :) I did enjoy doing the project, though. I’ll post it tomorrow-ish; can’t really do it from my dialup connection. :/

I used a loop from Primary Elements, and it’s “linkware”. But, since I used it for an audio-only product… I’m putting the link here. Go buy something from Primary Elements.

I dreamt (dreamed?) that I woke up. Twice, I think. I remembered that I had to take Hannah in to school for drivers’ ed, then found myself at school with the clocks saying 8:03. After wondering to myself about how I could have gotten to school at 8:03, I and a spattering of Student Council members ended up in a Supreme Council meeting in an apartment meeting, discussing an older tenant’s monthly fee. Or something.

So now I’m at school, and I seem to have left my keys at home. How’d that happen?

Very much so. And very much afraid of anything that might threaten the prolonged existence in such a mortal condition. That’s instinctive, that’s not cowardly.

And that’s my excuse for my reaction to the succession of slides that I found myself in the middle of, driving home through the backroads from piano lessons. :/ That wasn’t much fun, honestly. I’m extremely thankful that I’m at home where I’ll see my family again in the morning instead of… not. Or whatever. Maybe I’m overreacting, but… ee.

Speaking of pianoing, lessons went well. Bruce’s only going to be around for another two weeks, which means only one more lesson from him. We’re working on my Solo & Ensemble piece (a Chopin waltz), a perfectly lovely number that I’ve fallen in love with. :) Makes practice much more endurable.

Ha… I just took a “60-Second Survey” over the phone from an organization that I entirely approve of, actually, but it was still funny. :) It was about… something political, I think. Being entirely politically uninformed (-ish), my answers to the questions (which followed the general form of “Were you aware that…”) were always 2. Signifying “no”.

The second to the last question was “Would you be willing to call [ a senator, methinks ] today and [ tell him something ]?” 2. “The number to call [ the aforementioned senator ] is [ phone number ]. Would you like to hear that number again?” 2.

:) I admire the guys for their campaigning, and they get bonus points for using a survey method that’s relatively unobtrusive and something that I haven’t seen (heard?) before. Negative points for being a bit excessively biased and… whatever the word is for not-being-truely-interactive-because-it-ignores-the-answers-provided-when-presenting-new-questions, but they still come out positive.

Anyhoo, back to work.

Haven’t posted here for a while, so what follows will be a synopsis of the last… however many days I haven’t written anything. :)

  1. Decathlon competition was on Friday. Our team ended up fourth out of the eleven competing, and it looks like we have a decent chance of advancing on to State-level competition. The USAD (US Academic Decathlon) group is already $20000 in debt for this year’s stuff, from what I hear, so it seems that there may be no competition next year. A pity, considering that it’s the third-largest national academic organization.
  2. Oh! The regional competition was held at the Student Center at UWSP, and I picked up a 256mb flash drive from the student store. :) I needed one. It’s not USB2, unfortunately, but that’s what you get for $35.
  3. Hannah drove the truck to Fort with Dad’s guidance, and me in the backseat (I needed the truck afterwards to jump my car which was still in the school parking lot from the night before when we had gotten back from Stevens Point; the battery died, which was the last problem that I was expecting – I had bent my car key on that darn plastic package from the flash drive and was afraid that the key wouldn’t work). I was half asleep the whole time and Hannah’s driving… well, it’s improving. “No, Hannah, you’re in fifth. You need to be in third gear.” “I’m not in third? Where’s third?” “Put it back into nuetral and push the stick up.” “Put it in nuetral…” Isaac: “Stay on the road!”
  4. My computer’s sound is dead. It’s a little depressing; I like to listen to music while I work. Can’t imagine what’s wrong with it; everything seems to be working (as in it’s generating audio levels) so you’d think that it’d be a problem with the speakers or something. It’s not, suffice it to say, so… gah. Anthony! Help!

Some dolt unplugged the mouse on this workstation. Gah. I didn’t realize it until after I logged in, and not wanting to wait another hour for this machine to restart, went ahead and worked without it. What a pain. Though I did manage to get a copy of Firefox running on my flash drive…

Hurrah! Goldworthy just got the email – our Decathlon team’s going on to state!

Hour’s almost up… Guess what I accomplished this hour?

But almost understandable when used on a public-use network. Only… hm. My school’s network isn’t for public use, per se. Whatever. There’s a clause in the usage rules that syas that ”[u]sers should not expect that files stored on District servers and hard drives will always be private”, but that only pertains to files. Stored on servers and hard drives, no less (methinks that this policy needs to be re-written).

I don’t really have a problem with keyloggers personally, as I don’t have anything to hide with what I use the network for. The problem that I do have with it is that it logs passwords. ... Which is what it’s supposed to do, but honestly, is that… right? Anything that a user types in on a workstation connected to the network is subject to review by an administrator, and if the previledged few have unrestricted access to this information… where’s the accountability? How do I know that my passwords aren’t being hijacked by the admins, or that the teachers who do their banking online from school are having the security of their accounts compromised?

The obvious solution is to only do your “secure” stuff at home, but honestly… is this really necessary? It makes sense to have some service monitoring what’s being done on the workstations here (i.e. something that might alert an administrator if profanity or other junk is typed), but actually logging everything that’s typed… seems unethical. And a waste of resources, if it comes to that.

Edit
Yay for post number 123. My school’s using Aristotle DataVault for their… monitoring stuff, and access to the keylogger’s data evidently both requires a password and is logged. But still… of what benefit is that? The same people who use the keylogger data are the ones who would look at the access log for those who use that data anyway.

Not that I suspect the network admins to be doing this kind of thing at all, it’s just… I don’t like the concept. Again, it seems… yeah, unethical.

Not to repeat myself or anything.

Another Edit
Point 10 of the usage policy (which I quoted earlier) also says that the ”[n]etwork administrators may review files and communications to maintain system integrity and insure that users are using the system responsibly.” Communications – ah. ”[R]eview”, implying that the “communications” have been saved. I wonder how many of the non-tech-related faculty know about this?

Gah… There’s not point in writing about this. Nothing’s going to change – this is the system, this is how it’s been and how it’s likely going to continue to be. I knew earlier that they had a service monitoring workstation usage, but not that they were logging everything. That changes things a bit.

Dang it. Now I can’t do anything. At all – everything that I use the internet for requires authentication, and every password (along with everything else) is logged. I really don’t feel comfortable with that, even for my Council admin account. Everything’s logged… Sounds… Communist? Nah. Sounds uber-responsible administration, or something.

Some people have speculated that looser restrictions inspire a fewer number of broken restrictions. Yes, those people are idealists (humanity as a whole is not very intelligent), but it does make sense. To a degree. It would make sense if we were discussing the public library’s network, for example (albeit not a good example), but not for a high school. Especially for a high school.

So… I don’t know what I think. Monitoring the activity of network users, okay. But at the very least, users should be explicitly warned as they are monitored. Okay, there’s a warning in the usage rules. Okay, there are little signs up in the library. But if call centers are required to make little beeping sounds if the conversation is being logged and if school buses are required to post signs with they have cameras on board…

It’s all the same, isn’t it? ... This is dumb; I’m arguing with myself and loosing. I’m not even sure if US privacy law applies to minors, which the majority of the school’s students are.

Gah. I quit.

An Ethics For The New Surveillance – The Information Society, Vol. 14, No. 3, 1998. Yes, it’s outdated.

Gah, I’m so bored… :)

It’s fourth hour, and I’m refusing to do any real schoolwork. It’s the last day of the term. Third hour was building-bridges-with-spaghetti for the final; my bridge was 33g and held 1.7kg-ish. I’m a bit proud of that one. :D

We have the day off from school (end-of-term and all), and I’m just realizing that there really aren’t enough hours in the day.

Spent the last…. hour and a half over at my dad’s workplace, talking over myriad projects with the management. Now I’m off to my third job, making coffee, and… shoot, I just got a ton of emails to deal with when I get back. Three FreeTXP requests in one day; that’s odd.

I was looking for the song with the cool anime-style-3D music video involving a red and white windmill with the lyrics “windmill, windmill” in there somewhere, and ended up with “Windmill” by Helloween. Gah. Didn’t get a chance to listen to it until a few hours after I bought the song, and it’s not it. Shoot.

But guess what? The song’s called “Feel Good Inc.” by Gorillaz. Yay for dialup.

This is not going well. Nothing’s really going well.

… Never mind, that’s a lie. Looking at my day, a good majority of it goes well. Sleep (7-8 hours) usually is fine, 3/4 to the entire school day is generally fine. That’s the bulk of it right there, so as far as greater percentage of my time spent goes, I’m doing well. But then you get home after a 12 hour day at school to find an email from a dissatisfied client and more emails from other clients and people waiting on you for help/service and homework to do and a family to try and connect to and petty little self-comprehension issues that are entirely pointless…

Ee. Why? Why can’t I just get this all together and in one nice little box? Or, on the other hand, why can’t I just realize that this is what most people go through in their own degrees and get past it?

Just took a call from Danielle. Her computer wasn’t behaving. [ sighs ] First one’s free. All over again.

Finally – been looking for this forever. :)

http://www.dyn-web.com/dhtml/scroll/

But, for the time being, in sickness. I’ve got some kind of fever/swollen-throat/sinus thing that’s been on my back for the last two or three days. Would have stayed home from church this morning, but I needed to piano for Children’s Ministry and I was on duty for the sound system for second service.

Mom read the next few chapters of Alice in Wonderland for the masses this evening. Love that book. :) Reminds me of Swift’s Gulliver’s Travels, actually… I’m online now only to receive my upteenth-million messages (give or take) that I haven’t checked since Friday, among them being a letter from a client that… yeah.

That particular project hasn’t gone terribly well, as far as keeping up with my quote for worktime needed. It’s gone excellently otherwise, but my quote was, more or less 1000% off. :) The project involves taking 10 years worth of monthly magazines that a since deceased man wrote and preparing them for web-based presentation. Very tedius work. I quoted him 15 hours, but the actual number is likely to be… much higher. After having it proofed by Mom and Dad (nothing wrong with that), I sent the client a rather length letter explaining the situation and offering a few possible routes for completing the project. Thankfully, the guy’s reasonable and can understand the depth of the situation at hand. Projects are never fun when the client doesn’t have a clue.

So anyway… I’m going to bed. Night.

Yep. Sinus infection, looks like. Makes sense, considering the pressure in my sinuses and the aching top teeth. And the blood. :/

So… Went ice fishing today for Winter Outdoor. Szews (the teacher; pronounced “Zeus” for all practical reasons) keeps going on about how wonderful it is to be outside enjoying the weather, and all for school credit. I… yeah, can’t quite bring myself to see it that way. Using taxpayer dollars to buy tipups and jig poles (not to mention live bait) for an activity that isn’t remotely... well, it is remotely educational. I, personally, didn’t know that inserting a hook just below the backbone of a minnow felt like sticking a paperclip through… stiff gelatin, but now I know. So much for that.

Ah well. The class did catch 200-something inches of fish, more than double that of the previous hour for the day. ... How… gah. Look, my group of kids dragged lots more fish out of their natural habitat and into an atmosphere that their lungs can’t work in than your group did!

Hurrah. :)

Dad and I spent roughly 3 hours last night getting the wireless AP functioning in the right spot. The station spent $120-ish for a Hawking access point and signal booster, and when mounted in the right place it’s sufficient to bring the signal over to the house. :) Broadband, and free broadband at that. I’m very happy.

Took honestly longer than it should have, though. I must have re-wired the ethernet cable ends three times before I got it to work. Really, it shouldn’t matter how the little colored cables are in order, as long as the order is the same for both ends. But evidently, it mattered in this scenario. Go figure.

Lyndon said that he’d sell my tablet on eBay for me, as I’m not quite 18 yet and my parents don’t care to give eBay both their credit card number and checking acct info. Ah well. The photos and description of the machine are almost ready… I think I’m going to try dumping the keyboard in a bath of distilled water and see if that fixes it. It still hasn’t gotten over that Dew spill. And the screen needs to have its insides cleaned out again… Toshiba didn’t do a very good job with that dust-proof screen protector.

Had to drive the Suburban to school. Again. Only the second time, granted, but when I just charged my car battery last night… Gah.

I need a haircut.

After forever, we finally managed to get a broadband connection at the house. You have no idea how delighted I am. After a forever of clogging up the phone line everytime someone wanted to do anything and oh! those darn phone line wars… Gah.

But that’s all over now. :)

1. Put the new battery into my car this morning. The thing started after Decathlon; a pleasant suprise.
  2. Mr. S is going to be gone tomorrow and opted to have our class go skating today with Stengl and do the last day of fishing tomorrow instead. I haven’t been to the arena since… who knows when.
  3. Spent the last hour at the office trying to fix the network’s various difficulties. Failed at all of them.
    1. The wireless print server isn’t working, but that’s likely because it’s still got the serial connection to a workstation going.
    2. Felix’s computer, while its wifi connection works, cannot connect to the workgroup to share files/devices.
    3. Mom and Dad’s computer at home should connect wirelessly to the office network. It doesn’t, half the time, and complains at intervals about the driver not being loaded.
  4. Ordered a copy of The Phantom of the Opera for Hannah’s birthday. Mom brought up the topic of widescreen/fullscreen for me at the dinner table (and rather suavely at that) so as to discover Hannah’s preference. She’s good.
  5. I’m tired. I think Dad’s going to bring me in to talk to he (him?) and Felix regarding the project website that I’m trying to work on in my odd minutes of time. Gah.

Clarification: It’s the only Holiday Acres, to my knowledge, but it was my first time providing dinner music at that location. 3 hours straight of pianoing, no breaks (excepting the occasions where I allowed myself a drink with one hand while the other hand kept up the music). :) Fun fun. That was a very hard bench.

And I’ve just discovered what a lucrative business this kind of thing really is. Counting tips, I made roughly $45/hr this evening. Nice. I have a headache, though; 3 hours will do that to ya.

Dad and Abbey went with Aunt Amy to be with the family in St Paul. Uncle Bobby has a newly-discovered tumor somewhere in his head (behind his left eye, methinks) and surgery is… soon. Pray for him.

[ yawns ] Off to play MapleStory for a few minutes before bed. Night.

Regardless of what the sidebar says, I am indeed listening to music. More specifically, I’m listening to the Ambient stream from DI. Not bad. The last song had a lot of little sounds that struck me as rather like that of a baby… sucking on his bottle very rapidly. In a metallic box. Very odd.

Monday morning – drivers’ ed for Hannah! Course, that does give me half an hour of nothing time before the school library opens, but Walmart’s the only thing open at 6:45 am on Monday. Ah well. Batteries and contact fluid, and I was looking for sweatshirts but the only decent one I could find was emblazoned with “athletic department”.

So I’m sitting here at a workstation in the library and Ben Nebgen walks in. Sits down, puts his bag on the counter and notices the blood oozing from two fingers of his left hand. “Ben?” “Yeah, I think I cut myself with a knife this morning.” “And you didn’t notice until now.” :) He’s like that.

And not that this is related at all, but…

Peter (fellow programmer from Great Britain) and I scheduled a teleconference to discuss the Duck, where it’s at and where it needs to go. He’s 6 timezones away, which makes collab a bit difficult, considering that I’m a fulltime student. Yech. So we scheduled a teleconference, as stated, for 5:30 my time (11:30 for him). I duely set my alarm clock last night for 5:00 am and spent the entire night waking up at odd hours in anticipation for the alarm clock, which really defeated the purpose of setting the alarm at all.

5:00 came, as 5:00 generally does. Showered and booted my computer, then waited for Peter to show up. He didn’t. At around 5:42 I began to have some doubt as to the scheduled time of the conference, so I checked my message logs to find the time that we decided on. Suprise – we decided not on Tuesday, but on Thursday. Gah.

Happy Valentine’s Day. :)

post_title: And Happiness is Coming Home Again...
final_content:
... from Holiday Acres, doing music for their Valentine’s Day dinner thing. Didn’t go too badly, except that one guy requested that I play “Unchained Melody”, which I darn well should have known (I have the music in my Show Choir folder) but couldn’t recall at the time. Gah.

Anyway… I played for two hours, apparently. My watch skipped an unknown amount of time again so I couldn’t tell how quickly time was really passing, and time has a tendency to completely slip away while I’m pianoing. But it ended up at two hours. Good enough.

And now I get to write up minutes from the last two Council meetings to be reviewed at tomorrow’s meeting. Hoorah. :)

Or whatever the collective presence of Duck developers is called. “Water” will suffice, but there’s not very much of it – I count… 3 developers, 2 if we conclude that I can’t really be considered worthy to be counted, given my 5 month absense from the… collective.

But anyway, Peter (the guy behind the project) and I met this morning to establish where I’m headed for the time being. Should you be curious, though why I can’t fathom, my first little step is working in the automatic creation of a system account for any new user who signs in via an LDAP auth, based on a default account. Shouldn’t take too long (one can only hope), but it needs to be done before a deployment workshop in early March.

Found my calculator last night after my MapleStory spree. It was under the left-hand side of the front passenger seat of my car. Go figure. Must have fallen there after ACTs.

Note: None of these are available. They were at the time, but not anymore. It’s a sad day. (l0ol.com is still open, if you’re desperate.) (7/12/07)

Just for kicks, here are a selection of randomly generated 3-character (and a couple 2’s, but I have no idea where one could register them) .coms that are still available.

JHL.COM , PZU.COM , CZK.COM , PEZ.COM , 3VE.COM , 8BQ.COM , R0F.COM , C04.COM , FDU.COM , 4E5.COM , 4EO.COM , IC5.COM , Y0R.COM , A9N.COM , 8SD.COM , R7K.COM , 06I.COM , BV.COM , FB.COM , B6P.COM , 58I.COM , 6XL.COM , FP1.COM , KAK.COM , 6TA.COM , VXX.COM , VYF.COM , SVM.COM , SVF.COM , IQD.COM , 75A.COM , 5LP.COM , 6QS.COM , CFG.COM , 4MM.COM , 9ZX.COM , K34.COM , I88.COM , 28K.COM , I2I.COM , G2S.COM , 710.COM , BK.COM , VO.COM , NH4.COM , DZ1.COM , VAN.COM , 2V8.COM , MOG.COM , EF8.COM , P7F.COM , RT1.COM , 3RQ.COM , GGZ.COM , GCV.COM , YR5.COM , 7AH.COM , FDF.COM , 0KA.COM , 61K.COM , H2R.COM , 8GF.COM , I2.COM , H47.COM , 4DD.COM , HJT.COM , UTV.COM , I8B.COM , XT6.COM , 1X.COM , 2V5.COM , O1B.COM , 5FF.COM , PZG.COM , I4P.COM , ZR9.COM , A37.COM , 3SY.COM , DQO.COM , GQ2.COM , V7A.COM , UHA.COM , QK.COM , 9IA.COM , 8Y.COM , OKH.COM , 3XA.COM , D29.COM , X02.COM , F3B.COM , HL6.COM , T6D.COM , 22K.COM , ASY.COM , FZ1.COM , OY0.COM , XZJ.COM , QK9.COM

Cheers.

So I’m selling ijournals.us, invitepool.net and hq52.com on tdnam. There’s no shortage of domains/sites for sale there, but there does seem to be a decidedly small number of actual sales taking place. Hopefully someone’ll decide to take a shot at my selection… ah well. Maybe eventually.

And yet again, it’s Monday. I think I have a Destinos quiz in fourth hour.

So I’m looking for a judges copy of Chopin’s Waltz in A flat, op. 69, for solo & ensemble in one of the labs at school when the phone rings. I’m the only one in the room, so after four rings I answer.

“Hello, is this an outlet store for Foster & Smith?”

“No, I’m sorry, this is one of the rooms at Rhinelander High School.”

“Oh, I’m sorry, I must have the wrong number.”

Yep.

Goldsworthy and… the school-to-work coordinator (forgot her name, but she is female) organized an interview session with community members brought in to interview the Decathlon team members. Went well, though I ended up being interviewed twice by the same panel through some clerical error. Or something.

The interviewers gave us feedback in a group discussion/meeting afterwards, and while their feedback was good... A few interviewers were of the slightly-condescending-without-knowing sort, stating things like “And for you to be going outside of your comfort zone to do these interviews is, I think, a really incredible thing.” Gah. One thing that I truely cannot bear is an adult not treating those of a younger generation as equals. Really. Yes, we’re younger, but we’re still competent, dang it!

Stopped at BP afterwards to fill up, something that normally occurs when the little orange needle is between empty and half-full, but this time ended up being when the little orange needle was just under empty. Ended up only having $2 on me, but I thought I saw two quarters on my seat so I filled it up to $2.50. Only then did I find out that one of the quarters was in reality a nickel, presenting me with the opportunity to scrounge for more change in the recesses of my car.

Driving home with the confidence that only comes with the new addition of less than a quarter tank of gas, I noted that the car in front of me was a Drivers’ Ed vehicle. Said so on the bumper. The little sign on top declaring “Student Driver” was missing (that, and it was 5:50-ish) made it plausible that Mr. C was driving the vehicle (the bumper also said “Mr. C’s Driving School”), which I found mildly interesting. He was speeding. :) Hypocrite… Ah well. Aren’t we all?

100.1 FM was playing that R&B song… [ checks Google ] “Don’t Know Why” – Norah Jones. She opted to say “You’ll be on my mind / Forever” instead of “You’ll be on my mind / For all time”, which would have fit better with standard rhyming conventions and verse structure (the preceding line: “My heart is drenched in wine”), but I like the way she did it better. Showed a bit of musical maturity – stepping out from the conventional.

... went fairly well. My vocal solo ended up with a 1*, which was kinda exciting. I haven’t gone to State competition with a vocal solo yet, so this is.. a first. Yeah.

Show Choir and Madrigal both made it to State, as well as the guy’s trio (me, Matt & Ben). Have yet to hear results for my piano solo, but… ee. I got there, what, 15-20 minutes late and when I did play I missed both theme transitions. Gah. I covered them both well enough, but flinched visibly on the second. Ah well. The judge (who looked to be between 60 and 70; one of those old-but-not-quite-dottering guys – I liked him) told me that “there’s nothing more that I can do for you,” and in concordance with his statement that even though I was late it was like “saving the best for last,” I assumed that to be a good thing. :) Wow… Pretty sure that that solo’s not going to State, though. I’m judged on performance, not on… whatever, and my performance wasn’t 1* material. Quite definitely not.

But a good day, nonetheless. Grandpa Bob and Grace Ann (aunt) showed up and attended most of my and Ethan’s Ethan’s and mine the events in which Ethan or myself were involved and thoroughly enjoyed a few others. Heidi’s Musical Theatre was phenomonal (“Just you wait, ‘enry ‘iggins… Ho ho ho!”), and Calah’s went very well up until the last bit. She was trying to put the cool little… thingers that the actress from the movie put into the end of her performance of “Think Of Me” (Phantom of the Opera). Calah nearly pulled it off, but ended up not quite on the right note. Tricky, and she came close, but didn’t quite cut it. Ah well. Ob-la-di, ob-la-da, life goes on. Bra.

He’s still in the hospital. Not sure if he was ever given that day pass to try going back home or not. He came out of the surgery well enough, but there’s some kind of complication with his memory and… communicative processing ability. Or something. He can remember things like the date on which his credit card bill was due, but not things like the auth codes for his online banking service. And this guy’s a higher level programmer at Symantec – losing grip of this kind of thing has got to be one of the worst things that could happen.

So… pray for the guy, if you’re the kind of person who does. It’s not easy for him, the doctors, the family… Ee.

I quit I quit I quit…

So I find out… two days ago that it’s this week that we’re going to Madison to visit the school, not next week. Today I find out that the National Honors Society deadline was yesterday (my application is this much short of being complete). Friday is the deadline for an LDAP mod for the Duck that I need to finish, but it looks like I’ll need to delegate that one away because I can’t work in the hotel. (Or can I? ...) I make it to PreCalc with three seconds to spare because I was reading Decathlon material on Antony and Cleopatra because some English scholar’s coming in after school to go over Shakespeare, only to realize that I left the printout of my Spanish grades in the library printer. (I’m in an empty computer lab on a pass to the library now.) My Spanish grades are… interesting. Quite literally a string of A’s and F’s because I missed so many class periods… Gah.

I quit.

Dad, Mom, Hannah & I are at the Red Gym on campus, waiting for the tour to begin. It’s scheduled for 3:00, so any minute now… At the moment I’m just dinking around on the lobby computers, setting up a new website (hq52.com) and answering email. Fun fun.

The weirdest thing happened as we were driving in through Madison. Hannah and I both got this… really strange feeling of unease. Not sure why; maybe it was just the community that we were going through. Maybe not. Idk. All I know is that I felt very afraid.

Amazing song. Pity the strings were done with a synthesizer. Sounds great coming out of a pair of headphones, but when you’re playing it in the car it really comes out. Ah well.

Tonight was the MIOS concert, the last of P’s career as RHS Vocal Director. The mass inspirational number was a doozy this year – John Jacobson pulled out all of the stops with “We Are America”. Gotta respect the guy for his passion for America’s youth and their involvement in music, but the song was still a bit… sappy. Yeah.

So… Am playing with a few design projects on the side. I’m redoing the site for Glyph Solutions (it kinda needs it) and am thinking about what to do here.

Well, no so much anymore. Just now it’s stopped dying and has settled for remaining mostly dead. “All dead… there’s only one thing you can do…”

The fiasco started last night when I was adding a printer in the office building to my computer at home (they’re both wireless). It looked like it was working perfectly, but then… my computer rebooted. Didn’t go through the shutdown faze, it just rebooted. Odd. So I logged back in and started having Google Desktop and Trillian yell at me about how their respective dlls weren’t valid images of Windows, or something to that effect. And then it rebooted again. And again.

We’ve got a two-hour school delay this morning, so I’m trying to get it back into working order now. I’ve more or less given up on totally repairing the data on the drive, so I’m trying to get the crucial data off of it and onto my external 250gb drive. The primary one won’t boot, but neither will Hannah’s when I’ve got that bad drive in there. Yech. And my Ubuntu liveCD can’t access either drive, evidently. Thank you, Microsoft, for locking off everything that you’ve got on NTFS so that the rest of the world can’t play with you.

So I’m really hoping that I can get everything taken care off. Soon. I’ve got a backup from a few months back that I can pull stuff off of, but I’d rather not resort to that. :) If I have to just wipe the drive and start over, I can probably recover… One of the benefits of working online is that most of your mission-critical junk is online where teams of trained and certified professionals are paid to take care of it. :D Me, on the other hand…

Haha – yes! Google’s started a beta program for their “Gmail for your domain” service, which I’m sure there’s a better name for but I haven’t a clue as to what it is.

But anyway, I applied on behalf of the RHS Student Council to take part in the beta, and we’ve been accepted. We can now offer our members email at mail.rhscouncil.org, and it’s powered by Gmail! How cool is that?

I’m sitting in the Business Services … lab, I guess, doodling around. We’re at the Concourse Hotel in Madison for the Decathlon State-level competition, which is pretty darn cool. Just spent the evening wandering around State Street, which has thus far disappointed; I’ve heard it was supposed to be wonderful and such, but… Ah well. It is dark and it is raining. :)

But yeah, this should be a fun few days. Competition and such starts tomorrow; I won’t actually be participating (just an alternate, reaping the benefits without any work), but maybe next year. If Decathlon exists next year. :/

so you know it’s alright
your life will come your life will go
still you’ll feel it’s alright
someone will get a letter to your soul
when your whole life was on the tip of you® tongue
empty pages for the no longer young
the apathy of time laughed in your face
did you hear me say each life has its place

- Indigo Girls

Added a new site to my arsenal on a domain that I’ve had for a while but haven’t quite sold yet. The thing’s called “hq52” and for now serves as just a free domain-related service site (i.e. email/subdomain forwarders and such). There’s a grand total of… two accounts in action there, but I’ve only formally publicized it on one forum, so there you are.

And check out the ad for Student Council’s upcoming variety show – [ here ] – featuring O-Zone’s “Numa Numa”. Fun song, even if it is written in a dead language.

Collete called – I’m working Tuesday, Thursday and Friday.

post_title: The Touch of Midas's Evil Half-Brother
final_content: Ee. In the aftermath of my perfectly healthy hard drive’s demise (and the accidental-but-not-really-permenant death of my sister’s hd), I have also screwed over my trusty 256mb flash drive. Thankfully, it didn’t die quite so badly that I couldn’t reformat it, but all my data is (regrettably) no more.

Though Spanish and Pre-Calc will live on; I’ve got Incomplete’s in both from the tests that I missed during that week when I was sick. But we have tomorrow off, which is nice.

My computer’s still dead, but I’m now fairly sure that it’s not the hard drive. Went out and picked up a new 80gb from OfficeMax the other night after work and my machine still won’t play, so maybe it’s the ram or something. Ah well; will bring it in to the shop tomorrow. Along with my resume, perhaps; Dad had me start working on that tonight. It’s half-done-ish, but I can’t think what else to put on it…

And hey, check out ikebowen.net – if you can help out on a project or something, let me know. I really want to get CLASSYgeek going, but I haven’t the time or resources just now. :)

Gah, I’m tired…. I really wanted to go see a movie with Hannah tonight, but there’s nothing worth seeing out right now. She was looking at Failure to Launch, but mis padres pretty much vetoed that one. And for good reason, yeah, but… gah.

So it turns out that it’s not the hard drive after all. Pretty sure that the hard drive’s actually okay, which I should have guessed earlier when I was able to use it with my USB thinger…

So I was going to bring it into the shop, but Anthony’s first guess was that I was stuck with bad ram, so I downloaded the memtest86 iso. Oh yeah, bad ram. Very bad ram. OfficeMax has 512M DDR sticks for $70, but TigerDirect has a few selections of 1G sticks for about that, so I just ordered one (along with a repeater for the network; it’s a bit weak by the time it makes it to the house). Should be here before the end of the week.

Oh dear. [ edit ] Well this is why… I think I had a headache that day.

Ben (W) and I discovered this fun little map at weather.com during a bit of downtime during Show Choir. Look’s like Wisconsin’s cursed with Aches and Pains just now.

Huzzah! My computer is (finally) back in working order. With 1gb of RAM to boot. :D I’ve only just realized what the difference between making a machine work and making it workable really is – creating a working environment here is going to take forever. I’m well on my way, of course, but it’s telling me that it’ll be three days (or five seconds, one of the two) before everything’s downloaded and installed. “Everything” includes more or less everything from Service Pack 3 to Trillian to the last 238 messages that Thunderbird must needs retrieve.

[ happy sigh ]

How cool is this:

Deep in the basement of an ancient house in Sonobe (tucked in the fields of Kyoto, Japan), an amazing discovery has been made: real 1up Mushrooms. We know this sounds unbelievable, and we laughed when we were contacted by an exporter about them two months ago. But then we were sent a sample, and that’s when our lives changed forever.

The packet claims that eating the 1up Mushroom will grant “immortal life beyond dreams of man.” It also has the warning: Do not put in face. To be honest, we haven’t gotten up the courage to eat one yet. We have, however, sent one to the Smithsonian Institution and another to the National Institutes of Health for study. So far, everyone we show it to, especially the mycologists we know, have been very excited about this discovery. We sell them to you now, warn you not to eat them (yet!), and join us in crossing your fingers for the lab results. We’ll post more as soon as we know.

Read more…

In great haste and for no tangible reason, I’ve created a new template for this site. I’m trying to find a screenshot of the last few that I’ve had online, but all I can find is the one that you see, courtesy nameintel.com.

The little photo/graphic that you see next to the site’s label is the last image posted to the gallery; it’s linked to its article. Main site nav is over on the right, tag lists and offsite links are in the footer, along with the search box.

On an unrelated note, I’ve submitted an application to sell photos at stockxpert. Should find out in a day or so if they like what I’ve got…

Right, no offence to them and I won’t mention any names (mostly because I don’t know any), but honestly, can one give any serious credence to an organization that puts this kind of announcement up for the entire school to see?

For the confused, my school uses Carousel from Tightrope Media to air our announcements on a local cable channel. Not that bad of a system, but not quite as versatile as I’d like. Plus, it’s written in ASP. Ick.

Report cards were passed out during homeroom today – I pulled a 2.5 GPA for the last term! :D I looked at it and laughed… Two incompletes, yes, but it was still fun.

Council meeting was first hour… didn’t go too badly. Werbowsky did show up, but didn’t go on about the online arcade. A good thing, too; it didn’t need to be… gone on about. George (advisor) kinda chewed me out in an officer’s meeting. :) Ah well. I had put an arcade on the Council website for Council-only use, but didn’t know of a good way to block it from at-school access without writing a specific hack for the system. So it just kind of fell to the wayside and a Council member ended up using the arcade at school. Got caught, of course, and got the Student Council website blocked at school, providing me with ample incentive to figure out that block thing. Turned out the only thing that I needed to do was add a couple lines to the .htaccess for the folder:

order allow,deny
deny from xxx.xxx.xxx.
allow from all

Simple enough. Leaving the last few digits of the IP address out lets it block the entire range of addresses. Anyway… George freaked out when he found out about the situation, which really wasn’t anything more than me just forgetting to finish what I had started. Ah well. He’ll get over it.

Just bought Plumb’s latest album – Chaotic Resolve. Beautiful. “Sleep” is an awesome song; reminds me of a cross between Imogen Heap and Evanescence, interestingly enough.

And now, to bed…

And that title has got to be one of the greatest cliche-sounding titles online just now, but it’s kinda true. I’m noticing the proliferation of this web application and design paradigm that seems to have only emerged in the last year or so. I’m not terribly sure what to call it, but its all about clean, simple and functional.

A few examples:
Lussumo Vanilla
Textpattern – saw that coming, no?
CSS Zen Garden
Mint

And there are a ton more, but there y’are. I’m liking where this is going.

I’m mortally afraid. My external hd, 250gb running with some kind of pata->usb thing, has been making strange clicking sounds. A spattering of my mp3s stored there (along with the rest of my library) have been corrupted in an odd fashion and… eee. I’m backing up my library to my primary hd (ironic because I just backed up that entire drive onto the external one) just in case. Geeeah. Scandisk, here I come…

Gah, that drives me up the wall… “Inernet.” Say it a few times. “Inernet.” What gets me is realizing that I just said “inernet” to the person that I’m talking to. “Inernet.” [ shudders ]

Hannah and I are at Jennifer’s house. We drove up this afternoon after the dentist and such… dropped off Aaron at the Winkler’s, looking all alone, standing in the driveway with his 12oz Magic Jo cocoa and his paraphernalia various. We weren’t sure if the Winklers were home, see, and we needed to run back to the church (less than a mile away) to pick up the jacket that we had left there on Sunday and get it back to him anyway, so… whatever; he found the Winklers next door and all’s well. :) Good kid.

We stopped at Stef and Josh’s on our way up (down?). Little Gavin (4 months, I hear) had to get a couple shots in the legs earlier in the day and was a bit in and out. Absolutely adorable, and he’s one of those that actually makes distinguishable facial expressions.

So… we’re off to visit Grandpa tomorrow morning before heading back home – I’m on the work schedule for tomorrow at two.

Night… Or ã•ã‚ˆã†ãªã‚‰, as it were.

Wiping my hard drive naturally did away with my copy of StudioMX, but I’ve fortunately still got that activation code that I bought on eBay this summer. Macromedia (or Adobe, now) doesn’t offer access to their trial/try editions of their MX line anymore, but the files are still around. Trouble is (and the same trouble that a guy on Experts Exchange was having, methinks) that Macromedia (Adobe, dang it) does some kind of auth checking before you can download directly from the server. I was only able to pull it off for Flash by going to the download page for the Flash 8 trial and initiating that download and then going to the 2004/MX one. But work it did and I’ll hopefully have it running ere long.

So evidently, by Tickle.com (the same guys who told me that I’m most like Ethan Hawke), I’m an insightful linguist with an IQ of 136. Hm. But no, I don’t want to buy a 15-page IQ report, thank you.

Mom and the rest of the kids (minus Hannah) went to visit Grandpa this morning… should be back in a couple hours. Honestly, it’s kind of depressing to go drive through that region… houses and barns falling apart everywhere you look, while cows peruse the rubble. Picturesque, in the way that grunge music videos can be picturesque, but really depressing.

Yeah, so they’re abstract and practically shout “Iwascreatedintwentysecondsflat!” (give or take). Leave me alone. :)

Desaturated blue tones are the colors that I tend to use most often… the keynote speaker at the leadership conference in Madison says that your favorite color is indicative of how you feel about yourself, so there y’are.

[ edit ]
Added a slightly tweaked version – a little bit of a shadow in there and some color… actually, the odds are good that you can see as well as I can (likely better)…

Ha! Gold! Yes! [ goes into euphoria over, yes, a 50cc win ]

Right, I love this game…. I truely do. :) Found an N64 emulator and the rom for the game, which I’m delighted over. I’ll probably have to get rid of it if it ends up being illegal… maybe just buy the system and game on eBay or something. Vatevah. [ is still very happy ]

But why is the prize awarded by a blowfish?

“Haha – now she’s in the library box and now she’s not!!” – Aaron, while dragooning the cat. Yes, that’s a word.
“Did you see Ethan creep stealthily away from that squirrel hole?” – Aaron. These are the brothers that I have. :)

But only a little bit of espresso. One shot. With breve, a shot and a half of rum syrup, half a shot of javalua. Iced. Ahhhh…

So I open Firefox and I know Google’s fun little web accelerator isn’t to blame (my wireless card takes its own sweet time to connect), but…

Btw, download [ this ]. A beautiful little tool.

From my aunt Jennifer:——-
This Sunday we celebrate Easter, the most holy of days and
crowning feast of the church year. We rejoice in the radiance of the
Resurrection and the victory of our mighty King, who
vanquished sin and death.

With shouts of “Alleluia, Christ is risen!” we herald the pivotal
moment of human history, for which all of Scripture was a preamble,
the moment in which time and eternity collided. With choirs of angels
we glimpse the grand extravagance of God’s grace. And with St.
Peter we can say, “Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus
Christ! By his great mercy he has given us a new birth into a living
hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead” (1 Pt.
1:3).

Russell and I would like to wish you a blessed and
joyful Easter.

“The Lord is risen indeed. Alleluia!”——-
Amen. Cool! :) This is one of the few Christianity-related entries here, but that category definitely deserves representation. Honestly, without that faith, life has a total lack of purpose. Sometimes with that faith, life seems to lack purpose, but the end goal is to bring glory to God by living for Him.

Cheers. :)

A beautiful story, really. I’ll never forgive myself if Abbey has nightmares about it (she was in there for a bit of it)... A reviewer from imdb.com had this to say:

Like eveything I’ve seen by Tim Burton, this film is at one and the same time, warm and frightening, tender and heart-wrenchingly evil, uplifting and dark. The good and bad in humanity are shown in stark relief quite clearly for everyone to see. But in the final analysis, the most important message the film has to offer is this: Love truly does make the world go ‘round and redemption and just living to see another day is a kind of victory.

Appropriately sappy at the end, but that does about sum it up. I heard someone call this “one of Depp’s finest roles”. ... Yeah, that’s pretty close.

On a slightly more practical note, I’d love to see this movie redone. Carefully redone. Or maybe just added to – there were a couple incidents where a lack in effects were actually a distraction from where the movie was going. Could be just me. :)

Mom and I are heading out to visitar colleges for the next couple days – UWSP today and Lawrence (Appleton) tomorrow. We’ll be staying with Grandpa and Grandma in Stevens Point in the interim (what a cool word! Interim…). [ yawns ] Yes, Hannah, only one more drivers’ ed session. After this one.


May we all be so wise.

... That sounds dirty.

The envelope (honestly, what else would anyone make a list on? a napkin?) here was scanned on a flatbed with the cover open – I wanted to still get the envelope window visible as well as the little tears at the bottom (or side). Can’t do that with the cover down. The shadow was added, obviously, and the bg removed. The ceiling of the library is a nice ceiling, but might have distracted… never mind.

Should have seen it coming, but this has got to be the coolest thing that Google’s done since Gmail. I mean, come on – how perfect is this? Go to calendar.google.com and check it out. No longer shall I search for the perfect calendar app in vain…

This is why Google’s revenue jumped 79%.

FreeTXP one of the sites on my network, has a list of user sites present. cPanel has subdomain stats that show the last 6-ish subdomains visited, which I wanted to do with the member sites (accessible via subdomains) on the FreeTXP website. And here we are:

$src = file_get_contents( "http://username:password@freetxp.com:2082/frontend/x/subdomain/logs.html" );<br /> $src = preg_split( "/<font class="med">Latest Visitors</font>(n|rn)<br>/", $src );<br /> $src = preg_split( "/<br><br>/", $src[1] );<br /> $links = $src[0];<br /> $links = explode( "<br>", $links );<br /> $atitles = array();<br /> $aurls = array();<br /> foreach ( $links as $link ) {<br /> preg_match( "/<title>(.*)</title>/", @file_get_contents( "http://" . trim( strip_tags( $link ) ) ), $atitles[] );<br /> $aurls[] = trim( strip_tags( $link ) );<br /> }<br /> foreach ( $atitles as $key => $array ) {<br /> if ( !empty( $array[1] ) )<br /> echo( "<li><a href="http://" . $aurls[ $key ] . "">{$array[1]}</a></li>" );<br /> }

Not terribly elegant, but perfectly functional. The result is visible at freetxp.com.

[ click here ] Thanks, Anthony. Ha.

$6.95/yr domains can be purchased from Godaddy through xpBargains.com here, btw.

What a strange word. “Pants”. Say it a few times.

This is a small fragment of… denim found in the right pocket of a pair of dark-blue jeans that I bought for $10 (half off of a steep existing discount) from some outlet in Oshkosh. They’re nice pants. I like them.

post_title: Webby Awards - Best Visual Design - Aesthetic
final_content:
Google alerted me to a news article entitled “Corporate PCs: Underpowered for Vista. Overpowered for Writely?”, wherein “Google’s Writely” was mentioned. Not having heard of this service before, I Googled “google writely” and consequently discovered Writely, an AJAX service (yes, Google’s notorious for those) that takes the place of a more standard install-this-software-on-your-machine-and-don’t-pirate-it-or-we’ll-kill-you package. Not bad. I’ll sign up when the move to Google is complete.

But I digress. Writely has also been nominated for a Webby award in Best Practices and Service, which is pretty darn cool – they’re on the ballot right up next to Flickr, Shutterfly, Inc. and Google Maps. Whilst perusing the ballot listings at Webby, I noticed a category for Best Visual Design – Aesthetic. Ah – a category after… my own heart. Yep. From the 5 listed, my vote went to Big Ideas Come From Big Pencils. BFI and Bovine Unite were just too alike – going after that vintage look. Style Wars just wasn’t appealing (personal taste) and Remember Segregation... Suffice it to say that I’ve had it to the hilt with minority groups shouting louder than the majority. In all fairness, they weren’t bad, but even just based on the design (like it should be), they wouldn’t have won my vote.

But the Big Ideas exhibit… wow. Innovation, aesthetics… wow. One quote from Leo (#65; it’s the far upper-left apple) did a particularly good job of summing up the site (funny…), but I’ll make you look for it. Click here.

Cheers.

Edit: Leo Burnett’s official site is here – the other one was solely a demo for the Webby Awards, methinks.

Edit again: Right, I’m going to retract that comment about segregation. I still don’t like minority activist groups, but the website is anything but an outlet for such a group. My bad.

post_title: Commentary of Bush's Remarks on Energy
final_content:
I’m reading through the transcript of Bush’s last set of remarks…

... I’m here to talk to
you about the contributions you are making…
Oh, that’s grand. They might already know about those, though.

Before I talk about energy, I do want to share with you some thoughts about the war on terror…
What?!?

Yet amongst this hopeful—these hopeful signs, there’s an area of
serious concern, and that is high energy prices.
And the alarming rate at which America is falling behind the education curves of Eastern countries and their rates of innovation and development isn’t serious? And yeah, the American public is incredibly un-informed, but doesn’t high prices seem like more of an indicator? Rather than a problem in and of itself?

Addiction to oil is a matter of national security concerns.
That is a problem, and kudos for picking up on it, but… national security?

_If we’re trying to conserve energy, if we want to become less dependent on oil, let’s provide incentives for consumers to use less energy. _
Sadly enough, that’s the only way to do it… Oi, our psychology makes us look like primates.

I’ve directed the Department of Energy to defer filling the reserve this summer.
... That makes me feel a bit uneasy.

Our strategic reserve is sufficiently large enough to guard
against any major supply disruption over the next few months. So by deferring deposits until the fall, we’ll leave a little more oil on the market.
Still not helping.

One of the issues, as you know, that has been confronting Congress is ANWR.
Hiding it with acronyms… yay beaurocratics.

Technology is the way, really, to help us—to help change America for the better.
Amen. But who’s going to create it? All the engineers are in Asia (more power to them, though) and there are fewer and fewer youth going into science and engineering than ever! Geeah!

Ethanol is home-grown. Ethanol will replace gasoline consumption.
Hopefully, but if we keep telling ourselves that it might happen.

It’s a good—ethanol is good for the whole country, and we’ve been—(applause.) I thought you’d like that. (Laughter.)
Cater to the audience.

Last year America used a record 4 billion gallons of ethanol.
This is all well and good, but in 2002 we were using nearly 20 billion gallons of oil every month.

And so I am committed to furthering technology research to find other ways, other sources of ethanol.
If you can do it, man, do it.

And we’re pretty close to a breakthrough. We believe we’re close to a technology that will make it possible to drive up to 40 miles on
electricity alone. And then if you have to drive more than 40 miles, then your gasoline kicks in.
[ snorts ]

But you can imagine what that will mean for a lot of drivers in big
cities who on a daily basis, they don’t drive over 40 miles.
Flawed logic, to a point, but still a semi-valid point.

You know, there’s no doubt in my mind that one of these days, instead of people driving up to a gas station, they’re going to be going up to a fueling station.
This is going in the next Bushisms book.

We owe it to the American people to be aggressive on price gouging now.
[ blinks ] Why? What has the American people done?

At least he’s trying to do something. That’s all anyone can do, and more power to him for that.

[ drumroll ] The beta (2, actually) is out – get it here, but don’t try ie7.com – it’s been taken by the Firefox sect. Cheers.

The selling points? A new look (they cut out a few buttons), tabs (hasn’t Mozilla/Firefox been doing this all along?), better printing (a good thing – this needed improvement), RSS feeds (yep, Firefox), multiple search provider things (Firefox), and better security (Firefox, although the IE7 security alerts do look like they might go beyond what Firefox’s done).

So is it worth it? I’m installing it now; it’s decided to download all of the updates right away (makes sense for a beta) and then run a malicious software check. ... To make sure that nothing goes leaping through the beta’s holes?

What? It wants me to restart? Gah… Though I suppose it’d have to; IE’s in every corner of Windows… Yes, I understand that some applications may not function properly until I restart. Yes, I understand… didn’t you just ask me that?

Continued
I just opened up IE7. First reaction: ”... Ew.” Maybe it looks better when… ah, it does. The design was meant to go with the XP look, not the more traditional/standard theme.

So. First page: should I enable the phishing filter? Why not. Let’s open up a tab and see what happens. Ctrl+t – oh! “You’ve opened a new tab.” Oh. Oh ho. [ laughs ]

That is absolutely priceless. And on the first run, too. Thank you, Microsoft, for your efforts, and I still want to see how this beast treats CSS. But for now, you’re done.

So I’m sitting here printing off the parts of the Constitution relating to Officer elections that need distributing… the mouse for this workstation is a regular old ball mouse with one important difference: it has a little light that makes it look like an optical mouse, but it’s really not.

I tried to find it on the Labtec website, but it’s not online. Suprise; I wouldn’t leave it online either.

But yeah… Council elections are this morning. There’s honestly no Juniors that any of us would consider good candidates for the presidency, except maybe Laura, but she’s got Key Club going. There are other decent Juniors, but not for the presidency. So…. gah. So it goes.

Civic duty – check. My monitor person seemed more queasy at the prospect of my giving blood than I was. If several million blood donations have already taken place, the odds are against me not surviving mine.

I’m in the chorus room on a pass to go retrieve my notebook. I left it in here to dry after I spilled Mountain Dew on it and didn’t pick it back up when I got back from the blood-letting. My math teacher only signs passbooks three times each term, which makes a little sense, but not enough to justify it. She assigned a problem set yesterday, due tomorrow, which doesn’t make any sense when we’re generally given a week to do them. [ sighs ] She’s a good person, and a good tutor, and a good teacher, but I don’t like her classroom management.

Made presidency, btw… Not sure what I think about it, but I’m in for the year. Huzzah.

Oh my gosh… Microsoft, you don’t stand a chance.

Google’s released a beta of SketchUp Free with a $495 Pro version available. Looks like they aquired the thing from another company, like they did with Writely, but this product goes more along with Google Earth rather than… whatever.

I’m downloading the thing now. Looks like fun – this could be the first really useful free 3D modeling program. Others include PovRay and… hm, I can’t find the other one I was thinking of. And Maya, of course (well, just the education version), but unless you’re willing to go through training forever, they’re not fun to use. But this thing has potential… hm.

Ignoring my own vow to sleep late, my body woke up at 6:00. That’s Six-freaking-o’clock. Gah. So, in an effort to spend the extra time on something productive, I’m going through all of the little post-it notes that I slapped on the window next to my bed as my to-do list for today.

Not on my list is a logo for the Council. We’re painfully without one, but this might pull it… it’s a bit abstract, but I’ll check with the masses before making it official. Promise.

Ben and I weren’t intending to go to Prom; we were just going to go bowling for an hour or so and then head to post-Prom at the Cinema. The Prom advisor, however, gave me two tickets for helping the Court out with their intro audio, so… off we went. Both wearing suitcoats and shades, no less.

Prom wasn’t bad. Quite definitely better than Snoball, but there you are. :) The DJ, as Matt put it, “had his good times and his bad times.” He played the hampster dance right before the end (a good move), but played the Barbi song (“I’m a Barbi girl…”) directly afterwards. Which is why we left. :D The only restaurant open at 11:45 pm is Taco Bell, I believe.

So… Got home at 2:45am-ish, having Sunday School and such (later) this morning. A kid at SS had just been to two subsequent sleepovers, resulting in about 4 hours of sleep against the past 44 hours of consciousness (-ish). Poor guy… he broke down right in the middle of the lesson. Ee.

Slept for 4-5 hours this afternoon, then helped Dad out with a patch job at greenhouse 4. The pressure from the inflated plastic walls raised up the wooden rails on either side, leaving a gap underneath that needed filling.

And now I just found out that I exceeded my alloted 6 automated transactions with my bank account and have had a few services disabled until the end of the month (today, incidentally), in addition to the charge of a $20 fine. Geeah. Who knew…

This is a video for the Council elections coming up – a promo, if you will. Just to show off my rather limited skills in Flash. :)

Erm… What can I say to take up vertical space so that the floating image on the left doesn’t break… The vocals are modulated-me, and rhscouncil.org is a real place. The end.

5:30 – Awoke to the quiet strains of 89Q playing the same songs over and over again.
5:32 – Fell asleep again.
6:00 – Got up when my real alarm clock went off. Showered.
6:45 – Breakfast & mini Bible study con mi familia.
7:12 – Off to school.
7:26 – Arrived. Played with a few Council things and tried to get episode 1 running on the school announcement system. Eventually found out that it would fail; will have to try again tomorrow.
7:54 – Reminded the folks about Council applications in the office via the PA.
8:00 / 3:00 – General school stuff. PoliSci test, notably.
3:05 – Mini-meeting for those interested in Council.
3:25 – Homeward bound, with a stop at Walmart on the way.
4:15 – Adonica left a message; called back and found out that she needed someone to come in and finish the shift. Now. Yay for working for the first time in weeks.
4:30 / 7:45 – Work. I really do enjoy working there, but you tend to get very clear glimpses at other people’s life from inside that booth. A stressed mom who doesn’t really seem to see her daughter who’s dying on the inside, another mom who wears a headset and regularly starts phone calls without any visible sign or excuse. Kinda rude. A rather obese couple walking out to and from a gas station, picking up cigarettes (fairly sure that’s what they were). This is America – we are detached and overly-attached, not able to maintain contact without overdoing it. “What is the monster we’ve become…” – Switchfoot
8:00 – Home. I just bought a copy of McAfee Internet Security – $70, but there’s a $20 mail-in rebate. Geeah, I hate those. But $20 is $20, no? Also found out that Aaron got in a minor accident that could have cost him his right index finger, but only resulted in a cut. Needed stitches, but hey – could have been much worse. Thank you, God.

Released by Microsoft/Samsung this week – another example of getting sooo excited about a paradigm and then trying to do something without without actually thinking too much before releasing the end product. Microsoft isn’t notorious for this, but they do have a history.

Anyhoo. The UMPC, originally code-named “Origami” because… just because, is a 9×5.5×1 palmtop, turned on its side. More like the PMC-120, only without that many buttons on the edge.

40GB, 512MB, and a 900MHz processor. Slow, but it has the goods that you’d otherwise expect. Excluding any reasonable means of input, of course. The NY Times put it this way: Unfortunately, your next instinct is to try doing something on this computer â€” and that’s when you discover that there’s no keyboard, mouse or trackpad. You’ll have that.

The screen is 800×480. Odd, no? It includes software that’ll simulate 800×600 or even 1024×600, and I’ll leave you to imagine what kind of results that might have.

Go back to the NYT for a more in-depth review. I got distracted by a particularily bad advertisement on the side of the page – look at it here. No, that leaf looks like it might be radioactive.

Afterthought
I’d rather have an oqo. Though I am getting tired of new-age names: “Viiv” didn’t do much for me, either.

Eeeeeeeee. The masses are at Wiza’s just now, a few blocks from the University.

Went well. Show Choir pulled off the best performance of our stuff that we’ve done yet (1st); Madrigal and trio all ended up with 1sts. I’m told that my piano solo (Waltz Op. 69 #1 in Am, no less) got a first, but I didn’t see the scores from my vocal solo.

Ben’s vocal solo was the last thing on our list, mas o menos. P, however, lost her bag with all of the music in it somewhere on campus and… yeah. We waited for a while (the judge waited for a while) and eventually decided to grab Brian’s grandmother as a pianist and go get copies made at the library. I made copies, and P showed up while I was gone. :)

So… then Mom, Aaron and I waited for the Suburban to show up. Thought they were out filling the tank, but they evidently had already done that and had gotten sick of waiting for us, so they dropped off half of the delegation at the Wiza’s early. Ee. Murphey’s Law, manifested.

I’m hungry. Aunt Amy is a great cook. I love these guys… haven’t seen them for forever, so this is nice.

... will even reduce under-arm perspiration! The miracles of modern medicine.

On an entirely unrelated note, I’m looking forward to the full release of Windows Vista. Its UAP subsystems are getting a bit of heat from the masses, but it actually seems to be a more intuitive way of handling permissions than the Windows family has offered in the past.

Geeah… A friend of mine just called re the meeting for editors tomorrow morning and I didn’t recognize her voice. I feel like a jerk. Yes, I regret very easily. Worse was when I came to the conclusion that she was Heather Soukup, which was way off. :) [ sighs ] Ah well.

Wouldn’t come back, but I guess
I was wrong.

We are the Borg…

I gave in. Surrendered, compromised my ideals. MySpace now has posession of ikebowen. But not entirely – I’m still holding out against the machine that has made fools of the American youth (and taken a good part of the American non-youth along with them).

The thing about MySpace that makes it so darn viral is that you can’t do anything with it unless you immerse yourself fully in it. Do you want to post a comment about someone’s photo (this is where it started for me)? Join MySpace. Oops, sorry, you have to be that person’s “friend” first. Ask nicely. Okay, now you can post that comment. Oh, look! Your brand-new-shiny friend has other friends that you know! Talk to them! But… yep, you have to be their friends too! Weeeeee!

[ shudders ] It’s uncanny. People get sucked into this and… eeee. A friend acquaintance of mine had this to say to a “friend” of hers who had just given in:

You are here! I am so excited…now i can communicate with you easier, much easier!

[ blinks ] Does this not sound… I want to say cultish, but it’s not. Or maybe it is. I don’t know.

A college in Texas recently banned MySpace on their network. More power to them. When ”[T]he library is pretty much full with people on MySpace”, there’s a problem. On the other hand, consider this: “We pay for school and the resources that are used,” said Zeke Santos, 20. “It’s our choice, we’re the ones paying for our classes. If we pass or fail, it’s up to us.”

And I share a country with them?

Oi. Is this a joke? Okay, so I like the idea of a motion-sensing controller (unorthodox, but hey, when was the last time when we had a really good game-controller innovation?), but calling the box “Wii”? Alongside of “Viiv” and “Oqo” and the rest… The strange psuedo-phonetics are getting a bit old.

Basic sum:

Google Co-op
Looks kinda like a StumbleUpon concept, only… more like a community web-tagging initiative. Visitors to websites can brand pages with keywords manually, which will boost those pages in the rankings in searches.
http://www.google.com/coop

Google Desktop 4 (beta)
Coolest new thing: “Google Gadgets”. Yes, make sure you have that “Google” in front or Microsoft will sue you for infringing on Vista’s domain. They’re more or less widgets for Google Desktop. Fun.
http://desktop.google.com/

Google Notebook (to be released next week)
Take notes about what you visit, save clipping of what you see. Share your notebook and see those of others. ... Not sure about this; I’ll have to wait for the release. [ sigh ]
http://www.google.com/notebook

Google Trends
Basically an interactive version of Zeitgeist – search trends for your keywords delivered. Kind of a fun little toy, and I’m sure for some college kid’s statistical analysis.
http://www.google.com/trends

There’s a webcast for those interested – [ here ]. Go Google. Make those investors happy.

Go figure.

The Country Club (the one on Boom Lake, not the other two) is probably the worst place to perform if you don’t have your own traveling gear. The house audio is nothing more than a PA system, and the wireless mic (yes, they have a wireless mic, oddly enough) peaks the system every time its used. I brought my piano and amp, which Calah ended up sharing. The amp, not the piano. Ah well. Oh, Skype has declared free computer-to-landline/mobile calling within US and Canada until the end of the year. Nice. Not even voipbuster is doing that in the US.

Hm. So – Skype’s declared open season on all pc-to-landline/mobile calling in the US and Canada until the end of the year. While this is a very nice little offer, mightn’t it be a bit… rash? I’m sure they’ve thought through it, but suddenly anyone can call anyone anywhere at no cost whatsoever. ... Except bandwidth, but that’s not really an issue.

For example, for no price, I was able to call someone that I’ve never met before and who certainly doesn’t know me and ask them if they’ve ever been worried about anyone tapping into their phone calls. The person on the other end wasn’t at all, and laughed at the idea, but do you see what I mean? There can’t be much danger, but this seems like it kind of opens up the doors for pranksters and scammers (and independent pollsters) alike.

But I like free calling. I can make calls while my sister’s using our petty landline connection.

One more thing: why hasn’t this change been acknowledged much at skype.com? Aside from a little purple voice bubble on the front page (note to designers: that’s cute), there’s nothing. Even the Skype client doesn’t take much note, other than not charging you for the calls – you still get the little notices blathering on about buying Skype credit before making SkypeOut connections.

Let’s see what the community says…

Phenomenal movie. Wow. Right up there next to the Matrix and A Walk to Remember.

Not to go into much detail (this movie is, after all, from 2004), but Will Smith does an excellent job playing his usual semi-cocky good-cop. Loved Briget’s acting, and the effects are superb. Bit of a strange concept, but quite plausible if we ever make it to that kind of artificial intelligence.

“Isaac, can you pick me up after school if it’s raining? If it’s not, I don’t need a ride.”

Righto, Ethan. Anyway, it didn’t rain until 6:15-ish. And yes, it did rain. Really hard – like those huge raindrops that hit your windshield like hail but splat apart like soft paintballs instead of shattering the glass.

Went to Youth Group tonight, seeing as how it’s the last one of the year. We usually have a family Bible study instead, but Mom and Dad were okay with pushing it back to Thursday. I arrived a bit late, having forgotten that they actually start at 6:00, not 6:30. Then again, the first half hour consisted of the worship session, which really… Ee. There was no worship there. This was an instance of the program getting in the way of the worship. A music video with words overlayed, projected in a dark sanctuary… Potential, but it didn’t seem to work. Ah well. Mike’s teaching was excellent, as usual. This week was the final lesson in his series on Elijah.

The rain had lessened, but was still relatively… something. Can’t think of the appropriate adjective. I dropped in on baccaleuoreate afterwards. The service (service?) was half over by the time I got there, so I waited in the back. It had a comfortable feel, considering that the auditorium wasn’t hardly filled. Nice. I liked it. And there was the coolest ambience audible from the back… Let me try to describe it in prose.

Gah. Fritz sneaked past me and up the stairs again. Back, dog! To the porch with you!

The ambience had two distinct layers, not including the audio from the service (service?) up front. Imagine sitting at the back and at the center of the left third of a large auditorium, roughly 300×200x50ft. Got it? Now listen to the sound like the one used for large ships (or airplanes in minor turbulence) and such in movies – an engine base, gently grinding and moving. This is 40 degrees to your left and 50 degrees up fron the horizontal. The second layer is a bit more tricky to describe. If one were to take a ping-pong ball made of some metallic alloy instead of plastic and bounce it once on the concrete floor of a theatre, and if the bounce was more of a “pong” than a “ping”, then that’s what this would sound like. An erratic series of semi-metallic pongs (think almost like the child of a marimba and a pan flute, but not quite) coming from 15 degrees below you and 10 degrees to your right, ahead 250 feet and inside the wall, coming in two alternate tones: one tonic, and one fifth up from that.

Sounds strange, I know, but that’s the best I can do. I wish there was a way to capture the way that things sound to the human ear, or how things look when you see them. I see things, I hear things that I want to keep with me forever, but a mike and a camera can’t do them justice. A microphone can’t capture the sound echoing through a piano that’s ever-so-slightly missed its prime, sitting in an empty chorus room. That’s the kind of thing that I want to keep. Wish I could.
