Incident the First: Jim Bob the Photographer
After drowning my day in a cold glass (well, a plastic glass, probably manufactured by WalMart, the antithesis of entrepreneurship and, ironically, the image of capitalism) of Mountain Dew (also from WalMart – two 12-packs for $5), my mom deposited a few items from the days mail on my desk. Underneath the little thank-you note from the Y and on top of yet another college mailing (which may actually have been hand-signed by the admissions counselor) was an envelope, larger than your normal business or card size, but not large enough to be considered overkill. In fact, I don’t think I’ve ever seen anyone professional use this size envelope before… (Mental note: check on any correlation between envelope size and quality of content. Later.)

The envelope itself should have been a warning. #1: The use of a font designed to look like sloppy handwriting. The personal touch. #2: No effort made to hide #1 – same font used three times in different colors and sizes. Gah.

Page one is to your left. Can you say “Spam in print!”? The “fine print” is the small type with the “*” next to it… Ah, thanks. A selection of fine print: “I always knew we would go with —— for those important photos.” So… they didn’t act on one of these consumer alerts?

So yes, this is a senior photographer that I’m talking about, and one that is in bad need of either an advertising agent or… Yes, I’ve blurred out his name on these scans. No need to sway anyone’s decisions on where they get their photos taken, which brings up an interesting point that I’ll put back down until I’m done with my treatise.

I’ll spare you the entire document, but I will give you an extended sample and will cheerfully let you read it for youself while I get control over my gag reflex. The form is interesting – you’ll note that “June 15” is typewritten and printed (albeit in red). What, then, was the point of stamping “JUN 15” with a stamp on the cover page of this consumer alert? I’ll leave the little narration alone, but it is worth noting that this guy’s provided a little form for you to fill out when there’s only one given scenario (out of three) that would involve said form.

Oi… I know, I’ve made a terribly large deal out of this, but I am absolutely disgusted (and rather passionate about quality print design, or lack thereof). A previous generation of [ coughs ] entrepreneurs who haven’t a clue when it comes to effective advertising and presentation… shouldn’t be allowed to do this kind of thing. Or something. I am further inflamed by the fact that he sent this to my parents. My parents? At least give them the respect of addressing this “consumer alert” to me, the younger and more impressionable/inexperienced youth, and not to my parents. You insult their intelligence with this. … Man.

[ deep breath ] On the upside, his photography isn’t that bad. He included a sample sheet which I won’t scan because it would probably violate some professional copyright law. It does suprise me, though, that a guy with an eye for good photography would have such a horrendous eye for print design.

Thing is, it worked. A tasteless advertising stunt worked, and better perhaps than some of the other more “professional” marketing initiatives have. This… abomination called more of my attention to it, and in doing so to the guy’s product, than it likely would have if he had done a better job. So which is better, from a marketer’s point of view? A campaign that’s so bad that it actually works, or one that’s good enough to work? … Welcome to America. I may have to boycott this photographer.

I have another rant coming on regarding a clichÃ© in Flash (that would be Incident the Second), but it can wait.

And I just got more cynical.

I’m walking up the little hill from the little parking lot to the garage. Fritz didn’t bark at me. Odd.

Oh look! Lambs!

Half of mi familia went off and brought home two baby lambs (Megan and… someone else). Hannah and Abbey were bottle-feeding them in the pen outside the house when I got home. The cutest little things…

And then Abbey introduced me to Emma. Emma is the name of the 6-month-old-today burro that mi padre decided very recently to purchase along with the two lambs. A very last-minute decision; a bit unlike him…. although it was probably premeditated. Intentional burro-aquisition. In any case, Emma is decidedly the coolest thing yet to walk the ground of her current home. Never mind that its previous occupants have all been pigs (and one horse, but that horse has since demised and therefore doesn’t count). Emma the burro. I’m very happy.

Which it isn’t, actually, but today was the first real day of summer. As far as I’m concerned.

Kim’s brother took her off to a Brewer’s game today, giving me an extra shift to work. Not that I’m complaining – I need all the hours I can get over there. With 2.5 full time employees working at this kiosk thing, the part time folk hardly get any hours in edgewise. I enjoy working there (well, not the cleanup), but I really need to find someplace else.

Speaking of which, someone from Smith Barney called today about a possible job opportunity. My mom took the message; I’ll talk to the guy tomorrow. That call made my day. :) But then Ben Murphey stopped by the shpo and made it even better – he ordered the cheapest non-caffeinated drink we had (italian soda; “Suprise me”, he said – he got a kiwi-vanilla-rum soda, which interestingly enough tastes like root beer) and tipped me a free combo coupon for Hardees, which I didn’t find out until later. Great guy; hopefully I’ll see more of him during the summer. Here’s to Ben.

Link of the day:
http://abum.com/file/shadow/animations/17632.swf
Yes, this was shamelessly stolen from Digg, which has past its prime anyway.

Second link of the day, having slightly less significance than the first but still deserving of merit:
http://9rules.com/blog/2006/06/round-4-whats-next/trackback/
I believe I’ll try for round 5… wouldn’t hurt, anyway. I’d like this site to go somewhere. Ha.

Third link of the day, carelessly thrown in after the fact:
chrome://browser/content/browser.xul
Only if you’re using Firefox. You’ll need to copy/paste that URL, btw the way. It won’t work as a hyperlink. This is like PIP, only not.

An eventful day this has been (my young padawan) – I have taken delivery and am now the proud owner of a 19” widescreen LCD (which isn’t really an analog; it also has a digital out that my video card doesn’t handle) and, on a whim, have purchased a Black Moor.

The Moor first. No, I don’t have an African Muslim in my basement – this is a… [ searches for receipt ]... gah, can’t find it. I think it was $2.88.. or something close to it. Regardless, this is a relatively inexpensive little fish. He’s cute, too – looks a bit like this.

My dear mother referred to him as “Genghis Kahn”, and the name’s stuck. Which is interesting, because Kahn was neither Moorish nor Black, though the Black Moor was originally found in China.

He’s made his lavish home in a large glass votive candle holder with an assortment of blue shiny glass… things. None of the fish tanks at Walmart (yes, I got my fish from Walmart) were particularily appealing, so naturally I perused the wedding area of the craft department for candle holders and vases.

My only concern for the poor fellow is that he hasn’t quite managed to really eat anything. He seems to have trouble getting that little mouth open wide enough to get anything in it, especially when the food flakes are floating on top of the water. Hm.

And now, the monitor. She (yes, she)’s lovely – a VA1912wb from ViewSonic, native resolution of 1440×900. My problem is that my NVIDIA GeForce4 MX 440 (with AGP8X, no less) doesn’t have formal support for that kind of aspect ratio. Which is unfortunate – I’m having to deal with 1280×768, which isn’t bad but could certainly be better. Although, with the font antialiasing, you can’t really tell. Much.

And yes, ikebowen.com has attained yet another look. I’ll post a zip of the previous theme later for those who want it; it might be worth keeping.

On an entirely unrelated note, while looking up “ichthyoid”, I discovered an entry for “icky-poo” in the World Book Dictionary: “adj. Slang. icky.”

Cheers.

Update
I installed Forceware from NVIDIA, and all’s well. Sweet beauty at 1440×900. Lovely. The Helios screensaver (“try it” – you’ll like it) never looked so good.

Genghis Kahn Khan has been defeated. Somewhere during the night, the cold grip of death slowly settled around his being and dragged him down up to his place of rest. There he lies now, mostly because I haven’t gotten around to getting him a little baggie to pitifully lie in. Poor guy.

Might have been because I put a CD over the top of the jar thing to keep the cat from getting him… Would that have cut off the air supply? It’s possible, I suppose. Or maybe he never did figure out how to eat those food flakes.

In any case, Walmart has a handy little guarantee that provides for either a refund or a replacement fish if I bring in the cold corpse of the dearly departed. Good thing.

post_title: Why did my neighbor come home at 3 a.m. all last week?
final_content:
To be honest, I’m not terribly sure. But what about this: “Why did you see your neighbor come home at 3 a.m. all last week?”

More than anything, this entry is an experiment to see how many search hits I can ensnare by including this reference to an article in Wired News that I won’t link to here because it’s a bit disturbing. But still. Hear me roar.

post_title: Paranoia on behalf of the user.
final_content:
Thanks, Logitech (really), but making me verify that yes, I am indeed the one using this keyboard, is a little bit overboard.

The software from Logitech (came with the wireless keyboard/mouse set) isn’t terribly useful, but it does allow for the custom assignment of the little buttons on top (really, who needs a button whose sole existence is dedicated to the opening of the generic Windows calculator?). Though come to think of it, I don’t use that anyway. So no, it’s not really useful at all. But it does do this cool thing where it monitors the band that the keyboard operates on just to make sure that no one (who would?) is hijacking what I’m typing. Hm. Paranoia? Maybe.

Note: This paper is my periodically published work, inspired by the ridiculosity (yes, that’s a word) of my local paper. Scott Adams has my apologies, but that’s about it.

THE ELBONIAN STAR JOURNAL1

volume 30, number 8

Education, communication among future tribal goals
As the article title implies, these are not among the Lake Elbonia Tribe’s current goals, but with the cessation of their most recent set of trials and tribulations (namely the legal battle with a mining company that wanted to bring jobs to the area with a proposed mine), the tribe leaders begin to look to the future.

In fact, these future goals had already been forseen by earlier generations of tribe members who had prepared for their arrival, to the best of their ability. Funds were created to ensure that, in future days, such goals could be met: care for the children, education, exposure to modern technology, law enforcement, fire protection and medical care being among the goals planned for.

Unfortunately, the leaders of the tribe were cruelly forced to use these funds for other purposes. The legal team hired to fight the battle against the mine company did not come cheaply – “several millions of dollars” were spent to keep the proposed mine out (or at least several miles away from the reservation boundaries).

One would think that this wouldn’t pose much of a problem – many tribes are known for obscene profits made in the gambling industry. However, a representative stated that the tribe’s profits ”[aren’t] even close” to that of other tribes. The pity that this official release inspires only worsens with the news that the tribe, in a final attempt to “be proactive in making the tribe self-sufficient”, has plans to plan (yes, that is correct) to build a hotel, indoor waterpark and a golf course.

A spokesperson for the tribe made this statement: “Sure, our people living on the reservation are overcrowded. No, many do not have telephone service – or even Internet access. Yes, our expensive legal team not only drained our funding for much-needed services (like fire protection), but also ensured that no new jobs would come into the reservation. But we are hopeful that the new indoor waterpark will go a long way in achieving true self-sufficiency for the tribe.”

Officials work on solution for Elbonia Street bridge
The Elbonia Street bridge has long been a hazard to civilian life traversing Elbonia Street, not to mention the engineers driving the trains that cross it. Drivers of cars and trucks have struck the bridge no less than 14 times in the last four years alone, and while nearly all incidents have been attributed to driver error, the City Counsel still feels a need to do their civic duty to ensure that future strikes may be avoided.

The plan selected for action consists of two I-beams, painted yellow, to be stationed on either side of the road ahead of the bridge and adorned with flashing lights. The flashing pattern has yet to be determined, but one representative stated that he is hoping “for a message of warning – maybe in Morse code?”.

This plan was selected from many proposed at a public hearing several weeks ago, attended by nearly 8 of the general public, several railroad officials and the secretary of the city governor who was in attendance at the premier of Cars on a “fact-finding initiative”. Other plans included the replacement of the existing bridge with a drawbridge to allow passage for taller vehicles, or the removal of the bridge entirely. The former plan was amended to include I-beams of warning for oncoming trains for occasions when the drawbridge would be up, but no change was suggested for the latter concerning train safety.

Confidence is high in the performance of the warning I-beams. The City Counsel is proceeding carefully, however – as a spokesperson said, “We don’t want to put more into this than is needed. We are quite set on having yellow flashing lights on our I-beams, and hope that drivers will be able to see them.”

!!BUYING ALUMINUM CANS!!PAYING 45 CENTS PER POUND!!BRING ‘EM IN NOW!!CALL 1-800-CAN-MANS!!

Local student receives national award
Note from the editor: It is the my hope that by placing this article next to a large advertisement for the purchase of aluminum cans, you will overlook it. Academic achievement is distinctly un-cool, and we strive to emphasize what is important to our readers.
A students at a local school received an Elbonian National Award for her performance at her establishment of education. She will appear in the yearbook. Her parents are proud of her accomplishment.

Meditation – Transforming ourselves into being peace
From Cousin Bert at the Ego and Spirituality Center
A story is often told about a driver traversing a street and striking a bridge when his vehicle careens out of control. This only leads us to print sorrow and heebie-jeebies in our lives, and even upon the eath on which we tread – or drive. However, I know that if we all look inside ourselves, we will find that we truely do want to print peace and tranquility wherever we walk – or drive. We may not be able to change others, unless we hold high positions in government, but with the proper application of self-hypnosis (and perhaps psychiatric care), we can transform ourselves into being peace. Only then will we be able to avoid the inevitable bridges on the streets of life.

Turtles – in need of your help in crossing the highway
During the month of June, state officials are asking all motorists to conserve the declining turtle population. Take a moment, while you are transforming yourself into being peace, and help the turtles. This announcement only effective through June 30.

High school graduates recognized
Note from the editor: this recognition is mandated by archaic company policy. And all we’re really doing recognizing mediocrity anyway.
[ picture here ]
Caption: The new graduates let rip with their caps, while parents cheered from the packed stands. Students and parents honored the ceremony with an elated dignity.

Students deign to acknowledge World No Tobacco Day
In a controversial move, some students have put up a large sign, asking the student body to “have a safe summer”. In Elbonia, one out of five high school students smoke. While this number is significantly lower than what it is commonly believed to be, the students do feel called do do what they can. No trees were killed in the production of their sign – it was constructed entirely from foam cups.

Classified Ads
CANDY ROUTE – ALL CASH, NO EXPENSES! (ECAN)
WORK FROM HOME – TYPE FOR CASH! (ECAN)
PROCESS REFUNDS – GUARANTEED PAYCHECKS! (ECAN)
PROCESS CUSTOMER RETURNS – “EXTREMELY EASY!” (ECAN)
SPORTS STORE – SELL BAIT! (ECAN)
2000 HARLEY – ONE OF A KIND – $16,000 INVESTED TO KEEP IT RUNNING – WILL SELL FOR $9,000

At last (we know you’ve been waiting)...
The Elbonian Star Journal is proud to present “Recipes Remembered” – a hardcover cookbook. Buy ownership rights now before it’s printed for $19.95, or when we get it to the printer for $24.923. ORDER YOUR COPY NOW AND SAVE! Yes, you’ll still be out 20 bucks, but hey – it’s hardcover.

1 This has been a work of satire. Any alleged reference to any living individuals or their pets was probably intentional. By reading this footnote you signify your agreement that, among other things, you will not to sue the author. For a signed copy of the “other things”, please call. “Help! Rabid monkeys!”, if properly shrieked, will probably bring someone running.

Such is earth, and most of the individuals in it. Although there are a few deserving of careful evaluation – a point made clearer to me by a website that I just spent two-ish minutes at. Dear me.

Let’s talk about music, shall we? Music is good for you, as a rule. That’s “music”, by the way, not “semi-tasteless and unimaginative melodies backed by a synth track”. This does not apply to RÃ¶yksopp, which has wonderful taste. Mostly.

My musical tastes [ stops to skip past a country song that I purchased for my sister ] stroll together happily for a few yards and then stride passionately in separate directions after a difficult feud. My collection is expanding to accomodate my classical music, but the greatest growth is in Gregorian chants. Love those, but there aren’t enough of them. Pity. On the other colloquial hand is the collection of chick-pop music – Hillary Duff, Mandy Moore and Natasha Bedingfield come to mind.

And then there’s the… Christian music. I’d have more of it, but decent Christian music that doesn’t consist of semi-tasteless and unimaginative melodies backed by synth tracks (or the ones that are just these college guys with guitars and time) is difficult to find. Plumb is good (really good), as is David Crowder Band (though their website’s out of date) and a few others, but… gah. I own Lifesong (most recent from Casting Crowns), which I’m more ashamed of than anything else. That’s the album in my collection that I purchased simply because they have the label “Christian” and nothing else. Bah. Christian is good – this is what I identify myself with – but the music is simply lacking. A lot. I’m not even going to talk about it. I suppose a lot of it is personal bias, but the lead vocalist needs work, he should not be backed by a single female vocalist if you can hardly hear her (always seems like she’s at -20Db), the music itself is uninspired (ironic, no?)... Ee. I’m done.

Anyway. My next chant from Coro de monjes del Monasterio Benedictino de Santo Domingo de Silos has 71% to go. I’m hungry.

Link of the day
Can be found from Googling “buy a pet”, oddly enough.
penguinwarehouse.com

Bother – and I had just written this article and accidentally closed the tab.

So… these three girls wrote this song about the whole Save the Internet deal. I’m not going to pretend like I know the entire situation and then explain it to you in a consise exposÃ© – other people have done this and evidently people still don’t know what’s going on.

But writing a song? Is this crossing the line into unreasonable passion? Or just a publicity stunt? Though I do like their tagline: “The Broad Band: Writing songs about corporate malfeasance so you don’t have to!”.

Listen, courtesy NPR. You’ll need Real Player. No, honest – I’ve never seen this file extension before and only Real’ll play it.

Or just listen it to it here. Your choice.

Tomorrow is departure/arrival for/at the World Affairs Seminar. Should be something worth being at, considering that my attendence is sponsored by Kiwanis and I’m not really paying anything to be there. Except my time.

Eesh. I’m a bit off right now, not really feeling terribly confident about the rest of the summer, let alone next year. I got the job at Smith Barney (haven’t talked about that here; I’m interning with them for the summer and likely into the school year). Side note: one of the kids that are staying here overnight just wandered by as I’m writing this. Told him that I was writing for my blog – “Is that like a MySpace?” Kids these days.

Anyway… I’m hoping against hope (whatever that means) that I’ll fit the job decently. It matches my skillset, yes, but I’ve kind of a negative outlook and I’m afraid that I’ll not end up being what they’re hoping me to be. That and the place reminds me very strongly of a Dilbert environment.

More to say, but I need to pack my suitcase. Forget that it’s already packed.

It’s Tuesday here on campus. ... No, actually, it’s not; I’m not really sure why I said that. I did think it was Tuesday for a moment, there.

Subject: Re: hi
From: ike[at]glyphsolutions.com
To: “Home” <>
User-Agent: SquirrelMail/1.4.6

They had sour cream and union chips… and you beat the big ugly hairy one eyed monster thing. With Ethan. Cheers to you – that’s more than most kids your age might accomplish in an evening. :D There’s a walkthrough at http://db.gamefaqs.com/console/n64/file/zelda_64_x.txt, if you really want to cheat. Don’t ruin the game for yourself.

For you and for whoever else who wonders, the time here hasn’t been bad. Still haven’t met my roommate (he’s deposited his belongings in the room; we just haven’t seen each other yet), but “The Long, Dark Tea Time of the Soul” is a phenomenal book. Great stuff, Douglas Adams, as usual.

The seminar speaker this evening was excellent – a returned Peace Corps volunteer. The audience left a bit to be desired, at least during the q&a session. But then, such is the greater state of… teenagers. Never liked that word. :)

Mom, turns out that we need a note to get me released from this place. Send a faxed note of permission and such to 262-472-5210 – they need to know who you are and who I am and when you need to pick me up. And any other relevant (or not) information that you’d care to bestow upon whoever checks the fax.

I’ll pray for Abbey – glad that Megan the Lamb is doing well. The hall has a piano room in the basement; I’ll request the key, methinks. Not the talent show, this time, but I feel very strong need coming on to use a piano.

You’ll never guess who I saw at a Stevens Point gas station with Paul and Alison. No, don’t – you won’t. Actually, you might. Within several guesses. But I’ll relieve the suspension (for your sake, Ethan) – Aunt Amy with her kids! “And to think that I saw [them] [there]...” – Doctor Suess

I may call, if I either find a phone or manage to get the copy of linux (that’s running on the school laptop) to work with the wireless card properly. :) A challenge.

Cheers to you all – hasta luego.

Isaac

Not terribly sure how I feel about the future. That’s not to say that I haven’t thought about it, but when I generally think of it I get a very strong urge to think about something else and something preferably more pleasant.

Dave Zach the Futurist delivered the keynote this morning. Subject: “An Owner’s Guide to the Future”. Very good talk, well delivered. I’m generally suspiscious of those who make their present living from skillfully-delivered keynote speeches, but David knew what he was talking about.

I’ll scan my notes later (like the admitted geek that I am). But the talk, on the whole, rather served to depress (as opposed to variously inspire, uplift or incite a cheerful countenance). Not to be cynical or anything (honest), but the future looks kind of bleak. In America, anyway. ... No, for most of the world.

Think through this, or don’t if you’d prefer the fish: over time, your relative impact on your immediate environment lessens severely. At birth, you had impact on your parents (and grandparents and siblings, as applicable), and a strong one at that (in all likelyhood). You come of age and walk in the kindergarten room door, and have an impact on your parents (and grandparents and siblings, as applicable), classmates and teacher, but the average effect is less. Welcome to high school – you, out of several thousand kids, won’t make any lasting effect on most anyone. Mostly. You enter the workplace: Walmart, for sake of this one-sided argument. You don’t matter really to anyone, in light of Walmart’s global scale of employment/service.

This probably doesn’t bother most people, mostly because it’s not generally something that people like to think about (see first paragraph). This probably is why those with the widest viewpoint are often manically depressed.

And then God enters the picture (or creates it, rather), and then life gains meaning. It’s no longer about what impact you have (thank you, God), but about the impact that God will make through you.

And it happens, oddly enough. But I manage to forget this last, all-important facet entirely too often and generally come across as an individual who would much rather just forget his surroundings and do something mindless for a while. Or conquer the world, depending on what day it is. Usually not Tuesday.

Anyway. This is all if you consider the future on a global scale. The future, assuming that we’re only concerned about your immediate vinicinity or that you’re exceptionally bright in some obscure area where most people aren’t exceptionally bright with you, could very easily be very attractive indeed. Look on the bright side. You’re alive, no?

Fairly sure of his name… Tommy’s my roommate for the week. Interesting guy, interesting background. Interesting intentions for the future – more from a determination to not repeat the matriarchal past, but he’d make a good author regardless.

I am profoundly grateful that I was given a roommate that (1) is not one of the dolts who aren’t here for any reason whatsoever, (2) is not a jock, and (3) is intelligent.

It’s interesting. He knows more about me than I think most people do, and I get the slight impression that it’s the same the other way around. The odds that we’re going to see each other beyond this week are neglible, and perhaps it’s for this reason that I feel safe talking to him. About the things that I honestly don’t think I’ve told anyone else.

And the same goes for a few other guys that I’ve met here. A Canadian, for example (I haven’t a clue what his name is, but we’re on a first-name basis anyway) – being a random guy that I’ve never seen before who isn’t likely to move to my hometown makes him much easier to talk to (as opposed to simply exchange light comments with).

The speakers today were incredible. Honestly incredible. I’ll post the videos as soon as I can – these are the things that America needs to know. Wow.

Stay tuned.

I’m fifteen for a moment / Caught between ten and twenty
And I’m just dreamin’ / Counting the ways to where you are.

Fifteen is never a wish better than this. / When you only got a hundred years to live.

I’m thirty three for a moment. / I’m still the man that you see on the bay

I’m forty five for a moment. / The sea is high and I’m heading through
All crosses / Chasing the years of my life.

How the time goes by / Suddenly you’ll rise
Another blink of an eye / Six seven is gone.
The sun is gettin’ high. / We’re moving on.

I’m ninety nine for a moment
Time for just a moment.

Fifteen is never a wish better than this.
When you only got a hundred years to live.
——————————-

Oddly enough, I always heard “fifty three”. Ah well. When I sing this, walking down the sidewalk in the evening, through the trees on the hill, reaching for life, it doesn’t really matter. Music is not the words – when it’s just me, walking alone, it’s the music. Me and the music.

I’m happy. Not like if-you’re-happy-and-you-know-it happy, just… happy. Content is a better word. Quiet and satisfied.

Life, for today, is good.

It’s not that rap cannot be enjoyed. It has been observed – though not by reliable witnesses – that it can in fact be enjoyed in backdoor establishments when accompanied by alcohol, various hallucinogens that most of Great Britain would be shocked to find in existence, and the odd pole-dancer.

Fortunately for the pole-dancer, rap is in good supply. And, for that matter, even if all rappers were to die of unknown causes (most are admittedly known to die of unknown causes in the first place, but for the purposes of this thought experiment we shall assume that they would all be done in at once in as a humanitarian fashion as is reasonable during a particularly raucous Saturday-night party in a backdoor establishment of Chicago), a remarkably decent replacement can be served up by any knowledgable Mac user with a few minutes in GarageBand 3 (Â£40 in most surplus stores) and a noticably violent threat to his or her physical wellbeing. Or gotee, should the Mac user be male.
———
This written 9:15am – sparked (sparked?) by someone in a dorm down and to the left who thought to share with the neighborhood his music collection. It’s the fault of the schools!

Wow. What a week.

The previous sentence is meant to be read slowly, with large pauses placed between each word for emphasis of the disjoint words themselves. As in, “What … a … week.” The proper response, if read correctly, is “Wooah.”

Topics: Everything under the sun – persecution, roles of corporations in a globalized society, military, environmentalism…

Atmosphere: intellectual, but still enjoyable. Really enjoyable.

Participants: Excellent speakers. The students were split: some the “Badger Boys/Girls State rejects” who were there by default, and others were there to be there.

Food: Good enough.

I came with a bit of aprehension: what on earth is a week listening to speakers going to be like, and what on earth am I going to do between eating, sleeping and listening?

Fortunately and thankfully, two things were introduced that answered the question to the extreme. Like asking your parents for college money and then having your lawyer call and inform you that someone in Vermont created a savings trust for your education 400 years ago and the balance is now in excess of 250,000 USD.

First: an air-conditioned computer lab. The air-conditioning is important, because the temperature in there was somewhat cooler than everywhere else. The latter is also significant: I brought a laptop from school, expecting there to be (1) a wireless network and (2) an excess of time to burn. Neither of these readily presented themselves, and the network admin at school locked the beast down waay too tightly for me to even use the wireless card that I had for it.

Second: several Canadians, and Tommy. And Diane. And Vince. And Ellen. And Gram-ham and Eli.

The Canadians presented themselves in the forms of Riley Maggs, Jaremy Edigar and Graham the Unknown, called such because no one really knows his last name. Riley went on to become one of my closest friends in the span of 4-5 days (which either means that all of my pre-existing friendships must have been rather shallow or that a minor miracle occured), Jaremy showed me that, yes, humanity can be incredibly vulgar but still be decent, and Graham was called Gram-ham repeatedly by one of our very Spanish-speaking counselors. “Gram-ham?” And it was a quick “Gram-ham”, pronounced like one would in a Spanish locale, not as if one were in Georgia.

Tommy was my roommate. Wonderful guy: intellectual, very human, not overly geeky but not at all a jock, and with a wonderfully European nose. I miss him.

Diane. Diane Diane Diane. Diane is from Appleton, which happens to be 3 hours and 28 minutes from Rhinelander. Delightful girl. We spent a bit of time strolling the campus after a sub-par dance, talking over life, the universe and everything.

Vince: Vince is just cool. You look at him and thing, “Geeah, that guy’s cool.” We think that he has a house in Mexico, and will hold our reunion there.

Ellen: Reminds me very strongly of Paula Darmsteader and Karen Clark, for the hair and face/personality, respectively. Christian girl who loves techno and The Juliana Theory. Perfect.

Eli: One of the 6th floor counselors, with a tendency to wear white sunglasses, much like these, in conjunction with slightly tattered khaki shorts that likely were not shorts in a previous and more affluent life, but are enjoying a much more enjoyable lifestyle in the present. He has a dual citizenship in Canada, which explains why he’s so cool. Which reminds me: someone owes me $5 from pizza on Wednesday night.

Gah, I miss everyone. Riley put it this way in a conversation earlier today online:

remember the little speech that was given on meeting new people?
“somewhere in this crowd is someone who if you meet and converse with, both of your lives will be changed immeasurably for the better”
I dunno about you man, but I think that the group we had going on
was pretty d*** successful

In light of the closing dance at the World Affairs Seminar, I made a vow to mix a rap album as soon as I arrived home, just to prove that there’s really nothing to it.

So I stumbled upon MusiGenesis, which does prove my point about “anyone [being able to] create great-sounding music using only a personal computer”, but is developed on an interesting concept: the music is “grown”.

You’ll have to try it. Really. The thing’s entirely free for forever, unless you want to save or export. Then it’s $19.95, which I’m considering paying.

I performed a tiny workaround and will offer up this poorly orchestrated 2:10 sample: download here. Kinda fun. Now go play.

Camp Horseshoe
PO Box 458
Rhinelander, WI 54501

To whom it may concern,

Ted Truscott, the esteemed instructor of cane defense for seniors, once said this:

Tradition really does have the value of keeping us centered and safe in many situations and frees us from having to repeat the mistakes of the past. ... It is the pressure of the wind, new fads and ideas, held back by tradition, that allows the kite to soar.

It can’t really be said any better than this, so I offer this quote to you as a thanks for your adherence to tradition.

Like those who preceded you in ownership of the camp (it was at that time called Algonquin), you have fearlessly made use the public address system, fondly maintaining it and restoring its wiring when a speaker goes down.

Never mind, of course, that the other 20 households on the lake wish to spend their evenings without being subject to your announcements and tasteful selections of new age and dance music – bending to their desire of quiet would show you to be like a weak kite, unable to stand up to the “pressure of the… new fads and ideas”, in the immortal words of Truscott.

So carry on in your journey. Continue to delight the children and adolescents who come to stay in your newly-built cabins, and play with wild abandon on your tennis courts and in-ground trampolines. Perhaps, one day, you will even add horses to your offering and so fufill the name “Camp Horseshoe”.

But in all of this, remember the tradition of the public address system. Even if the families on the shores of the lake that we all share only want peace and quiet, I share your confidence that it is the tradition that matters – continuing to share your music and sporting events at a volume that allows the sound to travel for miles outside of the camp’s borders may actually be best for their health. A healthy dose of well-chosen music, according to recent studies, may after all be beneficial to one’s salivary system.

Carry on, Camp Horseshoe. Hold to tradition – continue on with your PA system and share the Camp Horseshoe experience with everyone within a 5 mile radius.

Sincerely,

ikebowen

At last – the disposable camera that I brought to WAS was disposed of by Walmart. It was, too – check out the photo of Tommy.

This brings back fond memories. The idiots running around floors 6 and 8 (not idiots, sorry, but at 2 in the morning no one’s really sensible)… being idiots from floors 6 and 8 (we were, too – who else would end up in a random stairwell only really accessible from the boiler room that connects all the dorm floors?)… beating the daylights out of everyone (and being beaten myself, on occasion) in Mario Kart (love that game; gotta get a DS one of these days)… and getting the camera disposed of at Walmart. I had a few extra takes left, and tried to get a shot of a greeter standing in front of the Subway sign.

Now I’m left with just a shot of a Subway sign. She didn’t want her picture taken.

Derived from a fragment of a melody that emerged from the middle of “Somewhere (over the rainbow)”, here’s a mix that I’ve been playing with since the last piano stint at Holiday Acres.

Mixed again with MusiGenesis. It’s difficult to achieve the right feel to it, but it’s getting there. You’re hearing a guitar, orchestra, limited percussion… and some high beast called “xpansive”. Clevah.

And I have discovered these things:

  1. Things will always work out. Although, that’s Biblical: “And we know that God causes all things to work together for good to those who love God, to those who are called according to His purpose.” – Romans 8:28. That helps, and also wreaks havoc on chaos theory. ;) Thanks, God. There’s no way that I could get through everything without You.
  2. You are .cgi Your life seems a bit too scripted, and sometimes you are exploited. Still a workhorse though.
  3. Krystal Harris doesn’t seem to have a website. Pity.
  4. I love it when people make good use of the resources that I give them. FreeTXP, baby.
  5. “I’ll call you” really means “Well… this conversation is getting kind of awkward, so let’s do this: if something reminds me of you during the week when I happen to have my hand on the phone and I can remember your phone number – no, don’t bother; I think I have it somewhere – I might give you a call. Depends on how hungry I’ll be.” This I know from shameful experience.
  6. Life goes on.

Google has celebrated the 4th again this year, and their holiday logo from this year contrasted with last year’s (they’re both there on the left) brings this to mind: “Mindless flag-waving is not patriotism: it is a form of hysteria.” A couple of you will recall this – Dan Maguire cited it. So goes America.

Cheers. Go play with fireworks.

I love my job. No, honest – it’s very nearly perfect. The people are excellent, the food’s great, and I’m doing a lot of the stuff that I love doing. Learning a lot as well – I now know what an ETF is. ;)

This is going to be one of those entries where I talk about what I did today. If you don’t like those or would rather read something else in the vast array of blogs, go there now. This could be boring. Oh, wait – the brownies are done.

Not quite. The toothpick still garners brownie residue.

Woke up almost exactly 30 minutes past my alarm clock (thanks, Mom). I’ve discovered that I’m much more comfortable when I sleep in pants, interestingly enough. That’s pants versus your standard pajama-style pants.

Skipped breakfast (I know, bad for you) and stopped by Metro Screen Printing on my way to work. They’ll sell their blank shirts for $5, and as they’re the only shirts that really fit me (honestly, no one sells clothing for people who aren’t semi-obese). Bought two ($10.13-ish) and picked up a latte from Magic Jo. Double shot, iced 2%, with rum. It’s a scaled down of my usual (double iced, breve [half&half], 1.5 shots rum, .5 shots javalua), but (the brownies are still not done) it’s considerably less expensive. And this I like.

Work went well, as usual. Found six-ish optical mice in the basement, along with the double 15” LCD display that I found yesterday. The things you find…

The work day ended a half-hour later; the tape drive that the server uses for backup was being finicky. I won.

JC Pennies Penny’s being open until 9 tonight (future reference: they close at 5 on holidays like the 4th), I stopped to pick up a couple ties and a shirt. I saved $30-something, and discovered that you cannot apply for a Penny’s card until you are 18. Blast.

And now the brownies are done.

Two things to note today, the first being that Pirates 2 was excellent. Davy Jones was seriously the coolest. I say this with a markedly straight face in light of how clichÃ©d that sounds.

But honestly. He has tentacles and plays the organ with them. How cool is that? I’ve thrown in a shot of him over der on the left. Wow.

The second thing worth noting is that Google has upgraded their Video services. A few videos are now free: sponsors like LowerMyBills.com have enabled you to watch full-length movies like Deadly Kung Fu Lady. Thanks, guys.

1. I’m easily distracted. If it’s new and shiny, I’m there.
  2. I also have ideas. Things that I’d love to do, and hey – why not?

These two things combined make for very little productivity on the initiatives that I begin on my own. I’ve got… what, Prospork, Gradflag, SuperBucket, CLASSYgeek… Four entirely seperate projects that could each do very well. But what to work on? Prospork is relatively stable, Gradflag is little more than a concept, SuperBucket is halfway complete, CLASSYgeek has been started and restarted more times than I care to count. Blast.

Right, I’m going to lay them all out on the table. Now.

Gradflag

  • Service: customizable/extensible online grad announcements/invitations, RSVP functionality
  • Target market: seniors in HS/college
  • Notes: should this be a paid service, then?

SuperBucket

  • Service: note storage/organization
  • Target market: scatterbrained individuals who spend a lot of time on a computer
  • Notes: half-done; working on note organization/retrieval

CLASSYgeek

  • Service: news, a community, merchandise
  • Target market: geeks who are do not fit the geek stereotype – out of touch with reality, failing personal hygiene, etc. – classy geeks
  • Notes: should this be for tech geeks alone, or expanded for art, music, science, etc? Powered by Textpattern, Drupal…?

Bah. I really want to see all three go somewhere. For whoever’s reading this – if you have any experience in web dev and have been taken by any of the three concepts presented above, let me know.

Yes, it’s a fundraiser. I’m not ashamed to be involved, even though some of its materials are a bit… cheesy. :)

My good friend Matt H (hello, Matt) told someone that I would be a good person to be locked up for a fundraiser, and here I am. This is for the Muscular Dystrophy Association, and what you’re doing is helping me raise bail money.

Click here to take a gander at my own little participant’s page (excuse the website itself; the ball-and-chain graphic is my addition – yes, it does look like an advertisement from the 90’s). If you’ve got a credit card, drop in a few dollars. Nothing huge – you don’t even have to do the $65 for a minute of research, you tightwad. Kidding, kidding – $65 is more than I’d donate. But then, I’m not even out of high school.

So yeah. Do your part – bail me out. You know you want to.

post_title: Video Game Music on the Organ
final_content: I fully approve.

[ yawn ] I watched entirely too many surreal music videos last night. Though Glosoli wasn’t bad.

Scott Adams’ thought for the day… The last set of Dilbert cartoons haven’t been that great, but I do like this one. I’d buy Kevlar lederhosen.

I have a noon presentation scheduled for Kiwanis. Off to tell them that, yes, the World Affairs Seminar was indeed worth going to and that they should sponsor more people in the future.

[ yawn ]

1. Private notice. Mailed to a specific name… or current resident.
  2. Blatantly fake watermarks
  3. The secured document was secured with one of those little sticker things.

Just like the last one, this is a phenomenally bad piece of advertising. Interestingly, the number under the little scratcher matched the number printed above it. Then again, there is absolutely no indication that either number was printed especially for my copy of the mailing. Usually something like that would be done seperately with a dot-matrix mass printer or something. The barcode too.

But then, this is something from “Commercial Solicitation”. The street address actually matches up to the Baerresen Group, Inc (here’s a satellite pic of their building), the VPO of which declares himself to be 84% punk rock on his Myspace (he has 30 friends). These are the guys who brought you Turn-Key Events, which you can call at 1-866-GROSS-4-U. No, I’m serious.

[ sigh ] If anyone from Sedlak (or the Baerresen Group) reads this, know that you can do better. I believe in you. Honest.

Update
Upon closer inspection, it turns out that there’s no problem in having all of the mailings have winning scratcher thingers.

The fine print says this (among other things):

Valid for first winning number. … Odds of winning grand prize $2,500 Wal-Mart Gift Card are 1:70,078. Odds of winning $5 Wal-Mart Gift Card area 70,077:70,078. Grand Prize will be awarded if winning number is presented during dates and times listed only.

And there you are. Assuming that all 70,078 recipients of this mailing are present, one will win the advertised $2,500 card. The rest, save the one lucky one, will get $5 cards. Not bad, I suppose. That’ll pay for the gas to pick up the card, anyway.

Final thought
“No gimmicks”, it says. No gimmicks. So the scratcher is…?

I’m not sure how they’re beating it, but VoipBuster is also now offering free calling in the US. Not Canada, though, so I don’t know how it’s beating Skype…

Though VoipBuster does have a couple cool features that Skype does not, namely text messaging and (my favorite) connecting any landline/cell phone to any other landline/cell phone, using your VB credit. And with free calling in the US, it’s like free long distance. Nice.

Works like this: you give VoipBuster the number of whatever phone you’re closest to (e.g. 1XXXxxxXXXX) and the phone number that you want to call. International format, remember, so the 1 in front is necessary. Hit the appropriate button, and your home phone rings. Pick it up, and you’ll be connected to the other phone number. It’ll ring, and you’re free to talk for… hm. Forever? I’m not sure if there’s a limit.

Anyway, VoipBuster. Good stuff, that.

Aaron, in reference to Zelda: “Isaac, is the Karaoke Village the one in the forest?” “The Kokiri?”

Hannah, leaning over the table while her nose bleeds, speaking sedately to Ethan who is fetching the tissues: “Quick, please.”

Hannah, after Mom told her to wash her shirt in cold water to get the blood out: “But I’m wearing three shirts!” Mom: “Yes, but only the white one got blood on it.”

Rosy, remarking on how the innermost toe is not always the longest: “Your toes should be like… the Cingular bars.”

From scene 76 of The Matrix script: “Morpheus nods to a blind man who nods back.”

Paula Darmsteader: “The designers are upset.”

2Advanced Studios has done it again – a rediculously good edition of their website that would make any respectable designer curl up under their desk and not come out for a very long time.

... I’m not even going to say anything else. And judging by the comments that they’re getting, they may have inspired a new religion.

Right, let’s establish this: I’m a nice guy. No, honest: I’m about to give you 50 free music downloads when I could just give you 25 and get 50 myself for referring you. DRM-free, too.

These tracks are courtesy eMusic, a music download service that I haven’t checked the legality of yet, but the fact that they’re still in service is a point in their favor.

This fantasgreat offer is courtesy DXG, the guys that I’m going to grab a camera from. They’ve paired up with eMusic, randomly, and are offering 50 free downloads. Why?

Click here and grab ‘em. eMusic will ask you for a credit card, but no worries: download your music within two weeks, cancel your account within that timespan, and you’ll not be charged. Cool.

post_title: Life and Music and Automated Ad Farms
final_content:
Life
is good. Steady and engaging job, decent work on the side, friends here and there to variously hang out or talk online for hours with.

Music
is lacking, unfortunately. I miss Calah. I did put music to one of her lyric sets, though, and a writing a song. You might remember the audio concept posted earlier – Stay With Me? Yeah, it’s branching off of that. And speaking of audio concepts, here’s a breakbeat loop for you to play with: .

Automated Ad Farms
While looking for the site referred to by the Lazy Sunday / Chronic of Narnia video, I ran into skoop.com, an unusually tasteful example of an automated ad farm. It’s another ad directory site (you’d think Overture would have caught on by now), but it doesn’t look ugly (DomainSponsor, you should be ashamed of yourself).

As long as I’ve mentioned DomainSponsor, let’s go into a bit more depth. DS is responsible for those strange blue sites that open popups from Revenue.net (same group, by the look of the logos). The domains get parked and an iframe points to a URL like http://landing.domainsponsor.com/?a_id=208&domainname=referer_detect. Interestingly enough, when you go directly to a url like this, the site returned is branded with “Information.com”. (Slogan: “What you need, when you need it.” That’s almost a clichÃ©.) It looks like the landing page pulls the parked domain from the referrer data, and when it doesn’t have any, it uses information.com as the default.

Which is silly, because information.com doesn’t point to DomainSponsor. Information.com’s had a long and varied history, posing as the future site of Interband communications (they were hiring, and they evidently didn’t get anyone), i2x Media (“Internet advertising is failing. i2x Media is going to fix it.” Not with invalid HTML, you’re not.), and a bland page (well, they’re all bland) with an empty mailto link (which did get fixed on Feb 29, 2000). It was hijacked momentarily by John Somebody (affiliated with Girosol they should never have been given a copy of Flash). May of 2003 is when the domain first appeared to have succumbed to immoral search/content advertising bots, in whose hands it then stayed for some time.

When it became a legit-looking search site, we shall never know. At least whoever’s in control of it now tried to make it look good – it really is an ad farm after all.

[ two minutes later ]
The site actually does turn out to be the property of Oversee.net, the guys behind DomainSponsor .com and Revenue.net. I guess they do the same kind of thing with sites like degrees.com, low.com and, interestingly enough, LiveDigital which does actually appear to be a site of some use to people other than advertisers.
———————————————
This blog entry is definitive proof of my obsessive tendencies.

post_title: How To Get The Supreme Court On Your Back
final_content:
Since the Supreme Court ruled that Grokster’s style of operations is illegal, Grokster’s been out of business.

But feel free to visit anyway… Heh.

You’ve heard of Sourceforge. Savannah, Tigris and the rest have just taken a rather large hit with the release of Google Project Hosting.

This is going to take off. You know why? Because it’s Google, silly.

Google’s been building up to this – their Code area to begin with, and especially the Summer of Code, initiated in 2005.

Project Hosting will take off, but it’ll be a gradual start. The service release was done quietly, and though ZDNet did catch on, its biggest publicity at first is probably coming from Digg. Project Hosting isn’t even linked from the Code Base itself, nor does it appear in a search for google project hosting.

The day that Google goes corrupt will be very, very bad indeed.

1. Courtesy TigerDirect, I am now the proud owner of a DXG518, an excellent little camera that is both small and capable of taking perfectly serviceable shots. All for ~$100, too. Good stuff, that.
  2. Three small hermit crabs are now in my possession. Father John, Robin and Fuzz. Robin is fetching, Fuzz looks a bit like a tick, and Father John is amiably majestic as only a hermit crab can be.

Got to hang out with Calah for a bit this evening – we made our own lattes and music. :) I’ve missed her more than I realized this summer. Can’t think what the next year’s going to be like, with everyone out for college. Bah.

(followup)

Hello,

Along with 23 other households, I make my home on the lovely shores of Snowden Lake. Beautiful – you couldn’t have chosen a better spot to park your camp. The clear waters of the lake complement the grounds, making it the ideal place for a home or summer camp, as it were. Consider yourself fortunate – with real estate prices on the rise, it’s lucky for all of us that you got in before the rates became too high.

And you’ve made excellent use of the property, building on and sometimes over what the previous landowners had established. They would be proud, and especially so if they were told of their public address system that you’ve extended. At least, I assume you’ve extended it – I didn’t hear is used half so much under the previous owners as I do now.

Not that that’s a bad thing in the least, for I do enjoy the musical selections that you choose to broadcast. The occasional announcements are a bit of a bother, but as an avid fan of Panic at the Disco, Natasha Bedingfield and the like, I can easily overlook these.

My only problem is that I can’t quite seem to make out the actual words of the songs that are played. The volume isn’t a problem at all (I estimate it to be a good 40 decibels from where I am now – at least half a mile from the lakeside itself), but the clarity of the sound itself isn’t very good.

I’d suggest better equipment. You’ve got the principles of projection down (which reminds me – I stop by for a closer look; the sound from my living room stereo won’t reach the upper level of the house), but you might want to add a couple more high-level speakers (maybe a Mackie – they’re known for sound accuracy, and the dispersion ratios are incredible) and raise them up a bit. I suspect the trees are muddying the sound, and while you’ve made it better by removing a portion of them, raising the speakers themselves above the treeline and pointing them at perhaps a -15 degree angle from horizontal would help a great deal. There’s really no point in listening to a song from Panic and not being able to hear it word for uncensored word, right?

Take this into consideration. Your taste in music is fine, as it the projection level itself, but the clarity leaves a bit to be desired. I’m sure my neighbours agree, and be assured that we support you in this endeavour.

And hey, if better equipment won’t fit in your budget, just turn it up. Do us all a favor.

Sincerely,

Isaac Bowen

P.S. Idea! Adding a few subwoofers wouldn’t hurt – water carries bass like you wouldn’t believe.
P.P.S. And the new-age-ish selections played during the evening are excellent. Sound clarity isn’t a problem there; flute music was meant to be heard through miles of trees.

TigerDirect would like to say that they’re giving you a free month of Blockbuster, but when the redemption page? (shown after an order) is unprotected and they don’t even give you a promo code to use in the final Blockbuster signup form. Silly.

But you’ll note that, in the Blockbuster URL (/acctmgmt/displayRegisterSubName.action?planID=25029), the planID variable looks like it might be important for the special offer. Nah. Chop it off, you get the same thing.

False promos. Bah. TigerDirect, you can do better. -10 cool points.
C. Holland bravely takes on the shredder.

Used by permission, here (finally) is Dan Maguire. All 73 minutes of him.

So I’m a bit behind the times. I’ll get by.

My hermit crabs have begun to burrow. A lot. I hope they’re alright. It’d be rough for me to have to watch my next attempt at small-animal care fail. Though I blame the previous deaths on Walmart.

Watched Hitchhiker’s with Megan, Emma and Cari this evening. Good stuff, but… right, it could have been done better. Not bad, though.

Gradflag’s coming along. It’ll hopefully be up for the grad season this year – I need a couple designers, though. Contact me if you’re decent and don’t mind being paid by commission-ish.

“Spirit” being the town – just outside of Ogema. I’ll let the photos speak for themselves. I’m tired.

Few things worthy of note: Josh & Stef went out bungee jumping, much to Jennifer’s dismay (“Sign Gavin over to me before you go!”), Sam arrived in a GTO, Grandpa’s turning 89 tomorrow (party today; the guy still drives), … and Walmart stopped carrying the L’Oreal hair stuff that I was using. Blast.

Found a message from Karen (of Leaving Prints and As the World Scraps) in my inbox. Seems I’ve been missing a lot in there. Hm.

WAS guys – let’s get a conference call in, shall we? Don’t let me forget.

If you can see what’s up here, all is well. This is going through XML-RPC for Textpattern, published with Windows Live Writer (in beta). Hm… Formatting? Images?

... No images. That’s a shame. Wonder how that could be implemented… without just doing the FTP thing, I mean. Hm.

Draft saving works. Publishing works. Formatting’s in HTML, obviously… Could we get that converted back to Textile?

End test.

Tommy pointed out something that I can’t believe I missed: Pandora.

Great concept, one that MusicMatch already actively uses with its “My Matches” service. Pandora takes a style/artist/song and plays similar music. When asked to play Rob-Thomas-esque material, Pandora responded with the following:

Lovin’ those angry lyrics and repetitive chorus. Score.

Predictably enough, Pandora returned This Is How A Heart Breaks, a really excellent remix of one of Thomas’s more well-known pieces. Good song, great remix. Though I’ve got to admit, I’m partial to electronic mixes anyway. Speaking of which…

Trippy soundscapes. Niiiiice. Wow, I’m impressed. Firstly, because it includes a registration feature within the swf object (sum effect of which is that I could keep listening to the music and register at the same time – rare for a browser-based service), secondly because it very accurately picked up on what I liked. ... Possibly because I gave it a decent example of what I liked, but hey.

This strikes me as something that Google might do. They’re watching what people do with their services, observing and tracking the correlations between user actions. I wouldn’t be a bit suprised if Google takes over / joins this project. Helping predict human patterns would definitely help them when they take over the world.

Oh. Well, Pandora just started playing “Problem Girl”. Yep, that’s Rob Thomas. Ah well.

[ update ]
Google Music Trends just showed up on Digg.

Call me… whatever, but I listened to WPR this afternoon. Merens was on the air with At Issue, where concerned citizens call in with their news items. Here’s a clip.

“A year after Hurricane Katrina… people are still… they’re… they’re not doing well. It’s a mess.” Yes, this is a very aware citizen here.

“Joy Cardine is jumping out of airplanes. I am really very concerned about her.” This wasn’t quite as random as it appears to be – Joy Cardine hosts a show on WPR and had interviewed someone on Thursday where the sky diving thing came up.

But I fail to see the direct correlation between civil unions and complete homes and saving on taxes.

post_title: The Little Man Against The World
final_content:
So… my hermit crabs are having a shell fight. Two Ecuadorian crabs, and Fuzz (smaller, male) is harassing Father John (larger, female) for her shell. I think.

They’re chirping like crabs do, I suppose (more of an atonal creak).

post_title: When your best just isn't good enough.
final_content:
That’s a Demotivator, btw. Could you tell?

Couple things today. TigerDirect appears to have an unobtrusive bug (or hidden feature, maybe) in their shopping cart script (see image).

These are the guys who listed a machine that I ordered as “To Drop Shipper” (i.e. pending shipment from the 3rd party vendor), then told me that it was delivered to the office last Wednesday – signed by a staff member. Turns out the machine in question is still in the warehouse, and for that matter, it isn’t even fully assembled yet. The processor won’t come in until Friday. Bah.

And tech.monstersandcritics.com is half-broken, by the look of it. http://tech.monstersandcritics.com/news/article_1193103.php/YouTube_eyes_ad_money_with_Paris_Hilton_channel is returning a PHP error: Parse error: syntax error, unexpected T_STRING in /home/monsters/public_html/phpinclude/phpadsnew.php on line 254. [ grins ] Go Paris.

Despite the fact that their site design reminds me very strongly of Oversee.net (bad connotations there), I think I like Omniture.

I didn’t know that they existed until 45 seconds ago, and I still don’t really know what they do. Stat tracking or something, likely. I noticed firefox loading a very long URL in the status bar, something from 2o7.net. Smells of advertising.

Most of what I broadly call anonomous domains (tlds that aren’t readily associated with anyone) return some kind of error page when you try to load their index page. 2o7.com gave me a pleasant suprise – I was redirected to a page from Omniture explaining the purpose of the domain (visitor stat tracking), and giving the visitor a way to opt out of the tracking mech.

I like this. Above board – no trying to disguise the system’s origin. [cough]omniture[/cough]

7:30am. My feedreader tells me that Google was planning on releasing Apps for Your Domain as of yesterday.

Suprise, they have. Tucked into a corner of their business services page, Google is making available Gmail, Calendar, Talk and Pages for any domain that you so desire. The beta’s available now – doesn’t look like there’s any waiting to be “approved” like there was with the original Gmail for Your Domain.

So. I’m toying with setting it up for hq52, but it occured to me that these services would do a fair job serving the business that I’m employed by. We already own a domain for use, but I checked on thg.org just in case – it’s an appropriate domain for the business, right, and it’s short. Turns out it’s a parked adfarm. Right click -> this frame -> page info reveals that it’s parked at oingo.com.

I’ve already said my bit about ad farm providers. Visiting oingo.com results in a redirect to appliedsemantics.com. Suprise: Applied Semantics has been aquired by Google. A large part of that, likely, went into the development of AdSense. But guess what else they do. Domain parking!

Google. Makes sense, I suppose. Their AdSense services are second-to-none, like everything else Google does. But I have two problems with their aquisition:

  1. It’s an aquisition. Google has a history of these, worthy of its own Wikipedia entry. Pyra Labs (turned into Blogger), Picasa (photos), Keyhole (Google Earth), Urchin (Google Analytics), Writely (web-based word processing), Sketchup (3d modeling)... The Applied Semantics aquisition was way back in April of 2003, but I’m still freaking out about it. One more in the long list of companies and projects that are now under the Google umbrella. If you can’t (or don’t feel like) beating them, buy them.
  2. Google is behind those flipping ad farms. Google!

[upd] Google wins eBay’s non-U.S. ads, e-commerce tie

I’ve fantasized for months about a service that would let me buy play-all rights to any song and then store it for me online. I’d have access to my library from anywhere.

Enter MusicMatch – or not. I’ve inadvertently purchased a one-year subscription from them (signed up for the trial, canceled a bit too late), granting me streaming access to their library. It’s a step up from XM Online, but… Unfortunately, while they know of all the artists that I’m looking for, they don’t have music from all of them (ATB, for example). Pity.

But wait – what’s this, patiently waiting for my attention in my feedreader? Something about MP3tunes?

Turns out that MP3tunes (from the guy who brought you MP3.com and Lindows Linspire) does nearly exactly what I’m looking for – the only difference being that you upload your own music to your “Oboe Locker” (I’m suspecting that’s a reference to HS band days gone by) to stream back later.

The news coverage that they’re getting now is for their addition of a free version of their service – previously, one actually had to pay for hosting your music on their servers.

This makes the most sense as a short-term marketing stunt. With the proliferation of the iPod, a service like MP3tunes didn’t stand much chance reaching the people who wanted their music with them without lugging around a desktop (though some do, evidently), but maybe now that it’s free…

My guess is that MP3tunes won’t be terribly mainstream. SpiralFrog, maybe, but not MP3tunes.

Except among geeks with a desk job. Yes!

Gah, it’s been a while. There’s no time, honestly, between school and work and school and work.

Anyway. Call me… whatever you want to call me, but I found this strange. WhatCounts – offering email publishing solutions for you and yours. They’re probably of little consequence (I strongly suspect that they’re using a template from somewhere for the site), but I stumbled upon them from a link in an email from Pandora. Something pointing to http://dbm.pandora.com/. But what’s this? It’s the same site! The same IP!

So… are the guys behind Pandora and The Music Genome Project also getting their hands in the mass marketing field?

There’s probably a conspiracy of some kind in here. You watch.

To: Arc90
From: ikebowen
Subject: Link Thumbnail

I’m perusing the docs on Link Thumbnail – a handy little script, but should Girafa – the source for thumbnail images – be credited somehow for the images supplied? Their services are, after all, paid-only. And you’re pulling images from MSNSEARCH’s account. The image references are to http://msnsearch.srv.girafa.com/srv/i?s=MSNSEARCH&r=[url here]. Presumably, if it is indeed the account for MSN Search (now Live search), they can afford to have other people mooching off of their subscription. But is that ethical?

Cheers to you,
ikebowen

Hello,

I seem to have received an excellent example of spam-in-print. A flyer, placed beneath one windshield wiper on my car – an advertisement for magickidsusa.com. This is my chief complaint – if you cannot garner enough traffic for your website through legit advertising methods (though you do say that you receive “an ‘avalanche of hits’”), doling out flyers in parking lots is really not the best way to go.

Also, a few notes for your own security. Perusing your site, it became evident that you’re simply using an installion of Zen Cart to power your system. Keep in mind that this is free, open source software – if you’re at all serious about doing business securely, you may want to switch to something professionally developed.

And along the lines of security – I do see the flash item from Starfield, telling the world that the website is indeed “Safe and Secure”. But what’s this? The site in question is not “magickidsusa.com”, but “www.magickidsdev.com”! Might this be the development site? Or is magickidsusa.com simply showing everything in magickidsdev.com, minus the administration panel?

If this is the case, you may want to take further steps to secure your online business. The Zen Cart administration panel cannot be accessed from magickidsusa.com, but it’s very available at magickidsdev.com.

Good luck to you in your further business ventures.

ikebowen

I’m having a lot of trouble (a lot) figuring out something about why the very existence of a function referencing a variable created in another….

oh.

Yes, Virginia, if you initiate a variable in one function, it does not necessarily make it global.
Scott Adams is my hero.

What was foretold (several times) and attempted (only slightly less frequently) has now come to pass: ikebowen is back online.

To a degree. Blog, yes. Crazy-web-development-projects, not so much. Which is a pity… but time’s limited, see.

So. I performed a quick redesign of the site, and it’s very much a work in progress. I’m trying to achieve a balance between the mildly striking and the aesthetic, without actually putting a lot of time into it. :) Colour will arrive, promise.

Developments since I last wrote anything:

  • The Zune is coming. Microsoft is trying to go social and artsy, all at the same time. Gizmodo’s had quite a lot to say on the subject: product design, functionality/features… I’ve preordered one from Amazon, hoping that either (a) someone will be able to hack a webbrowser onto it or (b) Microsoft eventually takes advantage of the built-in WiFi.
  • Christopher Scott (at FreeTXP) has been dugg, and has consequently taken down the FreeTXP service for more than a few hours. :) All credit to him.
  • Applications are in to MIT, UW Mad, Northwestern College and IIT. ... Time will tell.
    • On that note, my SATs are over and done with. This merits a larger huzzah than I would usually give it; between the subject tests and the actual four-hour… well, you’ve probably taken it yourself, so never mind. But the Conserve School was an amazing place to take the thing.
  • Music is back. Two songs on the grill; the (developing) lyrics will probably end up under expressions.

twenty minutes later
‘Tis the trouble with wireless peripherals… Anyway.

  • Am reading The Picture of Dorian Gray, which could arguably be called an extended thought experiment into the human psyche. It’s a book from last term’s english course that I never actually finished (time again), but I kept it past term ending to complete on my own time. Oscar Wilde’s ideas are fascinating, the conflict between intellect and soul personified in Dorian Gray. Very interesting read.
  • Also reading The Gods in Everyman for Classical World Lit; interesting treatment of the gods as personality ‘archetypes’. Ties in well to my thoughts on Dorian Gray, actually.

And so… bah, I’m sure there’s more, but I haven’t a clue just now what.

Cheers.

Background: this was written… or no, start over. I tried to write this song some time ago and failed relatively miserably, to which Calah B can attest. The lyrics that are below were written within the space of 30 minutes, entirely unmitigated and entirely unexpected. The song isn’t about death, per sÃ©, but about the parting in general. Probably brought on in part by the graduation of the class of 2006, a group that I still strongly miss.

———————————————————-

I once heard a tale of a man who was older,
and no one to hold him close at night.
Only one companion: a child from across the street
who stopped in to talk every now and then.

She reminds him of his youth, and of the days gone by;
recollections of the past he knows he had.
They’re walking through the park: tuppence for the birds she sees
and their friendship is strong, the old man and a child.

But the world keeps on turning, and time is moving on
We’re living this life and we live it for love, even when the rest is gone

Look ahead a couple of years: an old man on a hospital bed
a young woman, she’s kneeling by his side
A rose sits by the table; a photo album full of
memories of the life that they had shared

But the look on the nurse’s face tells the inconquerable truth – the old man sighs and his friend searches for these words:

Is this the time for you to go, and is the goodbye I say to you
my friend? Is there anything else I can give?
Is this the time for you to go? And if this is goodbye, I’ll say it again:
I’ll mis the time we had to share

[ interlude ]

(now) I’m sitting alone in the park, thinking of friends I’ve had
and how I’ve enjoyed the time I’ve spent with you
(but) I know it won’t always be like this: as time moves on
so we must close the door to turn to something new.

(it’s because) the world keeps on turning, and time is moving on
we’re living this life and we live it for love even when all else is gone

And when the time comes, I’ll search your face: what do you feel?
Have we come to our end?
But I look again; thought I saw a tear fall from your eye,
and it’s time for me to say:

Is this the time for you to go, and is this the goodbye I say to you
my friend? Is there anything else I can give?
Is this the time for you to go? And if this is goodbye, I’ll say it again:
I’ll miss the time we had to share.

The world keeps on turning, and time is moving on.
We’re living this life and we live it for love, ‘cause it’s love that lives on.

© ikebowen

I really don’t think that it’s possible to completely and intentionally communicate what’s going through one’s mind, using targeted words. The best way, perhaps, is through… some other form of expression. To understand what someone else is thinking, I find that measuring their reactions and impulses serves best.

Simply being around somebody, I suppose, works. And perhaps I’m only stating the obvious here, but I think that it’d be more effective to talk about something other than your state of being than to try to describe it. Observing the subconscious react gives me a much clearer picture than your consciousness trying to describe itself.

Music fits into this, yes? Poetry, visual arts… Creative efforts stem from what I generally call the soul (versus the mind), and what’s in the soul is thereby communicated in a form that isn’t confined to a language. Music has structure, yes, as does a painting. But the soul is more free to express itself in a medium where it’s not confined to a certain vocabulary.

Sing to me. Play for me. Or talk about the weather – whatever. There’s a place for defining your state of being, yes. Getting your thoughts out on paper makes life that much more… approachable. Treatable. But if you’re simply trying to show me your soul, don’t talk about it. Let it show itself.

In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth. Genesis 1:1 (NASB)

Did God create time, after all? The popular belief is that God created everything, but a definition of ‘everything’ isn’t really in place. Life, the universe, and everything, sure. But does time count?

To start with, let’s get a definition of time out on the table. For the purpose of this thought experiment, I’m considering time as the fourth dimension – one up from the third.

And as long as I’ve brought up the dimensions, let me cover those. The first dimension is a point. No movement possible. The second is a plane – two dimensions of movement possible, and thus one can move in the second dimension (the X axis, for example) and remain motionless in the first. The third dimension is space – three dimensions of movement possible, and thus one can move in the third dimension (Z) while remaining motionless in the first two.

The fourth dimension is generally considered to be time, as it’s logically the only way one can move while remaining motionless in the first three dimensions. If I stand absolutely still, I can still move through time. … I can really only move forward, granted, but the point stands.

Physical humanity exists, as far as can really be proven, in the fourth dimension. Not only in the fourth dimension, obviously; existence in the x dimension precludes the existence of all dimensions lesser than x. Does that make sense? If a ball is suspended in the air at eye level (not sure how; it just is), its distance from me forms one dimension, its height off the ground is another, and its distance from you might pinpoint the last.

So, with all that in mind, what dimension does God exist in? It’s really impossible to know, seeing as how… well, what’s the fifth dimension? Yeah, I don’t know either. :) It’s safe to say that God exists beyond the fourth. As physical humanity can move at will through all dimensions lesser than its highest (the fourth; we can move through the first three), and God can move through time at will, He therefore should (must?) exist at some dimension higher than we do.

Given this and the earlier conclusion that presence in one dimension mandates the existence of all lower dimensions, the existence of God requires that all lower dimensions, including time, must exist.

So, the question stands: did God create time after all? As He existed, so time must have existed with Him. Biblically, He created the earth and really everything outside of the earth (“the heavens”). Granted, the lack of any reference to time doesn’t mean that God didn’t create it, so this whole thought process may be relatively futile. How can we know the mind of an infinite God? To limit Him to what we know of Him would be foolish.

But still, it’s interesting to mull over.

I’m feeling a bit… wary. Cautious. Slightly unsure.

For a Monday, though, things have gone exceedingly well. Nothing terribly productive to do at work today, the Student Council meeting went decently, Decathlon is ever a good time, and ballroom… well, ballroom went decently too. I swear, we’ll get the hang of it.

I’ve never liked Mondays. Really never liked them, and I suppose I’m one out of… the rest of humanity in that opinion. Having to break from a routine that’s just been settled into is not ideal. You get up at 6:20am five days in a row, then sleep in a day, get up the next at 7:30, and then start again at 6:20. It’s an aberration, albeit a planned one, in schedule.

Anyway. Aaron got back this evening from his first-ever conference. Yes, there are multiple-day leadership retreats for junior high students. :) He’s an interesting character, that one. Feels deeply, he does. Generally takes him… a good 12 hours to fully deflate from an extended event like that.

Things I want to get done before November is over:

  • The-Project-That-Would-Not-End
  • Fully balancing my checkbook
  • Find some decent headphones that aren’t $30
  • Get a cell phone
  • Feel comfortable with life, and stop having to ignore parts of it

[ smiles ] Abbey’s already begun Christmas lists. I dearly love that girl… Actually, I love all (4) of my siblings. Can’t imagine life without them.

Am trying to get in some Decathlon cramming… yech. Facinating stuff, mostly… well, okay, the history gets a little long. So many Chinese dynasties.

As far as nostalgia is concerned… idk, I miss ‘06. Such great guys. Ben, Ben, Calah, Anthony… who else… Danielle, Matt, Kevin… Yeah, Adam too. Great guys, and I miss them.

upd And my Zune shipped! Huzzah!

Change is good, yes. People are always interested in change – trends, fashion, gossip… The National Inquirer makes its living speculating on change purely for change’s sake.

But… gah. This is going to be one of those blog entries where the blogger in question appears to be completely self-centered and self-pitying. Apologies; skip this one.

Change. Implies uncertainty of the future and an end to the present. Which, yeah, can be a good thing, and arguably is always a good thing.
