Not being rooted in the past/present lets you be malleable, flexible, ready to adapt. “Change is the only constant in life” – said by someone at McDonalds, probably, who was overheard and misquoted in a later conversation completely unrelated to the original context. But it’s generally the truth, and… I don’t think I like it. I don’t handle uncertainty well, and change tears apart situations that have begun to be comfortable.

I guess… bah. I’m tired, lonely and unsure. It’s times like this where I take a slightly displaced view of my own situation – a 17-yr-old in rural Wisconsin, trying to ignore the little voice that’s telling him to do his homework. Now. One kid in a million with his own internal conflicts, one side of himself unable to reconcile itself with the other. Does it matter? Probably not – everyone has emotions, everyone goes through emotional turbulence. This age bracket is known for it. It’s predictable, it’s usual. ... How very shallow it all seems.

[ sighs ] I have homework to do… People are valuable, and the ones that change the least mean the most.

Yes, that’s a generalization.

[ blinks ] I’ve decided – I need more than four hours of sleep.

  1. Received the acceptance letter to UW Madison – I’ll be going to college, at any rate. The envelope said “YES” on the back.
  2. Mom and Dad are in Madison (interestingly) for a meeting of some kind. Good for them to have a few days out together.
  3. Was drastically unprepared for Classical World Lit today, and was nearly late. McDonalds and Subway have both had faster turnarounds.
  4. Giovanni is scaling the climbing wall in the tank.
  5. My desk is an unholy mess.
    • Two contact cases
    • A container of hermit crab food and another for Zyrtec
    • Generic-brand Playdoh
    • Water spritzer
    • Pair of glasses (to which a minor miracle is associated; they were found the other day inside a crushed case on the driveway, unharmed – thank you, God)
    • A painted egg. Romanian?
    • Threadless stickers. They’re having a sale, btw.
    • Tape measure
    • [ many other miscellaneous items ]
  6. I’m off to bed. Cheers.

My job right now is mind-bogglingly dull. Go through every single cell in a worksheet containing thirty-four securities and benchmarks, with a cell for each quarterly return for the last three years. 34+34(3)+34(4*3)=476. Individually. This isn’t Excel – this is… well, never mind what it is, but it was not designed for anything other than hard data.

I generally enjoy my job, honest. I’m a professional geek, and there aren’t a lot of high school kids that get to do that. [ tips hat to Anthony ] Getting paid is kinda nice, but I think it’s the people here that have kept me here. My coworkers have all developed slightly jaded and cynical senses of humour while retaining some buoyancy in their personalities. One in particular is a one-woman comedy troupe.

And from all this, I’ve concluded what Scott Adams makes a living off of: business is a farce. For all the shiny-cover presentations and suit coats, it’s still just people who can get ticked off at their bosses.

[ sighs ] I wish this machine had speakers.

My Zune is in the mail – should be here early next week. I’m excited. I’m waffling between buying quality headphones or an FM transmitter (so as to avoid messing with cables in the car). Maybe both, but it would have to wait for the next paycheck.

I love music. Favorite bands, just now: Iris, RÃ¶yksopp, The Postal Service, Snow Patrol (only for the one song, actually).

Quit work, make music. Calah, we can go to Tennessee first, but can we work in a European tour?

Disclaimer: This entry is to be treated as a description of a hypothetical circumstance, and not necessarily indicative of any actual situations or people.

I left Rob’s house and took the first wrong turn possible. Made it back to Rhinelander without further mishap and got on to Cty C on the other side of town. Didn’t notice any fire on the way back; the housefire from my trip out must have been taken care of.

Pulled around the corner to where our turnoff is. There was a barricade of police cars, an ambulance. It didn’t really register. I turned around and took the back way in, then realized: there’s an ambulance. Outside my driveway. ... My sister… when does she get off from work tonight? My dad and Ethan – did they come home from the hunter’s banquet? ... Oh God… ...

The speed limit on the backroads is 5mph. Even 25mph felt like… something. It was a possibility, and my mind flashed through the reactions of my siblings. What would they do – what would their live be like if a brother, sister or parent was gone?

Made it home, pulled up next to the garage. The truck was back; Hannah was home from work. Not the Intrepid though.

Hi Mom. Yeah, what’s going on? Do you know when Dad’s planning to get back? Not for a while, then.

He did get back, he and Ethan. Walked over to the accident site on the highway, talked to a volunteer on the fire dept.

Three passengers and the driver in a four-door. Overcorrected on a turn, shot off the road and clipped off a power pole at four feet up. Hit the driver’s side. Rolled.

Welcome to Friday. Rob’s at school; saw him as he walked out of the faculty meeting. Someone died; the teachers always have a meeting when there’s a student death. Yes, that’s an observable pattern.

Kyle Malone.

[10:24] Anthony: :( saddening
[10:24] ikebowen.com: I was driving home from something; saw a barricade outside of my driveway. my sister was coming home from work, dad/brother from a hunter’s banquet. scared me to death.
[10:24] ikebowen.com: but this…
[10:24] ikebowen.com: the guy was my best friend in elem

news coverage

I looked up ‘mundanity’ to see if it was a real word. Primary definition, interestingly, is ‘secular’. Ah well.

My Zune came in last night. I’m pleased with it. Yeah, Engadget doesn’t think much of it, but for MS’s first entry into the market, it’s not half bad. I’d only change the sensitivity of the control pad, but that’s me. Radio/audio/video all work perfectly. Haven’t had a chance to play with the wireless stuff, but it doesn’t do much yet anyway. Here’s hoping that MS makes the most of that hardware in future firmware releases.

I’m ripping my copy of King Kong to put on it. The rip process itself isn’t bad (DVD Decrypter), but the recoding into a resized mpg (Videora iPod Converter) takes forever. “Forever”, in this case, being 4-5 hours.

In related news… Cars isn’t half bad either. Three of the family are watching it (again) now. There’s a little Italian forklift in there that reminds me very strongly of Jacque from Finding Nemo. My favorite character by far.

I woke up at 5:30 this morning, unintentionally. That kinda sucked. Was really confused for a few minutes; it wasn’t light enough to be morning quiet yet, but it wasn’t dark enough for night… yeah, anyway.

‘Mundanity’ reminds me of ‘Voganity’, which reminds me of Douglas Adams. I ordered Antigo’s copy of The Long Dark Tea-Time of the Soul... hopefully it’ll come in sometime soon.

Scott Adams wrote a book: God’s Debris. He released a free PDF of it online. Still haven’t gotten around to finishing it.

Cheers.

P.S. Somone managed to get a full-length rip of Cars online at Google Video. ... Wow. Google, that’s a real credit to ya.

It’s remarkable how really mundane everything is. You don’t even notice it after a while.

Monday proceeded in general as usual. ... But I don’t really feel like writing about my life, nor do you likely feel inclined to avidly follow it. Pander to the audience.

Hermit crabs are wonderful things. Nearly the ideal pet, I think. Small, fascinating to watch, require little maintenance, and they scuttle. Like dogs, they seem to have mental complexes, only less prone to guilt. Shell envy, restlessness, social… something. Awareness. Crabs are socially aware.

Giovanni just wandered over by Sebastian and Norgay, who were already sitting next to each other beneath the unpainted ceramic pot fragment. Not sure where Baccus is. I do think it’s actually spelled “Bacchus” (Baccus seems to be an (aged) jazz organist), but it doesn’t really matter.

Goldsworthy’s son is indeed adorable. It’s curious to me that we find small children so irresistibly endearing. Or most, I suppose. Is it the innocence? Unadulterated youth or the simplicity of mind? Actual size too, I suppose. Rick Moranis taught us that lesson.

The song of the day is Believe In Me, courtesy ATB.

Was finally reunited, after a fashion, with Ben Wohlleber. Life is better with a liberal, hm? Blame Megan.

My desk is a mess again. ... Bah. I’ll need to clean that before the extended family arrives. And they’re coming here for Thanksgiving, which might be considered a minor miracle. Or not at all, yeah, but… wow, that’s nice. Road trips with seven closely related humans in a car can be stressful, and the desire to get them out of the way (the road trip, not the humans) often cuts short the spend-time-with-long-unseen-relatives.

Hermit crabs also have a strange propensity to climb. I don’t know why, and I kind of doubt that they do themselves. Giovanni’s on the climbing wall again; Norgan dismounted the vine tower.

Current mood: scattered and slightly restless. I neeeeeed closure.

yes, I know, it’s getting late
the nights are getting harder to take
and I’d rather not fall again
to a sleep where I know I’ll get up again
and all too soon

and it’s only tomorrow that we’re waiting for
but let it go – let it go on its own
for now the time is ours alone
and life is still going on

it goes on, and we wait
tomorrow will wait alone

—
Incidentally, I did a double-take when reviewing this entry. It said “Tuesday”, and I haven’t left Monday yet.

Really is a decent video. This shipped with my Zune, and I didn’t watch it until… recently.

My feedreader has this listed for Nov 20, 1995. Why it’s on my list of recently posted items is beyond me.

Happy Thanksgiving, etc etc. Unless you’re in Canada, in which case, congratulations on those street lights.

My mom’s half of the extended family arrived today in droves. “Droves” here is equivocal to “about 30”, and it was therefore most fortunate that we were able to borrow chairs and tables from Dad’s meeting room.

Order of events:

  1. Appetizers (various cheeses and crackers)
  2. Several rounds of impassioned Dutch Blitz
  3. Final food prep
  4. Various interesting conversations, most notable of which concerning calculus, World of Warcraft, and how the two coincide in brilliant gameplay theory
  5. Food
  6. Post-food exhaustion
  7. Deserts (a larger assortment of pies and ice creams)
  8. Entertainment for the purpose of warding off the effects of tryptophan. Or something.
    • The Annual Spooons Competition (fairly sure we scared Shane’s girlfriend)
    • Family photos (plausibly labeled as “entertainment”)
    • Pit
    • National Treasure
  9. Farewells

End round one. Great times.

now playing: When You Were Young (The Killers)

I love my family. I honestly do – nuclear and otherwise. Watching the interactions of people who share the same genetic base can be very informative, not to mention entertaining. :)

Anyway, today (more yesterday, actually) featured the Bowen thanksgiving with the entirety of my dad’s family gracing our humble abode. And it really is a great time – dad’s siblings and parents all have very strong and defined personalities, and it’s shown in their offspring various. I shan’t go into too many details for fear of offending someone [ grins ], but… yeah. Glad to have everyone up this year. We’re planning Christmas for late Dec sometime (surprise).

Other activities of the day… received the acceptance letter for Northwestern, so not only will be going to college, but I will have some choice. :) Now, to find funding... FastWeb works very well, as you probably know if you’ve been through this, which you likely have or are in the middle of, assuming that I know you and you’re reading this.

But regardless of that, I need to get back to the Iliad. That was one text that I could probably have handled life without, but the test’s on Monday. Meh. Hoorah for Sparknotes (disclaimer: for supplementary aid).

By the way…

Right, and I promise I don’t do this very often, but occasionally there’s an issue of the one of the local papers that is absolutely ridiculous.

It wasn’t so much the articles themselves in this issue, but the classifieds. You’ve got to wonder, do people know how they are presenting themselves?

Some samples, excluding the one about waterfront property on “gin clear water”:

HIMALAYAN Kittens, three 2.5 mos. Old, first shots, $150 each. Call ##.
... Old?

TREADMILL never used…
And that was either a gift or a wishful thought.

243 Money To Lend
This category is ridiculous. Spam, the lot of it.

HATE TO shop or just don’t have the time? I’ll do it for you.
Oh good.

ABRAHAM BASEMENT REPAIR. Specializing in wet, buckled, cracked, sinking basements. “When you can’t get Moses, you can depend on Abraham!”
Honest.

$13,900 Will put you in the middle of the National Forest
Whereas $15k will send you straight on up to Canada.

530 Hay
You know you live in a rural community when ‘Hay’ has its own category.

CHEVY 2001 Prism (same as Toyota Corolla)
Wait, what?

What’s interesting is the number of ads that seem alarmist. The kind that scream to the world, or to part of it, ‘YOUR CREDIT RATING IS BELOW ABSOLUTE ZERO BUT WE DON’T CARE AND WE’RE REPUTABLE!’ You’ll note (actually, you probably won’t – but that’s what I’m here for) that most of these are branded with the label WCAN, which happens to be the Wisconsin Classified Ads Network’s insignia. They list a disclaimer in the ads to the effect of ‘We’re sorry that some of our ads are ridiculous, but it’s really not our fault. Feel free to complain, but we’re fairly sure you don’t care sufficiently to do so.’ (This disclaimer, incidentally, was listed directly alongside a listed opportunity for extra money and free trips to Tahiti, courtesy your friends at WCAN.)

The trademark of any alarmist ad is an overuse of exclamation marks, caps and bolded text. Simply because of who I am, I’ve discovered that 64% of the WCAN ads printed this week overused the exclamation marks, and 75% made gratuitous inclusions of all-cap or bold text. 85% of the exclamation’ed ads were also cap’ed or bolded (made bold?). You’d think WCAN would notice. ... Nah.

Thank you, publishers. You make us proud to… idk, live here or something.

Agent Smith: Have you ever stood and… stared at it? Marvelled at its beauty? Billions of people, just… living out their lives… oblivious. Did you know that the first Matrix was designed to be a perfect human world? Where none suffered, where everyone would be… happy. It was a disaster. No one would accept the program, entire crops were lost. Some believed that we lacked the programming language to describe your perfect world… But I believe, that as a species, human beings define their reality though misery and suffering.

So I don’t actually have much to write about, but here’s a spattering of distractions for you to toy with:

  1. Human Beat Box
  2. Dilbert Blog
  3. Boohbah Zone (for Anthony. and Emma.)
  4. QDB
  5. songstowearpantsto.com
  6. Despair, Inc.
  7. Perhaps the coolest and most powerful spork ever created.
  8. Something Awful (blame Riley)

Interestingly, relativefailure.com is still available for registration. Buy now.

addendum
This too, actually.

Most of my family’s off just now, fetching a Christmas tree from Grandpa’s place. Interestingly, my dad planted a larger area of spruce trees early on in my parents’ marriage. Good planning.

Hannah’s at work, and I’m trying to forget that I have work to do. :) Which isn’t too hard, all things considering.

Bob’s monitor is sitting in a box on the other side of the room. Blast. We set him up with a 21” widescreen lcd a while ago during the upgrades. The display was… hm. If a ghosted version of the screen image was blurred slightly and superimposed on the original, just nudged to the left, then that’s what it looked like. The replacement from HP came in, but the problem is still there. Which means that it’s either the cable (shouldn’t be; there were no problems with the old monitor) or there’s some kind of radiation under the desk. Bob’s not aware of any.

Went to the winter play at the high school last night: A Midsummer Night’s Dream. It’s the ’50s edition, meaning that the thing’s set in the 1950s but all of the lines are straight out of Shakespeare. :) Delightful. I never actually realized that poodle skirts have poodles on them.

I found Nathan M. loitering in the lobby as I walked in. Yes, Bottom did say “I can gleek upon occasion.” But that’s gleek, not gleek. [ grins ]

– some spammer

addendum
Incidentally, the YouAreBeautiful stickers showed up the other day. Meg and I got a pass from Kitze (“Meg & Issac / to garbage can / from r204 / Kitze”) and adhered one to the swinging door of the receptacle. “you are beautiful.” A custodian took it off before the end of the day, which miffs me. Who would do that, honestly? … Although, it just might have brought a smile to some downtrodden kid’s face first. It’s possible.

According to MyHeritage, my closest celebrity match is Kirsten Dunst. ... Honestly, Kirsten Dunst? Runners up (runner-ups?): Jackson Browne, Oguri Shun, Julie Andrews, followed by several Spaniards and Paul Dirac.

My parents up and bought another vehicle. We arguably now have a fleet. Two suburbans, a truck and a runaround car. It’s a decent Suburban (new-ish one); ’99 4wd. Best speaker array in the fleet.

Watched 1.5 Matrix movies last night with Sam, Sam and Meg. Sam… bah. What’s his last name, anyway? I really want to say Sam Hill, but that can’t be right.

Things To Do (weekly edition)

  1. Work as much I have time for
  2. Be at Decathlon more than work
  3. Ballroom (!)
  4. Meeting re: $ with Hanson
  5. Run a Council meeting
  6. Figure out what’s wrong with Bob’s monitor
  7. Find the contact info for a few Council advisors in other schools
  8. Run through the FreeTXP requests
  9. Christmas shopping
  10. Work a bit on The Project That Would Not End somewhere along the line

It’s Friday; I’m in love

Should probably go to bed at this juncture. Monday is inexorably approaching. ... Actually, they all are. A figurative infinity of Mondays, relentlessly marching on. Along with the rest of time, yeah.

The doctrine class this morning was excellent. The general topic concerned Jesus and his role, both in his incarnation and otherwise. It kind of transmuted itself into a discussion/debate over the motivation for creation and it could be justified.

Which is, in and of itself, a very interesting topic. Its premise goes something like this: “God is, by definition, infinite. Yes? Infinitely powerful, infinitely good, infinitely knowledgeable. Or omniscient, whichever you like. With that in mind, and knowing that God must have known what his creation would end up as (or has ended up as), why did he not create it so that it would remain perfect? Or, for that matter, how could he justify creating it in the first place?

Like the text says, that’s kind of like accusing God of “cosmic sadism”. The general conclusion to that line of thought is that God, by nature a giving and loving entity, created humanity as… as almost the means for him to fully express a few of his own traits: forgiveness, grace, benevolence, etc. (That’s not to say that he needed humanity; that’s another conversation, but by definition he doesn’t.) He gave humanity free will, allowing them/us to choose (or not choose) to love God in return. Yeah, that results in a significant percentage of humans not choosing him, but that can’t reasonably be leveled at God as a point against him. Forcing his creation to love him would be… worthless and shallow.

I’m starting to ramble. :)

Which kind of goes into the whole predestination thing… Free will is possible because God, in his infinite ability, can limit his own sovereignty. Wrap your mind around that one. [ grins ]

Bah, that’s the end of that for tonight. Recommended books: Christianity 101 (very academic and deliberate approach to all of this), The Case for Faith (goes through a number of apparent problems with God and the like; very honest/straightforward review).

Innnnn any case… I love buttered popcorn. Delightful.

“Religion” bothers me. The word and its connotations. It takes the focus off of God and puts it on man’s interpretation of God. My approach to it all is largely intellectual, which is… well, that’s how I approach a lot of things. Most of life. Necessarily, though, any belief concerning anything beyond humanity has an element of faith to it. That’s naturally a little bit more difficult to accept, but is something that can be assimilated completely by a mere human worth dedicating yourself to?

And on that note, to bed. Good night.

Very, very cold. Jessica gave me her sweater during fourth hour, which was… generous(?), but it was both tight and feminine-smelling. Warm, though.

I’m downloading Through Glass from Zune at the moment. Heard it on 100.1 on the way in to work (mi bosso has a meeting scheduled with me, so evidently important that it’s marked “personal”), and liked it. That’s it over there on the byline.

Winter is nice. I enjoy looking at it. From the other side of an insulated wall and a warm beverage. (The secret to great hot chocolate is flavored creamer.)

Cause I’m looking at you through the glass…
Don’t know how much time has passed
All i know is that it feels like forever
When no one ever tells you that forever
Feels like home, sitting all alone inside your head

How much is real? So much to question
And never dare make up the mannequins
Contaminating everything
When thought came from the heart
It never did right from the start
Just listen to the noises
(No more sad voices)
Before you tell yourself
Its just a different scene
Remember its just different from what you’ve seen

Poot. My dad came in with me to talk to Mrs. Hanson this morning, mostly regarding money and how to get it. :) Didn’t learn a whole lot there, only that procuring anything besides local scholarships and grants from the school in question will take some effort. Blast.

Mrs. Goldsworthy commented the other day that she didn’t think I had senioritus (or however that’s spelled), contrary to whatever the honorable Mr. Kitze may believe. Her observation is that I’ve ceased to see any point in high school. ... Which kind of is the going definition of senioritus, but it’s more of a decision than a lazy mindset. And honestly, I think she’s right. I’m only still semi-concerned about grades because of the MIT mid-year grade report…

My first closed-door with my boss has been suspended, due to a call-that’s-more-important-than-you. Ah well. He wants me to be working here more, which I’d love to do (most of the time), but it goes back to that 24 hours in a day thing. Day minus sleep minus school minus work minus decathlon minus miscellany = 24 – 6 – 7 – 2 – 5

Equals something – got to leave and get to decathlon just now. Bah.

This song isn’t finished by a long shot, but I believe it’s entered an incubation period. Much like the earlier one... Could be a while.

midnight flying past
headlights expose
unthinking insects:
facets of survival, the pain isn’t real
oblivion meets glass, and the night is still
mine to explore
as it divides me
peering inside things I try not
to
hide


the way you make me feel at night,
when I’m alone, and I remember
the last time that I saw your face
and you were smiling up at me

it’s the way you make me feel at night,
when I’m alone, and I remember.
I feel a quiet smile,
turn, and fall
asleep

This was written during what must have not been a terribly strenuous day in calc, inspired by the drive home from the night before. There’s a longer explication, if you will, that’s associated with what’s been written thus far… idk, see if you can figure that out yourself, though. The indentations are important, the phrases crossing lines are important, the images are important…

[ grins ] This looks very modern, which is interesting. I still think that [ coughs ] some individuals tend to read into works of literature a bit far, but this one does have a bit of depth.

It’s been a day. Left school after the Council meeting and went home, after stopping at work and the library. I picked up Ender’s Game. Goldsworthy first introduced me to the series.

And so, with an entire day at home, I more or less consumed the thing. Reviews and reading… supplements there are, and in considerable number, I’m sure. I marked lines from the book as I went through, and with these I grace you. [ bows ]

—

As he thought of it, he could not imagine what “just living” might actually be. He had never done it in his life. But he wanted to do it anyway.

Ender did not look forward to fighting with the wolf-children again, but to his surprise they weren’t there. Perhaps, killed once, they were gone forever. It made him a little sad.

All is going well, very well, I couldn’t ask for anything better – So why do I hate my life?

Perhaps it’s impossible to wear an identity without becoming what you pretend to be.

And it came down to this: In the moment when I truly understand the enemy, understand him well enough to defeat him, then in that very moment I also love him. I think it’s impossible to really understand somebody, what they want, what they believe, and not love them the way they love themselves.

“You don’t understand,” he said.
“Yes I do.”
“No you don’t. I don’t want to beat Peter.”
“Then what do you want?”
“I want him to love me.”

He heard a voice whispering in the forest, “You had to kill the children to get to the End of the World. And he tried to answer, I never wanted to kill anybody. Nobody ever asked me if I wanted to kill anybody. But the forest laughed at him.

“Welcome to the human race. Nobody controls his own life, Ender. The best you can do is choose to fill the roles given you by good people, by people who love you.”

... but what mattered in life now was who would marry whom, and who was sick, and when was planting time, and why should I pay him when the calf died three weeks after I got it.

... Which doesn’t likely give you a great picture of the book, but perhaps a bit of the flavor. “It’s a tragic tale of romance…” Not really, but I do recommend it. And those that follow.

There’s a film version coming out in 2008, same screenwriter as X-Men and Superman. I’m intrigued.

Honestly, read the book. Along with Brave New World. :)

afterthought
Anyone know how to effectively get the blockquotes up there pushed to the right far enough for the borders to show?

Ethan froze his toes during ski practice.

I found the first overdraft on my current checking account… blast. -$2.40. That’s all. If it was like… a $240.00 overdraft, it might be worth it. But $2.40?

Here’s a thought: Video games. Are you wasting your life? I’ve never actually compulsively gamed. … In fact, I think the last game I played was my emulated MarioKart 64. :)

Balancing my checkbook… bleh. Turns out that realtime assets and processed assets have two different values, and that one should really be balancing a checkbook more than once every two months.

several minutes later
Right, the checkbook is balanced. Though perhaps that’s arguable, as I find myself with $20 extra, and I don’t know why. … Not that I’m complaining; this puts me at a less negative balance than I thought I should be at, but… bah. Whatever.

Audio test. I swear, I’m going to get better at this. I have copies of MusiGenesis and something from Cakewalk, and I keep meaning to learn how to use them properly… Were I a Mac user, I’d have GarageBand to keep me company.

Ha. I’m not, though, and never shall be, I’m quite sure. Reason why: I’m infinitely more comfortable with the Zune than the iPod.

Woke up this morning at a bit past 7:30am. I was initially confused, first after finding the alarm clock buried beneath blankets one and two, and then because I didn’t remember any particular point at which I had suffocated the alarm. After carefully thinking this over, I slept for another two hours.

Didn’t go to work today, but I did catch english and calc. And Decathlon. Found out in Classical World that I missed an in-class essay, which goes on the list next to The Iliad test. My grades have been suffering like that.

But, so it goes. Kurt Vonnegut.

Bit of a strange phenomenon, all things considered.

Only This Moment (Royksopp)

By “all things”, I’m here referring to the human tendency to move on. People get sick of consistency – change change change change. Fashion, travel, news, tech. None of it really survives the mood swings of a society.

But in the middle of all that, we keep looking back. Or I do, anyway, and I’ve seen others do the same. People who miss what they call the golden age of music or whatever clothing trend they’re most fond of. Thinking out loud (or whatever), I guess it’s more the memories that are made (passive, Bronson) during those times than the characteristics of the times themselves.

Ha – three paragraphs starting with the letter B.

This all more or less has its roots in last year. I’ve had several grads in a row tell me that they miss high school 2005-06. Which… idk, I find kind of strange. Senioritus (there must be a better way to spell that) and all this – the desire to get past the present is very evident in the last few months of high school.

Or is it that? Maybe it’s just getting sick of the end. Kitze (the male) acts like that. No sense in drawing out what will inevitably end, right?

[ blinks ] Right, where was I? … Nostalgia. Missing the past. … Is there any real point in that? There’s acknowledging where you came from, yes, and that’s probably healthy. Learn from the past and all.

There’s probably no real point in going over this. It’s interesting, though, for a race society that always seems so ready to move on, that we often seem to look back wistfully at what we just passed on by.

[ feels like there’s more to be said ] How much does regret play into this, though? … No, never mind, that question isn’t really going anywhere either. I’m failing to muse properly. :) Regret… doesn’t always coincide with nostalgia. Nor, obviously, does it go the other way. Perhaps nostalgia is the more… fitting form of regret, after all. Looking back and missing it, but not necessarily wishing to go back to it. Like war stories. Ye battles of olde, maybe.

Bah, whatever. I miss you guys too. [ smiles ]

addendum
10:03pm. I’m cold, my eyes are tired, and I still need to find motivation for homework. Meh.

Entirely Unrelated Cartoon

There’s something wrong with my copy of the Zune software; can’t seem to get music from the marketplace properly. ... So, naturally, I buy it at work. :) Today’s selection:

  1. Island – Iris
  2. We Live – Superchick
  3. Courage – Superchick
  4. Sleep The Clock Around – Belle & Sebastian
  5. It Could Have Been A Brilliant Career – Belle & Sebastian
  6. Starting Over – Audio Adrenaline
  7. Wake Me Up When September Ends (video) – Green Day

Fairly varied selection… Nothing terribly intense here; mostly contemplative and/or laid back. Mood of the day.

So, in any case, here I am at work, still. We just finished a project (group presentation; imagine a powerpoint overview of the company printed out and bound in shiny wire-spine wonderment) that’s quite literally taken the last 6 months. Which pleases me. :)

post_title: Unforgivable Sin / The Question of the Innocents
final_content:
I’m starting to fall asleep, but I wanted to get this in writing before I actually do. Fall asleep.

This week, like last week, a few interesting points were brought up in the doctrine class. The two that stood out in my mind concerned the unforgivable sin and the fate of babies/children and the retarded who die.

So, starting with the first: unforgivable sin. The fact that there is one isn’t the question here, really; Jesus gives it as accusing the Holy Spirit and its work to be of evil – “blasphemy against the Holy Spirit” (text – I’m linking the NIV for readability’s sake). That aside, the idea I was toying with is whether or not a Christian (defined as one who have accepted Christ’s salvation, etc etc) can commit this particular sin. Perhaps this really isn’t muse-worthy, because I think the answer is fairly clear. No, one really can’t. A Christian is forgiven of an infinite amount of sin, really, because of the sacrifice of infinite quality that was/is Jesus Christ. But bringing the unforgivable into the mix: if the professing Christian truly has that relationship with God and is forgiven, the unforgivable sin cannot be a part of said Christian’s past/present/future because it was all forgiven. ... Yeah, not really muse-worthy. But interesting.

More muse-worthy is the question of the innocents. What happens to a baby who dies in infancy, or to the mentally-handicapped individual who doesn’t know his own name? The answer that one would like to hear is, of course, Heaven. What kind of god would damn an innocent soul? The key word there, however, is the word ‘innocent’. Technically, no one is innocent. Sin is something that more or less permeates the human condition, and has done so since what’s referred to as The Fall. Once introduced to humanity, the condition of sin remains simply because humanity could not and cannot remove it from itself. So, knowing this, the answer that we don’t want to hear is that a still-born infant ends up in Hell. ... Do I believe that? Honestly, it’s hard to say.

The other factor that needs to be considered is what I refer to as the point of sentiency. It’s why parents don’t (or shouldn’t) put one-year-olds in a time-out for spilling food. Punishing a being for something that it does not do consciously is fundamentally unfair. (Note that that’s different from doing something that said being does not know is bad.) Generally I’ve heard this called ‘the age of accountability’ – the point at which the human mind attains consciousness or becomes sentient.

Which brings up another interesting question: if an infant or a retard (retarded to the point where a consciousness is not present) cannot think, do they have a soul? Do they exist in anything beyond physical form and instinctual reactions? If they do not, then the point is completely rendered moot. It becomes more like the question of whether or not pets go to Heaven, which I refuse to touch. :)

So, food for thought. I really don’t know the answer to this one, and I’m fairly sure that no answer can be satisfactorily attained. We’re only human, after all, trying to fathom the mysteries of infinity.

addendum
I’m opting against a statement along the lines of “hope I didn’t offend anyone”, but I suppose I should probably say that, yes, infants are developing a sentiency. That’s what the growth process is all about, and arguing that infants can’t think is probably as plausible as arguing that adolescents can’t. [ grins ] That’s a stretch, but my point of clarification is that I don’t think babies are animals. ... As long as we’re clear on that.

Start Over (Audio Adrenaline)

This song is entirely unrelated, sorry. It surprised me – I don’t remember Audio A sounding like this ever before.

Beware – The Flying Dervish of Polka!

Ballroom has come to an end, and I’m tempted to simply pass it off with a good-riddance. There is one more session, but Sam and I have opted to skip it. Things we’ve learned:

  • Life is good in the Leonard Lane
  • Long-short-short only goes for so long
  • Youth is conspicuous
  • People who have paid to be taught something unusual are fun to watch
  • Drunken Polish -> Polka

[ grins ] It’s been fun. The instructor was/is grand, not the least for her glasses.

And now for something entirely different: I’ve gotten results from MIT. Turns out that the guys in Admissions announced on Dec1 that the decisions would be released on the ninth… ah well. I’ve not been accepted. … Yet? The letter from Admissions says something to the effect of “Conservative as we are, you’ve not made the first cut and have now been deferred. Don’t fret – most people end up with this. We’ll be in touch. In March.”

So the stress is somewhat off at this juncture. But I really need to get my grades in order for the mid-year report.

Gah, I’m tired. I should be reading Killer Angels for Early American right now…

Enjoy the morning/afternoon/evening, depending on when you read this. Cheers.

The Weather
Lovely, isn’t it? It’s 39Â°F (extended interruption here; phone call from Bob and the arrival of several sausages/cheeses, interestingly) with Dense Fog. [ happy sigh ] A few degrees warmer and it’s be perfect, but hey – this is Wisconsin. :)

My brother’s in skiing… I wonder what they’re planning. Brule and the like probably still have something on the hills, but there’s hardly any snow out at the moment. And lately the weather / Has been so bi-polar…

Work
There’s been far too much of it. ... Though I really can’t complain; (catches whiff of… something cologne-like) I log less than 20hrs/wk… ah well. Get paid. Pam Bishop (co-worker) is excellent – overworked people are occasionally a lot of fun to work with.

And hey – I got paid – I can now buy the pants from eBay and pay my hosting bill. And start Christmas shopping. Speaking of which…

Extended Family
Hope yours are healthy and relatively prosperous. Though, as Pearl S. Buck makes clear in her novel The Good Earth, wealth and a lavish lifestyle can corrupt an otherwise stable family. My aunt by (a previous) marriage called this evening, wondering if she could drop in with the kids next week sometime for the night. Which both astonished and delighted me – I haven’t seen her in years.

Miscellaneous Bits
Oh, the CDs on the chassis? Yeah, I ended up circumventing the Zune DRM problem by burning the songs to CD and ripping them back in iTunes… Klutzy klutzy klutzy. I’m trying to find a tool that’ll create a virtual CD burner that I can ‘burn’ an audio CD to, and then rip the songs off of the iso… or something. Anthony tells me that WinISO does wonderful things with images. (Anthony – thanks for the song. A lot.)

Conversation Killers
I dreamed that a friend committed suicide last night. Or rather, I dreamed last night that a friend committed suicide. And also that my youth pastor gave me a cell phone with fold-out drink tray.

Hey, look – a $90 Zune! But only if you (a) voted and (b) are a Chosen One. But hey – you could also get a TMX Elmo for $39.99 on that same offer – all off… well, no, the sale price is precisely the same as the list price. Never mind.

“You saved three people’s lives today! Isn’t that great?”

Civic duty – check.

I’m wearing a sticker that says “be nice to me, I gave blood today”. Megan beat me – her donation took seven minutes against my eight. :) Sam was planning on her first donation, and was nearly deferred for being in Europe last year. Ended up being deferred anyway; her veins were too small. She was crestfallen. Next time, hm?

something here don’t feel right
this is just a half-life,
without you I am breaking down

Half Life (Duncan Sheik)

It’s raining… Ahhh. Fall has earned a reprieve. In the middle of December, yeah. I love it.

My mom’s birthday was yesterday. Happy birthday, Mom. Dad bought a massive ice-cream cake that I brought home after work/decathlon. Very enjoyable event all around.

So, just now, I’m printing out prospectuses (prospecti?) for a selection of investment funds… I highly doubt that the recipients of these booklets will actually use the reams of reports contained, but hey – I’m getting paid for it.

Listened to a song by Eliot Lipp on the way in to school. Real Tragic; he sounds like a slim black dj. Which he’s not. Ha. Interesting sound, though. It grows on you.

Rather looks like sleet out there right now.

addendum
Turns out those prospectuses (all of them) weren’t collated when they printed. Consequently, I’m now going through all seventy pages of each and manually putting the pages in order. Bah.

post addendum
And then the printer, believing that it had had enough of the same old thing, opts to begin collating its print jobs. Just to shake things up a bit, see.

4:00 addendum
The printer, just so you know, has decided to cease collating for the very last prospectus.

I’m in love (The Cure)

Friday Friday Friday Friday. The week is done. … Granted, a new one will be starting promptly and a new one after that – a Monday will occasion itself every seven days of my life, but life goes on. I think that’s circular reasoning.

Anyway – I’m here at work, deciding exactly how much I’m going to allow myself to spend tomorrow. Ben M and I are going to wander Wausau for part of the day (Barnes/Noble, Fazoli’s, other shopping places for Christmas and whatnot); going to try to get the finale of the Matrix films in with Meg/Sam/Sam that evening.

I still have a craving for cheap frozen pizza.

Oh, incidentally, I fixed a couple bugs in the a.m. paper and added a feed for Crave. Because I know you care. :)

So. I turn 18 tomorrow. That’s really probably inconsequential – my daily pattern will remain the same and it’s only another birthday with 70 to follow – but I’m kinda looking forward to it. As anyone would. Matt H’s all about the “smokes and porn”. ;) Speaking of Matt, there’s a Facegroup Facebook group for RHS Music Alumni. Geeah, I miss Show Choir. Peterson, if you should ever happen to read this through some strange manifestation of improbability, know that you’ve done a great thing. You’re the best.

In related news, I’m trying to write a song involving the line “we’re really only two shades of blue”. The line came up when Kitze questioned my integrity where it pertains to homework – yes, Kitze, I did indeed finish the assignment. In two shades of blue, no less. It sounds cool, but come to find out, the phrase has been used in a few less than unexpected places. :) Stay tuned.

I know I mentioned him before, but Eliot Lipp is great for work music.

My hands are cold again. Enjoy the remnants of Friday, all ye who wander here.

addendum ut adsolet
Added the photo up yonder. Ethan was experimenting with eye photography. Also, check out that link to Nabaztag on the right ->. Possibly the coolest thing I’ve ever seen.

A Birthday
Picked up Ben and stopped at the Briar House before heading off in the general direction of Wausau. There was an Indian guy at the mall with a toy airplane launcher that he incessently demonstrated (something like this, but less army-ish). Poor guy. Accomplished my main Christmas shopping objectives there, thankfully, and Ben found a bellybutton ring for someone. Ha – two guys trying to find the best ring in Claire’s. :)

On to Fazoli’s, where there was a little blonde boy with a mohawk cut. And Danielle Larson, I think. TJ Maxx, Best Buy, Barnes & Noble. I found what I affectionately refer to as “twenty pounds of architecture”, though it’s closer to ten, whereas Ben discovered an anatomy coloring book. :)

At which point we kind of headed home… Discovered highway NN, which neither of us had previously known to exist, along with a liquidator’s store in a neighborhood that smelled of cheap Chinese food. Ben played DJ on the way back.

Spent the following… hm. eight hours at Meg’s house with varying numbers of others, enjoying Ben’s cake and the Matrix, in that order. A Shel Silverstein collection from Sam – thanks.

B Birthday
Spent with family. [ smiles fondly ] Really very enjoyable/pleasant. (Interjection: No ballroom tomorrow!) Missed second service (Dad wasn’t feeling terribly well, if you must know), and… yeah, there wasn’t any point to that; nvm. Frozen pizza and cake. :) I love my family – I truly do. The gifts from them were all precious, even the Skittles from Aaron that promptly went into the candy vending machine on my desk for him to buy back. … Mom astonished me. A photo album, containing a collection tantamount to a record of my life. From Dad, a longer letter, and a promisary note for later investment. And a tie clip.

Oi. The things one treasures. Fond memories. Honestly, if I end up at MIT, I really hope I make it back for more than just Christmas and Spring Break.

Thanks, guys. (Assuming those reading this are the ones I know; probably not the guy from Iran.) Love you all.

afterthought
So yeah, I’m considered an adult now. :/ Feels a little different, knowing that, even though it’s really just another day older. Ah well. I looked forward to this for a very long time, waiting for the point at which I could do things on my own without having to have my parents’ signature next to mine. Waiting to be taken seriously, I suppose. And I guess… I have that now? Idk. In the eyes of the law. I can sell stuff on eBay and buy cigarettes. (Matthew. You realize I’m going to think of you every time I walk into a gas station, right?) Mm. Bah, I’m having few discernible reactions.

Time marches on, as they say.
Some things never change. And some things do.
Stay inside my dream until our / Time wears thin
Distant worlds are you the home I have? / My orbit has me thrown / To the boundaries of the mind
Only this moment (Holds us together) / Close to perfection (Nothing else out there)
Would you lie with me and just forget the world?


now you know to be young
isn’t the hardest thing you’ve ever done
know before your time has gone away
you’re saving time

Meh.

I’m still having difficulty wanting to… to keep moving, I suppose. I’ve found that, once I slip, I don’t necessarily want to get back to where I was in the beginning. Which could be passed off as laziness or lethargy, but I’m hesitant to call it that. Probably because those are both derogatory, and I’m talking about me here. :)

Things I want to do before I die:

  • Jump onto a car on the freeway
  • Skydive
  • Achieve wide recognition for something that I’m proud of. Just once.
  • Get married?
  • Go on tour with Calah; release an album
  • End up where I’m supposed to be

bit after eleven
Scanning Sparknotes for class. I do appreciate Virgil much more than Homer, but it gets so very long. I did scan through the original text, though. Justification.

Listening to Pandora (after finally realizing that the monitor array I’m using has a speaker built into it). Their advertising technique is admirable and original – the advertiser seen is allowed to rebrand the entire page, not just toss in a banner.

Methinks I’m going to end up with a Tracfone sometime soon. I favor prepaid services over subscriptions, anyway. Although, Alltel has prepaid… hm.

almost eight
Ha – the Decathlon team had a psuedo-suprise mini-party at practice today. I didn’t go to work after school, not like usual, and Emma marched in with this cake. Knowing Emma to be the crafty person she is, and that she randomly shows up with food on occasion, I didn’t put much thought to it.

And then Sam told me that she needed me to go on a walk with her. … That was a little odd, but did I come to any kind of conclusion? Nah. I’m fairly oblivious when I’m not suspecting anything. Upon my return, I discovered straws and balloons in fairly large quantities. Far more straws than balloons. (There’s a story; ask me if you don’t know.) The cake apparently contained a layer each for Potter Puppet Pals, something I don’t remember, The Matrix and for Charlie the Unicorn. Absolutely incredible.

Ee. :)

Bit direct for my taste, but not bad.
die, n00b.


Really, this is cool. I’d never buy one, but it’s cool.
Mogo Wireless Bluetooth Mouse


For the battles against Waukeshaw West.
Titanium Spork


Can I tell you how hard it is to remove industrial-class staples with your fingernails?
Staple Free Stapler


A beautiful thing. :( Go check this out. Now.
The Special Edition


Honestly, I don’t care what anyone else says. It’s a great device.
Zune


:D
Nabaztag

This is driving me freaking nuts. A brand-new laptop, D820, decides that it no longer wants to use its ethernet port. Right, that’s workable, and you’d think that the silicon bead that I found jammed into the physical port would have been the source of the problem. No. It doesn’t even think TCP/IP is installed.

The connection’s listed as a 1394 Net Adapter… oh.

Beautiful.

Turns out, you need to install the driver. And before you mock me for not seeing this earlier, it was working earlier! DHCP and the whole bit!

Arrrrr.

afterthought
And why didn’t the drivers come freaking installed?

(other news: added The Onion to the a.m. paper)

Song of the day. If it plays several times faster than it should… whatever, deal with it. I don’t know why.

The weather outside is frightful…

But despite this, nine people have managed to show up this evening. Granted, nine out of twenty, but that’s still a decent number. The freezing rain alert lasts until 0600 tomorrow; the winter storm warning until Saturday. I can’t decide if I’m hoping for a school cancellation tomorrow or not (pros and cons, as always), but it either wll or will not be.

I finished Brave New World a few minutes ago. … The ending was painful. Painful and conclusive, which was an appropriate finish to a book that began pleasantly and inconclusively. I wasn’t sure where the appeal amazingness attraction [something] was for the first bit, but never fear – I’ve got it now.

And now for something completely different. For $.97, one can purchase a five-foot string of white/clear Christmas lights from Walmart, and $1.97 buys a small glass bowl (in the wedding supply area).

Not bad, I thought. Aesthetic. Excepting the unholy mess that is mu desk… ah well. Ethan and Mom, contrived the following:

Beautiful. The photo’s lacking, as photography does to the photographer; the full impression takes more than just one of the senses, but hey – it looks nice too. :)

And because I’m posting pictures, this is Cloud.

He has great hair.

addendum
Score. I found a source for Rhinelander cancellations, parsed it with feed43, and added it to the a.m. paper. [ feels geeky ]

Though more concerning Friday as I experienced it than for Rhinelander as a whole. Sorry.

That aside, school wasn’t canceled today, as I was disappointed to find in my feed aggregate. Blast. Crandon, Three Lakes, Elco, the lot of them – all canceled. Although… yeah, the weather/road conditions admittedly weren’t bad enough to call off school. I told myself this as I stared down my alarm clock this morning, trying to ignore its insistence that it is once again 6:25 and you should have been out of bed ten minutes ago, young man.

It’s a tri-fold alarm clock that settled itself on my windowsill some time ago. It sits there, quietly waiting for its time to come. It doesn’t have power enough for the backlight anymore, but the alarm has grown more jarring with time, like the bitterness of an old man who’s started to realize that he never really had any effect on the world at all.

But so it goes. The office closed at three today; Hannah and I left school and came home directly. Honestly, it was so very nice to come home by 3:30, in some semblance of daylight, rather than at 6:00. My pants came in this afternoon also – a pair of Arizona carpenter jeans, precisely the same as a pair that I’ve worn in and then some. My rockstar jeans. The new ones smelled both of old people and Goodwill merchandise; I’m not entirely sure what that means. The vanilla scent that permeates my office has warded it off, though.

On an unrelated note, people are idiots. While this has been established before, Reuters brings up an additional point against our noble race.


From outside this evening, wondering at the snow. Or, in this case, the lamp post.

A few quotes from today:

She seemed to fear nothing – and that, in my opinion, can be dangerous. (The Chorus; Antigone)
It’s like those people that are in all your classes… and you wish they were your friends… (Hannah)
And the city waits. (The Chorus, probably; Antigone)

I think I fixed the song from yesterday. Listen to it again, if you would. This song struck me rather oddly… Or in an unusual way, perhaps. Slightly unconventional, artistic/creative, and passionate. All together. For this reason, I’m giving you the song in all 192kbps of splendor.

Happy Friday. We have snow for Christmas.

It fundamentally bothers me when I see public material (e.g. poster, website, flyer, what-have-you) that is tasteless, especially when it’s for an institution that I otherwise support. You know this already, if you know me at all, but just now I’m specifically speaking of the local YMCA, the Chamber of Commerce, and HodagSports.com.

Looking at these sites really, really bothers me. The YMCA site, for example. Mixed fonts, random gradient, poorly executed navigation… there’s no consistency in the design. Same thing goes for HodagSports. In that way, the Chamber is slightly better, but only because the design simply has fewer elements in it.

And add the local theatre to the list. Of the four that I’ve mentioned, this one is probably the best, but by no means a work of art.

Which, granted, is not what they were made to be. All four sites are functional and accomplish their practical purpose – the information is communicated and a user leaves knowing, generally, what they needed to know.

But the impression given is lacking. No one will be looking at these sites unless they already intend on using the facilities (or… teams?) that the sites represent, because the sites are neither engaging or… well, pleasant to look at.

And I can deal with that, I suppose. So, evidently, can their owners, but to be honest – it kind of embarrasses me. I live here, I use the Y, I see occasional movies, etc etc, and they’re all “wicked decent”. [ nods to Ben W ] The thing is, if I were a guest looking through what Rhinelander has to offer, I’d think it terribly sub-par.

Probably because I pay attention to presentation as much or more than actual content, and I’m likely in the minority there. But isn’t presentation everything?

I suppose… bah. I don’t like that my town is represented poorly, and I know that I’m only looking at four different groups in one medium. But still.

addendum
Incidentally, Night at the Museum rocked.

Vince Guaraldi’s rendition of O Tannenbaum, from the album A Charlie Brown Christmas, was supposed to be here. Either my copy of the LAME encoder is dying, or… bah. Either way, the mp3 died and has left you, the reader, musicless. Apologies.

—

Ah… ‘Tis the season – for Christmas music remixes. And the like.

I’m full and happy and tired, which actually has happened a lot lately. The Gustafsons are over just now, playing Blokus. They come over for dinner every year, every Christmas evening. It’s kind of nice; they’re a great family. ... Also, there are only three of them, which balances out the seven of us rather nicely. :)

So. Sunday, we went off to the morning service (forgot to record the sermon as an mp3; will have to transcode it off the cassette), went home, and did nothing much until the evening service. We trucked the family off to the Gustafsons’ church in Three Lakes, actually, which was very enjoyable. They produced the service… hm. More like a dramatic production with a message. Kind of. The narrarator, interestingly, sounded a lot like Microsoft Sam.

One thing I noticed – the theme of how Christ’s birth affected (or “rocked”, as Pastor Darrell put it) the people involved in the situation was present in both services. How Joseph must have felt, discovering that his officially betrothed wife has ended up pregnant, for example. An interesting approach; I guess I’ve never really considered that. The Biblical accounts are, at first glance, a little austere. “His mother Mary was pledged to be married to Joseph, but before they came together, she was found to be with child through the Holy Spirit.” It’s worth considering what happened, between the lines.

Also interesting – someone was perusing materials on Germany (more on why on a later date) and came up something like “Christmas is a charming blend of pagan tradition and Euro-Christian influence.” Remember that, hear? Many American traditions/holidays are evidently Germanic in origin/influence, which came as somewhat of a surprise to me. Though I suppose Wisconsin is especially German… yeah, nvm.

As is generally done here, we’ve exchanged names for gifts – to be opened Christmas Eve after the evening service. [ changes tense ] I always enjoy that. Aaron and I ended up drawing each other’s names (‘coincidence, surely’) – I found a 5×5 Rubix Cube for him, and tossed in a pink rubber ball to balance out the relative complexity of the cube, while he gave me a new alarm clock. It’s replaced the sour old clock that used to take residence on my window sill, and I am well pleased.

And that’s probably all you need know, if any of that was necessary knowledge to begin with. But, all that being said, a very merry Christmas to you, God bless, and all the rest. ClichÃ©s and all.

1:51 pm
Had a bit of an odd dream last night. My dreams as a whole are very involved and detailed, from having the Carmex in my pocket break open to the arching ceiling/walls of the auditorium. Remembering them is the hard part. :) But in any case, this one circled around an AI that seemed to be making its home in what must have been RHS’s new music hall. Very strange, but the interior design was magnificent.

Interestingly, I can remember the logo for the network that the AI was inhabiting.

9:09 pm
Ethan’s always been great at snowboarding. Or perhaps it shouldn’t formally be called ‘snowboarding’, per sÃ©, as he usually only uses those plastic boards without bindings as his weapon of choice. He was using one earlier today at the Rhody Christmas gathering at Donny’s place. We’d been sledding on the hill that ends in a pond, fairly steep and, as the pond is frozen, without undue danger of drowning.

Anyway, Ethan owned the hill more than once on that little board before discovering that the hill could indeed pwn him. He’s ended up with a compressed skull fracture – if you’re the type, your prayer for him would be grand. He’ll be flown out to Marshfield shortly.

That aside… bah. The sibs are watching Narnia; I’m going to wander off and join them.

Cheers.

wednesday 10:12 am
He’s still in Marshfield, but reportedly doing well. They’ve opted against surgery; guess the trauma incurred wouldn’t be worth it. Given that, he should be released tomorrow.

Moral of the story: wear a helmet. Or at least make sure someone has a camera – I’m told his fall was spectacular.

I’m concerned worried freaking rather nervous about MIT. My application was deferred, like 90% of them, and I’ll find out in March if I’m among the 10% of the deferred that are accepted.

Statistically, the odds are somewhat against me. My test scores generally fit in to the upper-mid-range of the middle 50% accepted (well, excepting my SAT Math Reasoning score, which was abysmal. Oddly, the SAT Subject Math II test score was far better), but they’re nothing stellar against MIT’s norm…

Meh. I just want to find out, one way or another. If I’m in, I’m in, and I’ll be in Massachusetts this time next year. (Actually not; it’ll be Christmas break still.) If I’m not, I’ll either be at Madison, Northwestern College, or Illinois Tech. Or hey – I could always go to Nicolet. :) Though… I truly think that MIT is my best match. (Albeit it’s whether I’m the best match for MIT that matters.) It’s a higher-level technically-inclined school that also puts emphasis on the right half of the brain – creative intellect. Which is what I’m about, and not many schools of MIT’s caliber work hard at achieving that balance.

Geeeahhh. I’m generally able to put aside worry. The promise that ‘all things work together for good for those who love God according to his purpose’ is something that I hold to tightly, and I suppose it applies in my post-secondary education as well… Kinda bothers me that I can’t get myself past worry here in this relatively inconsequential item. I mean, yes, it does matter which college I end up going to, but one way or another, I think I will end up at a decent institution.

But, what happens happens, and the world won’t end come March. Then again, maybe it will, and the whole thing will be moot. You never know.

Washington & Lee has kindly reminded me that “it’s not too late too apply!” Bah. Colleges that spam don’t rank very high on my list. If a college needs to resort to spam to find applicants, then is it really any good?

—

Anyway. The day has come and gone, and just now it’s 9:30 pm. Ethan and Mom are still in Marshfield (though Ethan is likely to be released tomorrow-ish), and mostly everyone else is in the parlor watching Pride and Prejudice. Really an excellent film. Nothing terribly interesting on Facebook… Hm. I think I’m done here.

Enjoy the evening, should you read this yet today. Cheers.

Whilst looking through memberlists, I found an email address at cashette.com. Didn’t ring a bell, but Cashette seems to be a free email service that pays the user for each spam message they receive. The tagline:

Too much spam?
Name Your Price for Spam
You are paid for each “spam” you receive.
If they don’t pay, you won’t receive spam!

Doesn’t seem like a bad deal when you toss in 3gb of storage space. But do people really get paid for spam? A quick look through the testimonials only reveals rave reviews (r-r-r!) for the service itself, nothing about being paid. So – off to the ‘learn more’ section.

And the first thing to learn is that ‘Cashette is a spam-control service.’ Not necessarily email, then? But regardless of that (and the fact that Times New Roman appears randomly), Cashette only lets in email that’s from other Cashette addresses, or from addresses in your addressbook. The rest go through a BoxTrapper-esque process in which the sender must respond to an automatic reply before their message gets through. The result: only Cashette users can really spam you anyway (unless you have spammer friends), and they won’t be the ones spamming. Bah.

I’m registering an account now, just to see what the service is like… Oh, look. A checkbox: ‘I prefer to receive advertising email that pays me.’

Ohhh dear. The next step in the signup process is a demographic profile. Martial status, race, annual income. And the following notice:

To make more money, you need to provide profile information. We do not disclose any of your personal information to any third party. Advertisers only know that they are sending to a demographic group (e.g. age group).

So. They’re actually having spam sent to you intentionally?

Next step is an ad for eBay. But that aside, I’m in. And I have three new messages: a welcome letter from Cashette support, and two spam messages from ‘no-reply@cashette.com’.

Gah. This is a spam farm. ... And an ad farm. Why do people use this? One of the testimonials says that it’s better than Gmail. Because it uses a less intelligent and less flexible spam filter?

I’ve closed my account, even though the fine print amused me.

addendum
I saw an ad on Facebook with a kid that looks a lot like the Spoon Orphan from The Matrix. Also, it looks like the ads from advertising.com are relatively hackable – try clicking on this one.

Back in the day (here meaning 2005), I sort of took (here meaning ‘enrolled in, but did different work than’) a programming class at school. I sort of learned C++ (here meaning ‘took in the syntax and basic usage, but mostly worked with PHP instead’), and wrote a few programs.

The most involved one came to be known as iJournals. It had its origins in a user-management system I was working on and the minor frustrations had with three consecutive home-grown content management systems. And the fact that I wanted to start a journal, but didn’t feel like writing everything on paper in a notebook that I’d probably lose.

Thus, and after bouncing names off of Anthony for a while (remember SuperBucket? yeah, I’m still working on that one…), iJournals was born. Or rather, it slowly coalesced. I had yet to have any formal training in software development process or management (this is back in the day, you’ll recall), so development went along at its own pace and in its own way.

But the concept was fairly straightforward. ‘A simple, secure and uncluttered place to get your thoughts “down on paper”’, says the front page. Like blogging with no one watching, which is admittedly a less-than-common pursuit, but this was for the soul-searchers and diary-writers, not the 9rulers.

It actually was pretty cool. Sure, I didn’t use classes and the functions were very specialized, but I realized a few ideas with potential:

  1. The Clipboard. Almost exactly like pastebin.
  2. Conversations. Almost exactly like Gmail’s rendition.
  3. A templating system. Almost exactly like the untold thousands of other systems out there. ...

What’s frustrating is that I developed these totally oblivious to the more public versions. In addition to that, the iJournals concept is very close to that which LiveJournal is built around. I’m not sure if that proves that I’m a blind visionary or if I’m just clueless, but even though I was unknowingly building a system that was overshadowed from the beginning, I did learn a lot. Lots about database work, scripting, web hosting and the like. Valuable experience, and a few people actually did use the service. Granted, only 26 people, but it was still cool to see people using what I had built.

And, with this, I consign it to obsoletion. I’ve retired it to ikebowen.com/ijournals, should anyone still want to toy with it, but mostly to fondly and nostalgically look back upon. Good times, working in Dachel’s (nÃ© Wollner) lab with fellow geeks (and the mere wannabes).

Quite possibly the strangest night of my life, beginning with my grandparent’s 50th anniversary. This wasn’t so very strange in and of itself, but I did have the chance to play some music with a 92-year-old accordion-player who had been at my grandparent’s wedding. Lucille. She’s since become my favorite person – a white-haired little dynamo with an accordion. Incredible.

Next item of interest – Aaron put a magnet up his nose on the way back home. While this wasn’t as unexpected as it sounds – he’d gotten a bunch of little iron magnet stones from someone earlier and was a bit bored – it was exceedingly strange. We couldn’t get it out for anything (and we did try an stronger floor magnet), so there was nothing for it but a trip to the ER. I mean, honestly. That’s the second time in days.

The third oddity goes right along with the second. The folk in the ER couldn’t find the magnet in the x-rays, so they had me bring the rest of the magnets in as samples to see if the x-ray could even pick them up. Thus, I brought in a handful of magnets to the local ER at 1:15 in the morning. How freaking weird is that?

And then the fourth. I ran over to the Holiday station afterwards to fill up the tank. Couldn’t remember the date; had to ask the attendant. Yes, I have my driver’s license. Bowen? No, I don’t know why that would sound familiar. ... Yeah, Nancy. ... Wait, you’re my second cousin?

Aaannny way. Really a very strange evening. And I swear, if we have to make any more trips to ER before 2007…

random bits
Doctor Seuss is a popular gift item for graduating high school and college students.
Stone versus wood.
Birth order patterns. Worth looking over.
Tuscan Whole Milk, courtesy Amazon. Shamelessly mocked by the world. Ben W and I totally started that (second-oldest; back in the days of the Tenor Revolution).

And for the record, I do hope you don’t dream about that. Or this.

post_title: Time's Person of the Year: You
final_content:
Interestingly, Time has selected ‘you’ as the Person of the Year.

But look at 2006 through a different lens and you’ll see another story, one that isn’t about conflict or great men. It’s a story about community and collaboration on a scale never seen before. It’s about the cosmic compendium of knowledge Wikipedia and the million-channel people’s network YouTube and the online metropolis MySpace. It’s about the many wresting power from the few and helping one another for nothing and how that will not only change the world, but also change the way the world changes.

The conceptual Web 2.0 seems to be the greatest focus in the write-up, which seems interesting. Since Web 2.0 is all about the user base itself, selecting ‘you’ is like turning the camera back on the photographer, citing the camera as the reason.

Lev Grossman did well, though, in acknowledging that the Web 2.0 movement shouldn’t be overly glorified:

Sure, it’s a mistake to romanticize all this any more than is strictly necessary. Web 2.0 harnesses the stupidity of crowds as well as its wisdom. Some of the comments on YouTube make you weep for the future of humanity just for the spelling alone, never mind the obscenity and the naked hatred.

But that’s what makes all this interesting…

read: Time’s Person of the Year: You

via Chip Chick
God’s Debris – download (pdf) – author’s comments

From PostSecret – thanks, Meg.

Today was fairly normal. Morning (‘no, it can not be 6:15…’ ‘is it really 6:35?’), afternoon (hm… can I get more food for the price by ordering two small burgers and a medium curly fry at Hardees, or just something from Subway? and I dearly hope that the essay isn’t due next hour…), and evening (I’ll hide under the bed, shall I?). Turns out that Monday was an office holiday (stock market thing) in remembrance of Ford’s death (‘our Ford’), and no one really told me. Which explains why I was one of three people at work on Monday, but what have you.

In unrelated news, I’ve found a perfectly wonderful set of Monty Python skits on Google Video. They’ve subsequently found a home on my Zune.

Today’s inbox report: Linell regarding the wildly successful and brilliantly designed ‘sports shorts’ that we worked on, eBay/PayPal about a copy of God’s Debris (have I recommended it yet?), spam from Loyola U, a disk usage warning for ikebowen.com, and… yeah, that’s about it. Oh, a message from aJ.

And now for several other unrelated items:

Pay a visit to the South Australia Dept. of Health and search for “rights of private practice”. Just do it.

ThinkGeek knows: no one should be without at least five hidden jacket pockets and a conduit for stringing your headphones. Or a snowbot.

And that’s all, sorry.

But mostly just tired. I made a list of must-do-tonight items on the whiteboard, and was pleased to find all of them checked off by 9:30. Except study for the history exam, of course, so I spent the next three hours (carefully) throwing together a promo clip for Winter Formal:

Lovely-ish. I was using Windows Movie Maker, for lack of anything better, and it kept throwing “out of memory” errors. Which is silly, because it wasn’t anywhere near that point, but that still prevented me from exporting the clip as one… chunk. Segment. Had to do it in three pieces and put them together again… Meh. Ah well. “Corpse self-nominations”. The explosion seen is actually from How Not To Be Seen.

There’s a shipment of 72 cobalt mugs with the group logo on them coming in to the office on Wednesday. That’s a lot of mugs.

You know, this week really did seem… long. Drawn out. Oddly, since it was a short week. Wednesday-Thursday-Friday. Kitze scheduled a Friday test on Wednesday, then said on Thursday that “the test [was] tomorrow”. Which confused me, because I didn’t think that Friday came next.

It did, and is now nearly over. I think we’re watching LoTR III tonight.

I’m having a recurring vision of a long weekend with no ties to anyone else. Just time and time to spare, with a fireplace, a good book or two… wireless broadband… [ grins ] And so life goes on.

Happy Friday.

Google is flexing their muscles. And it looks goood. $10 off a $10-min purchase? This after their $10 off of $30 and $20 off of $50 deals from earlier. They can afford it, evidently, and these veritable free money offers are guaranteed to draw users to their Checkout service. There was some speculation when the service was released as to whether it would have any success, given PayPal’s market share.

But this… this is ridiculous. It’s great for the consumer at the moment, yes, but it bothers me. It bothers me that Google is amassing the largest search db in existence. It bothers me that they can therefore monitor the collective mood of humanity so closely, especially now that users use Google to communicate and plan their own lives. It bothers me that they’ve acquired nearly 30 other companies, and that they’re now collecting financial data and using free money as the lure.

There are conspiracy theories in abundance, of course. Tis the same with any growing power.

Gar.

Second credit card offer of all time. To begin with, the letter is written in a typewriter font, as if Carole M. Vaughn had taken the time to sit down at the one typewriter that CapitalOne kept during the upgrades and write to me with this offer. It’s cool, though, that I could get the card “with just a few clicks of [my] mouse or a phone call”. Though, if the card is so easy to get that anyone can get it that easily, is it really that great?

Though Carole’s sincerity is apparent – “because we want you to enjoy using your card, we’re offering 16 different card designs”, including Tropical Sunset (12) and Dolphin Sunrise (23).

To the circular file it goes.

Also in the mail – a letter from the bank with my debit PIN. Cool. Now I just need the actual card.

Email: PayPal telling me that the payment for God’s Debris went through (when will it ship?), eBay with some offer for sellers, Student Council announcement, Anthony, the guys at RSP (who waffle between professional and affable), Rob about the sermon library, and the invoice from Branders about those 72 mugs we ordered.

Classiest spam: “We accepted your loan request” from “crackdown begins”, and the following debt-elimination offer:

From: MARGIE
To: TERRY <>
Date: 08-Jan-2007 16:08
Subject: Dora Eliminate all that you owe not even mailing an other dime

Eliminate all that you owe not even mailing an other dime. Eliminate the awkward phone calls. End the payments!

Wild as it may seem virtually all lendors committing fraud. Amazing but correct!

If it isn’t I’ll have to stand it, that’s all. I will explain

Tastes differ, murmured the dragonette, slowly drooping its scaley eyelids over its yellow eyes, until they looked like half-moons. Perhaps you know that your fellow-creatures are more or less hypocritical

Remember – you too have a lot to acquire. And you can keep the dime. My theory on those intelligently-random-looking blocks of text is that they are indeed randomly selected sentences from the internet. The first bit’s from Dorothy & Co. and the line about fellow-creatures is from something else, should you wish to know.

Anyway, enjoy your evening, and may your mail be more interesting than mine.

The walls start breathing
My mind’s unweaving
Maybe itâ€™s best you leave me alone.

I’m looking through the product shots from Macworld and have yet to see the iPhone do anything remotely telephone-like. Pictures, yes. Video, yes, and in stunning quality. But can you make a phone call?

I’ve found another way to classify people. There are those who have legitimate problems to deal with, those that do not but create issues to fill the void, and those that have none and lead blissfully happy existences. Of the legitimate-problem-havers, some just deal with them and keep moving without saying much while others are constantly trying to find a shoulder to cry on. This latter group is sometimes suspect of creating the problems in the first place, consciously or no.

Though it’s all point of view, I suppose. This came to mind when I realized that a good number of my closer friends have a lot to deal with, and few of them, if any, make a big deal of it. That’s usually not a bad trait. I rather think I’m in the final group mentioned above. There are different degrees of everything, but… hm. Yes.

So. Moral of the story – ignorance is bliss.

I saw Beau at RHS this evening. Good to see him in public again.

Apple products do not appeal to me. They just don’t. Yes, they’re brilliantly designed. Yes, they “just work”. Yes, the design is beautiful. But – they are branded. They scream suave coolness. Can a product be self-righteous? More power to Jobs for raising the bar and all, but… meh. I detest overt branding. Maybe that’s all.

Ha – the Apple TV (thank you for not calling it iTV) includes the Ken Burns effect.

I feel dissatisfaction developing with this site’s design.

Wonder when Ferdy is going to release PIMB. It’s cool concept – hard to believe that no one’s really done anything like it yet. I had wanted to create a blogging bot with it; send a message to the bot and it gets posted somewhere, XML feed maybe, and I actually asked Ferdy about the product with this in mind. My bad. He implemented it in the demo video… meh. If you have an idea, don’t tell anyone until you have time to do something about it.

GAH! One of my crabs just molted! And one is scaling the tank cover!

addendum
Looks like they’re all okay though. Giovanni’s still clinging to the cover near the light and Baccus is quarantined until his exoskeleton hardens, but there you are.

Anthony moved (...) – hook.freetxp.com now.
