So I realize that advertising services filter out phony clicks. But what about bad referrals?

For example: I was looking at an article on wsj.com, and saw the plug for Toshiba (sponsor of the reprint/email thing – hooray!). The plug is served by Doubleclick.net with the following url:

http://ad.doubleclick.net/clk;15359958;6853491;c?http://copiers.toshiba.com/index.shtml

As expected, the url on the end sets the redirect and can be replaced with anything (like this). So – if someone were to switch that url to something else and somehow pull off a lot of legitimate clicks, would it entirely screw up the marketing stats?

nine forty seven, post meridiem
Just sent in an application for a substantial honors program at Northwestern College. Two essay questions, a “scholarly essay” and another scholarly work. I sent in a recording of Song from Heaven… It’s a bit old, and it’s not really a scholarly work. Per se. Which has no accent, I’ve realized, being Latin.

Would have loved to put in Calah’s song… the story one. “I’m going to tell you a story / the tale of a boy who walked along the ocean.” Beautiful work, that was.

So – application done. I have a bit more Classical World work to do, but I can fit that in tomorrow sometime. Turns out those two packets for Calc aren’t due until next Wednesday (blast), so… the Decathlon speech. Needs to be re-worked. … Tomorrow. I really hope it turns out well. I’ll post it here for (both of) you to read. Because I know you want to.

Anyway, enjoy the evening. Minimum wage is up, and we all know (or Nelson does, anyway) that that leads to unimployment. Well done, Congress.

Though not really “war”, but the regional Decathlon competition. I dearly want to make it to state, but…

The Rhinelander team’s decent, though lacking the sheer brilliance that we seemed to have on and off last year. (Geeah, I miss last year…) Megan’s opted to do her speech on something “I Love Lucy”-related (again), which should go over well. She ended up with 975 at State last year and was ridiculously proud. *is ridiculously proud.

So… the sketches on the right are from class when class got long. I think that’s a bean wearing a hat.

Mm. I have homework for next hour, but I need to pick up lunch at 11:30 for the office. Meh. I should be able to cram it all in, as usual.

Dave wanted trays to put the new-and-shiny group mugs on. Turns out that serving trays are a seasonal item, so we’re making do with raised cooling racks (the metal grid kind) with a non-slip mat over the top. Looks tolerably classy.

I stand by this: the office would make a great hidden-camera drama. And no more shall I say.

Off to pick up lunch…

post_title: The Last Days (as they concern Academic Decathlon)
final_content:
I like the Ad Council. Good guys.

Also, Paul van Dyk was also born on Dec16. How cool is that?

The caravan left school a bit after 3:30 on Friday, heading for Stevens Point and a hotel that wasn’t bad but had a set of mounting holes screwed into the wall two feet above the flat-screen TV in the lobby. They also have cheap extra toothbrushes, but I think that’s the way it is in hotels as a rule.

So, we crammed Chinese history and whatnot until after midnight, but perhaps the speeches had the most work. For some reason, the team largely neglected the speechwork until the last week or so before competition. :)

For those of you unfamiliar with Academic Decathlon, it’s an academic decathlon competition (ha!) with the following events: language & literature, art, music, social science, economics, mathematics, science, essay, interview, and speech (thank you, Wikipedia, because I would not have remembered them all). The science portion isn’t added until State, I believe, along with #11: Super Quiz. Besides local/regional/state/national competition, individuals compete at three levels, depending on their GPA: varsity/scholastic/honors (in ascending order). That aside, though, we study the topic at hand (“China” is incredibly broad, I’ll have you know) madly, then take tests (and interview and give speeches) madly, and then hope madly that we knew our stuff well enough.

Which we more or less did. The Rhinelander team placed fourth at the Stevens Point regional competition, which really isn’t bad. The difference between our score and the first place score was much less than last year (where we also placed fourth).

Wonder of wonders, I came away with a few ribbons. The ribbons are awarded on a per-something. per rank?-basis, meaning that the top three individual scores in the scholastic division on the music test are awarded. Et cetera. The music test was ironically one that I did not get a decent score on, nor the math test. The math test was abysmal, and I think that was across the board this year. I’m most proud of the speech ribbon, actually; I’ll post my speech tomorrow. I think it’s mostly because I’m competing at the scholastic division that I got the top-scorer award (also awarded per-something).

Rhinelander’s known for fanatical team spirit. I’m usually an exception to that, but the Decathlon teammates are really very close. When Amy got an art award, and one of the Abrams (they’re twins…) ended up with a math ribbon (surprise there), we cheered. Loudly, I suppose; the other teams were fairly quiet about it. Marathon apparently thought we were trying to beat them in volume, but we were just happy. :)

I’m praying we go on to State… The Madison competition is always such a blast. Kind of iffy this year, though, like it was last year. The first place team at each regional competition (there are five) automatically goes on, and then the top three or four teams per school division. Plus three wildcard teams, and I think we have a chance at a wildcard spot. We pulled one off last year, and… hm. Time will tell, along with my MIT application.

Ha. I love Decathlon. Dylan and I were walking past a group of hotel rooms, and someone started exiting what I thought was the Abrams’ door. I turned and raised my arms in preparation to… idk, attack or something, but it wasn’t an Abrams. It was, in fact, a guy from a completely different team (several teams used that hotel) without a shirt. With my arms raised, we regarded each other passively for a moment. I turned and continued walking down the hall, and Dylan started cracking up. No words were said, no reactions. Completely ridiculous. [ grins ]

To the RHS Decathletes: well done. Well freaking done, and I love you all. You too, Goldsworthy.

In The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy, the ultimate answer is sought to the ultimate question: the great Question of Life, the Universe, and Everything. The answer was discovered to be forty-two, which understandably surprised those who sought it out. Whether or not it was correct, the answer was in effect worthless because it could not be understood – there was no apparent reason for The Answer to be forty-two.

Connecting this to reality – there are scores of religions and beliefsets that claim to have The Answer. However, if I were to meet someone who claimed to be of a certain religion, and they presented their beliefs but could not give a reason to back them up, their belief would be more or less worthless, whether it was correct or no. If I met someone else who believed differently but could defend their beliefs, theirs would be automatically worth more because they could be defended.

What if I told you that we do not have free will, and that God destroyed himself? How would you react? If I could not defend these statements, they’d be utterly ridiculous and most would reject them out of hand. But what if I could?

Let me first examine the dimensional universe. The first dimension is a line, the second is a plane and the addition of the third results in the 3D space that we humans move through. Because we exist and are defined, all other points in the first three dimensions must also exist and likewise be defined. To illustrate this, because you exist, it can be known precisely what there is forty-five meters to your left. Now, let me bring in the fourth dimension, largely considered to be time. Because we exist at a point in time, it follows that all other points must also exist and be defined. If all points in time are defined and set, there is no room for deviation. If deviation is impossible, then we do not have free will.

Perhaps God is a more interesting subject, with many more viewpoints and also several wars. I’m going to begin with several commonly held assumptions: that God exists, God is infinite in both power and knowledge, and for the sake of convenience, that God is male. What would motivate such a god to act? What could possibly motivate a being that could do anything, already would know the results of doing everything, and because he has power over time it’s as if everything is already done? Only an action with an unknown result could possibly hold any interest. If the only unknown for an omniscient god is his own non-existence, then the only action with motivation would be his own self-destruction.

Now let me bring humanity into the picture. Humanity exists. This is widely accepted, with the exception of some post-structuralists and perhaps Michael Dummett. With our assumptions concerning God, humanity’s existence is proof that God acted at one point in such a way that humanity came about as a result. Given this and our conclusion concerning God, the connection is plain: God destroyed himself, and we are what remains. God destroyed himself, and we are his debris.

My purpose in all of this is not to invalidate religion, nor to question justice on the basis of free will. My purpose is simply to drive home my original point: for a belief to have merit, there must be reasons behind it. Had I presented my arguments without defense, they, like forty-two, would be entirely worthless.

To close: no matter what I believe, or what you believe, no matter who, if anyone, is correct, belief must be founded with a reason.

If you believe, know why.

fairly late afterthought (2008-10-02)
The following disclaimer will go on and attempt to ensure that you don’t draw any conclusions regarding yours truly. Ignore most/all of that. Thoughts on the subject have evolved somewhat in the last nine months, and not all of the below applies.

rather large disclaimer (2008-01-16)
This speech was fairly interesting in its evolution. The seeds, perhaps, were planted in my reading of God’s Debris (have I mentioned it yet?) which I actually have yet to finish. My first thought was to write a speech on the future, quickly dismissed as far too broad for 3.5 minutes. I next considered writing a speech disproving the existence of God.

If you know me, and it’s likely you do if you’re reading this, you know that I am a Christian. I dislike the word ‘religion’ as it refers to humanity’s interpretation of God, whereas I try to focus on God’s interaction with humanity. This is an entirely separate subject, so I’ll leave it there for now.

Anyway, the speech disproving God’s existence would have been an experiment, mostly to see if I could competently write such a thing and keep all personal bias out of the picture. I started writing this one, actually, working in a smaller thought experiment concerning the dimensional universe and how it relates to free will. I made a loose connection between the logical impossibility of free will and God’s existence, and somewhere in the process the speech topic changed to what it is now: the necessity of purpose and reason in and behind belief.

I wholeheartedly agree with the speech’s thesis, but completely disagree with both of the examples presented: the non-existence of free will and God’s self-destruction. Therein lies the experiment that I started with – the removal of bias. I think I pulled if off. The free will reasoning is my own (though others have probably come up with it as well; I haven’t looked), but the self-destruction of God came straight out of God’s Debris. (Marvelous book, by the way.)

I wore a shirt under my suit during the speech, emblazoned with “The Answer is 42”.

And there you are.

1. The woodstove blew up.
  2. The water drain in the basement is, by all evidences, backed up.
  3. We have the replacement part for the gas furnace, but not a clue as to how it’s supposed to be wired. The furnace works. But somehow we have no fuel.
  4. The front door, which has never really had problems, will not latch properly.
  5. There’s a leak in the basement hot water line somewhere in the basement walls. We had to shut it off. It’s on the same water circuit as the kitchen and adjacent bathroom, so we have no hot water.
  6. I have the box that’s used to record the sermons at church, where we are not, so Rob gets to rip the audio off of an analog tape.

So everything’s more or less sorted out now. Photos, anyone?

And life goes on. [ grins ]

This scene can be found in a dark and unfrequented corner of the Rhinelander UW facility. While nearly everything has been completely remodeled and revamped, this ecosystem has been left alone to its own questionable devices.

While the prospect of fixing the area up is daunting, it made an excellent grunge set.

Tulane and Northern Arizona
Both schools sent me messages today (which is now yesterday), stating something to the effect of “we were expecting to see an application from you before today but didn’t… so we’re extending the deadline and waiving the application fee.”

Nothing says top-caliber school like this does.

Seeing that the messages looked so very similar, and came on the same day, I checked the source of the messages to see where they actually came from. They were both mailed from app-info.net, which is a domain owned by the guys at Royall & Company. Marketing specialists for colleges, looks like. They’ve done a decent job, I suppose. It surprises me that colleges using their system have to buy a separate domain name to use with their services (Tulane uses tulaneinfo.org instead of tulane.edu, etc)... Although, perhaps that’s just the domain of the mailer. tulaneinfo.org and northernarizonau.org both have precisely the same content, but they point the user toward the .edu domain… ah well. Hooray for marketers.

Classical World Lit
I missed senior excemption by 35.01 points. That’s all. ... Though I should do decently on the exam, only an in-class essay…

[ thinks ]

[ flag-R -> “calc” ]

Blast. Even with a perfect score, I can’t boost the grade up to an A- with the essay. Had I talked more in class… gah gah gah gah. Gah. Though I won’t lower the grade as long as I get at least a C on the paper. No problems there, anyway.

That really really bothers me. I’ll be sending three B+‘s, one B and a B- in to MIT. Unremarkable. Though they’re all in AP/weighted classes, and I’ll have my work credits in there… bah.

Caffeine Intake
Second triple-shot coffee this week. Can’t be good…

Decathlon
We’ve been studying the Super Quiz material since Regionals. The subject’s climatology, which is… going to be difficult. Given its less-than-entirely-objective nature (e.g. “and this is what we’ve observed over the last 50 years, and most have concluded this about it, but this conclusion is debated and the observation period really isn’t long enough to come up with anything concrete anyway”; to put this in perspective, previous subjects have included The Ancient World, Lewis/Clark, the brain…), I rather expect it to be difficult to keep straight. Interesting material, though. We’ve decided to create a candy called the Millibar, advertised by emo actors, with the tagline “It’s Destructively Delicious!”.

I think that’s all for today. Oh, wait. It’s “inspiring”?

Finals are tomorrow. Or finish tomorrow, I suppose; the calc final was today. Ran out of time on that one, too; I misread a problem, worked futilely for fifteen minutes, re-read it and again misinterpreted it, and… yeah, I’ve been fairly upset with myself as of late.

So here I sit, trying to concentrate on the early history of the grand USA. I’ve gone through two different visual themes and nearly ended up with a new icon set, but opted to just keep the Vista cursors (look a lot like Ubuntu) and LClock. Good enough.

Few new links posted; of considerable worth is Vladstudio and in particular their flying tree image. Beautiful. Reminds me a bit of Feel Good Inc..

In other news… Madison sent me a gentle reminder to get my housing deposit in by Feb1. I hate waiting for important things. Little things I can handle (when will that photography backdrop arrive?). College admissions…

I’m wandering around Facebook. More or less have ditched Myspace.

Katie wants me to join Show Choir again. Show Choir. ... I’m unsure. I loved it while I was in it, to be sure. It would be different, joining now, than it was with P around… Wonder if I’d [ end of thought ]

fifteen minutes later
My computer crashed while syncing the Zune. Odd. I wouldn’t have minded so much, except I hadn’t saved this entry… But Firefox brought it back. Wonderful. :) [ saves ]

Wasn’t bad. I may revisit it eventually.

afterthought
Is it worth telling someone something if you know they’re going dismiss it?
