Term 2 is over. No longer shall I be graded for my knowledge (or the lack thereof) of America’s early history, for classical literature, or for… actually, I still have two more sections of Calc left. Never mind.

Up next: Econ, Calc (b), Spanish 5 (a). I’ll miss watching Jordan H drive Kitze up the wall.

More links… maybe I should add a directory.

Just tried to find a pen; ended up with a mini Bop It instead. Nearly as good.

I’ve been fairly meh as of late… Hopefully that’ll wear off with the weekend; I’m guessing it’s just finals week. And relative illness. My sinuses have been out for a week.

Before you tell yourself it’s just another scene / remember it’s just different from what you’ve seen

3:44pm
Mi boss already seems to have picked up the newsletters from the printer. Odd. He must have been overly excited about the second consecutive record turnaround.

My life looped yesterday. Or Wednesday, one of the two. Dropped off the siblings and was driving past Acacia Lane Dental when Endless showed up on the playlist. Precisely the same event in the same location occurred the following day.

Also: I finished God’s Debris before Classical World today. It nearly concludes with an outline of the levels of consciousness, but then tacks on a bit more plot development. Evidently delivery guys (and garbagemen, probably) are more enlightened than the rest of us.

Really… really a very thought-provoking book. As in, it will provoke your thought. (And spook the monks, come to think of it, like the Mongols did in 1006AD.) Do your neocortex a favor and read the thing.

[ end plug ]

What a cool thing – to find something that you’re not aware of ever being aware of before. Things like that are rare.

Though I suppose, operating under that definition, what I’ve found is not really a discovery. More of a finding. I made a list back in the day (here meaning 1.5 months ago) of things that I wanted to, in the future, muse upon. I present them here mostly so I have a remaining record of them for when I lose the tree/ink copy.

  • Indisputable fact doesn’t (shouldn’t?) scare: it is the possibility that scares us
  • did God create time? His existence is logically beyond the fourth dimension, and the existence of a body in the x dimension mandates the existence of all dimensions lesser than x...
  • what does “to live” mean?
  • immanency

Not entirely where the last two would go, actually. I’m guessing I was thinking of more than a heartbeat with the definition of live (v), and for immanency… not sure. Hm.

What have you discovered as of late?

addendum
Not like anyone wasn’t expecting to… become aware of this, but Hillary is officially running for the presidency. Hm. Watch the intro vid. (Irahq, not Iraq. Refreshing.) She’s planning video chats “starting Monday”. I wonder where this will go…

(lyrics)

I suppose this is a fairly ridiculous song for its genre; can’t think of any others that have such a topic. But gah I love sleep. Took a three hour nap earlier today and, oddly, dreamed that I was stuck in town at night in the winter. Couldn’t think clearly, even in a dream, so after concluding that it was too far and too cold to walk home, I set off the proximity alarm at someone’s house and asked to use their phone. No one at home; left a message. No one ever got the message.

At which point I dreamed I woke up (hate that).

random photos

If you haven’t touched the preloaded video on your Zune, you’ll note that there are two categories in the video section: “All Videos” and “Music Videos”. This is all well and good, but what if you want to add music video from your own library to the appropriate category? It’s surprising to me that the Zune software doesn’t make this easier, but there really is no simple way to do this. Microsoft does give you a hint in kb article 929005, but falls short of actually telling you what to do.

Fortunately, there is a solution that will suffice until MS adds this as a feature. The following assumes that your videos are all wmv’s already; scroll further down if they’re not.

download this
WM Attributes Editor (I use the English version, myself.)

  1. Unzip the editor somewhere, making sure to keep the manifest file alongside the executable.
  2. Important: close the Zune software and anything else that might be using the files in question.
  3. Run WMAttributeEditor.exe
  4. File -> Open Files
    1. Select all wmv files (hold shift) that belong in x category/genre (e.g. your music videos); hit Open.
  5. Tools -> Mass altering (which sounds weird, but isn’t)
  6. See the “Name” selector? Find “WM/MediaClassPrimaryID”.
    1. Further down, there’s a selector called “Special”. Select “Video”.
    2. Click on the “Add” button.
  7. Back up to “Name” – select “WM/MediaClassSecondaryID”
    1. “Special” = [appropriate genre – only feature-length movies, music videos and TV shows are supported for now]
    2. Click “Add”.
  8. Lower-right corner of the window: click “Commit changes”.

And that, hopefully, should do it. Sync your Zune again and you should see additional categories in the video section with your video collection satisfactorily sorted. If not, you’re more or less on your own – post here or over at ZuneMAX if you’re having issues.

All of this aside, there’s obviously more than just the two media classes that can be set. However, not all metadata entries will transfer over to the Zune device at the moment, as noted on the Zune website:

In the initial release of Zune, WM/Year, Author, and WM/Genre metadata does not transfer to the Zune device. This will be addressed in future updates.

If your video collection is in any format other than wmv, all is not lost. If you already use Zune to manage your collection, try this:

  1. Apply the storage hack.
  2. With the Zune software open and your device connected, open up My Computer.
  3. Look for your Zune device somewhere in the list – should have a telling icon of some kind.
  4. Open ‘er up -> Storage -> Video
  5. You’ll see your video collection here in wmv format. Copy it back to your hard drive and replace your existing files with these. I’d keep a backup somewhere, just in case.
  6. Follow the steps from earlier, and you should be set.

If not, and you really don’t want to use Zune to convert the files (can’t really fathom why, but it’s possible), you might try the WM Encoder from MS.

Cheers –

addendum
Looks like someone did eventually write a program for this purpose – well done, dLICI0US.

A girl was babysitting at a children’s birthday party. The parents were out. She went down to the den and noticed a statue in the corner – a full-size sculpture, probably five foot ten, dressed as a clown. “Expensive.” It actually looked a bit unnerving (“Why would you have a clown statue in the basement den?”), so she called the kid’s parents.

“Would you mind if I moved the clown statue into the storage room for the night?”

“... We don’t have a clown statue.”

“...”

“!!!”

Turns out that it was an actual person (evidently frozen in shock upon seeing the sitter) who had been living in the storage area of the basement, coming out during the day when the house’s occupants were out. When the kids said earlier that they were “playing with the clown”, the parents more or less assumed that they had an imaginary clown or perhaps a toy that someone brought.

Not an actual clown.

——

I have no idea who this was, or where, or when. Any resemblance between this description and an actual event is, for all practical purposes, purely coincidental.

addendum
This was also odd: a phone thief repents after 21 text messages.

post_title: Cars, and what may be derived from them
final_content:
Roughly 1:15. I have less than twenty minutes to get to Walmart, find my three-ring binder of choice (and food) and get back to school.

I’m in the left lane of Lincoln street behind a dark magenta four-door. Looked too budget-class to be considered a sports car or anything. There’s a car next to me in the right-hand lane – it’s a rich magenta (there’s a difference) sports car with curves.

My dilemma is of course this: which car should I stay behind to get to Walmart with the greatest speed?

First thought: The sports car is probably going to be faster. Second thought: It’s not. Observations: The four-door ahead of me is screaming female assertiveness suppressed by socio-demographic factors! while the one on my right is in all likelihood driven by an upper-class blonde – the car looks flashy (and is nearly pink and has curves), the driver is probably concerned about how it looks, the driver is probably both female and looks at things very much from her own point of view which doesn’t seem to be practical efficiency. Ergo, she’s less likely to innately want to go faster than the married college-grad ahead of me.

Which seemed to be the case, until the rich magenta sports car decided half a mile ahead to speed up by 5-7mph. My guess is that the driver realized she was being beaten by a four-door. Should have seen that coming.

in the mail

  • A mailing from BMG Music, doing business as Sound and Spirit to lure in those with a preference for Christian music. Gmail thought it was spam.
  • Several FreeTXP exchanges.
  • An exchange with Paula Gainey (nÃ© Darmsteader) – an inhabitant of Buffalo, NY. Pleasant surprise.
  • An envelope from CapitalOne (another one), encased in a larger envelope with a tear-strip opening. Why it merited the extra security is beyond me; the contents are exactly the same as the last one, only with stickers of the different credit card designs instead of a mere pamphlet.

mostly unrelated Monty Python short

Matt H invited me to the Facebook group.

Reactions:

  1. He’s using YouTube. That’s taking it a step up (or down) from Hillary in playing to the masses
  2. 0:24 Convincing convinced US citizen. Female. Caucasian.
  3. 0:34 Appeal to hope. Male. Hispanic.
  4. 0:48 Sense of humor shown.
  5. 0:50 Parents divorced – the pity here could be dangerous…
  6. 0:56 Same thing with the father dying. Hmmm.
  7. 1:05 Looks like it was safely turned around to a diverse background thing. Indonesia -> USA...
  8. 1:12 Self-made man. Good and American.
  9. 1:18 Community involvement – well-rounded interests.
  10. 1:25 A recent-looking picture of him posed in a classroom. Sepia. For effect?
  11. 1:40 Power of the ordinary people working together. Reasonable appeal… Predictable, though.
  12. 2:15 Though I like where this is going with the “local-level wasn’t big enough” concept. Teaching background is also good.
  13. 2:25 Family/Religious appeal
  14. 2:30 Awww….
  15. 2:50 List of achievements. Objective – good.
  16. 3:11 Oh, look. He opposed the war in Irahq. Hindsight, as they say… not a bad point, though.
  17. 3:30 “Democrats from all over Illinois…” This after “there is no Liberal, no Conservative America…”
  18. 3:57 Appropriate musical crescendo with rousing applause.
  19. 4:30-ish Shots that are obviously staged are fairly meaningless. Even if it is on a farm.
  20. 4:42 “... he’s brought Democrats and Republicans together for the common good.” Sorry, Indies.
  21. 4:52 An attack on the pundits. [ laughs ]
  22. 5:40 Ends with the campaign url.

Not bad. Still an emotional appeal, but then, that’s what works for most of America.

The biggest parallel I’m seeing between this and Hillary’s schpeech is a cross-party appeal. Or an attempt at one, anyway. Referring to “us all”, rather than a specific party. Never mind that a lot of Barack’s footage was from his Dem campaign; he was in a partisan senate, after all.

Hm. I’ll be interested (along with maybe 60% of America – we really do suck compared to the rest of the world) to see how this develops.

addendum extrarius

  • My camera came (back)! Hooray!
  • Come now, who doesn’t need AA batteries with USB chargers built in? Or a DIY blood test?
  • Why does this look so much like a religious experience? :D

It’s kind of a dangerous thing. American Idol. (As an aside, I’m looking at the Idol website just now… There’s a McDonalds ad on the side, one of the ‘dollar menunaire’ ones. “The Dollar Menunaire doesn’t pay for music. [ character winks ] She ‘shares’ it.” … What? McDonalds, have you sunken this low?) Jewel’s guest judging for this round, and had this to say in a Newsweek Q&A:

What’s it like judging “Idol”?
It really is heartbreaking, seeing those kids walk out of there dejected.

But there were so many terrible performers.
I thought a lot of the contestants were going to know they sucked and do it as a joke. I was shocked at the seriousness of them. They really, really believed they were going to win. The difference between the twoâ€”what they are, what they think they areâ€”is so great, there’s no way to bridge it. All of a sudden you’re shattering somebody’s perception of themselves.

Newsweek stated earlier that “31% of teenagers believe they will be famous when they grow up”. I mean, honestly. I completely believe that figure – the quest for fame seems to be a trademark of my generation.

For all that we may be the internet generation (or GenY, for that matter), it seems that having so many points of view presented has rather made it more difficult to assume a wide/broad point of view. Humans are inherently one-sided in their approaches, and as increased exposure to other ‘sides’ makes judgments more relative, I’m seeing people actually be less inclined toward seriously considering other points of view – instead, holding on more tightly to their own for fear that it may become moot.

Maybe that’s why some Idol contestants seem to be so deluded. Perhaps. I’m kind of talking about two different ideas here and making vague connections between the two, but I do think the connection is there. Isolated as we are in a global network, we’re clinging to the remains of our self-perception in the hope that we’re still worth something.

spirit cry for this generation (generation)
we’re chasing the wind trying to embrace it
open our eyes to all the lies that we try to justify when deep down inside
all we want to find is someone that loves us all of the time and it’s you

I can honestly say that this is the first somewhat clever phishing attempt I have ever seen. I mean, yeah, the sender had the capitalization problems that every spammer seems to have, but all things considered this wasn’t bad.

Dear Credit Union Member,
CONGRATULATIONS!
You have been chosen by the Credit Union online department to take part in our quick and easy 5 question survey. In return we will credit $50 to your account – Just for your time! Helping us better understand how our customers feel benefits everyone.

With the information collected we can decide to direct a number of changes to improve and expand our online services.

We kindly ask you to spare two minutes of your time in taking part with this unique offer!

SERVICE: Credit Union OnlineÂ® $50 Reward Survey

Confirm Now your $50 Reward Survey with Credit UnionÂ® Reward services.

The information you provide us is all non-sensitive and anonymous
No part of it is handed down to any third party groups. It will be stored in our secure database for maximum of 3 days while we process the results of this nationwide survey. Please do not reply to this message. For any inquiries, contact Customer Service. Document Reference: (GX4937FJJAH242XI3).

Â©2006 Credit Union National Association, Inc.

Gmail didn’t think this was a phishing attempt, nor did Firefox think anything odd about a URL with an octet-encoded IP. (It does now.)

The headers on the email revealed that the message had a Comcast-based ID and I’m fairly sure that it also had a User-Agent/X-Mailer set to Thunderbird (can’t find that now, oddly).

Anyway, the phish page. It’s been taken down now (ha), but it was a survey form with the CUNA template around it (official/valid links and all). The questions were fairly normal (“How satisfied are you with your credit union?”), the only oddity being that they were multiple-select boxes instead of the usual radio button or drop-down thinger. The important stuff was at the bottom of the page (“important stuff” here means inputs for full name, email, credit card number, cc verification number, account PIN and ATM access code). The fool. The promised reward was 50USD credited to your credit card using the requested information, as if you need the ATM code for that.

The URL looked like this: http://0xd8.0xef.0x10.0x90/cuna/cuna.php?process=sign-up. This wouldn’t be terribly strange, had CUNA been using a cPanel server (missing a tilde in the address, though). A visit to the webroot returned a default congrats-you’ve-installed-the-server-correctly page (at that time; it’s now – oddly – a security cam page), meaning that the phisher in question was probably running this on his home box with PHPTriad (a now-defunct AMP stack). I tried screwing around with the scripts he was using (4111-1111-1111-1111 is a valid – bogus – VISA number) and the server itself, but didn’t get very far… He wasn’t an idiot, evidently.

“The information you provide us is all non-sensitive and anonymous”. [ grins ]

Before we begin:

Also: Monty Python – Flying.

So – my camera returned to me. Or was replaced, I suppose, but tis nearly the same thing. I’m very pleased about that, so I shall subject you to ten of the roughly two hundred photos I’ve taken since last Wednesday.

$songset = array(
"When You Were Young (The Killers)" => "Ben Murphy",
"Such Great Heights (The Postal Service" => "Sam Brown",
"The Scientist (Coldplay)" => "Anthony Hook" );

foreach ( $songset as $foo1 => $foo2 ) {
echo( "I shall forever associate {$foo1} with {$foo2}. Or vice versa.n" );
}

I did not know you could hate a tab, but I despise Tab 5. … And it looks at me, like…
Pam Bishop

[09:31] Anthony: I wish I could use PayPal on the energy drink machine.
[09:31] Anthony: or even Google Checkout’s free $10

How do you spell ‘revalent’? I can’t find it on dictionary.com
Sister Bowen

What follows more or less serves to describe the current feel of the day (expressed in a hex color code as #464853). Me, yeah, but also that of the people I’ve seen and interacted with. Not as a whole, perhaps, but what I’ve noticed. Somewhat media-heavy for a single entry, yes, but media’s like that.

From what I’m told, the points at which one simply breaks down and cries alone do not cease with adulthood.

It was me on that road / But you couldn’t see me
Too many lights out, but nowhere near here

It was me on that road / Still you couldn’t see me
And then flashlights and explosions

Roads are getting nearer / We cover distance but not together
I am the storm and I am the wonder / And the flashlights, nightmares
And sudden explosions

I don’t know what more to ask for
I was given just one wish

It’s about you and the sun / A morning run
The story of my maker / What have I and what I ache for

I’ve got a golden ear / I cut and I spear
And what else is there
Roads are getting nearer / We cover distance still not together

If I am the storm if I am the wonder
Will I have flashlights, nightmares / And sudden explosions

There is no room where I can go and / You’ve got secrets too

I don`t know what more to ask for / I was given just one wish

RÃ¶yksopp

And I know I’ve been posting a lot of media lately, but one last song with which to close the day:

I downloaded the DVD image of SuSE in the hope that I’d be able to mount it and install it using Microsoft’s Virtual PC toy. … It takes a long time to download 3gb (here), and it was something of a disappointment to find that the download manager messed it up somehow upon completion. Ah well.

For the 1.68% of you who have your video card set to 800×600, get a bigger monitor. Widescreen’s nice.

post_title: "Bush says he didn't intend to insult Democrats"
final_content:
Why does this sound like an Onion article?

WASHINGTON, Jan 29 – President George W. Bush said on Monday he did not intend to insult Democrats by failing to pronounce their party’s full name in his State of the Union address.

“I didn’t know I did it,” Bush told NPR in an interview.

In his speech last Tuesday, Bush declared to a joint session of the U.S. Congress that “I congratulate the Democrat majority.” Some Democrats were incensed he did not say “Democratic.” The party’s proper name is the Democratic Party.

Republicans for years have dropped the last two letters of the name as a slight to the party. Bush’s prepared text of his speech had the proper name but he misstated it in his address.

Bush called it an oversight and said he was “not that good at pronouncing words anyway.” He said he was surprised at the level of distrust in Washington.

“There is a lot of politics in Washington — in my judgment, needless politics. And it’s almost like, ‘If George Bush is for it, we’re against it,’ and ‘If he’s against it, we’re for it.’ And the American people don’t like that,” Bush said.

In his speech, Bush went out of his way to praise California Democratic Rep. Nancy Pelosi, the new speaker of the House of Representatives, and declared his intent to work with Democrats in the majority of the House and Senate.

Reuters Oddly Enough

I’m sending in my housing prepayment to Madison. :/ I’m somewhat afraid I’ll end up going there. Not that it’d be a bad thing, by any means; it’d just mean that I wouldn’t be going to MIT. This is one of the situations where you’re afraid to hope too much.

Which I suppose I don’t end up in often. “Hope” is inherently a foolish thing. Which sounds cold, but it honestly is – what happens will happen, and if you hoped for it, well, okay. If you didn’t, you were setting yourself up for disappointment. What do you gain by a realized hope? Fulfillment?

Though I suppose the same thought process could be applied to emotion. What you feel. Ech. What is feel? What’s the value of something intangible, generated by a flesh machine, which can cause it to act irrationally? Is the brain a machine? Every input triggers, on some level, a physical change within the brain which can only have one reaction (another point against free will). If it’s not a machine and you really can decide how to react, then where does that choice take place? It can’t logically take place in the brain, can it?

My feet are cold.

Before I begin, I’d like to clue you in on something that only the lucky elementary students who benefit from the GLOBE program know:

Some people are really very passionate about dirt the soil.

And don’t take that wrong – I live in rural Wisconsin, I recognize that it’s important. … But F. D. Hole, may he rest in peace, took a love of the soil to new heights ground. For proper effect when you read the following aria, find a secluded grove and sit by yourself with your shoes off to the side. The chords are F, A, Bb, F, Bb, F, Bb, C7, F.

1. Great Lakes region, fertile land; glaciers spread both clay and sand;
Winds blew silt, then forests grew, giving soils their brownish hue.
2. Great Lakes region, fertile land, you strengthen us in heart and hand;
Each slope, each flower, each wild bird call proclaims a unity in all.

(At this point, the congregation will please rise.)

3. Antigo, a soil to know, Wisconsin’s crops and livestock grow;
and forests too, on Antigo; and forests too, on Antigo.
4. Plant a seed and pull a weed; the soil will give us all we need
And plenty more, so birds may feed: and plenty more, so birds may feed.

(The music here shall quiet and leave only the twelve-string guitar and the violin synth.)

5. Of all the crops, true peace is tops; its soil is love that never stops;
It blesses sand and water drops: it blesses sand and water drops.

… I’m trying not to die here, honestly… the performance notes are blatantly fallacy, but does this not look like something religious?

Now, it’s important to note that Francis wasn’t the only one to write songs in holy exaltation of terra firma. Dozens of primer-school agriculture inductees have written their own anthems, many of which have already been cataloged.

There is, for example, “I Wanna Dig”, sung to the tune of the Spice Girl’s “I Wanna Be” (“If you wanna be my partner, get down and dig, / We’ll be doing this forever, so you’d better make it quick. … Collect those soil samples, how wet does it feel?”), “Old McDonald Had a Pit”, “You Are My Soil, My Only Soil”, and even “I Love Dirt” (to the tune of “Three Blind Mice” – you can credit the state of Oklahoma proper for that one).

But I shall leave you with this, one final chorale of F. D. Hole in honor of (oh give me) the loam:

There are soils in south New Zealand.
There are soils in China West.
There are soils in Argentina’s pampas.
There are soils in Hawaii’s islands blest.
There are soils all over these vast landscapes,
in whatever land your foot steps fall;
But the _____________________*
They are the very best of all!

* Select line from choices below:
1. soils of southern steppes of Russia
2. prairie soils of North America
3. regur clays of central India
4. plaggen soils of the dear old Netherlands
5. volcanic soils of Indonesia
6. alluvial soils of upper Amazon

Go ye now in the unity of the fertile Great Lakes region.

addendum
You have not lived until you’ve seen 150 ag students fervently singing the Antigo Silt Loam Song.

From the local paper… They’ve mentioned turtles before.

And now that we’ve got that aside, consider the hash. Not the drug, nor the drinking/running clubs, but the hash function:

A hash function (or hash algorithm) is a reproducible method of turning data (usually a message or a file) into a number suitable to be handled by a computer. These functions provide a way of creating a small digital “fingerprint” from any kind of data.
Wikipedia

The MD5 hash of “foo”, for example, is acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8.

A question, then. A few hash functions, MD5 for example, have exploited weaknesses, meaning that inputs can be constructed that generate a given hash. This poses a problem for security and whatnot. But can we use that for data archival?

Say a hash function is written for which two inputs of the same length cannot have the same hash output. Example: thishash($a) <> thishash($b) where strlen($a) <> strlen($b).

If this is so, and inputs can be constructed to match a given hash value for this function, then it should be possible to plug any input into the function and, given the length of the original input and the resulting hash, rebuild the original input from scratch.

Correct me if I have my concepts skewed, but this could be great for data archival. … Might take a while, but it should be theoretically possible to rebuild the Wikipedia article on turtles given only 5164cabf185abcc87d5a37ef30e86ec6 and an input string length of 18407. Follow me?

addendum
I have now seen everything. Someone stumbled upon ikebowen.com by searching Yahoo for “fun things to do in Wausau Wisconsin for people under 21“. I appear at #8.

Heavens.

I forewarn you, this may not make a whole lot of sense. I’ll be back.

Royksopp’s “Remind Me”:

Chris Rice.

As it happened, the fileid for that was 42.

We left each other today. For the time being, it’s done. Gah, I love her. And I swear I wish I could be the one to make her happy.

“Friends”. Can you still be that?

I’ve hurt her in all of this. I hate myself for that. I remember telling her for the first time “I love you”. I remember it coming back, for the first time returned.

But I kept it from going much further. Like a little bit more than friends. Which is, of course, impossible… You’re either together or not. Existence in limbo is impossible. The attempt is painful.

And then she found someone else. A good guy, and she likes him. Doesn’t love him yet. She felt guilty for it, but didn’t really have a reason. I told her to go to him, try it. He’ll be there for her, will enjoy being with her and will be with her often.

Sam, I’m sorry. I love you.

Spent the first bit of the day at work. We were planning on starting at nine and ending at noon, but considering that I was there until three last weekend, getting out of the office at two wasn’t bad. The backup system needed to be completely reset. It was dying slowly.

We’re beginning to assemble a presentation for one of the larger clients. I can legally tell you that, for this purpose, I was commissioned with the purchase of a number of 3” binders.

As it was still Saturday at the time, someone locked the office entrance after I left. Despite my request to the contrary. Meh. I get back from OfficeMax with a set of presentation binders, wearing a long-sleeve tshirt, and someone had locked the door on me.

Ken let me in. “If you want your intern to live long enough to serve you, make sure he can get in the building when it’s fifty below!” :)

So anyway… a few photos for your viewing pleasure:

Two items of possible interest:

  1. Emma’s having a Superbowl party tomorrow. I’m going, if only to see her family as Bears fans clash with all of the Packer guests.
  2. eBay does free voice alerts! How cool is that?

School’s cancelled for tomorrow! … But Rhinelander never cancels, so… it’s going to be cold tomorrow. Very, very cold.

Wait, do I have to go to work then?

——

I’m at Emma’s house, watching the game. Meg and I aren’t terribly interested in the game itself (e.g. we’ve taken over the couch and only pay attention to the commercials), but we are cheering for the refs, specifically #58 and #99.

Meg: “Isaac Bowen, we should get a reputation.”

I’ll be wandering in here (“here” being the Robinson’s office area), randomly. Updates, probably.

Favorite ad thus far:

——

back at home
So, 158 pictures later… I’m only going to post six of them, not because it’s the sole digit making up the number of the beast, but for no terribly good reason whatsoever. Except that uploading the 70 photos that survived the purging would take a very long time.

——

The moon on the way home (from the Superbowl party) was… wow. Very, very large. And orange. And oval, interestingly. I tried to take a picture of it, but my fingers froze and the camera slipped a bit, resulting in a blurred and fairly worthless image.

And my feet are freezing again.

1. It’s cold in the analytics room. We plug in two spaceheaters. Result: a fuse is blown. ... But the lights still work.
  2. Down in the basement – find a fusebox with labels made 25 years ago that no longer seem to apply to anything. Who’s Chuck?
  3. Someone else finds another fusebox. None of the fuses are tripped, but one isn’t red while the others are. They flip it and the main server rack blinks.
  4. They flip it again.
  5. The main server rack dies. And, fortunately, comes back.
  6. The entire office looses its connection to the various work-related networks.
  7. Panic ensues.
  8. We call the guy who owns the place to see if we can get the electrician to come in and sort everything out. He won’t let us – the fee, you know.
  9. But he will let us call in the garbage man.
  10. Who sorts out everything in five seconds.
  11. By flipping a switch on a totally different fusebox that no one knew existed.

And now our main analytics suite is broken, and no one really knows why. It worked on Saturday.

addendum
I found out why the analytics program was broken. The local server thought it was Wednesday (it’s not, actually), posing a problem when it tried to connect to another network in a future context. ... Yes, this took a conference call to figure out. I felt like an idiot.

——

Okay, yeah, one more ad. Here’s to the new workweek.

11:01 am
So the internet’s down. Kind of. This is the only site I can get to.

Which, as you can understand, doesn’t do any good at the office. ikebowen.com isn’t terribly useful for financial research. … In fact, now that I think about it, it isn’t terribly useful for anything much. :) In a hedonistic kind of way, that pleases me.

11:19 am
Actually, I can also get to cisco.com. That makes me slightly suspicious of the (Cisco) firewall. Which, yes, I have twice tried reloading.

6:04 pm
Back home. Today sucked royally. I made three phone calls to Charter, for a total of roughly two hours on the phone. Arguably.

Actually, I only talked to a someone for probably fifteen minutes. But I hear Charter’s like that.

From the 45-minute hold period on the first call (“Please hold while I pull up your account information.”), I concluded that, while classical is nice, it’s wholly inappropriate when one concerto is looped more than six times. I personally find that demotivating, especially when a new person then picks up the call, tells me that I’m in the wrong department, says something about transferring, puts me on hold, and drops the call.

This was frustrating, yes, but I only became really infuriated after the second call where I was greeted, unexpectedly put on hold and dropped all within the space of three minutes.

The third call put me in contact with the call center supervisor without too much trouble. I ranted at him for a few minutes which he followed with the textbook “we’re sorry for the inconvenience and this isn’t Charter’s way of doing business” mini-speech. Like a well-scripted dance. (I have this mental image of a consumer and a service provider performing ballet, which really isn’t appropriate. But it does work with the classical hold music.)

Anyway, Eerl (I asked; he’s from the Philippines. Surprise there.) tried to help me fix the problem. Check that an IP was assigned via DHCP, repair the network connection. He told me to boot to safe mode, and I kind of feel bad for chewing him out for it. I told him that I was dealing with a network-wide problem here; the modem was servicing multiple nodes, not just one PC.

Anyway. He scheduled a rep visit for sometime tomorrow, which I’ll have to cancel… Finally realized that if I could ping IPs but not resolve names (I am something of a dolt, yes), and if Charter wasn’t reporting any problems with our connection, then the problem was somewhere local. The bosses gave me permission to call in someone from One Prospect – ‘Sam’ was the tech who showed up. Nice guy. It took two hours (“I don’t know a PIX from crap, I’m afraid…”), but he did find a line in the firewall’s config that was causing problems.

Which doesn’t really make sense. The line essentially looped all outward requests back to the local server, which would cause a problem, but didn’t until 10:00 this morning. At that point, the connection to Charter’s DNS died, leaving us to run off of cached IPs. (This explains why I could get to ikebowen.com – still not sure why cisco.com would be cached.) It would make sense had the problem begun immediately after the issues from yesterday, if the config line in question had been removed earlier but not been saved, b/c the PIX box would have rolled back to the saved file with the problematic line in place.

Bah.

Today was the first day in a very long time that I got seriously angry. ‘Angry’ meaning ‘seriously choleric’. I don’t do that very often… bah. Now I’m just upset at myself (again) for having to call in a tech to remove a line in the firewall’s configfile that I could have taken out in fifteen seconds had I found it to be the problem.

[ sighs ] Meh.

I’d rather be programming.
by ikebowen – $3.95
(Get this custom at Zazzle)

Went somewhat better. I made a bumpersticker, for example. Nothing really self-destructed at work, though my boss was very disappointed that school was in fact in session today.

Randomly went off and sat in the car by the trainyards during lunch. Music, a few pictures. I’m on a Linkin Park binge, and I blame Anthony for that.

An example, if you will, from the article on Dewey Decimal Classification:

1 How this nigga works
The DDC attempts to organize all knowledge into ten main classes that, excluding the first class….

Et cetera. The rest of the article is very articulate and well-composed. Just not the title of subsection 1.

Upd: someone fixed it. :)

——

Just called Legg Mason (and Clearwater, and Western Asset), looking for the fact sheet for the Partners Aggressive Growth fund. No one seems to know who has it, and I don’t really mind that (I will, come Monday), but the last person I talked to absolutely made my day.

She was (sounded like, anyway) a black secretary, early fifties. She had no idea if she could get the fact sheet or not (“Well, I’ve never had to do that before, but…”), but she was very… the-Oracle-when-she-was-baking-cookies about it. Cool.

——

I’ve concluded: Mt Dew makes me happy. Honestly – when I have none, I’m down and out. When I’m on the 55mg of C8H10N4O2 that is Dew, I’m happy. On top of the game.

The secret of life.

I flatly refuse to call it ‘Foto Friday’ or any other such nonsense (‘Phriday’?). I’m calling it such only because it’s Friday and I happen to be posting a number of photos – it could easily be Tuesday next time. Be on your guard.

It’s likewise tossed in expressions because… I suppose photography is a form of expression. Then again, so is blogging.

post_title: EMI in talks to sell unprotected MP3s (AP)
final_content:
Right, I don’t usually repost news items, but this one was kind of worth it. Sorry.

From the AP at mercurynews.com

NEW YORK – Music company EMI Group PLC – home of The Rolling Stones and Coldplay – has been talking with online retailers about possibly selling its entire digital music catalog in MP3 format without copy protection, the Wall Street Journal reported Friday, citing numerous people familiar with the matter.

The MP3 format, which can be freely copied and played on virtually any device, would allow consumers to play music purchased from any online store on any digital music device.

Currently, music purchased at Apple Inc.‘s iTunes Store, for example, is wrapped in Apple’s proprietary version of Digital Rights Management technology known as “FairPlay” and can only be played on the company’s iPod devices. Songs purchased from rival online stores that carry different DRM technology cannot be played on iPods. That has caused some to wonder whether it might be hampering sales.

According to the people familiar with the matter, London-based EMI asked the retailers to submit proposals by Thursday telling the company what size advance payments they would offer in exchange for the right to sell EMI’s music as MP3s, the Journal reported.

One of the unidentified people said EMI would decide whether to forge ahead with the strategy based on the size of the offers. A decision about whether to keep pursuing the idea could come as soon as Friday, the Journal said.

When asked about the report, EMI spokeswoman Jeanne Meyer told The Associated Press, “We’re not commenting on speculation.”

Earlier this week, Apple Chief Executive Steve Jobs called on record labels to abandon their requirement for online music to use DRM, which is designed to limit unauthorized copying. Jobs said such restrictions have done little to slow music piracy and eliminating them would open up the online music marketplace.

One person familiar with the matter told the Journal that several major music companies have recently floated the idea of scrapping copy protections, but none appears to have gone as far as EMI, and some maintain that copy-protection software is critical to stop piracy.

EMI is the world’s third-largest music company by sales and home to acts ranging from The Beatles to the Beastie Boys. But some of its performers – notably including The Beatles – do not yet sell their music in any digital form.

EMI has experimented with releasing singles in the DRM-free MP3 format. In the past few months, the company has released tracks by Norah Jones, Lily Allen and the band Relient K.

Meyer said Thursday night: “The results of those experiments were very positive, and the fan feedback has been very enthusiastic.”

... Come to think of it, reposting materials from the AP is probably not legal either. The irony.

But GAH this would be cool.

Today. Spent mostly at work – left home at seven, got back at four. … For a Saturday, that’s far too much time. But what can you do… We did accomplish a lot. The group’s in client-reporting mode, which we kind of hit every quarter. For the intern, this means that things become insane for six-ish weeks every three months, while the rest of the time he does useful chores like stock the fridge. Et cetera.

I’m kind of in a strange state of mind. Methinks it’s mostly caffeine-induced, as strange as it sounds, combined with not eating. Kind of detached. (Example: my feet are freezing, but I don’t feel cold.) Hm. Slightly heightened awareness, things move slightly more slowly and can be examined slightly more easily. Bit interesting.

Tried to nap when I got home, went upstairs sometime after four. Conclusion (reached after roughly an hour of trying not to think): caffeine and sleep do not mix. Bah.

addenda (that is the real plural… ech.)

  • I seem to be a National Merit Scholar. Cool.
  • Filed Fed taxes with TurboTax. Not too bad, actually. No, I do not hire a nanny.
  • Watch the Pachelbel rant. Ha.

I’ve pretty much concluded that free will doesn’t exist. In an absolute sense. Nothing really points to it, other than the commonly-held belief in it. Brain chemistry to a study of the dimensions – there’s no room for free will, God or no. (Though the addition of God makes it a bit more interesting – he’s a wildcard with that infinite nature and all.)

So – free will doesn’t exist as fact, or so I think I choose to think, but it does have a quasi-existence as a practical illusion, meaning that life seems to be set up as if it existed, giving us the responsibility of choice that we’d have if free will existed to begin with.

Which more or less renders the entire thought process moot. Bah.

post_title: As long as you weren't expecting this...

final_content:
I’m really at a complete loss for something to write here, so I’ll save you several paragraphs of aimless rambling and just post music. Enjoy.

These two songs are easily at the top of my list – #1 and #2, respectively. No question. I’m waiting for something to fill #3 (and following), but for now these are solid. Both synthpop, yeah. I’m very… very attached to that particular genre – it’s the only one that really has consistently deep music. Music subtly layered upon itself. Love that.

And, of course, the lyrics work well. Lines I identify with.

Anyway, yeah, enjoy. I think I know two other people who will compulsively listen to this kind of thing because they actually like it, but you might as well listen to them once. Broaden your musical scope and all.

Only This Moment (RÃ¶yksopp)

lyrics / video

The Way I Live My Life (Iris)

lyrics

addendum extrarium (‘extrarius’?)
From the spambox, a message with this subject: “Informational Superhighway, computer networking seems to be moving toward the status of TV sets and microwave ovens”.

Take note.

Thanks to a concentrated marketing effort, Valentine’s Day has emerged in Japan and Korea as a day on which women, and less commonly men, give candy, chocolate or flowers to people they like. This has become an obligation for many women. Those who work in offices end up giving chocolates to all their male co-workers, sometimes at significant personal expense. This chocolate is known as giri-choko (ç¾©ç†ãƒãƒ§ã‚³), in Japan, from the words giri (“obligation”) and choko, a common short version of chokorÄ“to (ãƒãƒ§ã‚³ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒˆ), meaning “chocolate”.
Wikipedia

If you’ve never done anything requiring constant mental activity for three hours, you should know straightaway that it’s a considerable task upon which to embark.

That said, I’ve been at the Holiday Acres piano since 5:30. Or, well, I’m back now, but I left at 8:30. … Oi. They asked me to come back for Valentine’s Day this year, and my acquiescence belonged firmly in the category of ‘shoot, what else can I reasonably say?’. Ach. But it went well. And no, your hands do not get tired – just your arms. And right on about 2.5 hours, you start to wonder why there’s no cushion on the bench.

But that’s neither here nor there. I met Ross B’s mom (and Tara!), which was both unexpected and pleasant.

Topic the First: Chantsong
I love chantsong. I just do. Give me a Gregorian chant album and a task to accomplish and it will take me three times as long to complete it, but I will be much happier about the whole thing.

Topic the Second: Unexpected Referrers
Yahoo search: job description of ice cream parlor data encoder

Google Hong Kong search: Carole M. Vaughn

Yahoo search: boy stuck in machine at Antigo Walmart

Yahoo (and MSN) search: things to do in wausau for people under 21

Google Vietnam search: Speechwork Audio cd

Topic the Third: Kevin (and Charlie)
Session Start (ikebowen/gmail.com:Kevin): Tue Feb 13 14:15:12 2007
[14:15] Kevin: Shun the non-believer!
[14:15] ikebowen: shuuuuuuuuunnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnn
[14:15] ikebowen: -nuh
[14:16] Kevin: Candy Mountain..you fill me with sweet sugery goodness.
[14:16] ikebowen: a /magical/ neoplurodon!
[14:16] Kevin: It didn’t say anything!
[14:17] ikebowen: yeah, good/bye/, Chaarrllliiieee!
[14:17] Kevin: Wait. Goodbye…
[14:18] Kevin: aww. they took my friggen kidney.
[14:18] ikebowen: [ happy credits music ]
[14:18] Kevin: Indeed. I am addicted.
[14:18] ikebowen: :D
[14:18] Kevin: Like the tenth time today.
[14:19] ikebowen: [ raises eyebrow ]
[14:19] ikebowen: careful, Kevin
[14:19] ikebowen: it will take you
[14:19] ikebowen: like dungeons and dragons
[14:19] ikebowen: only filled with sweet sugary goodness

‘Cerebric Smash’
The subject from a message in the spambox that I didn’t read. I’ll be using it in unexpected places, as in, ‘Oi, it’s five below – what a cerebric smash…’

(Friendly warning: this could be slightly depressing. … Or not, depending.)

They tell you where you need to go
They tell you when you’ll need to leave
They tell you what you need to know
Tell you who you need to be

But everything inside you knows
There’s more than what you’ve heard
Theres so much more than empty conversations
Filled with empty words

…

What everything inside me looks like
Everything I hate
You are the hope I have for change
You are the only chance I’ll take

…

And you’re on fire
When He’s near you
You’re on fire
When He speaks
You’re on fire
Burning at these mysteries

Switchfoot

——

I’ve concluded the obvious, I suppose. Life sucks. And when all is said and done, it’s more or less worthless.

Unless we bring in the single factor that exists outside of life, known variously as Elohim, Adonai, Shaddai. God. There’s potential there.

The shadow proves the sunshine.

——

Or, Upon the Discovery of 700 Hobo Names

For the sake of my own convenience (I was up late, sorry), most of this shall be in list form, usually in chronological order with some un-noted exceptions.

  • Departure from RHS at 6:00am, or something close to it. Seven people in the suburban, eight in the minivan. We may be in Decathlon and therefore highly intelligent by association, but logic doesn’t apply to anything before ten o’clock.
  • (Four hours pass, briefly interrupted by a Mexican working community, population 176, and it’s cafÃ©/rest-stop. And also Thorp.)
  • The Minneapolis Institute of Arts, having no connection to the military acronym (Nathan), was most excellent. Our focus was naturally on the installation concerning Asia, but the elevator was also fairly diverting. It was the sort that one would expect in a theatre complex from the late 1920’s, actually, and had a manual door.
  • The Mall of America.
    • Food. This was at the time a matter of particular importance, and for reason of the same gets its own subsection. Even if my pizza was cold.
    • Gamestop – I think Will was looking for a game (would make sense). I ended up with the Matrix trilogy in its multiple-disc-widescreen-special-edition entirety for less than 20usd (!!).
    • Various Other Stores, not deserving of their own individual subsections, but including such as Sox Appeal and Sam Goody (the clerks there were very suspicious of my Gamestop bag’s contents, which set off the merch alarm no less than twice).
    • Barnes & Noble. I think I could live a fairly pleasant existence at any given Barnes & Noble without ever leaving, but my current income wouldn’t support that. And neither would the Mall’s security staff.
      • The Areas of My Expertise, an almanac by none other than John Hodgman (you may know him from the Get a Mac ads or the Little Gray Book Lectures, depending on your social life). This book has proved to be possibly my best purchase from the weekend (excluding a bamboo stalk and two bottles of Bawls, but I’ll get to that). Excepting the Bible, and perhaps the life’s work of Douglas Adams, this is truly the only book you ever will need. Or the first third, I suppose, for two additional compendiums of world knowledge are on their way and continue the page numbering from where the respective predecessor left off. It has nearly everything going for it, including a plug from the High Priest from the Church of Satan (I do not lie). I expect I’ll cover the book in more detail later, but I was intrigued at finding within the book a significant reference to the precise Barnes & Noble location from which I made the purchase. “Coincidence?” (The book, by the way, includes 700 hobo names – all of these, curiously, have been illustrated at e-hobo.com.)
  • Ikea. What a great store, and I’m killing myself for not posting photos right now. Ranks right up there next to Barnes & Noble, not only for the cutting boards arranged in the art-deco style, but also for the reasonably-priced meatballs. I purchased two table-lamps, and also a bamboo stalk.
  • Hotel. A few interesting incidents, including a malfunctioning pool door. And sleep, which isn’t really interesting, but worthy of note.
  • Departure from hotel. We stopped at the nearest Holiday station for a caffeine fix, where I discovered that that particular Holiday station is among the happy and tireless few that stock Bawls, energy drink of the gods. And the poor caffeine addicts of Prentice High – ask me sometime.

Anyway, I’m home now. And exhausted. I’m working on ripping the Matrix films in a Zune-friendly format, but my computer has lost its grip on the normal flow of time and logic.

Goodnight.

Google search tracking
My Google homepage (the google.com/ig one; I have yet to figure out what ‘ig’ stands for) shows me what Google thinks I would find interest in, given what I’ve searched for in the past. It bothers me that a full 20% of the recommendations are in Russian.

The Prestige
It out on DVD! Ha! Walmart and Circuit City have the lowest prices, excluding any applicable shipping. And then there’s eBay. Interestingly, Google recommends the search query “the prestige torrent”, entirely of its own accord.

Passport photos
Another way that Walmart screws America. 10usd for a manually-trimmed Polaroid?

Godaddy
Yes, their advertising is despicable. But they’re cheap. Use the code ‘gdd0129d’ to purchase/renew/transfer .com domains for 6.95usd. I’m unsure if the pricing holds for future renewals.

1st Financial Bank
Mail-spam. A ploy against the innocent (here meaning ‘naive’) college student. The back of the letter is the embodiment of the archetypal fine print – the stuff at the top is large and the stuff at the bottom is minuscule. And even if the student in question gets to pick his/her own background graphic (interesting that the only state flags available are for Illinois, Texas, Ohio, NY and California; also that the zodiac paintings each have an ® in the actual painting), an apr that goes up by 19.95 percentage points for balances over $250 is ridiculous.

It is nice, though, that they include a letter to the parents to console them about their child having a credit card, of all things. Even if the closing reads “1sr Financial Bank”.

Gravatar 2.0 (jump)
+10 for the trendy version number, but minus several thousand for the site dying utterly only days after the release. And for the irked masses. I quote: ‘I never had any problems with it until this 2.0 thing started happening’. That just makes it all worthwhile. (upd: they’re back online. The user base has high expectations.)

Ha! And it’s not even Tuesday!

Music for the mood, or whatever:

——




——


——




——

Turned in at 7:30 last night, mostly because I needed to be alone for a while. Played Mario, worked on Spanish/Econ sporadically. I can’t concentrate on much as of late.

Newsweek’s cover last week was on men and depression. This surprised me, frankly. It’s evidently a large enough issue phenomenon among members of the y chromosome to warrant considerable attention. (The article was written by a woman. :))

It’s strange how people attach themselves to each other. Like by becoming part of someone else – and vice versa – they are somehow more valid. Real. People are defined by their relationships. People define themselves by their relationships.

Humanity. Ech.

I miss feeling alive.

Annoying thing of the day (or of yesterday): Batman/Ualuealuealeuale. I thought about embedding the thing in this post, and then realized that I’d have to listen to it again. ;)

Heee. I slept until roughly eleven. This is the first weekend in probably a month, given that weekends involving two or more obligatory activities aren’t really weekends. But there you are.

Software of the week – all free:
Juice – a podcast receiver. Very simple, very nice.
Noiseware Community Edition – useful app for removing photographic noise. Works very well, though this version doesn’t do batch processing.
VirtualBox – better than Virtual PC, imo. And it’s open source, under the GPL.

And now, a little toy of my very own. … Or, well, not really, it’s a derivative work under the GNU, but it’s close.

dark aquatics screensaver
Download here. There used to be more info here, but it’s gone now. I’m sorry. [01142008]

addendum
Styke has gotten his FreeTXP site off the ground in what I think is record time. Kudos.

Clark Gable / The Postal Service

I want so badly to believe that there is truth,
that love is real
and I want life in every word to the extent
that it’s absurd

Through Glass / Stone Sour

I’m looking at you through the glass
Don’t know how much time has passed
And all I know is that it feels like forever
When no one ever tells you that forever
Feels like home, sitting all alone inside your head

——

Btw, I’m playing with the site layout and such. It’ll likely change significantly over the next couple of days.

post_title: Selections, not necessarily from 'The Areas Of My Expertise'
final_content:
The following are not excerpts from the somewhat astonishing book, THE AREAS OF MY EXPERTISE – a work of falsehood by John Hodgeman. This does not constitute an unauthorized reproduction of said book, as I have spelled certain words incorrectly and shall conclude by asking you to purchase the book, which justifies my purpose.

The Third of Six Oaths of the Virtuous Child
I shall be a faithful chile, and I shall ever make science my enemy. Also eels.

Hobo Name #691
Undertaker Robert, the Lint-Coffin Weaver

A Selection of Debated Planats
Neptune: The residents of its thirteen mooons believe religously that Neptune itself doesn’t exist. When they purify it from their minds, the “Great Blue Insult” shall dissapear.
Jupiter: Possibly just a moon of the largest planit, Gigantor.
Super-Gigantor: A hypothetical mass designed to annoy Jupiter.
Mercury: Zero axal tilt? Please. Most agree that this is either a space station or a self-aware supercomputer.

North Dakota
Motto: “Liberty and Union, Now and Forevah, One and Inseparable, Except for South Dakota.”
Notes: Since its seccession from South Dakota in 1941, North Dakota has sought a unique identity for itself, largely through the yearly commissioning of random new nicknemes, including “The Soo State,” “The Flickertail State,” “The Peace Garden State,” “The Birthplace of the Macabre,” and “The South Dakota of the North.”

Three of Nine Presidents Who Had Hooks for Hands
The association of hooks with pirates begans with J. M. Barrieeee, author of Peter Pan, whose “Captain Hook popularized the still-seductive concept of extreemely sharp, largely useless seafaring prosthetics. In fact, though, it cannot be proven that any nonfictional pirate ever replaced his hand with a hook.

Jifferson (who designed his own hook)
T. Roosevelt (first draft: “speak softly and pierce their eyes with a golden hook”)
F. Roosevelt (note: his hook was actually a wheelchair)

Hobo Name #117
Spazmodic Hilary

——

That said, you really must read buy, and then read, this fine almanac of blatant lies. It is even endorsed by the High Priest of the Church of Satan, which is not a lie. I leave you with the following book rating/blurb, and its accuracy rating by the book’s author:

——

Comment
“The flat-out funniest book of the year. IT’S IMPOSSIBLE TO DISLIKE. So comprehensive (and so blastedly funny) that you may never read another almanac again.”
Source
The Virginian-Pilot
Accuracy
86%. Some scientists have proven via a thought expiriment that it is, under certain conditions, possible to dislike this booke. If you wish to tri it at home, the experiment requires this book, a box, a cat inside the box, a canister of poisonous gas, and the willingness to kill the cat for the sake of a mere thought experimente. I hope you are satisfied, monster.

——

By the way, even if you don’t purchase the book, at least find it at the nearest quality bookseller and read the cover. And the introduction, not forgetting to note the inner cover, which features a painting of a metallic silver dragon and much more.

Or, well, you could visit the website. But you’d be missing out. It is COMPLETE WORLD KNOWLEDGE, after all.

I have concluded that there is a positive correlation between caffeine intake and overall mood.

This may be simply that the brain is simply jacked up to a higher pace, and one is not left to dwell on whatever happened five seconds ago. Which works; I’m hardly complaining.

Deja vu is an alarming thing. More alarming when you get the feeling that you’ve had the feeling you’ve done this before.

MIT hasn’t received my transcript yet. I asked the guidance office to send it in a month ago… they didn’t. Meh. That was probably in some way, shape or form my fault – they were under the impression that there was something that had to be added to it. [ shakes head ] Ah well. It went in the mail on Friday, but hasn’t been processed yet in Cambridge. I’m slightly nervous.

And in 17 days I’ll find out if I’m to be on the east coast this time next year. And whether or not I’ll leave school with several not insignificant student loans. Whether I’ll be as far away from home, alone, as I’ve ever been before, and whether or not I’ll be at a school that looks like an extension of my mind (in principle) or at a product of public education.

Though I suppose it’s hard to argue that it’s worth worrying about. The decisions have probably already been all but made, with or without my fairly tardy transcript. (I’ve decided as of now to also have it faxed in, assuming that school isn’t canceled tomorrow.) And, if I’m correct about free will, … no, if I’m correct, my opinion doesn’t matter. Never mind.

Forgot to complete a workpacket for calc, docking my grade by 35 points. Ah well.

Decathlon essay test is tomorrow – it’ll be something on climatology. Hopefully not too much emphasis on China; I don’t think I could make any sort of quality argument with the two combined.

addendum
Matthew’s instructor reportedly demonstrated the wonder of Wikipedia today, by changing the definition of RAM to Really Awesome Memory. … Oi. This is nearly as good as the Dewey edit.

Tis now the eventide, and the landscape is decidedly white. Windy, cold. White.


——

This is long overdue; it’s an ambience recording from the recent Decathlon trip – the Minneapolis Museum of Art – the Psychedelic Posters exhibit room. Came off of my cheap camera, had to tweak it a bit to get rid of the microphone noise. The sound was interesting, made me wish I had the recording equipment an significantly greater budget would allow. (I love location ambience – the sound of a place – I’ve mentioned it before.) Anyway, most of this is the HVAC. Slightly tweaked, as stated.

——

This is also fairly old. “Old” meaning “having an age greater than one year”.

——

I’m walking through a hallway,
And it seems an eternity long.
The only window is at the end,
And through it peers the dawn.

The ceiling is all of brilliant white,
The floor as cold as stone.
Only mirrors grace these walls,
Leaving my reflection and I alone.

I don’t know how I got here,
I can’t remember when.
No idea how to escape here,
Or when I’ll find the end.

So for now I’m forced to continue on,
At the threat of standing still.
Only mirrors stay by my side,
Only showing an empty shell.

An empty shell is all that’s left,
Feels like the rest has drained away.
There was nothing of value to keep it there,
No reason why it should stay.

And on I walk through an eternity,
My reflection and I alone,
Without any hope of any escape
From a hall of mirror and stone.

This is Calah’s writing, interestingly. Musica mia.

——

verse 1
Everything dear to me,
All the things my heart would say,
The worries wearing at my weary soul,
And all the things that I can’t control.

Why can’t the world be black and white?

chorus
Piano keys – keys to doors I just can’t open;
My senseless heart just keeps hoping,
That someone would get the walls of this door,
So I wouldn’t have to use these useless keys
On a door that won’t open.

verse 2
It’s all coming down on me,
Tearing on my heart strings,
Striking every painful chord,
Reminding me of these painful things.

Why can’t the world be black and white?

chorus

bridge
If I could write my own lifesong,
It’d be so beautiful;
But it seems that I just ride along,
With hands that aren’t mine,
only playing the pain within me.

chorus

Seems to be raining down on me,
Pulling me under so I can’t breathe.
This weight is so heavy – If someone would only lift it,
...
And set me free.

post_title: Several items of no relation at all.
final_content:
An excerpt from The Now Show from Radio 4 (now with podcast!), dated 02/03/2007:

——

I deleted my Paypal account, created under my dad’s name a long time ago, and recreated it exactly as before. Only now, they want me to pay 2usd to use my card with it and I’m doubtful they’ll hold valid the $15 off $30 that is to be paid later this month.

——

today’s purchases


Titanium Spork – ThinkGeek
Though ThinkGeek intends this to be a hunger-fighting tool, I consider it to be the Decathlete’s weapon of choice.


Acrobot – ThinkGeek
Articulated, stackable and very artistic, Acrobots feature crystal clear round heads, magnets in their hands and feet, flexible joints and the ability to contort into hundreds of shapes. Pose them gracefully and stick ‘em on metallic stuff. Great to fidget with.


meh.
Black, zip-down sweatshirt. Says “meh.” across the front. Wear your indifference close to your heart. An ikebowen product.

——

Couple shots from the State Theatre in Rhinelander, home of snow and beer.

If a species is to survive, it must have a drive to do so. Yes, this is stating the obvious. There is no reasonably sane buffalo that wants to die (not that enough of them haven’t died already).

So it’s interesting that suicide rates are, over the long-term, rising. It’s possible, of course, that other causes of death are being diminished. Fewer people in the United States have been killed in land-wars than ever before, for example.

But it’s still fundamentally bothersome that 2003 saw suicide to be the eighth leading cause of death for US males, and while men are more likely to actually kill themselves than women, women make the attempt three times as often. (Or say they do.) (ref)

And forget men as a whole – suicide is the third leading cause of death for youth. Youth, defined in the study as those between 15 and 24. The young people, the ones supposed to be full of promise with their whole lives ahead of them, commit suicide more often than their elders. (ref)

That’s terrible. And totally against animal instincts. While the connection there might be a stretch (there are neurotic deer who will simply stare into the headlights, waiting for their undoing), the fact that 10 out of 100k Americans kill themselves is still appalling. (ref)

So why is this happening?

People kill themselves for a variety of reasons, I’m sure, though I’ve not spoken with anyone yet who has committed suicide after speaking to me. (…) Other obscure reasons aside, I’ll willingly conjecture that it’s simply a depression so deep and dark that a person honestly doesn’t believe their life is worth living. They have no reason to live, nothing to live for.

So. Given that rates are going up, if slowly, is it reasonable to say that people are losing grip more often? More people have nothing to live for? Nothing to anchor themselves to, no concrete assurance that they are indeed worth something?

And what might that say about humanity?

——

(unrelated photo, honestly just to take up vertical space on this monitor)

I need to say something, but I don’t know what. So – this is what I’m thinking:

  • It’s Threesday, and I have yellow toner dust on my sleeves.
  • music > geekiness
  • Is it better to feel good on a couple occasions, or not to feel at all?
  • Davy Jones. If I were half-sea-creature…
  • Miss Calah.
  • This is a really gaudy doughnut. I like the little sprinkle-things, though.
  • Miss Sam.
  • MIT on the 17th.
  • That’s St Patrick’s day, right?
  • The spork is in the mail.
  • Daylight savings ends (starts?) early this year. Yech.
  • Somethin’ here don’t feel right / This is just a half-life / Don’t you see I’m breaking down?
  • hook.freetxp.com/2007/03/05/mother-father
  • tired
  • rushed
  • meh

addendum
Despair, Inc. is going into ‘blackout mode’ tomorrow – password protected with exceptional prices. Login tomorrow with COWER/TRANSAURUS.

muÂ·sick (myoo’-zik) verb
to engage in the art of sound in time, expressing ideas and emotion

All around me are familiar faces
Worn out places, worn out faces
Bright and early for the daily races
Going nowhere, going nowhere

And I find it kind of funny
I find it kind of sad
The dreams in which I’m dying
Are the best I’ve ever had
I find it hard to tell you
I find it hard to take
When people run in circles
It’s a very very, mad world, mad world

Gary Jules

I’ve
become so numb
I can’t feel you there
become so tired
so much more aware

Linkin Park

Distant worlds are you the home I have
My orbit has me thrown
To the boundaries of the mind

Iris

So keep the blood in your head
And keep your feet on the ground
Today’s the day it gets tired
Today’s the day we dropped out
Give up my body and bed
All for an empty hotel
Wasting words on lowercases and capitals

Brand New

You sit there on the couch,
Sipping your scotch and ice,
Turn the tv on, and tune me out again

Plumb

I am colorblind
Coffee black and egg white
Pull me out from inside
I am ready

Counting Crows

Only this (moment)
Holds us (together)
Close to (perfection)
Nothing else (out there)
No one to (guide us)
Lost in the (senses)
Deep down inside I know our love will die

(okay)

Only this (moment)

Random pictures. Nothing better for the moment, lo siento… Which reminds me, I wrote a reasonably coherent essay entirely in Spanish, for which I am proud.

I told myself I wasn’t going to spend anything more until Madison. Nothing more – State Street will be bad enough, and I don’t even have my meh shirt yet.

It seems that I don’t have quite the resolve I thought I had. Either that, or coffee now holds sway over my soul.

But, regardless of that, it does seem to be Thursday. “Couldn’t even be freaking Friday!”, as a co-worker aptly put it… The week is crawling. It felt long on Tuesday Threesday, though it is some comfort that we’ll be doing absolutely nothing in Calc through Friday. Aside from a negligible amount of actual math and two hours of The Prestige, which amounts to more or less nothing anyway.

At work, plugging away… Challenge of the week: editing out a chair from the most recent group picture. Missed another NHS meeting for work, regrettably… Evidently I’ll be doing something piano-related at the induction, which means finding something formal-ish to play.

Diane showed up online last night; unexpected and pleasant conversation. I think I’ve said this before, but it’s weird how people that you’ve known for only a week can be some of the best friends you’ve had. Riley, for example.

Dylan’s tryout for Sound of Music is this afternoon. I dearly hope that I won’t screw up the accompaniment… The Point of No Return, from Phantom – lots of full/straight diminished chords all in a row. It’s the kind of score that you can’t really think about; just go straight through it or you’ll miss something, and you’re thinking through the music anyway, you’ll get distracted wondering how F minor and A major are supposed to sound good together. Though perhaps that’s the point.

Annoyance: discovering after a large print job that the collate box wasn’t checked.

So – while looking through my photo library, I found some clouds. And, not being one to do anything productive when there’s an opportunity to play with visuals…

If you want to download the desktop-size versions, have at it. Be forewarned that they’re all 1440×900 – I like widescreen.

Get ready – this company is ready to blow. Indeed, it is brewing traders as we speak.

Went skiing off of Hwy 70 near Eagle River on the National Forest trails. Three-ish hours. Largely pleasant.




This was the first, and likely only, time I dug out my 75mm three-pin boots this winter. A pity, that.

This machine has SiteKiosk. It’s a browser of sorts; layers kiosk-type-stuff over IE. IE 6, which appears to be more outdated than I thought it was. ... Odd.

Anyway. It’s 5:15 (the system clock here is off, too) and my interview has just concluded. My speech is in fifteen minutes. I imagine I should go find out where it is… [ saves/leaves ]

10:50
K, I’m ticked off. This kiosk thing randomly restarted and lost me this whole thing I was… ah, whatever. And the browser still has the bad CSS box model. Bah. ... And alt-tab doesn’t work, which annoys.

So. Where was I.

Speeches were grand. Interviews also. My speech judges seemed to be thinking when I finished, which is either good or bad, considering my topic.

Super quiz tomorrow, both the written thing and the arena thing. Climatology. I’m okay with nearly everything except for the whole on-this-date-in-the-Southern-hemisphere-what’s-the-angle-of-the-noonday-sun-in-Nebraska bit.

[ saves ]

I have a few pictures… will post them sometime. My camera’s upstairs.

Oh. We had dinner at Chin’s, which was excellent. The musical selection was interesting (Chinese, erm, rap?), but the restaurant layout/decor and food was great.

One of the State Street coffeehouses was playing Need to Breathe. Will have to get an album from them or someaht.

Also – there is no shop on State St that sells the Zune 3.5mm->RCA+Video converter thing. Which is also bothersome, as it’s prevented us from watching the Matrix tonight.

But so it goes. Cheers.

Thinkgeek: Animated Retro Table Tennis Shirt

So – we’re home. Something like 12th in the state, which isn’t bad, but also isn’t quite as great as we had wanted. Ah well.

Lin pulled off a medal in the math competition, which is highly commendable. 50 questions of everything from general algebra to differential calc, no graphing calculator. Ech.

I landed a medal for my speech, which was unexpected but cool. One of the judges asked about The Question (The Answer being 42), and when I couldn’t remember, he mentioned that it was found to be “WHAT DO YOU GET IF YOU MULTIPLY SIX BY NINE”. This meant that I got to use the quote “I may be eccentric, but I don’t make jokes in base 13” (Douglas Adams, author).

This is going to be a filing day at work. Lots of forms and whatnot. Meh.

Speaking of ‘meh’, my shirt is in the mail. It shipped from Bavaria, oddly.

The great experiment – Zune has never been able to sucessfully save a download from the Marketplace onto my secondary drive. What happens if I switch my download/rip folder to the primary?

[ purchases “Dear Jamie… Sincerely Me” by Hellogoodbye ]

Failure. Poot. What happens if we kill McAffe?

[ kills McAffee tray thing ]
[ restarts download ]

Still failure. What the heck?

[ kills every process beginning with “m” ]
[ restarts computer after explorer hopelessly locks up ]
[ kills mcaffee the right way ]
[ restarts download ]

Still failure. ... I have no idea what the problem is.

Bah.

Thought: I am the inevitable product of mass society.

——

I didn’t do senior pictures, and I’m not sure if I will yet or not. And… I think that’s mostly because I’m not sure I want to be remembered.

Not that, you know, high school friendships generally last very long. You keep up with a couple people, maybe. But people are, by and large, replaceable.

And… yeah, that sounds cynical. But think about it. The divorce stats over the last decade prove the point. Marriage is supposed to be a promise to stick with this one presumably special person for the rest of your life.

——

I’m picking this up after several days. You know what it feels like to be screaming on the inside without any way to let that out? Like railing at reality for being?

——

Anthony asked the question the other day – is ignorance/bliss better than awareness/…not-bliss?

My first and immediate reaction was yes. Yes, it’s better not to experience the bad, even at the sacrifice of the good.

My second and immediately following reaction was a double-take. Probably because I second-guess everything I say, though perhaps there’s some vestige of the optimist left.

——

Random pictures.

——

Smith/Oracle: Why, Mr. Anderson, why? Why, why do you do it? Why, why get up? Why keep fighting? Do you believe you’re fighting for something, for more than your survival? Can you tell me what it is, do you even know? Is it freedom or truth, perhaps peace – could it be for love? Illusions, Mr. Anderson, vagaries of perception. Temporary constructs of a feeble human intellect trying desperately to justify an existence that is without meaning or purpose. And all of them as artificial as the Matrix itself. Although, only a human mind could invent something as insipid as love. You must be able to see it, Mr. Anderson, you must know it by now! You can’t win, it’s pointless to keep fighting! Why, Mr. Anderson, why, why do you persist?

Neo: Because I choose to.

Isaac, you are invited to apply for this Capital One Visa Platinum offer with No Annual Fee!

First reaction: cool, they printed my name on the envelope.

Second reaction: … They might have done a better job with the faux release auth stamp. At least not use a handwriting font. But hey – there’s a sticker!

Dear Isaac Bowen,

You could buy what you want with a new Capital One Visa Platinum card. Could I? Woot! Apply online or by phone, or simply mail back the completed Platinum Application. So… if I do it online, how do I verify that I have a Platinum Offer sticker?

Upon approval, this card comes with no annual fee! Which is different than Chase, MasterCard, Discover, and American Express… how? Plus, with $0 fraud liability you won’t be liable for unauthorized charges if your card or account number is lost or stolen and used without your knowledge. This is good.

Isaac Bowen, you can use this card around Rhinelander and at millions of locations and ATMs that accept Visa credit cards! Hey, you know where I live!

You are invited to apply for this offer. Aha. And there’s more. ! Because this card has the power of Platinum _, you can take advantage of [several other things] at no additional charge. More information about Platinum benefits will come in your welcome kit. _“Welcome kit”?

We’re waiting to hear from you. I’m sure. Apply today!

Because we want you to enjoy using your card, you can choose from our fun card designs. YES! Pick the one that suits you best. Well… The one with the Constitution on it is classy, but I think “Wild Horses” suits me better. Or maybe my personality is more “Dolphin Sunrise” than anything else. Give yourself the buying power of Platinum today! I’m still missing how I can afford more with this than I could before. Unless I get free money out of this…

Sincerely,
Carole M. Vaughn, Director of Consumer Services

P.S. Let us hear from you today. Be sure to put the Platinum Offer sticker on the postage-paid envelope if you reply by mail. Should I mail it overnight?

Gah, I hate these. I’m sorry, Carole. … Kinda.

Oi… I had a smashing headache this morning. Caffeine withdrawal. Ach.
