MIT
Received the rejection letter today. Well, no, that’s not accurate. It was more of a non-acceptance letter than anything.

Which I’m okay with, actually. (Firefox doesn’t think “okay” is a word.) More or less chose to expect this, so it wasn’t a shocker by any means. That, and I still hold confidence in Rom8:28.

So I’m thinking UW Madison for next year. I don’t feel a huge desire to go there, but still no less than for any other school. And Madison’s range of offerings should give me an idea of what to do with the next three years of college thereafter.

parents
They’ll be going international for the next two weeks, visiting the Germany in preparation for the upcoming sabbatical.

luncheon
Matthew invited me to lunch with Ben & Allie (and him) this afternoon – enjoyable. Ben/Allie had ‘The Franny’ (we were at The Friendship House), and we mocked them for it. Matthew had pictures of his desk burning.

Econ. Meh.

To introduce the role of government in private life, Nelson presented a few statements. Marijuana use should be legalized; a smoking ban in public places should be instated. Really agree, agree, disagree, really disagree.

Welfare should not be a government service – it should be provided by private organizations. Strongly agree, agree, disagree, strongly disagree?

Most disagreed on that one, a few agreed. My general line of thinking was that welfare is guaranteed for those who need it, while it remains a government-backed, tax-funded service. If it was left to private organizations, there wouldn’t be any such guarantee.

After stating this, someone on the ‘agree’ (an odd word, come to think of it) end of the room expressed their astonishment that we disagree-ers didn’t believe that enough people would step up to charity, that enough funding could be raised to give welfare to those who needed it.

I think the statement was, “I can’t believe that you don’t think people would care enough…” Something like. Paraphrase.

And I don’t, honestly. If people cared enough, more than 24% of Ethiopians would have drinking water. (ref)

The agree-ers seemed to think that people as a whole are good enough to support those who need it. Which then raises the argument, are people fundamentally good or evil? (I hesitated to write ‘evil’. … Strange.) What say you?

addendum
I generally avoid reprinting offsite links (the ones down and to the right) in articles, but this you really must see. Have you heard of Desktopography? It’s been around for three years now, and Exhibition III has (consequently) been posted. Go there. Now.

So – Anthony pointed out the other day that a tool to parse the XSPF (XML Shareable Playlist Format) files from those Myspace music players could be handy. Pull out the song name and file URL, and away we go.

Thusly, mp3_xml. (Misnamed, yes.) Plug in an XSPF URL and it gives you a list of songs with links to download from, including a list of only URLs for use in something like Wackget. I put the sourcecode below – it could be better written, but this works. And I haven’t written a random short script for obscure and potentially dubious purposes in a long time.

ProjectPlaylist made XSPF-based players popular. ... It can’t be legal. You can type in any of a million song names into the search box and download the file a second later. ...

Ah well. For the time being, it’s fun. And it’s not like the Myspace hordes aren’t downloading their music illegally anyway.

Situation: NCSS has reached its third year of existence, and is out from under the provisions of its first two years, where graduates were given an RHS diploma and guaranteed the option to participate in the RHS graduation ceremony. That being said, there are two graduating seniors at NCSS that want to march in this year’s RHS graduation.

Their situation is understandable – they both spent most of their secondary years at RHS, and have spent the greater portion of 12 education years with students now at RHS. It’s only natural that they’d want to stand next to their peers at the graduation ceremony in June. And if it’s only two, is it such a big deal?

It rather is, mostly because it’s a question of precedence (what happens next year, when there are more NCSS graduates?), but also because of the die-hard RHS loyalists who want no trace of other school district schools in the graduation ceremony.

As I see it, the only real issue is one of name. If it’s a Rhinelander High School ceremony, it makes no sense for any non-RHS graduates to participate. It just doesn’t. Incongruency.

The option is there, of course, to declare it an SDR Ceremony, and make it all-inclusive – allowing all SDR graduates to participate.

Aside from home-team passion, there’s no real argument against this. There was never a problem with it being an RHS-only ceremony in the past (well, more than three years ago), as RHS was the only secondary institution in the District. Now that there is, who’s to say that there shouldn’t be a District-wide ceremony?

No, there doesn’t have to be. NCSS already has their own ceremony, after all, scheduled this year for the 5th of June.

But then, RHS also has an awards ceremony, scheduled this year for the 23rd of May. If this is held comparable to NCSS’s ceremony, then why not take RHS’s actual graduation exercises and expand them beyond RHS itself? That’s not unreasonable.

There is also, however, the question of SDR policy. This was raised in a meeting this week with Ms. Machtan from NCSS, Mr. Werbowsky (RHS principal) and the RHS Council officers. SDR Policy 5459 (which can be found online) states the following:

PARTICIPATION IN THE GRADUATION CEREMONY

Except for extenuating circumstances and prior approval of the Superintendent, as the Board’s agent, a student must
have met all requirements for graduation in order to participate in graduation exercises.

[ “extenuating circumstances” listed here ]

A student will not be permitted to participate in graduation ceremonies if he/she has outstanding fees, fines, and/or
behavioral/disciplinary consequences remaining to be satisfied.

The administration will make a reasonable effort to inform the student and parent(s) or guardian(s) of any student
who is ineligible to participate in the graduation ceremony. Individuals may appeal their individual circumstances to
the administration for review.

It was argued that this policy guarantees the option to participate in a District-wide ceremony for all those eligible (NCSS students are held to the same District graduation requirements as those at RHS, btw). This interpretation is arguable, as the policy was approved when only one high school existed and might expand to cover additional high schools as they are incepted, resulting in a multi-school graduation ceremony.

I personally don’t interpret the policy as such. From an email conversation concerning the policy:

... it doesn’t seem that such a guarantee is made at all, nor is a single, all-inclusive graduation ceremony mentioned. In fact, while 5459 requires that a student “must have met all requirements for graduation in order to participate in graduation exercises” (except for extenuating circumstances, etc), 5459 seems only to state the disqualifications for participation in “graduation exercises” (rather than, say, “the District’s graduation ceremony”).

So – where does this leave us? This entire argument seems like overkill for this year’s two NCSS grads (clarification: the two wishing to participate in the RHS graduation), but again, this is a question of precedence. Do we go to a District-wide graduation ceremony? Or leave it per-school? Does policy 5459 apply to this situation, and if so, must a District-wide ceremony be created? Or should RHS keep its awards night and expand its graduation exercises to cover all SDR schools?

What say you?

——

For the record, there’s a parent/student meeting on this topic at RHS this Tuesday, March 27th, at 7:00am (early, I know… I didn’t schedule this), probably in the LGI.

I love photography. I hate stopping. Mostly because it means that I’ve missed more frames that I could have captured. But so it goes. My feet were wet.

It’s 43 degrees outside, winds south by southwest at 8mph with a somewhat dense fog settled in. It’s perfect, and it’s the kind of weather that only shows up between Wisconsin’s two seasons. Never lasts long enough.

I have resurrected The Leviathan.

“The Leviathan”, in this context, is a Compaq ProLiant ML370. (Check out the product page from back in 2001, or a Pakistani product promo, positively glowing.) A massive PIII with 128mb of ram and what looks to be three 30gb SCSI drives in a hotswap RAID cage, running Server NT 4.0. The administrator password, for reasons completely unknown to me, is “stallion”.

Why have I done this? The higher-ups wish to know if there are any parts that can be salvaged.

Foolishly, I thought that I could simply boot the machine up and find out everything from within the OS. Silly me. NT doesn’t have a device manager. (Which, for a system that can’t actually shut itself off, is understandable.)

… How does one open this case?

I’ve made friends with the power button. It’s one of those massive old biased switches that has mass. You can really feel that you’ve shut the thing off.

Conclusion: No. There are no recoverable parts.

post_title: Inherent bias, and the perception of such (& vice-versa)
final_content:
I seem to have put out a few NCSS students with the article on the graduation. My bus-riding siblings actually told me about a student who believes that I am to blame for NCSS grads being kept out of the graduation ceremony. … Which is odd, both because I’m not, and because they haven’t been kept out.

I’m not entirely sure what to think about that. I haven’t taken sides in this, I swear I haven’t. What I wrote was from a neutral point of view, arguing both (count them: two) sides of the situation. And I can understand their indignation – the fact that I’ve treated it as an issue could imply that I don’t think they should be allowed to march with the RHS grads. Or something to that effect. For the record, though, I’ve no bias. Honest.

What’s more interesting than this, however, is that they care enough about what I say/said to become angry/perturbed as a result. … Odd.

——

Unbeknownest to many in this office, The Leviathan was not the only piece of hardware quietly growing its own ecosystem beneath the coffee counter.

Oh, no. With a BIOS ©1982, the Pre-Leviathan has been maintaining homeostasis for longer than anyone seems to remember, having established symbiosis with the shredder years ago.

Spinning SCSI Hard Drives…

Interestingly, the PLev is significantly quieter than its successor. This is probably because its processor runs at 166MHz and doesn’t need the cooling systems that The Leviathan does.

OS Loader v4.01…

It’s a Compaq ProSignia 200 (product page, dated May 1997), and in its day was single-handedly responsible for taking South Africa’s Skynet to such great heights. It features a “high-performance 8X CD-ROM”, and a “Power Switch”, both of which pale in comparison to the awesome power of Microsoft BackOffice Small Business Server, version 4 and copyright 1985-1998. The password is not “stallion”, and attempting “admin” nearly shuts the system down. I do not know why.

So. How to dismantle it…

Aha.

This is… wow. … Old. So old, it doesn’t look like I can get at the processor at all. Every panel seems to be soldered together. …

I’ve decided to abandon this machine before it takes me with it. Those old token bus servers can be bitter.

——

By the way, I’ve realized (shame on me) that this site doesn’t look quite right in IE6 and earlier. So – if you’re running IE6, upgrade.

I’m beginning a series, entitled ‘studio time’. This is neither creative nor accurate, the latter being because I have no studio, only my office and a digital piano.

So, more or less, what you will be hearing (oh avid listener) will be an unedited, unplanned recording of me rambling on a piano for varied quantities of time. It may sound decent on occasion, but other times will serve to remind why I’m not playing at a performance venue near you.

Bearing in mind the unspoken respect that we have for each other, you as reader and I as writer/musicker/photographer/whatever (yes?), try not to be too critical. It’s just me.

——


download this

addendum
I detest recording off of a digital piano. It’s not real. And normally non-real things don’t bother me, but in this instance it does. For example, as it’s a work of precision electrical and mechanical engineering, it is perfectly and consistently in tune. This annoys me.

Possibly because I’m in love with the dear old (“old” here meaning “at least a century in age”) piano sitting quietly in the corner of the parlor. It is decidedly not in tune, and would probably make any virtuoso cry.

But. But. But, you can feel it. Play your heart out on it. Use the imperfections as nuances in musick. Make the keys extensions of your hands, knowing each piece of chipped and worn ivory like a part of yourself, listening to and feeling the sound wash back over you. I love this. It’s something that a digital simply cannot accomplish.

I took the two themes from the music up above and wandered through them again on ye olde upright. It means… means so much more with that instrument. I want to have it sampled some day, save every piece of the sound and have the piano with me wherever I end up, if only as a reminder of the times I’ve spent with it. Him. Her. The music.

Do you know what it feels like (and now I’m rambling) to fully and completely express your soul? To take everything that you feel, everything inside of you, and to let it all out in a medium that completely fits who and what you are.

It’s pointless, of course. No practical value.

And is very, very important.

World Time Clock
When understated function and Holland manufacturing combine. Rotate the clock so that your timezone is facing up, and there y’are.


Magnetic Ring
This… bah, I want one of these. Partly because I like the titanium/nickel look (I’ve been wearing a titanium ring for years…), partly because of the geek factor. There. I’m out.


Hug Salt/Pepper Shakers
These are worth every one of the 2,500 pennies they cost. I don’t think I need to explain why.


James the Bookend
I’m not sure how much I like the actual product, but with a name like “James the Bookend”, I may end up getting one anyway.


Music Mug
Stick the mp3 player of your choice into the mug, plug in the 35mm audio cord, and away we go. My first moment of doubt came when I realized that the mug had no powersource except for the mp3 player, which means that the sound won’t get very loud. But hey. It’s a mug.

——

in the news
Chinese MMO offers accounts to banned players who donate blood (via Boing Boing)
Harvard to bestow Honorary Doctorate on Bill Gates (via MT)

Friday evening through 2am – dealt with a friend’s social (“social” as in “social”, not “friend-related”) crisis.
Sunday evening through midnight – Nathan, Nathan’s brother’s Wii, Nathan’s brother
Monday Tuesday at 7:30 – alarm went off
Tuesday at 9:45 – achieved consciousness

——
——

Deep inside, you’re the rogue
While your soul’s gone hiding
Dare you say
Here your love is won

In your age, answers come
Still you’re undecided
Hurting as your body comes to play

But you keep living the same way
Cheating your mind’s ache
Telling yourself your life isn’t empty
Seek what you want or think that you need
But this life still won’t be giving

Vacant stares, hollow spin
Get you all excited
Left unseen
The one who you’ve become

You’re in place to find the wall
And without you knowing
There your tortured innocence has crawled

But you keep living the same way…

Optimist: The glass is half full.

Pessimist: The glass is half empty.

And as the cynic may opine: The glass is merely twice as big as it needs to be.

Put neutrally, the glass in question holds a quantity of liquid (presumably) in such an amount that it displaces half of the air (or whatever) that the glass in its original state contained.

The optimist and pessimist seem to treat the glass as if it ought to be filled with whatever it’s currently got a taste of. Whether half full or half empty, they imply that the glass in its natural state would be filled to the top. (Or one could argue that only the optimist really means that, whereas the pessimist is simply bitter at the contents for showing up the void in the first place.)

From the cynic’s point of view, however, this is an exercise in futility. The glass is half full (or empty, whichever), but in all practicality it’s just twice as big as it need be. The cynic would go on to say that the rest of the glass is just a waste of space. Unless you go for the aesthetic ying-yang universal balance of things, the second half has no purpose.

Siding with the cynic for the time being, the optimist and the pessimist seem to be deluding themselves. The glass could hold as much as it holds again, true, but it’s a waste of time to expect that. Or even treat it as a possibility. As far as reality is concerned, the rest of the glass is superfluous – only misleading the romantics who want to think that the glass might some day hold more than it does now.

Optimist: But hey, the glass could be half full.

Pessimist: ... It isn’t.

Cynic: For today, and as far as anyone is concerned, forever, the glass is twice as big as it needs to be.

Besides, it’s probably just arsenic.

IIT sent me an email a while back exhorting me to apply. The application in question being both short and, more importantly, free, I applied. The acceptance letter came some weeks thereafter.

I didn’t give a whole lot of thought to the school, and haven’t until… yesterday. The application was free, and the word “technology” was in the school’s name. But, what the heck – I sent a copy of my FAFSA to them, along with my ACT/SAT scores. Didn’t cost me anything, and it gave me a school to fall back on in the event that both UW Madison and Northwestern College abruptly blew up. One never really knows.

But I found a financial aid award letter in the mail the other day, with quite a generous offering contained therein. Better, actually, than Northwestern’s offer, bringing the cost of attending such a school down below what Madison is likely to give me.

And so, the school research process begins again. IIT seems to be a slightly lesser version of MIT, situated on the southern end of Lake Michigan. (I now know which lake is Superior and which is Michigan – a momentous occasion.) It has a substantial engineering program, but I’m eying the Institute of Design for the long run. Maybe get a Bachelor’s in compsci and go to the design school for a Master’s.

This is all speculation at the moment, but methinks we’ll visit the campus during Spring Break. The aid award letter was completely unexpected (in both its arrival and contents), and… hm. God does weird things like this on occasion, and it’s entirely possible that I’ll end up in Chicago next year. Oddly enough.

——

Or, well, three of them. It’s still news.

First and foremost, EMI has authorized Apple to sell drm-free tracks through iTunes for $1.29, thirty cents above the normal price (yeah, I know, you passed second grade too). For the higher price, you get an AAC file at 256kbps (higher than usual 192, I think it is). I’m very pleased about this. If Microsoft follows suit with Zune, this could be big. (via blogcritics)

Like every year, April 1 was nuts. And, like every year, Google won. Google announces free in-home wireless broadband service, as appeared in headlines yesterday. Some people have been confused and frustrated by this announcement while others helpfully assist, but some see this as a chance to capitalize. Shame.

Guitar Hero 2 comes out tomorrow for the 360, expanding from the first edition by adding three new instruments. And also “deep online connectivity”. (via ars technica)

I’ve had this sensation of… hm. Of just missing. Nearly attaining, but not quite getting it right.

Like a photographer. Finding a flawless subject in perfect light, waiting for the right moment to snap the frame. Taking the shot, only to find it imperfect. Not by a lot, and you could probably ignore what’s wrong. What’s missing. But if you had moved a little to the left, waited another moment for the shadows to deepen, it might have been right.

Like that, if that makes sense.

If I sing you a song, will you sing along?

Trying to think of a word for this. Like bittersweet, but mostly sweet. A moment that was nearly right, but you saw it coming. Saw it coming and tried to accommodate it – make the right moves, say the right things, but you tried too hard. Saw the chance for perfection and watched yourself overshoot.

Or, conversely, not going far enough. Waiting for the moment to effloresce of its own accord, to bring itself to rightness, only to find that it couldn’t go far enough on its own.

If I tell you Iâ€™m strong, will you play along?

Not that that really leaves anyone anywhere, but… gah. I can’t decide. Whether it’s better to have that taste of perfection, of complete and inherent near-rightness, or to leave it alone and move on. The classic question, I imagine. To be, or not to be?

... or should I just keep singing right here by myself?

(Sing Along / The Blue Man Group, feat. Dave Matthews; via hook)

decathlon-related

not decathlon-related

And the week…. is over. -ish. Work tomorrow for a few hours, but sleep can last until 7:30. Woot. And hey, we found the region code hack for the DVD player – DIE UNGLAUBLICHEN can now be viewed.

So. [ yawns ]

Spring break next week. I’m excited. I’ve no really special plans, aside from visiting IIT on Monday, but I’m looking forward to sleep.

I personally doubt that Microsoft would stop at a little popup saying “get the Genuine Windows Advantage now!”. Especially when the user agreement for installing this patch/update/thinger includes the following:

6. Computer Information. This supplement uses Internet protocols to send to Microsoft computer information, such as your Windows XP product key, hard drive serial number, PC manufacturer, operating system version, Windows XP product ID, PC BIOS information, user locale setting, language version of Windows XP, validation result and whether the installation of this supplement was successful. Certain information derived from your IP address … is retained in association with this computer information.

addendum
Though I see that (sigh) the rest of the world is copying Microsoft again. Linux Genuine Advantage, anyone? (thanks, Anthony)

Before I begin, I’d like to point out that Google’s top recommended search query for ikebowen is currently miserable failure. I’m unsure why, but not surprised – they’ve recommended stranger things than this.

And now, I shall begin.

The last few days managed to pack in more than enough material for… well, a few entries. For the time being, I’ll leave you with an overview and a few pictures, with the promise that I’ll be expounding on the details of both in a bit.

  1. Saturday/Sunday: “The Resurrection Celebration: Broken For You” (play); Family/Easter
  2. Sunday/Monday: Chicago/IIT
  3. Monday: a highway construction site in Stevens Point

Driving back from Chicago, we stopped at a highway construction site outside of Stevens Point. My grandparents live on some land off 51, and the DOT’s requisitioned a parcel of it for roadway expansion.

This doesn’t effect me personally much; I’ve not been able to empathize with their frustration. But my dad’s reaction to what they’d done to the land… I think changed that.

He grew up there, see. He was my brother’s age, hunting with his dad in the woods. Getting the first deer and all that. Memories. To see the forest where he spent his childhood, now razed to the ground and in piles… I can’t imagine.

“The ground over here is rocky – we weren’t able to do a whole lot with it. Didn’t have the equipment to clean it out or get over the rocks. The machines they have now can do it easily, but with the little tractors… I built a road there. Took dad’s tractor through the woods and used the claw in the back to scrape the ground. There was a lever, around at the back, and I made a path around the rocks, scraping the ground.”

He made a road. It wasn’t nearly as random as it might sound. He’s standing there, remembering the effort he put into a path through the trees with the equipment at hand. Spending hours on it. And now watching the Ponssees tear through the ground like water, erasing memories with hydraulic precision and power.

Because it’s not the land, so much. It’s remembering what you did there, and what it took to pull it off. Remembering what you made your life of, and then seeing the machine that is the world tear it into pieces, fueling someone else’s next step forward.

Trees line the quiet streets of Two Rivers, an all-American city thatâ€™s surrounded on three sides by majestic Lake Michigan. In the center of town, gracious old buildings frame Central Park, where young and old alike gather for festivals or just to sit and talk. Customers shop at well-kept stores and are greeted with friendly smiles, while modern factories provide economic stability to the community and offer a secure lifestyle. Throughout the city, visitors can find comfortable, well-appointed lodging and restaurants that serve every kind of fare, from fast food to gourmet meals.

Never mind what the official site says, my cousins live there. ‘Tis enough.

We spent Easter and the day before with a branch of the family that I haven’t seen for some time. Two Rivers is up the Lake Michigan coast from Manitowoc and south of a town cleverly named “Two Creeks”.

So. We met up with most of the group at the theatre. It’s an actual performance venue, and several of the area churches had rented it for something like the 34th annual Resurrection Celebration play (this year subtitled “Broken For You”). It was… really an excellent production. My uncle portrayed the Christ. Powerfully done.

The Easter service the next day was also at the theatre, simply to hold the people that come. Again, an excellent service. Inspired. The salvation offer was presented at one point. Honestly, one of the coolest things I’ve ever seen is a person taking a step towards God.

This next set is from the lake. I think I set a personal record for photo exposures per minute.

A slow strangle with your feet on the floor
I’ve got 14 angels and we’re sleeping alone
In the back of a cave, where the rest of us go
To feel normal

I call baby up, leave me alone
I’m in pain but I won’t let you band-aid my wound
I am mad at a stage where I can’t even handle my own

Give me a quiet mind and I…
I love you
You give me a quiet mind and I…
I love you
Until the end

Give me strength to be kind… to combine
All the good things in life that were so hard to find
But I have and I won’t let them go like I do with my friends

Still hearing voices, from front, from behind
They’re the reasons I choose when to live, how to die
When to cast, when to reel
When to buy, when to steal
When to fiend for the friends that taught you
Being inappropriate will

Give me a quiet mind and I…
I love you
You give me a quiet mind and I…
I love you
Till the end

Right, it’s been awhile. And I still haven’t said anything about IIT. Ergo:

We (meaning my dad and I) visited the Illinois Institute of Technology on Monday. The itinerary was fairly basic – meeting with an admissions counselor, and a campus tour. Lunch on the house.

It became rather more interesting directly upon our arrival to the campus, when we realized that neither of us had a map or any idea of where to park. After paying for parking in one of the several lots marked “Visitors”, an affable-ish black security guard (who fulfilled every one of the stereotypes that are running through your head – I’m sorry) pointed us in the direction of the main building.

Now, the main building houses a few different things, and the only one of immediate interest seemed to be the financial aid office. Somehow the secretary decided that we should have a meeting with a financial aid counselor (I still don’t know why… all we wanted was the admissions office), but I fortunately found a spot to print off the email from whoever had set up our visit. To Perlstein Hall we go.

Sparing you the details from the admissions meeting, I will say that my impression was very favorable. IIT is no MIT, but if you cut MIT roughly in half and slapped it in the midwest, it might come close. And they have an Internet Communication major. What’s not to like?

On to the tour:

All in all… hrm. I like this school. And I think I’d feel good about going here. Which is significant – I felt no such thing for either NWC or Madison.

So… I’ll keep you posted. But I might end up in Chicago next year.

AllOfMP3.com is an online music store based in Moscow, Russia which was founded in 2000 by Mediaservices, Inc. The store sells music encoded in standard, non-protected audio formats at a significantly lower cost than other online music stores. (Wikipedia)

Now, I love this site. I used it for months. When you can buy music for .10usd each, you appease the part of you that doesn’t want to steal music outright while satisfying the other half that doesn’t want to spend 40% of your income on x albums.

That said, I miss using the site. It beats eMusic, iTunes and the rest hands-down for site design, catalog scope, price and usability. And it doesn’t force fricking DRM onto everything that’s purchased.

But while you save 90-odd cents by using the site, there is an ethical cost. No money is paid to the labels that fund the artists. AllofMP3 does pay royalties to ROMS, but this Russian entity isn’t generally recognized by record labels. The by-the-book workaround to this is straightforward: when a US visitor purchases a track from the AllofMP3 catalog, they import it from a foreign country for personal use. This, technically, is legal.

But ethically? As far as I know, all that the site owners have to do is purchase albums, rip the music for the encoders to use, and rake in $30 million every year from the people sick of iTunes and the RIAA (source).

Oh, yes, the RIAA. Now, aside from their efforts to eliminate counterfeit CDs (MPAA-style), they’ve ticked off quite a few people. 531 individuals offering music on file-sharing networks were nailed in the last round of lawsuits. Yet, for all that the RIAA seems to have the music industry’s blessing, some still believe that the RIAA and its ilk will meet there doom. EMI’s dismissal of DRM in their iTunes catalog is a positive sign for those hoping a future with less FairPlay and Limewire.

There isn’t a whole lot more to say here, as volumes have been written elsewhere on this subject and everything connected to it. Bringing ‘er back around to AllofMP3, though (I’m getting offtopic and haven’t really made a point yet), let me share with you this exchange from the AllofMP3 blogs:

14. by Wes – US, 27 December 2006, 18:42
Why are people so resistant to change. Change is good. If millions of people are visiting and using Allofmp3, why not figure out why it is so successful? In addition to the low prices, there are additional features and musical selections that other sites do not offer (iTunes) that attract me to the site. Please keep up the good work Allofmp3 and I hope the RIAA realizes that the youth are going to rise up against it (your days are numbered).......

18. by Stewart, Australia, 27 December 2006, 19:14

“I hope the RIAA realizes that the youth are going to rise up against â€¦” Yeah right Wes, dream on dude. So you come from America right. And what percentage vote in elections in your country? Fifty percent that’s how many. I don’t exactly see the youth of any western country rising up. (Except perhaps the French but they do that all the time.)

There isn’t one mainstream Western politician who gives a fig about about allofmp3.com. Likewise, most politicians don’t really understand the issues behind copyright. And when the record companies tell them it will lead to industry unemployment they’ll shaft allofp3, Kazaa, Limewire et. alia.

For crying out loud. Your country has lost over 3000 soldiers in Iraq. Do we see mass protests? No! Do we see Americans demanding subsidised medicine? No. Do we see Americans dumping their gas guzlers and making do with one car instead of three? No! And you think that American youth are rising up against the RIAA whilst at the same time being sued into history? A big fat NO!!!!

My father, an American vet had a saying: “People get the government they deserve.” You got George W. Bush: a liar and a cheat.

If you think it’s any different in Australia forget it. We’ve got John Howard (and he’s a rascist AND a liar and a cheat) and his government has just criminalsed copyright breaches. And Tony Blairâ€¦another liar.

Copyright is slowly dying out. It will take another decade or so. And what’s doing it is the power of technology. Eventually DRM and copyright will become a thing of the past. But the youth rising up. Forget it. In the West if there was an attempt at revolution most people would stay at home and watch it on television. If they thought it interesting they might email some of the footage to their friends.

post_title: And this is the sixth grade...
final_content:
We’re having a garage sale sometime between now and November. It promises to lie on the scale ahead of the sandwich stand I decided to run one day (age 9) and just behind the 1939 World’s Fair, which should explain why we’re pricing items now.

And while running through boxes collected in the second grade and finding considerable amounts of spare change (not all of it American, oddly), Abbey found my sixth grade yearbook.

Sixth grade. Forever ago. Only six years, yes, but that’s a third of my life at the moment (gah, how does 18 qualify as ‘adult’?). It’s hard to even remember what happened there in the halls of what was then James Williams Junior High – none of this Middle School nonsense. Back in the days when the worst crime imaginable was painting the Hodag’s eyes red and a five-point demerit was equivocal to a death sentence. No recess for you.

And I’m flipping through the photos. Seeing occasional signatures, good wishes from friends and the sub that happened to be at school that day.

But it’s weird. For all that junior high brings out the worst in kids (ish), everyone seemed so… innocent. And now… I don’t want to say that they’re/we’re not, but that’s kind of how it is. Six years later.

Ha. This girl’s smiling. … She never does that anymore.

Ah, hello. Your hair has improved, but you’re one of the ones that looks precisely the same as you did then. Not a bad thing.

Hrm. Were you gay then too?

Drugs.

Transferred? I don’t remember you.

Ach. Your house burned down two years later.

Yeah, you run your own site now. Like Something Awful combined with b3ta as performed by a solo high school kid. Well, no. Not ‘kid’ anymore.

Oi… yes. I loved you once. Or thought I did. Hooray for hormonal rushes.

I can’t remember. Did you tell me about the teacher caught with porn? Gah. Even then…

Band geek meets thespian. You’re a great actor. But you don’t smile now any more than you did then.

[ smiles ] You still make me happy.

Ohhh dear. You were my best friend for… a long time. You died this year. Just down the highway from my house. I… I’m sorry? (What do you say?) I wish I had stayed by you.

Ha… Charismatic as ever. Your signature was loopy and practiced – I think it still is. Though your haircut has followed fashion.

Twins? I used to tell you apart by your shoes – figured it out by that time, though.

:D I wish I had met you then.

The girl that no one liked. May the world be better to you than it was then. I still like you.

Aaannnnd you. I was in a play with you. You had a crush on me then. Oddly, though I suppose no one seemed to care how I flipped between wannabe white-boy punk and Ivy-League-for-preteens at the time. [ grins ] And you’ve changed. The travel was good for you, I think. The substance abuse, less so.

Back to sixth grade. People change in six years. Or, well, maybe they haven’t. Maybe they’re just more experienced. The trouble-makers end up in minor court. The student council members earn the scholarships and head east. The ones who looked questionable have probably ended up that way, victims of social profiling. This is America.

I don’t miss sixth grade. Ha, that’s a ridiculous notion. But I guess I miss the past. Probably everyone does. You don’t want to go back, but you miss parts of it. The people you knew. The people that people were – not the people that they’ve turned out to be. Did they have a choice?

…

Did you?

——

Passed out on the overpass
Sunday best and broken glass
Broken down from the bikes and bars
Suspended like spirits over speeding cars
You and me we’re kings over the parkway tonight
And tonight will go on forever while we
walk around this town like we own the streets
and stay awake through summer like we own the heat
Singing "everybody wake up (wake up) it’s time to get down"
(everybody, everybody wake up it’s time to get down)
And when I pass the bottle back to Pete
on the overpass tonight, I bet we laugh

I’m gonna stay eighteen forever
So we can stay like this forever
And we’ll never miss a party
cause we keep them going constantly
And we’ll never have to listen
to anyone about anything
cause it’s all been done and its all been said
we’re the coolest kids and we take what we can get

Soco Amaretto Lime (Brand New)

Northern Arizona University
Now, to be fair, it’s my fault. I gave them my address. Indeed, I started the application of my own accord.

But they’ve hunted me.

March 15 I just want to remind you that the deadline to submit your application to Northern Arizona University is right around the corner …

March 24 According to my records, I haven’t received your Personal Advantage Application to Northern Arizona University yet. This “Personal Advantage Application”, by the way, seems to be a thing of special pride to the Admissions office. Every single message extols its virtues, including such things as no application fee, or no essay. And also a one-week scholarship decision.

March 30 The deadline to submit your Personal Advantage Application is this Sunday, April 1. I hope you use this weekend to complete and submit your application…

April 1 Today’s your deadline to submit your Personal Advantage Application. Apply before midnight tonight and take advantage of these exclusive benefits…

April 2 You might think that they’d leave me alone, having missed the deadline. No. I didn’t see your Personal Advantage Application to Northern Arizona University among those that were submitted last night before the deadline … but since yesterday was a Sunday, I’m going to give you another day to submit your application. … What? What kind of excuse is that?!

April 7 So, I didn’t apply, even given the gratuitous one day extension. But look what arrives in the mailbox: Because you’re one of the candidates I selected to apply using the Personal Advantage Application, I’m extending your deadline to apply to Northern Arizona University. Your new deadline is April 15. APPLY NOW!

April 12 I’m writing to you because I really want you to apply to Northern Arizona University … but the deadline for you to apply with your Personal Advantage Application is this Sunday, April 15.

April 15 By this point, I’m annoyed. But, okay, it’s the 15th. One last reminder. Isaac, be sure to apply before midnight with your Personal Advantage Application today to make sure you get priority class registration at Northern Arizona University. Fair enough.

April 16 Today, I receive the following email (comments in italics):

Dear Isaac,

Last night was a busy one at Enrollment Services! Oh? We received a lot of Personal Advantage Applications before the midnight deadline. Shame I missed that. Silly me.

I was disappointed not to see your application among them, Isaac. You were selected to receive this exclusive, streamlined application because I believe you would achieve success here at Northern Arizona University … Is this a guilt trip?

… and that’s why I’m giving you one more day to submit your Personal Advantage Application and still receive all of its benefits. OH DEAR LORD

Bleh. /me feels nauseous.

——

Anyway. Council elections were today – Michelle Mays will serve as President with Ben Mixis as Vice. Rahul Jain won the position of Secretary, opposite Dan Barbian the Powerful Treasurer. I think I feel comfortable with them taking over. May they lead the Council on to new and exciting heights.

shopping list

1× 1’x5’ chrome grid panel (10.25usd at Palay)
or whatever size/color, really

2x chrome wall-mount bracket (1.00usd each at Palay)
also available in white, black…

35x clever clips (0.23usd each at Palay)
if you order everything from Palay, getting 35 of them will just put you over 20usd – thus avoiding the service charge for small orders

total: 20.30usd

other supplies

4x drywall fasteners
4x screws (that fit the fasteners…)
drill/bits
rag
pencil

assemblage (really simple)

  1. Decide where you want the gridwall to end up, and whether it should be hung horizontally or vertically. Mark the wall through the brackets’ screw-holes, making sure that the marks are level. (If you go horizontal, like I did, the brackets should be roughly at eye level.)
  2. Grab the drill and put holes through the drywall (I’m assuming drywall – if you’ve got something else, I assume you can deal with it). Insert the fasteners and screw the mounting brackets in.
  3. Hang the gridwall.
  4. Admire. Use the clips to hang photos and such. Classy, no?

friday, april 20
So. The decision has been made. I sent a letter of declination to Madison yesterday; left a message at Northwestern. Still have to tell the National Merit guys.

But yeah – the housing deposit went in with the acceptance form a few days ago. IIT it is.

And I think I’m excited, actually. Despite the tone I’m writing in just now (caffeine + antidepressants, you know). IIT really seems like… the perfect school. Central location in a major US city, great architecture on campus (let alone around Chicago), easy access to public transportation. A undergrad degree in Internet Communication, at less the cost of going to Madison (net of scholarships). Awesome dorms, great food service. Not too far from home.

It’s kind of hard to believe that… well, yeah. I had virtually nothing to do with this. Yes, I applied. But that was a fluke – the application was short and free. What the heck… If Madison burns down, I’ll have somewhere to go. The acceptance package came in a few weeks; didn’t pay much attention. But then the aid offer showed up, and that really couldn’t be ignored.

So we started looking more closely at this IIT place. People who know of it only have good things to say, and it’s been around (as Armour Tech) since the late 1800s. Great programs, great people. It didn’t show up in any of my school searches, no one mentioned it to me. Like I said – an apparent fluke that’s turned out really, really well. Thanks, God.

So – it’s done. Set. Decided. I’ll be in Chicago this time next year.

today’s afterthought
Uncertainty is what frightens. The definite isn’t terrifying.

Linkin Park / Reanimation

Just to continue the trend of not posting my own stuff, here are a few items of interest –

——

Fascist America, in 10 easy steps

If you look at history, you can see that there is essentially a blueprint for turning an open society into a dictatorship. ... As difficult as this is to contemplate, it is clear … that each [step] has already been initiated today in the United States by the Bush administration.

The Brit’s point of view. :) This reminds me, there was something on The Now Show about the US… I’ll have to post that later.

[ read the article ]

——

Code for a flight simulator, in the shape of a Cesna

No way to summarize this – see for yourself.

——

The Olympiad of Misguided Geeks at Worse Than Failure Programming Contest

As only Worse Than Failure could orchestrate.

Unlike other programming contests, the goal of the OMGWTF contest is not to flex your algorithmic muscles and solve some abstract computational problem like you might in an ACM contest. Nor is it like the International Obfuscated C Coding Contest; in fact, writing code like that would be a surefire way to lose this contest. Instead, the goal of the OMGWTF contest is to solve an incredibly simple problem using the most obscenely convoluted way imaginable. And for this first contest, the simple problem is to build and implement the logic for a four-function calculator.

[ check out the contest ]

——

Control multiple computers with a single keyboard and mouse

Yes, I know it’s called KVM. But that’s hardware. Check out the opensource software solution, and the walkthrough from Hack Attack.

——

Staple remover

At first glance, a fairly ordinary Wikipedia article. Until you see the heading “staple remover gymnastics”.

Office personnel, in particular, cubicle workers, sometimes fiddle with staple removers while talking on the phone. This practice developed into a more organized form of entertainment known as staple remover gymnastics.

[ read on… ]

——

Connectile dysfunction

It’s not what you think. Or, well, maybe. But Sprint can help. (And oddly, Wikipedia doesn’t have an article on this yet. Now’s your chance.)

——

And finally, ghettocooler.net

I don’t really have any reason for recommending this except for the tagline: It’s like myspace, digg, and cnn all in one site!

[ go now ]

9:14 am, psychology
Oi. [ yawns ] I fell asleep in front of the computer in my room at around 5:30 yesterday. (Not as weird as it sounds if you know how my room is laid out.) Woke up once for a half hour, went back to sleep. Until midnight. I was confused, upon waking up – it was dark, and no one was up. So I went back to bed. That’s like… twelve hours of sleep. Wonderful.

1:19 am, work
I love my sr. boss. All the more because he refers to it as American Telephone & Telegraph. Not AT&T.

3:27 pm, work
Back from school. It’s interesting – to be “back”, for me, means “at work”.

Anyway. Some sort of calamity at school – a threat, by the sounds of it. The staff can’t say anything, obviously. (This bothers me.) No backpacks allowed, no large purses. Only enter/exit through the front door. I’m guessing bomb threat, but… bah. If there was any serious danger, I assume hope we’d be sent home.

Played calc football during fourth hour. “Right, run x=10 until the intersection with the integral of sin(x), then head back in the direction of the fourth quadrant”. Good stuff. We’re challenging the stats class to a game of kickball. “Those students who think that they’re taking a math class… Ha! Integrate this!”

4:57 pm, about to leave
Eeee. I’m in a really excellent mood. /me sighs

[16:31] [Anthony]: what the…
[16:31] [Anthony]: ENTERTAINMENT
RHINELANDER BLOOD DRIVE
[16:32] [Anthony]: right on rhinelanderdailynews.com
...
[16:33] [Anthony]: >.<
[16:34] [Anthony]: I don’t think “Entertainment” is the correct heading for a blood drive…

The best defense against the atom bomb is not to be there when it goes off. British Army Journal

The principal told the school yesterday at 2:50pm that an “inappropriate message” had been found, and that the administration was working with the sheriff’s department to sort it out. Additionally, no backpacks or large bags would be allowed. You may enter and exit only through the front doors.

The obvious conclusion to make was that there was a bomb threat. Forget this “inappropriate message” stuff; if they’re not allowing large bags, it’s a bomb. You can fit a gun in your pocket.

In a similar fashion, the principal made an announcement today at 11:10am, saying what everyone had guessed – there is, in fact, a bomb threat. What wasn’t expected was the date – May 7. Now tell me, May 7? That’s more than two weeks from now.

For what purpose would a hypothetical bomber make a threat and leave the powers that be with more than two weeks to mull it over? ... A demand? Something that admin would need two weeks to decide to comply with? And what could you demand from a high school anyway? If such a bomber just wanted to do the school in, he’d have done so already – no warning needed.

Unless he wanted to inspire fear. (Which he’s probably achieved, to some extent; kudos to admin for keeping their heads about them.) But why? Why why why why why?

[15:28] [Anthony]: what has happened to humanity?

addendum

This was in the Daily News:

According to Dr. Roger Erdahl, superintendent of the Rhinelander School District, the inappropriate message, which he referred to as a â€œthreatâ€ was made in writing and delivered Wednesday.

Made in writing and delivered. Does this not sound like a threat with a point? Not just a prank?

Interestingly, the public records indicate that someone will be going to court for a past bomb scare. I’m fairly sure that this is the guy responsible for a threat… last year(?) at the high school. He’s still a student, at any rate. Interesting that he’s going to court now, at the same time that a new threat is present.

If you haven’t heard this yet (and even if you have, I suppose), Linkin Park is releasing Minutes to Midnight on May 14.

Because of this, it’s probably still okay for me to toss out a review of what is still their latest album – Reanimation. I bought the thing at Walmart the other day on a whim. 7usd-something, down from 14.

1: Opening (Mike Shinoda)
The album opens with an excerpt from KRWLNG. Moody, introspective. Drawn-out strings topping an audioscape-style progression. Sets the mood for the album.

2: Pts. Of. Athrty (Jay Gordon)
The mix for this track is considerably more edgy than the original. As mixes go, it’s not terribly original – the original elements remain more or less intact and the song’s progression is untouched. It’s not bad in that it expands on the original’s mood without sacrificing any impact, but as a mix, it’s not that great. C+.

3: Ente E ND (KutMasta Kurt)
The mix artist should not be using the song as a plug. D.

4: Chali
Linkin Park tosses in a few skits with this album. Not full-blown skits, just thirty-second clips from an answering machine. ... Why?

5: FRGT/10 (Chali 2na)
Not a lot to say here. It annoys me when multiple (and drastically different) vocalists are in one song, especially when a secondary vocalists makes up new lyrics. Now, granted, it’s a remix. But still. Influence from uninspired rappers armed with synths and drum machines doesn’t do a lot of good. B.

6: P5hng Me A*wy (Mike Shinoda)
Directly contrary to what I just finished saying, Mike does a decent job mixing in his own vocals next to Chester’s. A nice job. They complement nicely (harmony bit on the chorus is great), and he doesn’t try to take over with extraneous verses. The guy takes the term “mix” and does it credit – he twists and flips the original around into something completely other, but still reminiscent of Hybrid Theory. Well done. A-.

7: PLC. 4 Mie HÃ¦d (Amp Live)
Meh. It’s okay. B.

8: X-Ecutioner Style (Black Thought)
Overly angsty? Not nearly melodic as it could be. All credit to Black Thought for mixing multiple songs together into something new, but I’m not too fond of this one. C.

9: H! Vltg3 (DJ Babu)
Right there next to track seven as far as the music is concerned (kudos for using a piano, but a loop?), though the lyrics are cool. My blood type’s Krylon Technicolor Type A. B-.

10: Riff Raff
Another skit. It fits in with the album, but I don’t know that these were necessary.

11: WTH>You (Aceyalone)
Feels a lot like something Linkin Park themselves would do with the song. Which makes sense – though Aceyalone is credited on the album cover, Mike Shinoda and Joe Hahn (both of Linkin Park) worked on this as well. B.

12: NTRMssion (Mike Shinoda)
A lot like the opening.

13: PPR: Kut (Cheapshot & Jubacca)
“Kut”. It works with the whole let’s-rework-every-song-title, but c->k is overused. Generally speaking, and speaking generally for the actual mix itself. C.

14: Rnw@Y (Backyard Bangers)
Removing half of the lyrics and re-doing the other half is creative, but won’t carry a song. It’s catchy, but… yeah, could be better. B-.

15: My<DSMBR (Kelli Alli)
I FREAKING LOVE THIS SONG. Beautiful. Better than the original. (And mixed by a female.) A.

16: Stef
Skit…

17: By_myself (Josh Abraham)
Also well done. Enough new elements were (tastefully) added to make it new, and enough of the old is present in new form to make it work well. A-.

18: Kyur4 TH Ich (Chairman Hahn)
I didn’t much like the original, either. Not that this is much like the original (definitely an instrumental line from Points of Authority in there), but… yeah. Respectable, but not something to cheer wildly over. C+.

19: 1stp Klosr (Humble Brothers)
Got a bit of mild gabber going on with this selection. Nice. A-.

20: KRWLNG (Aaron Lewis)
Appropriately, the album concludes with the full version of KRWLNG, a taste of which was given in the opening. This really is a beautiful song – the kind you can sit back with your eyes closed and get lost in. ... I’m unsure what else I can really say about this, except that it probably makes the album. (Along with My<DSMBR. :)) A.

Conclusion: would I buy this again? Probably. Or, well, perhaps not. Maybe I’d just buy a few tracks. Idk. Linkin Park deserves a lot of credit for pulling in musicians and pulling off an entire remix album. Not all of the songs are a perfect work of art, like most albums, but there are a few in here that stand out all the more. Cool.

unrelated oddity

post_title: America, as seen by the British
final_content:
The following is an audio clip from the April 6th edition of The Now Show. Credit for this particular bit goes to Marcus Brigstocke, who has my utmost respect. I’ve included the text transcript, because I am a geek.

Now, it has come to my attention that there have been accusations, and you’re going to find this hard to believe, but there have been accusations of an anti-American bias here at the BBC. I’ve searched my soul, and upon finding it almost entirely morally bankrupt and devoid of any sensible answers, I did a Google search instead.

It turns out that there are thousands of websites devoted to this exact subject. There’s one called “American Thinker”. Now… Come on, that’s not fair – it’s hardly my fault if you say “American” and you feel you have to point out you’re capable of thinking, but that is the name of the website. Anyway – their London correspondent Michael Morris said “America is being slandered minute by minute, hour by hour, every day of the year by the BBC. The BBC is the enemy of all right-thinking people who understand that the world is a safer place with the Trans-Atlantic Alliance intact.” He means, of course, the Special Relationship. Now I’ve said this before, but the Special Relationship basically boils down to the fact that we couldn’t be bothered to learn French. This is roughly what happened – one chap tried, but no, we’re going to be friends with those people over there. We don’t really like them and they’re further away, but seriously, what is the subjunctive tense? You see, I think we have a lot in common with the French. People seem to think the French have no sense of humour. Not true – the French wrote the European Constitution – and then voted ‘no’ on it. Now, that’s funny on about four different levels. It’s incredible.

So, if the BBC is anti-American, why would that be? Well, because America’s broken the world. Look, I can’t speak for the entire BBC – I’d like to, obviously, but because the BBC is a Communist organization, they don’t have kings, which is a shame really, I have to make do with six minutes on Radio 4 once a week. Anyway, I’m taking responsibility in looking at my own attitudes toward the United States.

I think the first thing to say is that I’m not… angry with America, I’m just… disappointed. And scared. And angry. America is a brilliant idea, it really is – it’s up there with marmite, the zit, and the internet. It’s fantastic – it’s just broken. If America was marmite it’d be full of margarine and toast crumbs. And for some reason, Guinness (it tastes the same; stop paying more for it!). If America was a zit, it would have the top third of somewhere very undignified trapped in it, so that no matter which way you pull, the agony and degradation can only get worse. If America were the internet, it would be BT (bloody) broadband.

Iraq is a good example of why I feel negatively about the US right now. Saddam Hussein was a bad man, connected with some incredibly dangerous people – Cheney, Rumsfeld, George Galloway. But seriously, right, here is a question for America and the UK to answer – how do you make Iraq worse than it was before? It was a mess before we were rushed in there by the hawks and neocon murderers in the White House. Conditions there were beyond awful. You can’t make something like that worse; it’s already at maximum crapness. That’s like getting a glass of Sunny Delight and putting Bailey’s in it. It’s like buying a Burberry cap and attaching a radio to the side – it’s already as bad as it can get! It’s like a Lloyd Webber musical and then asking Ben Elton to do the lyrics.

Yes, I’m critical of America because they’re in charge. We consume American films, television, music, literature, journalism, foreign policy, weapons contracts, food. Some of our children go out not wearing one, but two baseball caps at the same time. (You look like a tosser, and don’t stay “gangstah”, you live next to Nottingham.) In truth, I’m glad that America is the world’s only superpower. I’d choose it over China, Russia or Scotland any day of the week. (I include Scotland on that list because if the SNP have their way, who knows how powerful Alex Salmond may become? I think he may be a Jedi.)

It’s no good complaining we’re critical of the US – of course we are. They’re the ones running the show – that’s our job. They are the boss of the world, and if the hand that feeds is only giving you cheeseburgers and Starbucks then it needs to be bitten. We got our sailors back from the dreadful Ahmadinejad (“Oh, he’s a bad man; he is so naughty and immoral…”). Well, the US is still holding a large number of Iranians without proper charges or representation, and Guantanamo Bay is still full of people who have been there for five years.

So for all I mock and criticize the United States, I do it in the hope that it really could be the land of the free and the home of the brave. It’s a land of pioneering immigrants from everywhere – including space, if you believe people in the Midwest. It has boundless possibilities and opportunities for good. Whilst they may be responsible for git-wizards like Bain or the Microsoft paperclip (bendy-metal -------...), let’s not forget they gave us The West Wing, Ben & Jerry’s Ice Cream, and Elvis.

So while we in the UK are so far up America’s back passage that we can see the next doughnut as it’s forced down its swollen, gluttonous throat, let’s be critical. Let’s raise questions, and let’s watch Curb Your Enthusiasm because that is what the license fee is for. Thank you.

If you look at life long enough, one thing more or less becomes completely clear: something is not right. And in fact, something is quite wrong. (For those of you who caught that allusion, more power to you. And yes, there are support groups.)

Just look at it. People are born, live, and die. There are two ways to view this: each person is a miracle of life, or, look – they keep reproducing. The temptation to become completely cynical is, well, tempting. And if all you’re looking at is the planet Earth, then yes, cynicism is what any thinking person is probably going to end up with.

Which brings me to the subject of this particular entry. Why we believe. I’m going to bring up The Matrix again (“again”, yes, if you’ve been here a while) – remember the scene where the Architect is disseminating Neo as a human? “Hope. It is the quintessential human delusion.”

People hope. Why on earth?

Or okay, let’s start here. Hope. The desire to see something better in the future. This is weird, right, considering the finality and inevitability of death. People live and die, largely without making a scratch on the surface. Those who aspire to change the world might have some effect, but in the scheme of human history and all foreseeable future, it’s negligible. You’re quite literally one in a million.

So why hope? Why want to expect something better for you, insignificant and ultimately worthless you?

Because you don’t believe you’re worthless. Or don’t want to believe it, I suppose.

And this is why we believe. Believe in God, believe in the power of good, believe in something better, what have you. Because if life is all we have, we don’t matter. And we know it. On some level, we know it. Looking at life as it is, it’s largely futile. Get an education, a good job, provide for the kids. And then they do it over again. To what end? If there’s nothing to believe in, then nothing. That’s it – for all practical purposes, you’re a Walmart paperclip. Do something passive for while, then when your job is done, you’re gone. And there are always more like you.

A friend of mine made the comment that illusions are kind of necessary for sanity. I think he’s right, to the extent that if we don’t believe anything beyond the immediately concrete, our ability to function is out. And this point is of particular importance – if we can’t function without believing something intangible, what does that say? Is it an inherent flaw, or is it by… well, design?

And this gets into the debate about the existence of God. On this, I’m only going to say that it’s largely impossible to prove. Christianity and atheism are both nuts. Christians can’t prove God exists; atheists can’t prove He doesn’t. The finite cannot grapple with the theoretically infinite.

But I suppose that’s what it comes down to, isn’t it? The theoretically infinite. It’s an intangible, and is therefore entirely necessary. If there wasn’t something more, if this is all we’ve got, then screw life.

This is why we believe.

It’s quarter after nine, and I’m in Psychology. Everyone’s expressing their reactions to the memory project grade – either disappointment or confusion. And aggravation. :) Ah well. Fourth-term senior.

I’m breaking out fairly badly – hives covering my forearms. Odd. A friend-of-family recommended an allergy clinic in Lacrosse. Might have to check that one out. This has been happening for roughly a year with no obvious cause.

“Uncovering your personal defense mechanisms”. Right, I understand that it’s a good thing to delve into your own psyche, but writing down what you find and turning it in for a grade strikes me as something of an institutional invasion of privacy. Not that high school isn’t, but… yeah. Let’s leave that blank.

——

Post-spanish, at work. I looked out the window into the school courtyard. There was this girl sitting alone at one of the tables with her lunchbag. No one else was there, just her. And the robins. She waved at them. She’s one of the disabled students; I’m unsure what her particular disability is. Probably one of the saddest things I’ve seen as of late.

Thought: the strongest indicator of this generation’s screwed-up-ness is the music. When the “Today’s Hits” station on Slacker will only play Timberlake, Chris Brown, Akon, Diddy, Daddy Yankee and Mary J. Bilge, there’s a problem. Melodic rap on uninspired love themes is not music, even if you’re black.

——

I took the Jung test over at similarminds.com for psych.

INTP: “Architect”. Greatest precision in thought and language. Can readily discern contradictions and inconsistencies. The world exists primarily to be understood. 3.3% of total population.

Introverted (I) 65.52% Extroverted (E) 34.48%
Intuitive (N) 60% Sensing (S) 40%
Thinking (T) 66.67% Feeling (F) 33.33%
Perceiving (P) 61.29% Judging (J) 38.71%

I took the test no less than three times, deciding at the last to answer based on who I happen to be, rather than who I try to be. :/

But interestingly, the test script sent me off to introspectives.org after giving the test results. I’m intrigued.

Bla bla bla bla.

left front panel

  • Two punch cards for Magic Jo
  • Visa debit card
  • half of a one dollar bill, signed by Tommy, Riley, and another guy whose name I can’t read (feel terrible about that)

  • Driver’s license
  • Two school IDs; one from junior year, one from this year.
  • A post-it note with my health insurance number on it
  • The ID label from the World Affairs thing
  • Four Chinese fortunes –
    • “Be patient and love will find you when you least expect it”
    • “Your natural charm will attract someone special”
    • “Statistics are no substitute for judgement. Lucky Numbers 33, 12, 47, 19, 5, 32.”
    • “Your present plans are going to succeed.”

  • business cards

    • David Zach (futurist)

  • pictures
    • Calah
    • Barbi

    • Danielle
    • Sam
    • Meg
    • Jackie, randomly
  • insurance cards
    • American Family – Intrepid

  • little card: “God’s man. In God’s place. At God’s time. For God’s purpose.” (from Heather, I think)
  • two movie tickets
  • movie stub from Night At The Museum

  • gift card for Coffee Beans, Etc
  • receipts
    • Walmart x4
    • Stoxen’s

Let your curiosity be abated.

addendum
Should you find my wallet and are looking for something, don’t go by this list. Things got shuffled when I put them back.

It’s morning. Ech.

Six a.m. arrived waay earlier than it should have, or would have, had I any say in the matter. Self-help books will have no credence in my mind until they can properly teach the manipulation of time.

But yeah. Alarm went off, and despite my vow from the night before to get up on time, the sleep button found itself repeatedly shoved around and generally abused. NHS meetings are way too early.

So here I sit, falling asleep, but with a heightened awareness of doing so. I was late for first hour. Felt like the coffee would be worth it. “Twenty ounce triple iced latte, half a shot rum1, half a shot java.” My punch card was full.

Admin is considering banning drinks brought in to the school. This line of thinking is completely understandable and defensible – enough people bring in laced drinks to make it a problem worth addressing – but it would really tick off a lot of people. Me, for example. Caffeine = energy and a decent mood, more often than not, and I suspect that it’s the same for many others.

Though that brings up the issue of energy drinks. My take: the occasional doubleshot or Rockstar probably isn’t a bad thing, but downing Cocaine during class is ridiculous. Cocaine is ridiculous. Especially if you require medical attention because you passed out after drinking one.

Channel 12 came in and interviewed a couple students on the subject of energy drinks. I brought a Dew to the interview.

Banning foreign drinks would definitely cut down on the abuse of such drinks, but wouldn’t eliminate it entirely. This isn’t a pertinent argument, of course; banning tobacco hasn’t gotten rid of the wear mark in people’s back pockets. And stripsearching everyone in order to find a hidden Monster would be rediculous – can’t micromanage that kind of thing. Enacting the policy would help, yes, but… bah. Admin will lose a lot of face with the student body if they do this, and they’d have to win that back. Either by opening a coffee shop in the school or… idk, something. If you don’t want kids drinking vodka from a Dasani bottle, okay. That’s fine, and if you know it’s happening, it’s your responsibility to do something. But while Cocaine can seriously screw up your physiology, do they have the right to deny it to you? It’s your right, after all – they can suggest a healthy diet and serve balanced meals in the cafeteria, but can’t stop you from picking up McD’s instead.

But yeah. What do you do. The world would be simpler and probably better off if humanity had just done itself in at some point. But here we are, tenaciously clinging to a slightly unstable existence, and drinking vodka in class.

And coffee.

Enjoy the day.

1 “Rum” being the flavor, incidentally. Butter rum. It’s excellent, but really sweet. Hence the java.

addendum

That was freaking awesome.

When you try your best but you don’t succeed
When you get what you want but not what you need
When you feel so tired but you can’t sleep
Stuck in reverse

And the tears come streaming down your face
When you lose something you cannot replace
When you love someone but it goes to waste
Could it be worse?

Lights will guide you home
And ignite your bones
And I will try to fix you

And high up above or down below
When you’re too in love to let it go
But if you never try you’ll never know
Just what you’re worth

Lights will guide you home
And ignite your bones
And I will try to fix you

Tears stream down on your face
When you lose something you cannot replace
Tears stream down your face
And I

Tears stream down on your face
I promise you I will learn from my mistakes
Tears stream down your face
And I

Lights will guide you home
And ignite your bones
And I will try to fix you.

Coldplay

post_title: hola, for lack of anything better
final_content:
before school
Eee. Once again, and infallibly, it is morning. Probability would have it that at some point, six ay em would show up and it wouldn’t be morning, but today is not that day.

in spanish, not doing homework. again.
I read something somewhere about a theory in which two solids coming into contact repeatedly ad infinitum would theoretically fall through each other at some point. Can’t find anything directly related to that anywhere.

Though interestingly, Sra knows a ton about physics. An interesting character, that one. ... Yeah. Interesting that she’s a spanish teacher and not a physicist.

So. It sounded to her like harmonic resonance, only applied to molecular solids instead of waves (so kinda like quantum harmoic oscillation, without actually knowing anything about it). And after trolling wikipedia for a while, that’s about what I came up with. Atomic coherence is more or less as close as I got – when the electron spin of multiple atoms are aligned, they can pass through each other (the Rabi cycle, from what I can tell).

Everything that I could find on the subject outside of Wikipedia (excepting q/a) seemed rather the-aliens-are-coming-esque.

So… yeah… we’re going over self-actualization and the like in psychology. Why we aspire to greatness, and why we don’t. What’s needed for ambition, and the conflict between self-perception and potential. I printed out why we believe, partly because it could plausibly be applied as extra credit (no motivation during first hour = less than desirable grade), partly to see what reaction Nelson would have to it. He also is an interesting guy (though I suppose hs teachers are generally like that). I decided for a while that I didn’t much like him (during the days of econ… just goes to show how carefully motivation needs to be examined), but I’m reevaluating that. I can see more of him in this class than in econ. See, based on more than only how he tries to act. Which methinks is what econ was – an act. A respectable act – it’s probably difficult to get adolescents to care about the economy – but an act nonetheless. Hrm.

Ah. I’ve fixed the bug in the search results. That box up in the corner (â†‘â†’) is a search thing, btw.

Off to work…

In preparation for The Garage Sale, someone found this old parameter perambulator (geek geek geek geek…) in the ceiling of the garage itself. Odd what can be found in unexpected places.

So, like anyone might, I took it to the basement where my lighting stuff is set up and took random pictures. Enjoy. Pretty sure MYDC0693 is my favorite.

I was at Hodag Park the other night, sitting by the lake. Watching the water. For the record: it’s still cold. Numb feet.

It’s interesting, watching the waves intersect with each other in a perfectly orderly fashion. Like trig and physics, being played out on the lake. It crossed my mind that all of this happens naturally – all the laws of nature carried out without any perceptible maintence, while programmers and designers work for years perfecting rendering engines and ai’s to replicate what happens every day. Amazing that we work so hard to imitate the ordinary, and that it takes so much to model it.

Which brings me to a theory: reality exists in the mind of God. I don’t give a whole lot of weight to this, but it’s worth thinking through.

So. Reality happens – laws of physics and whatnot. Every action has an equal and opposite reaction, etc. We write simulations, right, that replicate this kind of thing. Virtual reality, if you will, where laws are followed, but movements have to be calculated and put into play. The better the processor, the closer to realtime such a simulation can get. But the simulation doesn’t happen on its own – every action and reaction is calculated.

Now, there’s no obvious evidence that what we live in is anything like this. From our point of view, you throw a rock and it goes off and hits the ground without anyone having to think through the motions and ensure that the physics are carried out. But does that make sense? If we were a part of a virtual reality simulation, would it appear the same way? Things wouldn’t seem to be calculated and put into action, they’d seem to happen “naturally”.

So this kind of plays off of the theory that for every n-dimensional being, there’s always an n+1 being out there. We create virtual reality where there are rules, but everything must be calculated and maintained as the rules are followed. Mightn’t it be the same for our reality? What if God is the renderer, if you will, that powers our world?

photo by patator at sxc

Right, it’s Monday. And what you see above is from a screenshot – a side project called Workplace Confessional. It will be cool. Promise.

Anyway, Monday… The bomb threat date being today, none of us (speaking of my hs sibs) went to school today. Honestly, I wouldn’t have felt good about dropping them off at a school where there was any elevated chance of danger. ... Not in the least.

So, they stayed home. Slept in, enjoyed the day.

I went to work.

Now, you have to understand. Monday. Having the day off from school was nice, yeah, but spending it at work… well, could have been worse, I suppose.
