It appears that your account was accessed by an unauthorized third party and used to place bids.

Someone jacked my eBay account and bought… wow, a lot. Men’s black Prada swimshorts, women’s Prada heels, a Prada phone case (since when does Prada make phone cases?), a women’s Prada tshirt, (more) men’s Prada swimshorts (our hacker has a 34-inch waist), and a little pair of Agatha Ruiz de la Prada girl’s pink shoes.

They’re all listed in the UK (except the phone case – that was in Hong Kong). Evidently we have a British guy, married (or not), with a daughter. Or, as a co-worker noted, a cross-dressing transvestite pedophile.

Agent 9:29:55 AM
Most accounts are taken over when someone answers a “spoof” or “phishing” email. Please be cautious of links received via email, including those received in your My Messages.

It mildly alarms me that the guy was able to get my password… I’m positive that he didn’t get it through a phish attempt. Couldn’t have guessed it without going to a whole lot of trouble… it’s a larger number of random characters. The only way anyone could have gotten it is… oh dear.

/me goes slightly white

warning
The following is geeky. If that’s not you, try the new-and-shiny photog section. There are pictures.

and now, our feature presentation
In theory, the following code should fill a hard drive to the brim.

while ( 1 < 2 )
file_put_contents( "foo.txt", rand( 0, 1 ) . "n" );

However, in most cases, it will not. This is because of the friendly little max_execution_time that a good server technician will keep firmly set at 30 seconds. More power to them.

Except that it doesn’t seem to always work. Completely out of curiosity (okay, well, I wanted to see how much output I could generate), I ran the following code:

$foo = md5( $foo );
while ( 1 < 2 )
echo( "$foon" );

That’s not entirely correct, actually. I’m still running it. It’s been going for a good 10 minutes thus far. The output looks like this:

acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8
acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8

Good for absolutely nothing, except demonstrating that server operating parameters aren’t quite as set-in-stone as one might think. Interestingly, the script breaks (and by “breaks” I mean “works properly”) when echo is replaced with file_put_contents (or its PHP 4 equivalent), in effect writing the output to a file rather than to the browser. The execution time limit jumps in the way, as it should.

few minutes later
Had things gone as expected, this entry would have closed here with something like “x megs and counting”. Heh. Firefox crashed when I tried to copy what the script had thus far generated. Going to try this again in a more isolated environment…

If you’re so inclined, try running the following script and see how far you get.

header( "content-disposition: attachment" );
$foo = md5( "foo" );
while ( 1 < 2 )
echo( "$foon" );

33.7megs and counting, at 36kbps. That’s a lot of acbd18db4cc2f85cedef654fccc4a4d8.

days later
Running it again. 305.4mb, no sign of stopping.

I tried the following, just to see precisely how long it’d keep the game up:

header( "content-disposition: attachment" );
$foo = time();
while ( 1 < 2 )
echo( time() - $foo . "n" );

Didn’t work. Why PHP blows past the time limit with a fricking string but not with a calculated number is beyond me.
[I’m the one handling your three-million IRA…]

And thatâ€™s when the left side of my brain looks at the right and says,
Itâ€™s dark in here, and we may die.

A quote from Lewis Black, taken more or less completely out of context.

It’s Friday morning. Nathan stopped in last night, left around 11. It never fails – I take a sleeping pill, and Nathan calls. Heh. Great guy. He declined food on the grounds that he’s partially photosynthetic, which poses a problem when he works at the theatre.

Oddly, it feels like Monday again. This bothers me. Yesterday felt like Monday. Which is also bothersome, because it means that a single day can feel sufficiently enough like my entire weekend to throw me off. I guess that’s what working here does to you.

Sent a letter last night to the therapist I was seeing. I’m done with therapy – final decision. Not going back. Well, for a while. Maybe something in Chicago. It wasn’t hard to talk to the guy; just difficult to see a point or derive any benefit from doing so. There was the occasional epiphany, yes, but nothing that couldn’t have been achieved by talking to someone less expensive. … I hope my insurance covered all that.

There’s a sobe on the corner of my desk. Couple ounces left.

Anthony pointed me in the general direction of a beautiful revolution – blog.

tried so hard / and got so far

Curious phenomenon, that. Meaning blogging. Like… like an arena. (Excuse me while I wax contemplative.) An arena jammed with people, each one jumping and screaming and waving their hands, trying to get the attention of the others. There are collectives here and there – avoid that corner, that’s Myspace – and in a few spots there’s a person sitting alone against the wall, whispering to the madness.

The logic – logic, though? – is that there’s got to be someone in there who will listen long enough, just meet your gaze for a moment, to give your existence some kind of worth. Enough to let you think you mean something, anything, to someone else.

Why do they we try so hard to scrap significance from people like us? Why is the attention of a peer worth anything at all?

Heh. Hypocrite.

in the end / it doesn’t even matter

Ha, no. Our hero crashed and burned, and the series was ended. Forget the hero bit.

I caved. Added an ext3 and a swap partition to my laptop’s hard drive, threw in Ubuntu. I know. My first warning sign was having no idea where to open the terminal from… In my defense, installing Ubuntu was largely because of hook’s review of the os, and coming from a guy who scored more os’s than gf’s far before I did, it had some weight. (More power to you, man.)

Installed KDE without mishap, loaded it. I was pleasantly surprised that the OS worked well with my wireless card. My reaction was less positive at its near-total lack of communication with the sound device. The little audio level wheel works perfectly (a little level indicator even pops up), but no sound. Blast.

And it looks like I’ll need to be fixing that, because for some reason my Vista installation is toast. Lightly toasted, mind you – it’ll boot, but only up to the point where it loads the gui. It then, decisively, goes into a coma. Imagine toast in a coma. Yeah. That’s my laptop.

What’s exceedingly odd is that precisely the same thing happens with the Vista boot CD that the machine came with. It boots, but only until it loads the gui. This last time it managed to pull the cursor into action, but that’s it.

Blast.

So I’m downloading Xubuntu now, just because it’s cleaner and doesn’t come with several thousand preloaded packages. Methinks I’ll just install that as primary, tweak it as needed. Reinstall Vista somewhere. Wonder when someone’ll figure out how to use the Zune with Linux…

update
It’s fixed. And don’t get Xubuntu. The next article goes into further detail on both counts.

From youtube, via motionographer.

Oh, and don’t tell youtube (or blip, for that matter), but the youtube player is not the only option for displaying youtube video. Which is probably self-evident; they’re just flvs…

Try this:

<embed wmode="transparent"
src="http://blip.tv/scripts/flash/blipplayer.swf?autoStart=false&file={$videourl}"
quality="high" width="600" height="420"
name="movie" type="application/x-shockwave-flash"
pluginspage="http://www.macromedia.com/go/getflashplayer">
</embed>

Grab $videourl from kej.tw/flvretriever. Takes two seconds, and gives you the zen calm that comes with release from youtube’s obnoxious… yeah. Something. It’s just cleaner.

post_title: Adventures with an A200, Vista and Ubuntu
final_content:
part one – the mistake
One of the multitudinous differences (yes, that’s a word; I’m as surprised as you are) between Vista and XP is this fun little bootloader thing. Vista has its own bootloader.

This is probably entirely irrelevant, but I’ve chosen to place the blame for Vista’s current menopausal behavior squarely on the bootloader’s shoulders. Or boots, perhaps.

The mistake probably went as far back as ordering a copy of Ubuntu from Canonical, with such timing as it arrived more or less in time to fix its steely gaze upon my laptop while it was still shrinkwrapped. I had no choice, you see.

Popped in GParted, nudged the Vista NTFS partition off into the corner, added an ext3 and a swap, and installed Ubuntu. Worked brilliantly – recognized my wireless card and everything. Not finding quite everything I needed, though, I went back to boot Vista.

And encountered my very first Black Screen Of Death, which I affectionately refer to as the BLASOD.

part two – the second mistake
So – Vista wouldn’t load. To its credit, Vista did scroll the little loading graphic for a while before passing out. Kinda like making you a cup of tea before, say, shooting you in the forehead.

Me being the clever boy I am, I concluded that it should be easily fixed by first removing Ubuntu and then expanding the Vista partition to its original size. This was the second mistake. Bullets should not be removed with q-tips.

Ubuntu comes with its own bootloader, which upon installation maliciously takes over the MBR. The upshot of this is that, while you get geek points for having it there, its removal will render your other OS(‘s) completely crippled and gazing at you with that bleeding puppy look.

(Clarification: I have never caused a puppy to bleed in any fashion. Ever. But if I had, it would look like what Vista looks like now, only without twitching quite as much.)

So yes, I removed Ubuntu. But – clever me – GParted couldn’t expand Vista’s filesystem – it hadn’t been shut down properly. My bad.

part three – look! something shiny!
At this point, I’d more or less given up on fixing Vista and had more or less decided to pull my music and photos off of Vista and and reformat. Further, I had my eye on this fun little Xubuntu distro, which is like Ubuntu, but naked. I discovered this when it did not recognize my networking equipment out of the box.

Installed Ubuntu for the second time in hours, trying to ignore how self-righteous the three little people in the logo suddenly appeared. Blasted little people.

Which brings me to right about now, as I’m copying stuff from the Vista partition on over to Ubuntu in light of the impending reformat. The original plan was to back up to this 200gb NTFS drive I have, but I’d forgotten that Linux doesn’t play well with that particular format. Or vice versa. I’m banking on the fact that my Zune has all of my music on it. Something had better not go wrong there.

part four – /slap
It’s a good thing I’m uncertain, fearful, and in possession of a Windows XP boot disk. Or I just might have killed off Vista entirely.

I’m not I’m going to bore you with the important details just in case there’s anyone else out there trying to dualboot Ubuntu and Vista who’s discovered crcdisk.sys giving the system a bsod or a black screen. Yes, that last sentence was keyword-laden.

The solution, as revealed on the Ubuntu forums, is fairly simple. Boot to the XP disk, jump to the repair thing (hit R), choose the Windows installation in question, type in a random password three times (make sure you don’t use the correct password; that’d be bad), reboot. Boot to Safe Mode with Command Prompt (tap F8 a few times right as Vista starts). It’ll run into a brick wall of sorts when crcdisk.sys is loaded, which is fine. Let it churn. It’ll reboot at some point; Vista should then be fixed. Enjoy.

part five – the end
I’m an idiot. And I’m all thrown off now – Ubuntu doesn’t do cursor acceleration quite the same as Vista.

Slightly frantic, edgy. Might be the caffeine.

I’m at Anthony’s, waiting out the brunt of the storm.

And now I’m at work, 15 hours later, looking over a list of 20-ish items assigned to Team Intern. Trouble with seniority and geekishness is that you end up having to handle most of… whatever. We’re expected to be able to handle anything, but… bah, we can’t even get into the client management system. We’re interns. There’s no way…

Quiet now.

We lost power at the house last night; came on while I was sleeping.

My sobe is warm.

It occurred to me the other day. I want someone to mean the world to me.

Which is easy enough. I’ve done it.

But I want to mean everything back.

sigh

addendum
I made some toys… imgcolor.php and xmlmp3.php. The second one’s old; credit to Anthony for the idea. The first one’s in use over in the photog section. Neither of them has much of any practical use, I’m afraid.

This used to be our song. Do you remember?

I am thinking it’s a sign
that the freckles in our eyes are mirror images
and when we kiss they’re perfectly aligned
and I have to speculate
that God himself did make
us into corresponding shapes
like puzzle pieces from the clay

and true, it may seem like a stretch
but its thoughts like this that catch
my troubled head when you’re away
when I am missing you to death
when you are out there on the road
for several weeks of shows
and when you scan the radio
I hope this song will guide you home

they will see us waving from such great heights,
“come down now”, they’ll say
but everything looks perfect from far away,
“come down now”, but we’ll stay…

I tried my best to leave
this all on your machine
but the persistent beat it sounded thin
upon listening
and that frankly will not fly
you will hear the shrillest highs
and lowest lows with the windows down
when this is guiding you home

they will see us waving from such great heights,
“come down now”, they’ll say
but everything looks perfect from far away,
“come down now”, but we’ll stay…

listen to it over and over, remember the way you smiled

come down now
okay

The Postal Service

Few new additions to the photog collection. This shot’s from there.

pulls beneath the surface

It’s been raining on and off the last few days. The kind of weather that keeps me from concentrating at all unless I’m on a highway somewhere.

Tried to musick on the way home. Heh, failed. Not completely sure why – it was missing. ‘Missing’ in the context of action, like a projectile. Like throwing something and missing the target – it wasn’t hitting right.

Pulled over next to a field of… something. Not rye, some sort of grain. Got myself soaked walking through the stuff.

without a sense of confidence

Just tested a 129 at the High IQ Society; qualified for membership. I feel slightly bad about that, as I looked up the answer to the one about the author of In Cold Blood. And the location of the Festival de Cannes, which I should have known anyway.

It’s not like I’m joining, though – lowest membership package costs 79usd.

Why does an IQ test have knowledge questions?

post_title: and pull the covers over your head
final_content:
make it mine styrofoam

but you’ll shine and take it over

Don’t be afraid of the media player’s odd progress bar movement. Textpattern changed up some things with the upgrade that affect data transfer for downloads; I’m switching this player out for a different one soon anyway.

I’m at the office. The CFO brought in his kids (ages 1-6, I think) for lunch; he’s showing them the shredder. The kids were freaking out, but they’re getting better. “… Buh why you do dah doh?”

A woman called in the other morning, said someone called her house at six a.m., said “screw you”, hung up. Which is odd, as I can’t think of anyone on our team who would do such a thing. Sober, anyway. I looked her up; turns out that the woman in question had just done a mini-seminar for senior citizens in California on protecting yourself from financial predators. Oh, the irony.

trek your steps end
leave your imprints in reverse

… I really, really need to go for a drive. … I may go to Wausau today.

yeah… heh. There’s a story there.

i’ll try to make it mine

afterthought
And if you tried to subscribe earlier (little box down in the lower-right), you’ll need to do so again. My bad.

At the Barnes and Noble slash Starbucks in Wausau. The lady I opened the door for turned out to be one of the aids at my elementary school. Also, AT&T hotspots aren’t free.

Caramel frappuchino, extra shot of espresso. It’s been far too long, my dear.

Home architecture book, a copy of Wired. All a guy needs.

I love coffee.

A lot of nerds aren’t aware they’re nerds. A geek has thrown his hands up to the universe and gone, “I speak Klingon – who am I fooling? You win! I’m just gonna openly like what I like.” Geeks tend to be a little happier with themselves.
Patton Oswalt, quoted from Wired

I may have to get a subscription to this. Just for that.

Hokay. Tying up. My internet time is running out (blast you, AT&T), and I finished paging through that copy of Wired. I found a subscription card; 12 issues for 10usd. Wonder if I can ethically use that.

Man, there was a ton of cool stuff in this issue. Firefox has like 15 tabs open with things to go back and look at… Stay tuned.

Back to the road. I downloaded Year Zero while I was here; will be rocking that on the way home.

Fazoli’s. A slice of pepperoni and a… single breadstick. Yes, that’s all. … (He just said he’d see me at the window.)

Cheers.

tabs opened for further review

Twitter
This is actually cool. I had this idea – miniblogging. They stole it. >.< More power to them. (And hey – ping me.)

WIRED + LivingHomes = Wired Living Home
(Clever, no?) Sustainable with the best of technology. And you can live in it. … For 4 million usd.

The music library of Eric Holtsclaw
Found this purely by accident… or, well, not really. I was looking for the mp3s from Year Zero. This worked splendidly.

Wilf
Verb. Derived from the phrase, “what was I looking for?”.

Invisibility… hairbrush.
And it only works for the color red. :/

The Camera Phone Book
I saw a bit about a guy who did a phototour of the country with a cameraphone. Promotion for some cell provider. Now they’ve gone and made a book. Bah.

Monkey: Journey to the West
A stage opera, brought to you by the co-creators of Gorillaz (which evidently performed live via holograms at MTV Europe…)

Spoon. The band.
“With a history of stellar, no-filler records, Spoon has somehow topped themselves with Ga Ga Ga Ga Ga…”

FlipStart
A Vista micro-laptop. Shame that it looks like it came from the 80s.

Persuasive Games
Hacking the idle mind. Brought to you by Ian Bogost.

reCAPTCHA (speaking of utilizing wasted human cycles…)
Works like the old captcha system (all hail Luis), but this time, you’re actually digitizing books at the same time. Try it – it’s fun.

Trevor Paglen
Boldly photographing what he most certainly should not be. Or couldn’t be, if he was any less than forty miles away.

Reiser4
What arguably could have been the filesystem of tomorrow, had its creator not been accused of murder. Go on, read it – the story’s interesting.

Semapedia
Physical hyperlinks. … Be afraid.
from The Book of Bunny Suicides.

The lesson of NIN’s latest creation is the same as what your mother kept telling you when you were eight. “My boy, track order doesn’t happen by accident. Now eat your salad.”

The album plays like a reality show (assuming that you listen to your mother and go in track order). The husband crashes through the front door, raging about the office. Screaming about the state of things. Blinks, then is calm. Deep breath. Apologizes, gives her a kiss, and retires.

Never having heard any of NIN’s work, the first track left me slightly taken aback. Which is understandable, coming as I do from the influences of Linkin Park, the Benedictine Monks of Santo Domingo de Silos and Hilary Duff combined. It’s gabber, essentially, but with more subtle undertones than what you’d hear at di.fm.

And vocals. I’m not a fan of the vocals. By and large. When the guy’s melodic (e.g. The Great Destroyer), it’s not bad. When he goes monotone, it makes children cry.

I downloaded it, yeah; still deciding whether or not to buy the thing… It was sitting in my Amazon cart from earlier (sign up for our Visa card, get $30 off!). Might just get a few songs.

Not that you care terribly, but there you are.

> /me nudges Isaac
> dude. I just gotta say. You’re an awesome friend, I just wanted to say thanks.
> I dont know where that came from

That more or less just made my life. No one has ever said that to me, straight out of the blue, without sounding like they’re just returning a complement. I’ve had girls tell me I’d make a great boyfriend, but not for them, and far too many guys just say ‘we should hang out sometime’ and never call.

sigh

Ah well. Evidently I mean something now.

——

I’ve unexpectedly come across the photo from my second grade class. Mrs Baksic was cool.

Oh… you just found a boyfriend. Haven’t heard from you in years. You’re normal. You’re dead. Don’t remember you. I think you dropped out. Haven’t seen you since… sophomore year. Normal. Unknown. Most-likely-to-have-an-abusive-boyfriend. Unknown. Unknown. Unknown. Normal. Me. Fairly normal. Anger disorder? Consistently high.

sigh

All other factors aside, Wordpress still has one up on Textpattern for custom RSS feeds – a function with quite a lot of potential. Textpattern doesn’t technically offer this capability, but it’s fairly simple to construct an alternative. Step the First: Page/Section Open up the Textpattern control panel and scoot over to the Pages area (under Presentation). Create a new page (or copy an existing page); save it as myrss or something clever. Open up the Sections tab. Create a new section with the same name as your new-and-shiny page. After creating the section, find it in the section list and change the “Uses page” field to myrss. Twiddle with the other settings if you’re terribly bored; we won’t be needing them for anything. Step the Second: Constructing the Feed Back to Pages. Open up the myrss page. Delete everything in it, then copy in the following: 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<rss version="2.0" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"
xmlns:content="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/content/">
<channel>
<generator>http://textpattern.com/</generator>
<title><txp:sitename /></title>
<link><txp:link_to_home /></link>
<pubDate><txp:php>echo strftime( "%a, %d %b %G %T %Z" );</txp:php></pubDate>
<txp:article_custom allowoverride="0" form="myrss" limit="5" pgonly="0" section="blog" />
</channel>
</rss>
(Note: change the section attribute of txp:article_custom to whatever section you want to be pulling articles from. Also – the presence of the PHP bit means that PHP parsing must be enabled for this to work properly. You can set this in Admin -> Preferences -> Advanced -> Publish -> “Allow PHP in pages?”.) Save this, then move to the Forms tab. Step the Third: Custom RSS Items Open up a blank form (“Create new form”), then paste in the following: 
<item>
<title><txp:title /></title>
<description>
<![CDATA[
<txp:body />
]]>
</description>
<link><txp:permlink /></link>
<pubDate><txp:posted format="%a, %d %b %G %T %Z" /></pubDate>
<dc:creator><txp:author /></dc:creator>
<guid><txp:permlink /></guid>
</item>
Name it myrss (or something different; you’ll need to change the page if you go all creative here). Change the form type to “Article” and save it. Step the Fourth: Slack-Jawed Admiration You’re done, actually. Or nearly. Load up domain.com/myrss and gaze in wonder. Now take a step back. You’re here to trick out your feed, and thus far we’ve only created the framework. At this point, you can go back to the myrss article form and have your way with it – anything you put in into the <description> area will be used in the feed at /myrss (check my feed for an example). Article images are a common addition, but anything that Textpattern can do, your feed can use. (Note: Don’t mess with anything other than <description> unless you know what you’re doing, btw. Feeds break easily.) Epilogue: The Problem The only issue with this technique is the content headers. A feed validator will tell you that it’s being served as text/html, and that this is bad. In theory, tacking <txp:php>header( "Content-type: text/xml", true);</txp:php> on to the beginning of the myrss page would fix this, but it doesn’t seem to have an effect. If anyone has any brilliant ideas, leave a note and I’ll add it/them to this article. Mike has a plugin available that’ll take care of this – download it here. (Thanks, Mike) In the meantime As an alternative, running the feed through Feedburner will solve your problems (and add even more functionality, actually). Go in customized-Textpattern-rss peace. (And yeah, that photo up above is entirely unrelated.)

(audio only)

Come up to meet you
Tell you I’m sorry
You don’t know how lovely you are

I had to find you
Tell you I need you
Tell you I set you apart

Tell me your secrets
Ask me your questions
Oh, let’s go back to the start

Running in circles
Coming up tales
Heads on a science apart

Nobody said it was easy
It’s such a shame for us to part
Nobody said it was easy
No one ever said it would be this hard

(Oh, take me back to the start)

I was just guessing
At numbers and figures
Pulling your puzzles apart

Questions of science
Science and progress
Do not speak as loud as my heart

Tell me you love me
Come back and haunt me
Oh, and I rush to the start

Running in circles
Chasing tales
Coming back as we are

Nobody said it was easy
Oh, it’s such a shame for us to part
Nobody said it was easy
No one ever said it would be so hard

(I’m going back to the start…)

Coldplay

Things the little designer inside of me desperately wants:

Sonicum
(right, so this one is jointly desired by designer and audiophile)

Verbarius
(beauty. in a clock.)

——

Just took receipt of a nondescript grey plastic mailer with a Royal Mail shipping label adhered to the corner. There’s a custom’s mark on it, says “clothes”. It’s been sent through air mail.

This makes me nervous. Remember the eBay/Prada situation? One of the sellers involved mysteriously left me positive feedback… Though I paid her nothing, so I don’t see why she’d actually ship the Womens Prada T-Shirt BNWT in Black Sizes S & M NEW!! in question.

——

Man… I think I might actually hate life. (Clarification – ‘life’, not the people in it.) Just went through a slew of old… things… papers and cards and CDs from the last 18 years. If all of my untouched-for-more-than-a-month possessions were just burned, I really don’t think I’d have a problem with it. Might actually be for the best, as I have a terrible time every time I remember something that used to be important. Letters from the girl, cards from grandma, a CD with that rotating 3D lighthouse model that I wrote in raw POV-Ray script in sixth grade… Gah.

Here’s a print of a conversation with Anthony, an old Best Buy gift card that I should probably check the balance on before it gets tossed. Copy of Rainman from someone at work. Stack of Glyph Solutions business cards, email addresses from everyone in my cabin at Fort five years ago. This is interesting – a dual session CD that has the sound effects for a puppet show script from… idk, something for the kids at church. The data session has the runtime engine for RPG Maker.

These are recent. Copies from the English Language AP test. Synthesize six sources and write an essay on the effects of advertising. Analyze the strategies used by Scott Russell Sanders to develop his perspective on moving. Develop a position on the ethics of offering incentives for charitable acts. … Can’t believe I pwned that test the way I did.

sigh

Memories suck. Even good ones. I hate remembering things that aren’t anymore. Old friendships, old enemies, old loves. There’s always something coming on that’ll shove them out of their place and into the corner. I forget so many things, and that’s probably for the best. Though it just makes it difficult when I find things that bring them back.

in cards and flowers on the window
your friends all plead for you to stay

I was thinking the other night, looking at whoever that is on the other side of the mirror. All I really want is to sleep, and sleep without dreaming. Complete lack of any brain activity. This isn’t anything new; it’s why I take sleeping pills on occasion. What struck me was the thought process that followed as I wondered if I wanted to wake up.

Do I want to wake up? Would it be so terrible to just fall asleep and never have to get up again? There would be nothing to regret, nothing to miss. Just dark and nothing.

Well, okay. What about sleeping for, say, a week. Would you miss a week of your life? Probably not.

Right, okay. You wouldn’t miss a week of your life. This tells me that you’re not particularly attached to the day-by-day nature of… life. The little idiosyncrasies of existence.

Not terribly.

What about a year? What if you cut out a year?

It’s not like I remember much of last year. Live in the present and for the future.

A year’s a fairly big chunk of time.

Time is relative.

A week, a year, okay. What’s to stop you from scaling that to, say, the rest of your life? Would you miss the rest of your life?

——

At this point, the little conversation in my head stopped abruptly.

…

I’m only friggen eighteen.

Saw Transformers again, and realized, as I started to get emotional for no particular reason, that I (deja vu) really seem to be able to feel only when I am flooded with sound. Completely overrun with audio.

I’ve been writing random little notes in Textpattern for the last few weeks; just going to throw them all in now. Excuse me.

——

Just took receipt of a nondescript grey plastic mailer with a Royal Mail shipping label adhered to the corner. There’s a custom’s mark on it, says “clothes”. It’s been sent through air mail.

This makes me nervous. Remember the eBay/Prada situation? One of the sellers involved mysteriously left me positive feedback… Though I paid her nothing, so I don’t see why she’d actually ship the Womens Prada T-Shirt BNWT in Black Sizes S & M NEW!! in question.

——

Things the little designer inside of me formed a bond with upon seeing:

Sonicum
(right, so this one is jointly desired by designer and audiophile)

Verbarius
(beauty. in a clock.)

——

> /me nudges Isaac
> dude. I just gotta say. You’re an awesome friend, I just wanted to say thanks.
> I dont know where that came from

That more or less just made my life… not sure if the guy on the other end knew it. No one has ever said that to me, straight out of the blue, without sounding like they’re just returning a complement. I’ve had girls tell me I’d make a great boyfriend, but not for them, and far too many others just say ‘we should hang out sometime’ and never call.

sigh

Ah well. My (former) therapist would take this opportunity to say I have some sort of inferiority complex. I would say he’s wrong.

——

I dreamed of flying last night.

I was with others on a boat, I think. Landed on an island. I saw two small buildings, and in one of them was a small, golden falcon. He was left alone on the island, and needed someone to go with. He showed me how. We pushed the clouds away and followed the wind.

Last night left me shaken. I’m not sure why; there was nothing that would have warranted such a response. I simply felt unsure, and pressured, as if there was a decision to be made quickly. (About God, I think.)

shred your lungs, I need to hear you louder now

——

We went to the fair. More crowd-watching than anything. Struck me how all the entertainment and emotional high is crammed in to one spot. Everywhere else is just bland – here is where the good times are.

Or something like that.

——

I’ve unexpectedly come across the photo of my second grade class. The teacher was cool.

Oh… you just found a boyfriend. Haven’t heard from you in years. You’re normal. You’re dead. Don’t remember you. I think you dropped out. Haven’t seen you since… sophomore year. Normal. Unknown. Most-likely-to-have-an-abusive-boyfriend. Unknown. Unknown. Unknown. Normal. Me. Fairly normal. Anger disorder? Consistently high.

bleh

——

That grey nondescript mailer from England? Yeah, they were *NEW* MENS PRADA BLACK SHORTS BNWT SZ:34” NO RESERVE!!. The fellow thanked me for my honesty and asked me to mail them back. Question is, will he pay shipping?

——

Cheers

there’s a thing we call heartbreak,
but I don’t think
my heart’s ever let me down
my heart’s never let me down
but I still cry ‘cause I can’t always have it my way
and sometimes cryin’ can help ya out

sing it aloud
sing it aloud

and scream…

then I don’t know if you can hear me,
but I can hear the sound of my own echo coming back alone and,
I don’t know why that should scare me
to be so lonely
but I can’t stop cryin’ out

sing it aloud
sing it aloud

and scream…

I want to hear you sing this song
back to me,
across thousands of miles from home where I should be,
and I miss you so badly,
but I won’t waste a simile
‘cause you already know what you mean to me,
if only I could hear you

scream
shred your lungs
I need to hear you louder now
and sing
as if you’ll never sing again

and when the morning comes and your throat is sore
you’ll face the day like you did before,
with a smile on in the end

Ronnie Day

I: God save the queen!
J: … How old /is/ the queen?
——
B: You’re not getting at reincarnation are you?
I: No. No no no no.
B: Good.
I: Yeah. If reincarnation existed… I’d kill myself over and over until it /worked/.
B: Ha. I’d be a butterfly.
I: Yeah, they don’t live terribly long.
B: But /think/ of how much havoc you could get away with. Who would suspect the butterfly?
I: Not that, you know, a butterfly could wreak much havoc to begin with.
B: True… well, okay. I’d be a butterfly with hands.
I: …
B: And opposable thumbs.

7153600357: Definitely better than weed or alcohol imho

post_title: WPC, Rediscover and a nice girl
final_content:
From: Terrie Mckenzie
Hello! I am bored tonight. I am nice girl that would like to chat with you. Email me at [what is presumably a spamtrap] only, because I am writing not from my personal email. Hope you like my pictures.

Pah. You sent no pictures. That wasn’t very nice.

Tell me did you want to die sometimes,
tell me did you want to smile, when I cried

Not that this has anything to do with anything, but I just pushed release 2 of Workplace Confessional to the internets. Or not just, I guess, more like last week. Saturday. Or something.

Anyway, yeah, check it out – workplaceconfessional.com. As far as I know, it’s one of the only AJAX Textpattern sites. Integration with Clean AJAX wasn’t hard, actually; that particular library is very barebones (but functional), making it simple to mod and implement.

In other news, I have three weeks left in this town. At the max; not sure what my plans are. Move in at IIT is the 19th, so I suppose it isn’t even three at this point. I swore at the beginning of the summer to take a few weeks off of work at the end of summer and visit family. Looks like that fell through.

In my defense, that was before I realized that my employer was going independent. Bah. It’s been a good move, of course, but it’s meant 50hr weeks all summer.

cause tonight will be the last night that you ever see, my pretty eyes
and you can finally sleep without your telephone ringing
and you can finally be better,
better without me

Catchy. They’ve put their entire EP online for download. Good move.

This video was an accidental find. Either that or fated, and the latter is very possible. A Zune Arts ad came on Pandora featuring a video from Fulltank. Their artist profile on Zune Arts mentions that they’d love to work with Michel Gondry, a French motion designer who worked with Beck on this video. Good stuff.

unrelated sms conversation
