post_title: if you make it out alive

final_content: To See You Leave (After Edmund)

I dunno. I guess I needed another place to write, open-ended. This was originally going to be a communal blog, high aspirations of building some kind of cultured mini-juggernaut that would have some place on the greater internet. Maybe give that a go some other time.

As it stands, I think this is more of a conversation. Maybe largely one-sided, maybe not. If you can see this, you have equal right to do whatever you want with this space. Respond to foregoing diatribes, write your own, or do nothing and simply observe from time to time. Open-ended.

12:32. Will get back to this later.

I’m beginning to think emotion exists in discreet quantities. Every soul has a hard limit.

To that end, I appear to have met mine. I think that’s why I haven’t been able to eat, actually. Hoping that passes with acclimation.

Trying really hard to keep level-headed about this. Writing helps.

Really fricking glad anthony/I got to see each other this week. Just wish the distance wasn’t so great 99.99% of the time. Still though, 0.01% is worth it.

10:26

Dad: “But what matters most is that you’re happy. Because… if you are, so are we.” They’re not, of course, but I’m trying my best to cover… Remember why I’m here this week. This is hard, harder than I expected.

1. school
    1. classes upcoming, need to finish registration
    2. figure out how to transfer into a half-decent major and not have half of my credits fall through
    3. money
    4. get my gpa back over a 2.5
  2. family
    1. dad has no idea what’s going to happen with work, and talks about it
    2. mom is sad, and doesn’t talk about it
    3. I can’t talk about it
    4. still haven’t come to terms with grandma
  3. bills
    1. rent – $995/mo
    2. utilities/internet/phone – roughly $200/mo
  4. work
    1. get enough hours in on top of school to get ^ paid
    2. do something worth the salary
  5. misc
    1. can’t eat

All in your head. That said, as long as I’m not left to think for too long, things can be handled. Hives are reappearing, unfortunately. My body’s not been this affected before.

This domain will probably be repurposed yet again… Maybe not, idk. While any noble ideas about its purpose are nice, I’m unsure if they’ll ever.. work. If it’s to be kept like this, I don’t want it to end up like my-own and ikeemo and white facade before it (these collectively being a concentrated whine-fest).

Bah.
Here's To The Night (Eve 6)
Sunrise. I'd resolved some months ago to spend more time by the lake. Starting to make that happen.
I Wish You Were Here (Matchbook Romance)
Girl in the Fire (Pendulum)
Intercede Light (Iris)
There are a few things that matter, he said. And fuck the rest. -- Silver Poetry (Digitonal)

post_title: ready for it, here we go
final_content: Right Now (Fort Minor)
The Last Firstborn (Celldweller)

post_title: celebrate the day a better world is won
final_content:
Sentinel (VNV Nation) Been a while, yeah? Since I've actually spoken, I mean. As you've no doubt observed, all of these stuffs have been moved to a new domain (A new domain, a new you!), which happens every so often. Probably connected to some astronomical cycle. There is no great significance to this; expect the usual photograph/musick pairings to be posted at the usual plodding rate. But, in an effort to provide you, the doting reader, with something approaching a personal update (I understand bloggers are expected to do that), know the following.
  • I have spent an unnecessarily large amount of money on Chinese takeout, as of late.
  • A week and a half were recently spent in Superior, WI, spending time with Anthony and his cadre. A better time I have not had in years.
  • On a related note, Daemon makes for an excellent read. Or two.
  • For the moment, still employed at the Chicago Public Library. By extension, I'm still living in Chicago. Going to the same school. Giving serious thought to leaving this place, but that point is, for the moment, moot.
  • Relaxation hypnosis works. It's an abhorrent surrendering of cognition, but it works, and I appreciate it.
  • I am currently in possession of three coffeemakers, one of which was left behind by this apartment's erstwhile tenant, who apparently didn't feel like warning me that the carafe leaked very, very badly. >_>
Cheers.

post_title: we will be the future, and you, you will never change
final_content: Oven (Seven Mary Three) It's funny, actually. My grades suck because I value my professional work over academic performance. Predictably, HR wants to fire me, because my grades suck. Never been fired before, let alone for what amounts to dedication to my work. Perhaps someday I'll get a normal job, and leave it under normal circumstances. Could happen.

If You Were Here (Cary Brothers) Contingency plans, sorting out directions. An extended discussion over lunch (and coffee) regarding the value of recording in vinyl, and the inherent limitations of digital media in an analog world. Drawing circles with pixels, as it were. Though ultimately, this isn't so different from using text to evoke a mental image - the lower the resolution, the more the mind is left to interpolate, rounding off and filling around the sharp edges.

post_title: and if you feel it let me hear everybody go
final_content: I Fear All The Moments You Will Need Me And I Won't Be There (Stendeck) I will be fired on November 6th. The Department of Human Resources passed it up the chain to the Department of Compliance, and with that action the fight was over. This is not insignificant. My work here has been my primary (read: geographically limiting) tie to this city. With this absolved, I am leaving. My application to UW Superior was submitted last week, along with all requisite transcripts and the like. The apartment went onto Craigslist today. My dear Slavic landlady was somewhat concerned about the timing (apparently winter is a suboptimal time to move), but it'll work out. Decision's been made; the rest is just details. Looking into a web development job (not so much dependent on location) to potentially hang on to for the next few years. (Granted, I said this about my current employment as well. It's funny, when the other two developers left this place, I'd assumed my job security had dramatically increased. Should have expected a draconian act of bureaucracy to interfere. Ah well.) I'm hopeful that this will work out. From a professional/academic perspective, going from Chicago to a small city in northern Wisconsin is something of a strange move. Unsurprisingly, then, my motivations for this are hardly professional, or academic, and for that matter are entirely unquantifiable. (Directly, anyway; the death spiral that my gpa has launched into is painfully quantifiable, but this is more a symptom and less the cause.) This might have something to do with the fact that I'm still young and naive, not quite resigned to spending my life flat-lining behind a desk. To that end, as my boss observed, it's probably for the best that I won't be coasting along with this organization for the next x years. Though I will miss the coffee. Intelligentsia's shipping rates are absurd. Comes down to this, then: the relationships we have are the most valuable things in the world. There is only so much time.
Nexus (Aes Dana) 12:44am, which recently would have been 1:44am. Apparently this thing works both ways. Fortune cookie: The heart that loves is always young.

post_title: voices in my head have all begun to sing
final_content: Birthright (Beta 1.0) (Celldweller) To my family: No, I am not retreating to the woods, or finally discovering that I really only ever loved small rural communities or anything remotely like this. Damn it, who do you think I am? To my friends in Chicago: No, I am not just running off. I will be back. And oh look, an internet. Honestly, I've been all but absent in the last few months as it is - a shame, yes, and this was my fault, but no, I am not letting you go just yet. To my academic institution: I have watched the most intelligent, most talented people that I've ever met languish within your walls. You are my only regret. To my coworkers and managers and everyone else that I've spent the majority of my waking hours with: I love you all, I swear. I'm sorry I'm leaving under these circumstances. I'm not angry about being fired, but I'm pissed off that I can't work alongside you anymore. To the bureaucracy that hired me, and then realized a year later that they didn't mean it: I'm curious to see what becomes of you over the next few decades. Your present course appears unsustainable at every level. To those in Superior: ... Fuck everything, I will be there soon.

Wth<You (Chairman Hahn feat. Aceyalone) Pulseaudio is cooperating, granting the piano life. Thinking about getting a guitar pedal, and then not eating for two or three weeks. Spent a few hours today with Elly, taking in the neighborhood and large amounts of coffee. Discussing life. She produced a token from her time in Africa, which I'll hang on to. I keep mementos from the people I know, helps keep them real when there's distance between.

Innerpartysystem Mixtape Vol. 2 Winter 2009 I have a month left here. A couple weeks in my hometown, then, up to Superior. It'll happen soon, only challenge is getting through the holidays with the family. But we'll make it. Better things are coming.

post_title: this is where you come in
final_content: Psychic Gibbon (Younger Brother) Slow Tuesday, the details of which are dull and mostly a waste of time, but I need some text down here so the site layout doesn't look off-balance. Those tuning in via feedreader, suck it. I've discovered this alarm clock on the Android Market, which seems overly proud of itself for exploiting human sleep cycles by aurally nudging the human half an hour before s/he actually wants to wake. Supposedly this makes it easier to wake up when the alarm proper is sounded. Which seems to work, unless you sleep like a dead man. In which case, it requires an actual phone call from an admissions counselor to jar you out of what had been up until that point the best sleep you've had since who knows when. Still, it's probably for the best, as you honestly have no business skipping this class, again. No, really, stumbling in five minutes late is better than not going at all; have you /seen/ your grades? (We learned about business leadership styles today. The class plays like a bad workplace seminar. It's worth it, if only to observe what goes into manufacturing a white-collar drone.) Coalesced in my desk chair* around noon, accomplished roughly nothing (read: watched back-episodes of Dollhouse) until 3pm, at which point I realized I'd might as well be accomplishing nothing in a place with better atmosphere. Arrived at Intelligentsia around 3:45; the coffee's worth every second of the requisite public transportation. I'd record the rest, but it's less exciting than the above and the aesthetic balance of this beast is already a lost cause. That, and sleep is probably in order. After the coffee's finished, yeah. -- * The chair is indeed coalescence-worthy. Visited Ikea some months ago, intending to return with a bed of some kind. Managed to rationalize purchasing an unnecessarily expensive desk chair instead. I sleep, in the living room, on a futon.
Half Light (Athlete)

post_title: then I'll give you nothing less
final_content: Come Back When You Can (Barcelona) There is much to love and enjoy and there are memories to be made, to be counted and held close. And fuck if I miss any more of this. I've been gone too long. addendum Yeah, I don't know why I'm being vague. This domain has been locked down further (paranoia++), and it exists solely that I might speak freely. To nobody in particular, albeit, but it's still worth something. I'm at home just now. "Home", the house that my family occupies. And it is home, yeah. The depression was bad, last time I was here, and the stress from being around my family was .. very bad, couldn't keep food down for weeks. But I'm sort of better now, all around, and consciously clearing the cobwebs from my head helps. I'm alright here. It was hard, to an extent, having the family here and having Grandma not be. I still haven't come to terms with this. My instinctual response is to get as much distance as I can between me and my family, lest this happen again. Or for when it happens again. This is by way of explanation for the original statement, up top - I'd be missing too much. And I've missed a lot already, both with the family and with my friends here (Rhinelander), in Chicago and in Superior. Rhinelander and Superior, I sort of have an excuse. (Fucking teleport. >_>) Chicago, not so much. .. I get this nagging, uncomfortable feeling whenever I put down what amounts to a stream of consciousness. Like you all will think less of me, having seen what actually goes on in here. This is another case (and I'm getting better at this, hah) where I have to consciously kick myself back on track. in sum You all are worth more time than I've allotted in the past. Making a concerted effort to turn this around.
New site, for whatever reason. Eventually this blog will contain something. Perhaps it shall even be moved off of the stock template. I'm feeling a little wild.

Kings and Queens (Innerpartysystem Remix Main) - 30 Seconds to Mars Calling it good for now, going to get the new site out the door this evening, half-done. And leave Wordpress sitting here with a stock template, because I understand that's the ironic sort of thing that my generation does. (I'm only going with the norm because, really, who /does/ that?) Things that are known:
  • I have fourteen (or thirteen, depends on definitions) days left in this city.
  • Money sucks. All hail capitalism.
  • Next semester, I shall be at a state college. (See what I did there?)
  • Someone has offered to take a sublease on the apartment when I leave (thank you).
Things that are less clear:
  • When I shall return here
  • How everything will be paid for
  • When everything will be paid for
As for this blog, we shall see what happens with it. A new one was warranted, for some reason. Cheers.

Kings and Queens (Innerpartysystem Remix Main) Eleven days here, really cannot wait to get out... I have a feeling it'll be like this whenever I move from one long-term scenario to another, to some degree. Implicit obligations hanging that need to end, patterns that need to be broken, if the scope is limited to factors here. There's a handful of people here that I will miss, and some more than others. Goes both ways, again, some more than others. ... My 21st birthday will be spent moving my crap from here to Wisconsin. Funny how that works. And I think I need to find a decent girl when I get up to Superior. :p I'm a chronically lonely bastard, which kind of gets old. (Yeah, I was surprised too.) It's unfortunate that I keep ending up close to ones who either smoke pot or are psychotic... All extremely nice, intelligent, good looking, otherwise solid prospects. Good friends, most of them. But, new environs, eh? (Alternatively, my standards need to go lower...) Picked up Neuromancer (William Gibson), on a recommendation. Apparently the author invented cyberpunk. We were the kings and queens of promise We were the victims of ourselves Maybe the children of a lesser god Between heaven and hell

I've lived in Chicago for the last two and a half years, which .. not sure how long it actually feels like, but it's evidently long enough. If all goes well, I'll be heading north on Wednesday with everything to my name boxed up and in the trunk. Except for some sort of philodendron that's been left at my old office, continuing its quest to conquer the entire east wall.

I'll be in my hometown for a couple weeks, over Christmas at least, and will then be moving further north to UW Superior. IIT was valuable in its own right (albeit less for the education and more for the people), but it's evidently time to move on. I hear it's slightly colder there.

It's past midnight - I have one full day left here, heading out on Wednesday. But I think everything/everyone's taken care of, been seen to.

Not sure what else to say. Time to move, is all.

my old apartment, more empty than usual.

21st birthday was Wednesday, moved into my parents' basement. I sort of have a studio down here. Also, was on the receiving end of Anthony's trolling while driving north from Chicago, earlier that day. A string of frantic text messages, saying that his laptop was on the verge of meltdown and I CAN"T AFFORD A NEW LAPTOP. He emailed over what was allegedly a recording of what the fans were doing, which my phone failed to open. Gave him a call, he detailed the situation in grave tones, uploaded the audio file to his website and sent over a link. This did manage to download and play properly, after freeing up some space on the phone's sd card. Turned out to be what sounds like a bad DDR-esque mix of Happy Birthday. Made my day. I'm writing this from whitebox, my primary machine. More to the point, I'm writing this from the basement, on the far end of a less than elegant network. The dsl modem (could be worse) is sitting in another building entirely, and is connected to a D-Link wireless router, which has a Hawking signal booster attached. This signal is caught and passed on by a Hawking repeater (armed with a high-gain antenna) over here in the house. Down in the basement, my laptop serves as a glorified network bridge - it's connected to the network broadcast by the repeater, and relays the packets to/from this connection to its ethernet port (iptables rules all), which is connected to a Netgear router's uplink. (Wireless router, making a total of three wifi networks...) Whitebox is attached to this router, and thus are internets provided. It works disturbingly well. Still, exposing whitebox to the internet at large would be impractical just now, and given the chronic uncertainty surrounding UW Superior's network, we've gone ahead and moved whitebox's primary functions to a Linode VPS. This was the consensus after giving Dreamhost's PS service a trial run - while it does indeed provide a vps, it's still tied fairly tightly to their service management platform. Functional, but not the best if you need a completely independent box. Thus, Linode. Those who've used it speak of it in awe, and thus far it seems like they might have a point. Digitonal - I recommend this.

Still here, yeah. Been getting some work done, down in my basement hovel and such. Got past the archetypal family crisis that happens over Christmas. Will hopefully be getting a car within the next couple days; kinda sucks, being actually within less than a hundred miles from people while being immobile. Need to mail out the rent check tomorrow.

Happy New Years, all. May 2010 be more and better than 2009.

My thanks to Anthony and the Blue Ayes crew for a memorable celebration. Good memories.
Life Is Beautiful (SIXX:A.M.) Heard this on the radio while heading up to Minocqua, with Anthony. Happy New Year's, all.

post_title: sometimes goodbye is a second chance
final_content:
Fuck, I don't know.

Withdrawal from my old school is in, everything is sort of tentatively paid for, car and all. The paychecks (er, Paypal receipts) aren't coming in as regularly as I'd hoped for, but with any luck at all the sublet will be a success and I'll save seven hundred a month.

Pissed off without a really good reason to be. A lot of nights are like this.

Haxxored the Wii, which has proven to be really useful. Turns out, full games can be saved to an sd card (or some sort of usb storage media), in addition to the usually touted benefits of playing burned discs and torrenting WiiWare titles. (One would only do such things to provide backups for one's own legally purchased games, obviously.) Other bonuses: MPlayer, an ftp server, and .. that's all I've really messed with. And a savegame extracter/importer, for when Super Mario's restrictions get in the way.

Not sure yet if I miss Chicago. Or how that works. Transitioning is something that's historically come with relative ease. (Not counting preliminary second-guessing, which sucks.) City to city, it is what it is and there isn't a whole lot of difficulty with that, after it's done. Taking it as a good sign that it's not bothering me that I left. Though I haven't really kept in contact with anyone, since then. Only been a couple weeks, but.. meh. There were a handful of really important relationships there. I don't know if it was ever communicated, how much they actually meant. Though it's not like it's too late.

The timezone on Wordpress is off again, noticing this as the draft saves itself. "Draft Saved at 1:23:53 am."

Work to do tomorrow. This generally has had little to do with whether or not work actually gets done, but one can hope.

A former co-worker forwarded me an opinion piece from Boy Genius Report: Google Android Personal Thoughts. Read this before going further, or just skip this entry entirely. My response to the article follows here, which I'm posting here at others' behest. His statement that Android is missing an element of human warmth: .. okay, sure. I'm sorry that using this os doesn't make you feel warm and fuzzy inside, and that the Android phone doesn't carry with it an aura personally imbued by Steve Jobs. This is not objective. Someone corrected him on the icons rant, fortunately. This would be a solid case of user error, and throws some of his competency into question. It's anecdote-against-anecdote, but I've had touch events misfire perhaps once. Could easily have something to do with the hardware at that point. Regarding the lack of "beautiful" applications. Ignoring for a moment that the SDK has only been out since August 2008, making judgments on an operating system based on applications written by 3rd party developers is complete and utter bs.
Why does the VNC application I bought and paid for crash on the Nexus One with a Java.IO error? Because your entire OS is fragmented, poorly driven, poorly policed, and because in typical Google fashion, you’re already on to the next thing before making this an absolutely flawless experience for users.
VNC: because you bought an application from some idiot developer who doesn't know what he's doing. Google's objective is not to police the entire experience, and here be the difference between Android and the iPhone os. Android is about letting whoever wants to make whatever the hell they want out of it. The iPhone (and everything else that Apple has ever touched) is strictly policed, to use this guy's description, lest anything pollute this hallowed ground. Though I am curious as what exactly he means by the os being "fragmented". I'm hoping he's referring to (again) the interface and available applications, not the actual os, as he would here be making a mistake. As observed, the coders at Google are exceedingly good at what they do.
What happened to ferociously making sure the absolute core applications in your package were 100% perfect before shipping? BlackBerry’s email application is flawless. Apple’s web browser is flawless. But there’s not a single application on Android that doesn’t have carbon spots in it. (Look it up)
Because Google's vested interest is not in the applications. (With the exception of Gmail, Maps, Chat, Voice, and the others - all of which are exceedingly solid apps.) They build the os. In a handful of cases, they also step in and work on the experience itself - see the Nexus One. +1 Elitism for using 'carbon spots', and +1 again for being sufficiently condescending that you feel it necessary to tell the reader to look it up. It's a mistake to imply that Apple's corpus of software is without such flaws. It is true that they focus heavily on polish and veneer before shipping - this is simply what they do, and it is integral to their process. Google, not so much. This is why Gmail was released as a clearly flawed beta, back in the day - brilliant software with a couple dim spots can still be hugely beneficial for a user with a modicum of intelligence, and thus does Google make it available to the user before it's completely finished. Different ways of doing business. As a user, you can choose to live within a glossy white box with rounded corners, or .. not, really. There are less closed options of equal or greater quality/functionality, but yeah, out here not everything has been rubbed down by Steve Jobs' exacting vision.
Here’s another issue on why for the foreseeable future Android won’t be anything like what Apple or another company can offer: coders aren’t designers. It’s really as simple as that and anyone in the business will know exactly what I’m talking about. That’s why Apple’s entire developer ecosystem is different, because believe it or not, Apple’s developers are amazing designers that make beautiful things, and they happen to know how to code. That’s entirely different from someone who’s the best coder in the world and trying to create something that looks, works, and feels great. And so, this is my issue with Android and why you won’t see applications of iPhone-quality on Android aside from any SDK and programming hurdles.
Coders aren't designers. Agreed. Thus, Apple hires designers. Their brand dictates that every single product display the same aesthetic, so yeah, if their developers create something new, the designers are going to be working on it with equal effort. Google isn't in the business of making beautiful things. Google makes systems that allow people to get things done, and that applies with Android. You can write whatever the hell you want for the thing. The iPhone's app store is moderated, and this is why they have the applications that they do. Android Market is indeed more like a free market, and functions as such - the operative ideas here are completely different. The point of Android is not to offer up an open source implementation of the iPhone os. If that's what you expect, then yeah, you'll be disappointed. Please move on; your Jobs pinup needs some love and we're working here. ... sigh. It's the internet, fanboys will have their say. Are they completely wrong, probably not. Are they lacking some objectivity, yeah. In boatloads. Then again, the consumer is not objective, and will be rendering judgment based on who they themselves are and the way they think. The Android vs iPhone situation is not dissimilar to Ubuntu vs OSX. It's not a 1:1 situation, but a lot of the core differences (heh) are present. If you're happy in your glowing Apple-branded bubble, then fine, there's a whole industry out there that'll be more than pleased to make sure you never turn around. The rest of us will be over here, blinders off.

I've been told I need to write more. I don't think this sort of thing was the idea, right, but all things in time...

my dorm room workspace. the flag is integral, as the desk light is more than a little abrasive.

Falling asleep as I write this. Day three on campus was much like day two, except in that there was Little Caesars rather than Jimmy John's for the mealoftheday. The campus welcome week activities seem to be largely geared toward freshmen, and apart from one last night (my involvement was limited to a two hour group conversation with existing students, was worth it), my time has instead been mostly spent on work. (Per usual, I know.) Classes start on Tuesday, thus I've self-imposed a Monday night deadline for the contract at hand. The photo above is, as captioned, a view of my desk. I'm in a double-occupancy dorm room, first time since early freshman year. Which is fine, not a big deal. Nice to not have to deal with rent/utility contracts. (As an aside, the subletter (subleasee?) moved into my Chicago apartment on Wednesday. Horray.) Whitebox was up here initially, along with the monitor, but has since moved down to Anthony's room, one floor down. The space there is better suited for the thing. 1:42am. ... Having a roommate may actually force me back into a somewhat normal sleep schedule, come to think of it.

Quer fazer um álbum íncrivel? Conheça o Windows Live Fotos clicando aqui.
She found me. Bruna Soares Meirelles found me. And I thought, watching her red-eye to São Paulo take off from a Parisian runway, that I had seen the last of her and could move on with whatever was left of my life. Whatever she left to me. Oh she plays it coy, with this absurd schoolgirl act. "miss talking 2 u" indeed. I suppose she has no real reason to be subtle, not after Montmartre. But then, subtlety was never something she preferred. Women. Never trust them. Not while drowning expatriate loyalists in the river Seine, not ever.

Wrapping up stage one of the project at hand. The owner is slow to get payments out (e.g. he owes me more than a grand at this point), but he'll get in gear once this stage is done and he has a solid sample of my work to judge things on. This from the sysadmin, who's someone I trust. Should be okay. Just a little frustrated that it's taken me this long to get this far - five thousand lines isn't a lot, and it's been at least two months. The work has been spaced out, yeah, but this is subpar... I have a Paypal transfer coming in tomorrow (later today, I guess), should help a little in the interim. Food and all. Classes start Tuesday, still waiting to see/speakwith my advisor about classes and transferred credits. Picked up a copy of Freedom(tm), which both Anthony and I should be getting through in relatively short order. Also working through Pattern Recognition, and a handful of other books courtesy of Joe Mastey. Looking up at my bookshelf: Tolkien and Watchmen. come with us to the other side, come with us through the gates of hell where we'll drag you from where you are to where you belong

UW Superior uses Cisco Clean Access to authenticate users on its networks, both wired and wireless. This is a pain. Windows users get a little daemon that sits on their machines, letting the powers that be know that the local system is secure. Right. For the rest of us, the following script (after the break) can be thrown in /etc/interfaces/if-up.d/ or run on cron or something, if you're a Linux user with cURL installed. And lockfile-progs, I guess, which you should have already if you're on Ubuntu or a derivative thereof. 
#!/bin/bash

# network credentials
username=uname1
password=123456

# uws wireless
server=nac-w.uwsuper.edu
provider=UWS\ Wireless

# uws wired (resnet)
#server=nac-srv.uwsuper.edu
#provider=ResNet

# other settings
maxtime=60
PATH=/sbin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin
lockfile=/var/lock/uwsnac

# setup lockfile
lockfile-create $lockfile
lockfile-touch $lockfile &
locktouchpid="$!"
trap "kill $locktouchpid; lockfile-remove $lockfile;" exit

# initial check - do we need to authenticate?
if !(curl -# -m $maxtime http://google.com | grep -q $server)
then
echo "already authenticated; exiting"
exit
fi

# submit credentials
authresult=$(curl -# -m $maxtime -d cm=ws32vklm -d "username=$username" -d "password=$password" -d "provider=$provider" https://$server/auth/perfigo_cm_validate.jsp)

# check for user limit error
if (echo $authresult | grep -q "Too many users using this account")
then
echo "too many users on this account; booting off the oldest of these"
echo "your network connection may reset - hang tight"
authresult=$(curl -# -m $maxtime -d cm=ws32vklm -d remove_old=1 -d "username=$username" -d "password=$password" -d "provider=$provider" https://$server/auth/perfigo_cm_validate.jsp)
fi

# evaluate results
if (echo $authresult | grep -q "Invalid username or password")
then
echo "invalid credentials (protip: reconfigure); exiting"
exit
elif !(echo $authresult | grep -q perfigo_cm_agree.jsp)
then
echo "finished authenticating"
exit
fi

# submit policy agreement
userkey=$(echo $authresult | sed -r 's/.*"perfigo_cm_agree\.jsp\?userkey=([^&]*).*/\1/')
agreeresult=$(curl -# -m $maxtime -d "userkey=$userkey" -d "provider=$provider" https://$server/auth/perfigo_cm_policy.jsp)

if (echo $agreeresult | grep -q "You will be redirected to the URL")
then
echo "finished authenticating"
else
echo "ran into some difficulty, sorry"
fi

# done here
exit
(Anthony astutely points out that the part about /etc/interfaces/if-up.d/ is a lie. We're having some difficulties with that particular trigger. But, failing everything else, you could have this run every two minutes as a root cronjob. It'd work.)

So, turns out that I pretty much don't have any idea what the hell I'm talking about. I have some vague, half-formed idea, but nothing concise and exact, and this is probably why it feels like my head is unraveling a little.

No context in particular for this. Generally applicable. When I speak with you the reader and trip over my words more than usual, know that any words that do manage to follow each other in some logical order are most likely the result of instinctual bs-ing. Feel free to count them as such.

meh. I just want to be able to communicate. Speaking your mind is hard when you don't know what your mind is doing.

Just a quick note for the sake of Google, who doesn't know much about this yet. The Ubuntu Netbook Remix works almost perfectly out of the box on an EeePC 1005PE (screen brightness controls are a little iffy), but only comes in a 32bit edition. The 1005PE is stocked with the Atom N450, which is in fact a 64bit processor. And a fairly new one, which is probably why, upon booting the 64bit release of Ubuntu 9.10, I discovered that the keyboard and trackpad were completely unresponsive. A little odd, as at least the keyboard worked during installation. The fix for this was fairly simple, and may be a nonissue in the near future - reboot the machine, and as GRUB loads, hit the escape key, and boot into recovery mode. Drop down to a root terminal with networking (you'll want a wired network connection for this), and run aptitude update && aptitude install linux-backports-modules-karmic && aptitude safe-upgrade. Then, reboot. Keyboard and mouse should be functional - go ahead and log in. I should point out here that installing linux-backports-modules-wireless-karmic-generic might also be a good plan, as my wireless wasn't working out of the box.

The English Way (Fightstar) Alright. In the spirit of vomiting up your soul into a textbox for your own sake, here we are. Parenthetical: I'm aware that none of this is unique or special or anything. It's the product of sitting in a corner for too long with the lights off, so to speak. "You", as used below, refers to everyone I've known and loved. Oh melodrama. It's alright, I've taken the liberty of scorning this ahead of time. There's a very deep self-loathing that I can't get over, despite repeated assurances that I'm 'a great guy'. To you, I may be a great guy. I'll bend over backwards for you, open my wallet and do whatever I can for you with complete disregard for self. This is selfless by definition, yeah, and on the other end people seem to like it. It's because I care so much more for you than for me. Your schedule, your priorities, I play second string and it's because I have and am nothing, apart from what I can do for you and with you. I have no self-worth. I hate that I have to do this, write this out. This is probably in part why I have no personal goals. I realized this the other day, I have no ambitions, nothing to follow, no dreams. I could pick an arbitrary set and go for it, sure, but I'm led to believe that these are the sort of things that people are supposed develop instinctively, born of who they are. And fuck, I don't know. I'm doing my best to remain halfway interested in passing my classes, let alone get a degree. So. Please be patient with me. (You are, what am I saying, all of you are.) Yes, I'm stuck in a mindset and I know that and I fucking hate myself for it (circular progression, awesome). Maybe someday it'll be better. I will never give up on you for all the times you sat and sang to me trying to make me better

The cv is now up to date, and I've introduced a new media section to house the creative stuffs (work in progress). Henceforth, this space will include development notes/adventures (I have a backlog of these) and the occasional update on what I'm having for lunch. I understand people on the internet are interested in such things.

Short version: order from Amazon, and if the manufacturer won't issue a refund after your purchase, you stand a decent chance of receiving a goodwill refund from Amazon itself. Long version: The machine in question was a ASUS Eee PC Seashell 1005PE-PU17-BK ($368.59 at the time of purchase), along with a 2GB stick of memory ($43.99). Grand total with shipping: $420.56. The netbook (great little machine, by the way) comes with Windows 7 Starter Edition, which is a joke in every respect. What if I want to change my desktop wallpaper? A quick search will give you a number of stories in which users have squared their collective shoulders and gone up against the manufacturer, arguing with "Jonathan" until both he and his manager tire of the game and award the battle-worn caller their prize. Not being terribly excited by this prospect, I started with the seller, Amazon:
Hello, I received my EeePC from Amazon.com today, and while in the process of getting it set up was asked to accept a Microsoft Windows license agreement. For many reasons I am unable to accept the licensing terms, and thus, per the agreement itself (http://i.imgur.com/Vs308.jpg), I would like to find out how to go about returning the operating system, or receiving a refund for it. In lieu of Windows, I will be installing Linux as an os. Could you inform me of the procedure for expediting a refund? For reference, the EULA ID for the packaged version of Windows is Win7_RM.1_STR_OEM_en-us. There is also a Microsoft Service Agreement, marked as updated September 2008. I have not and do not intend to accept either of these agreements. Thanks for your time, Isaac Bowen
The response from Amazon was prompt and helpful, if somewhat misguided.
I'm sorry to hear that the operating system for the personal computer you ordered is defective. I'm not able to replace or refund for individual pieces from a set, but I'll replace the set for you. Once you've received it, please ship back the original set. The quickest way to get the part you need is to contact the manufacturer and get it directly from them under the terms of their warranty.
The rep went on to list contact information for ASUS, and a link to let Amazon know how the manufacturer responded. Also, the following three options, should ASUS fail to respond:
1. We will replace the entire set at no charge 2. If you prefer to keep the item we will refund 20% off the purchase price of this item 3. You may return the entire set for a full refund.
I sent an email to ASUS, saying more or less what I had said to Amazon (namely that I'd like to keep the machine, but I have no interest in using this Windows license that you've so kindly included), and waited for a month, not expecting much but knowing that Amazon had my back regardless. Happily, I received no response. Amazon issued a full 20% refund for the netbook itself in a matter of hours, totaling $73.72. (Though, oddly, the refund notice divided the total evenly between the memory and the netbook. Why, I do not know.) Conclusion: if you want to get your Windows tax refunded, order through someone like Amazon who can afford to throw you a bone to keep you happy. Your mileage may vary, but if the manufacturer doesn't pull through, Amazon (probably) will.

Now available: Gatekeeper, the content protection tool for Shopify. Gatekeeper is built on CakePHP, using an extension of Shopify's official PHP api (to be released in the near future as a Cake component - leave a comment if you're anxious).

Version 1.0 features:

  • Automatic installation on shop templates
  • Single-click protection for pages and products
  • To preserve settings, locks can be disabled without deleting
  • Username/password or username-only users
  • Multiple users per lock
  • Automated cache renewal to ensure locked content is up to date

Planned:

  • SSL support
  • Storefront authentication without page reloads
  • Customize login message per-lock
  • Style gallery for Gatekeeper's login forms and messages
  • Global enable/disable
  • User import/export

––verbose

This project started out as a value-add for a client who maintains a Shopify storefront. They were looking for a way to lock down a single page of their store, such that only users who had a valid username could enter. Shopify does offer password protection, but it's applied globally - the store is either completely locked, or completely open. Thus, Gatekeeper. Implementation was somewhat less than straightforward. There are no provisions for local scripting in Shopify, and because Liquid is sanely designed it does not provide access to arbitrary HTTP query data (so no POST/GET vars, let alone any session identifiers). This meant that the role that the Shopify storefront could play was limited at best. The solution I arrived at, and what is in production now, involves metafields set on the requested resource (currently implemented for pages/products) and on the shop itself to control whether or not the resource should be delivered from Shopify, or retrieved from Gatekeeper. If the resource is locked, Javascript is used to pull the requested data from Gatekeeper's domain (necessitating JSONP). This data is only delivered if an authenticated user session is active - if not, a login form is returned, which points back to Gatekeeper. This obviously means that Gatekeeper must actively maintain a cache of resource data, which it does. This same cache powers the lists of resources (again, just pages and products for now) that are offered to the user from the Gatekeeper dashboard, and is regularly validated and renewed. This allows Gatekeeper to capably handle thousands of resources per shop while keeping the user experience responsive, and keeping api calls to a minimum. Gatekeeper spent exactly three weeks in the approval process. Dennis Theisen handled its review, and provided surprisingly practical and insightful feedback throughout. I'm thoroughly impressed with the level of care that Shopify gives to the user experience, even as it extends beyond Shopify to third-party applications. The App Store is a walled garden, yes, but close communication throughout makes this a benefit, not a hindrance. Gatekeeper is being released today into the wild, with a free one-lock-one-user trial and an unlimited-use subscription for USD$20 per month.

This past week, I had the pleasure of spending a few hours photographing my good friend Brittany Collins (fiancée of Anthony Hook, the lucky stiff). Partly a chance for her to get a few decent photos taken, partly for me to put a new camera through its paces, we headed out to Superior's Wisconsin Point. I generally stick to environmental photography, and thus I'd never really done a formal photoshoot. I hastily scratched out a list of shots I wanted to get and the locations to get them in, but with no real experience in directing live subjects, I wasn't completely sure what to expect. Or what to do, really. Things I learned, as an amateur:

Keep it loose. Formality is boring. Natural movement and posturing is everything, so give your subject enough room to be comfortable within the bounds of your direction.

Tell me a story. The best candid portraits happen when the subject is completely ignoring you, and has their mind on something totally different. (Surprise.) The most effective method I found for this was to have Brittany tell me a story, something notable from last week, or even a scene from The Office. Or several scenes from The Office.

Let me tell you a story. You've just ducked around the corner, and you're hiding from someone - try to see if you're being followed, without being seen. Alternatively, you're a professional model who takes herself far too seriously.

Plan for colors. We nailed this one, actually. Bring changes of clothing with a range of colors and patterns, bearing in mind the general location you'll be shooting in. I say "general", because it's important to --

Explore. The only place I had planned for was one stretch of beach. And the lighthouse. And we didn't even do the lighthouse.

Use the environment. People don't go out by old barns and pose next to classic cars of their own impetus. Someone might be expected play in the sand on the beach, though.

Shoot in RAW. Do it. Even if Lightroom doesn't yet have native support for your camera's implementation. >_>

The full photoset is here, on Flickr, and is roughly 2/3 complete. Turns out, I spend a lot of time in post.

As promised, github.com/isaacbowen/shopify-cakephp. This project is a fork of the official Shopify PHP api, differing in that all global symbols have been prefixed (read: haxxed namespacing, until the world gets around to upgrading to 5.3.0), and including /cake/shopify_component.php (the good part).

English language classes teach the five-paragraph essay, math classes teach proof structure, and marketing classes teach inventive techniques for lying. (Kidding.) But I have yet to see a single CS professor teach any kind of framework, let alone any actual architectural/design patterns beyond some vague mumbling about separating your middleware. This is a problem. Teaching the tools without teaching technique, ignoring the vast majority of progress made in development practices to date, is tantamount to having an intern build a cargo plane using balsa and a model of the Wright flyer for reference. It's flagrantly irresponsible. I'm a web developer, for context, and a relatively young one at that. Just about to finish extracting a BS degree from this university. Like many of my peers, I picked up the bulk of my knowledge online - started with liberally-applied tables on Bravehost (which apparently is still around), hacked out the basics of CRUD by reading php.net, etc etc. But it wasn't until I started in on the Zend framework that the quality of my code started to seriously improve. Sure, I had already developed a relatively consistent coding style, but the structure of my software still wasn't anything transcendent, and "code reuse" still meant sifting through phpclasses.org. Using a framework meant that I could learn by example, at the pace of my own discovery. This is something that academia has totally failed to provide. Obviously, I can speak only of my own experience. I've taken development courses at both the Illinois Institute of Technology and UW Superior. While I've been occasionally surprised at the caliber of the faculty at both universities, and while both will provide the aspiring developer with a solid grounding in CS fundamentals, they do little to nothing to prepare the student for actual, real-world development done well. The emphasis here is important. Sure, my capstone project at UWS involves creating a tiered web application. Yes, we were told how the stack should probably be separated. But making the students start from nothing ensures that the final product will only be as good as the students' sum efforts, and their efforts alone. This is pointless, and a waste of the students' time. We are capable of more. We can build a functional product faster by using PHP rather than C, sure, but we can build a better product by allowing ourselves one more abstraction out of the gate: a framework. In talking with my professors, it seems that the hesitation in bringing such demons into play (besides the fact that they just don't know them) lies in the initial opacity of the system. Run rails new, and what do you get? Skeletons! No guts that the students can read, line by line, and somehow assimilate in one gradual pass. This is nonsense. You don't learn to drive a car by pouring over blueprints for the powertrain. Understanding the mechanics will help you improve your mileage and preserve your investment, sure, but that's not where you start. I'm not suggesting we ignore the language fundamentals and throw the 101 students straight into MVC (or what have you). I am suggesting that we merge the two. A programming course starts with printf("Hello world");, and it should. It's not impenetrable to the uninitiated, and in teaching it we assume that their brains can wrap around a function call without first having deep understanding of what a function is. My point is that there's little difference between this, and starting one level higher. Now, we see echo("Hello world");, but it's given context - this code is a "view", and it talks to the user. The fundamentals may still be taught with equal efficacy, but now they are accompanied by structure, something that the students can pick up gradually as a concept integral to development, and not just a good idea to tack on towards the end. (I should probably clear some ambiguity here before I get any flack for it. There is a distinction to be made between computer science, such as it is, and software development. The pure CS (read: math) that I got out of my degree is great, and in retrospect I should have focused more on it, but I entered college with the idea that I was going to build tools that were going to help people. It took far too much time for me to discover that this wasn't going to happen within the confines of academia. Perhaps this is a greater problem than the one I've been railing on about here - the total lack of any declared distinction between academic and applied computer science. Other schools may be better with this, but I know I'm not the only one who was screwed by IIT on this point.) Ultimately, my concern is with the potential of students. There's a reason why calculus is introduced in high school now instead of being sequestered away in college - when given the proper support over time, kids can handle it. And by acquiring a deeper understanding of mathematics earlier on, they are that much better equipped to make progress faster. Wasted time is just sad, especially when students have no idea there's a better way. So - teach frameworks in school. Do everyone a favor.

TL;DR

Yes, Virginia, there is a way to boot your physical Ubuntu (or whatever) partition as a VirtualBox machine from within Windows. With port forwarding, no less.

Background

Last week I took receipt of a Dell XPS 15z. Intel Core i7-2620M, NVIDIA GeForce GT525M with Optimus (for switching between integrated and dedicated graphics), 8GB of DDR3 memory. Which is fantastic. The chassis does resemble that of a Macbook Pro, and its keyboard is straight out of The Jetsons, but on the whole it's a nice machine. The issue is that Ubuntu 11.04 still doesn't have solid support for the i7, let alone Optimus. Not to mention the Cypress Semiconductor trackpad, which I got working once after restarting to test an NVIDIA driver. As it stands, I'm now able to boot Ubuntu by using the acpi=off flag, if I'm willing to sacrifice three of my four cores, power management, dedicated graphics, and my trackpad. I have every confidence that eventually I'll have everything working, but for now, I need a little more than this. Enter VirtualBox. A friend (who shalt remain nameless) has started running his various unix-like instances as VMs under a Windows host, which he loves - full, tuned hardware support for the host, and everything that Ubuntu and OSX need to operate virtually. Still, the idea of creating a virtual machine and virtual disk drive for Ubuntu, while keeping my actual Ubuntu partition separate, was unpleasant (ignoring for a moment my intense dislike for Windows as a whole). And while a couple people have written up tutorials for booting a physical partition in a VM, they were all dated <=2008. And so, good reader, I give you this:

Solution

Note: This assumes that you've already got Ubuntu (or similar) dualbooted with Windows, with your bootloader sitting on the Ubuntu partition. If you have a separate /home and/or swap partition, fear not.
  1. Boot Windows. Install VirtualBox.
  2. Run VirtualBox as an administrator (right-click the shortcut, click "Run as administrator").
  3. Create a new VM (click the blue "New" button). Customize your heart out. Don't worry about adding any media to it just yet.
  4. Open up the command prompt, again as an administrator (click Start, type cmd, right-click the shortcut that appears, click "Run as administrator").
  5. Change directories to the VirtualBox program directory - probably just cd "C:\Program Files\Oracle\VirtualBox\".
  6. Run VBoxManage internalcommands listpartitions -rawdisk \\.\PhysicalDrive0, where 0 is in the index of the physical drive you have Ubuntu on. This will give you a list of partitions for that drive. In my case, my boot, /home and swap partitions were 4, 5 and 6, respectively.
  7. Run VBoxManage internalcommands createrawvmdk -filename C:\Users\user\VirtualBox VMs\ubuntu.vmdk -rawdisk \\.\PhysicalDrive0 -partitions 4,5,6, where 4,5,6 are all of the partitions used by Ubuntu, and C:\Users\user\VirtualBox VMs\ubuntu.vmdk is the full path of the file you want to create to represent the Ubuntu partitions. Doesn't really matter where you put it, as long as you know where it is.
  8. Open up the settings for the VirtualBox VM you created earlier. In the Storage section, add the vmdk file you just created as a Hard Disk. Make sure that you also add an empty CD/DVD device - this will be used for the VirtualBox guest additions later.
  9. Go back to your command prompt. For every port you need forwarded from Windows to the VM, run this: VBoxManage modifyvm tank --natpf1 "guestssh,tcp,,22,,22", where tank is the name of your VM (yeah, yeah), guestssh is the name of your forwarding rule (be logical, but this one's up to you), and tcp,,22,,22 are respectively the protocol and host/guest ports (e.g. use tcp,,8080,,80 to forward TCP port 8080 on Windows to port 80 on your VM).
  10. If all goes well, you'll be able to start your shiny VM, load GRUB, and boot into Ubuntu. Don't forget to install the guest additions (Devices -> Install Guest Additions...).
Main caveat: whenever you run something that accesses another partition, you must run it with administrator rights. I ended up creating a shortcut directly to my VM (Machine -> Create Shortcut on Desktop) and modifying it to always start this way (right-click, Properties, Compatibility, Privilege Level, Run this program as administrator). Credit to Jexel over at Neowin for figuring the bulk of this out before I did.
